column10: An older game, but there is a reason it is considered a classic.

After playing BG3 for 300+ hours, I decided I'd give the OG a true shot. I have been reading everything, taking the time to figure out how combat works and generally taking my time. I haven't finished it yet, but i have been having a absolute blast. It's nothing like the new game, but it's a very calm and relaxing way to spend a few hours at night. 100% Recommend, if you can get past dated graphics and somewhat clunky mechanics.

If you enjoy CRPGs then this is a nice one to look back at and understand where a lot of the tropes came from. Be warned though, negative ACs and THAC0 are annoying as all hell and frankly, it's a good thing they were dropped after the 2nd edition of D&D.

Yes, the answer for the question if I recommend this game to other players was always yes. Its amazing, a must play game for any RPG fun. I have completed this game multiple times, every single time it was a whole new experience. Graphics is outdated, mechanic is simple and sound is not the best I ever hear, but it does not matter. Story, world, quests, secrets and characters are simply amazing, there is nothing to compare to it, even BG3.

The game has of course aged but it's still pretty good.

The AD&D 2nd Edition ruleset on the other hand sucks as much today as it did when it was released 30 years ago and I am glad that we don't have to suffer through it anymore in new games.

Played it with two mods (mostly for convenience options and base rule tweaks): Sword Coast Stratagems & The Tweaks Anthology

Well Lets see... Baldur's Gate Enhanced and Neverwinter Nights Enhanced are the best 2 non MMO Dungeons and Dragons games ever made, with endless quests and replayability and multiplayer servers and everything. Nuff Said?

7/10
Baldur's Gate I allured me mainly to play the rest of the DND games, as I fell in love with BG3 quickly on. While BG1 is practically different in nearly everything apart from setting and a much, much older dnd ruleset to follow, I still found a bit of the charm I had while playing bg3 as well... with some outdated mechanics and storytelling along the way.

Story
Baldur's Gate I starts off with a pretty strong opener, you are the son of a mage who is suddenly being attacked by assassins and need to leave the home you lived at for so long, just to watch your father be murdered by forces unknown. Stuff like that can get me super pumped, but once you leave the first chapter and onto the rest of the game by being introduced to your potential companions ( I played with the canon party for the entire game just for bg2 continuity reasons), you do start to realize some shortcomings of the way the game is structured. There are still exciting moments in the story, the iron shortage, sarevok, the reveal near the ending of the game are very exciting points of the story, but the writing at times isn't the greatest compared to previous stories I have experienced, and worse of all, literally nobody has any reaction to what you do or anything you have to accomplish apart from repeating "good guy do good thing!" or "you do bad I don't like that!". While the main quest line has its moments, its the side quests that really hamper the experience with how inconsistent the pacing of any of them are or just how worth they are in a story telling way. Most of the sidequests until you reach baldurs gate is basic "fetch me this please, kill this please" and just ends with no lingering effect. Maybe this is cause of how BG3 handles side quests that I notice it way more, but it is pretty random if you are doing a side quest that is worth it or not. However there ARE pretty good side quests, for the base game I did really enjoy the one with the B queen (if that is a side quest or not idk). I did not play SoD as I heard that the writing is terrible there, but I did play through the tales of the sword coast, and I would like to split it into two parts. One half of it is the durlag's tower, which has really good writing and a very engaging storyline of a man struggling with the past as you explore the dungeon. On the other half you get to explore an island, which has some of the worst writing I have ever seen in terms of a jump between two different storylines. So many obvious jumps and turns, character motivations make no sense and you are forced to basically resolve the scenario in a matter that leaves things to be desired. BG writing can be a bit over the place, but I do hear BG2 writing kinda outclasses it so I do hope for that. Overall good writing, but too spread out to be considered noteworthy imo.

Characters
The characters in this game are pretty interesting... Till you finish their very short quest, then they turn into one liners who do nothing but tell you the same comment, same joke, react to the same way till the end of the game. There ARE very interesting companions, but they were added in the enhanced edition and as a way to play through bg1 in a more original way I played with just the canon party instead (I am so sorry Rasaad the monk your backstory was so damn interesting as well but had to remove you for minsc sadge). I do know that the biggest problem that bg2 fixes a ton is companion chattering, cause my GOD BG1 companions that are NOT new from the enhanced edition have 0 flavor, and once you finish their questline are just blank slates with like 5 lines to say something new. I really wish I played with a custom party instead but I had to experience these companions just for continuity sake my playthrough. They do each play distinct as the dnd classes are varied of course, but other than that I could had probably done with a custom party and had the same experience, but would had kept minsc at least as I did enjoy his 5 lines the most... and Jaheria as well you can stay. 
Gameplay
While this game is very old, it still has the charm that I was looking for in what I would imagine, a dnd much game. While this game uses the DND 2nd edition, which is VERY different than DND 5e that bg3 uses, it still holds a ton of similarities, but enough differences that took me awhile to get used to (AC is better when lower instead of higher for example). The combat in this game has a huge gap imo, as lower level has you being kinda forced into a cheese strat, where the main strategy is to have EVERYONE using ranged attacks, as nobody can survive a hit yet, and just looping them till they die. This is pretty annoying, and It doesn't really change from that till mid game when you start getting your abilities and spells in place. mid game the combat DRAMATICALLY improves, and you start to feel the excitement as you plan your next moves with the pause-real time combat system. However, end game basically turns back into a bit of a cheese, as you start encountering not 1, not 2, not 3, but like 20 traps all at once. While yes, thief can just disarm them, sometimes those traps are literally 2 ft away from the enemies, forcing you to pull them anyways. That is when you quickly realize the best way to handle the enemy over preparing, is to over prepare yourself... but throwing fireballs and ice storms off screen so the enemies get damaged, but won't engage for some reason. Especially the end fight where the boss basically summons a shit ton of high level enemies and has literally 10 traps waiting for you, throwing fireballs and forcing him to come to us so we can jump him was the main strat I had to use. In Durlag's tower especially requires the most cheese ( apart from the demon knight he was a pretty interesting boss design). Once you figure out that enemies won't engage when attacked off screen, it starts to turn into your main battle plan, and unless reasons force you to use a different strategy, most of combat boils down to that, which does get a bit boring after awhile, as while playing on hard difficulty, fighting the enemy head on is certain death for a companion, which in this game and ESPECIALLY with the canon party, insanely hard to recover from, as with the lack of a cleric, the only way to revive is to walk allll the way back to a chapel to revive, and even then their stuff is still on the ground so you have to walk back and reorganize their shit for them. Overall a ton of the mechanics I did enjoy, but being a much older version of DND, some mechanics I am glad are either much improved 5e, or removed outright ( Thanks for the much better trap detection and having really cool magic synergy that isn't just stun enemy is good in bg3).

Music
Pretty good. Not the best I have heard, but overall I liked the ost in this game. They fit really nice into the setting, and while some do get annoying like the inn theme repeating a bit too obnoxiously, I really enjoyed the battle songs and other ambience songs in this game.

Conclusion
Overall I really did enjoy BG1 a ton. Is it masterpiece? No I don't think so, but I will still look at this game with a positive outlook, and hopefully, a better point of view after I play BG2, which supposedly does fix a ton of the writing and companion issues I had with BG1 (and high level spells yay). Do I recommend BG1? If you enjoy pause real time I do, but it isn't the easiest recommend as it really depends on the taste of having to play with old ass dnd mechanics and outdated gameplay mechanics. Looking past that, you do generally get a good game, just missing some sauce that would make it REALLY good. But for a 1998 game, still really damn good.
7/10

Wow, what a magnificent RPG. I started my Baldur's Gate journey towards the 3rd one with this and i didnt regret it. Story was awesome and the DLCs were amazing, especially the Durlag Tower and the Dragonspear one.

Loved it.

Story is great, very well done compared to BG2, gradually developed as any heroic tale should. 
Mechanically gameplay doesn't reach the levels of absurdity and completely broken balance as in BG2, especially ToB which was to my opinion completely unplayable in certain boss fights.
All in all I'd recommend BG1 to anyone on a desired difficulty level.
There has not been another ISO RPG that comes close to BG1 & 2. Divinity is fine as is Diablo but this game leaves them both in the dirt.
Full plate and packing steel!
There's so much to do for a game that was originally produced more than 20 years ago. Took me back to my early days of gaming, Had a great time.

2024 Review - A great game that I'm finally playing :D BG3 fans probably won't like because it operates on real time combat instead of turn based combat. If you're a mainstream player that's new to the CRPGs, again, you probably won't like it. The graphics are pixelated, the UI is dated, the voice acting takes you back to the 90's, and the character customization is limited, but I'm already having fun with it!

 You start off running about town and already feel the similarities to Pillars of Eternity, Tyranny, etc. The characters and world building are immersive, the combat is a bit complicated since it's built on 2E DnD, but faithful. Charming, well-written, packed with personality, and I love that most side quests have a choice involved. It brings out the importance of roleplaying a lot more often, and doesn't hold back on evil options either.

Nostalgic, hard to learn, but packed with flavor. I can already tell I'm going to enjoy BG 1 :D Oh and please don't leave negative reviews just because you compare it to modern games or even BG 3. It's much different, give it the respect it deserves!

Old-school, top-down rpg. 
The story is decent, and the characters can range from mildly entertaining to absolutely annoying.
The game is, like many similar games, quite difficult. The alternative is playing the game with no difficulty at all. There definitely should have been an easier mode that still provided some challenge.
The Music is nothing to go crazy over but still good.
The art and set design is a real selling point for me. Gives a decent representation of the old fantasy vibe of the 70s and 80s.
Its great.

Anyone coming from BG3 for a retro fix will find it here. I haven't played BG1 since the 90's and it looks like Beamdog have done a great job bringing this classic back to life. 

Tips for BG3 players - 
- keep in mind the game is 25 years old, graphics are from a different era
- 2E is very different to 5E. You'll get the hang quickly but in short be ready for things to be a lot less flexible. For starters, there is no Withers and no re rolls. Characters on a bench don't level up at joining your party and so on.
- It moves much faster. You can customise when the game pauses in the options menu. Don't let your characters die!

One huge positive is that the level caps are higher and you can keep your character all the way through to the end of BG2. By the end of the game your party will be insanely powerful.

Oh - and you used to be able to record your own voice (and those of your friends if playing multiplayer). I assume you still can - it takes a fair while but it is highly recommended.

That's about it. Have fun!
Art doesn't age and this game is proof. Give the writing and combat a fair try to get mesmerized for tens of hours in return.
What can I say? This is where the love for story driven cRPG has started for me more than 20 years ago. I have only good memories with it.

No I don't want to waste skill points (or whatever nomenclature) on dual-wielding, dual-wielding is beyond retarded... Ah sod this, I uninstalled...

Now this isn't a failure of the game in itself, it is a D&D game after all. Ah, D&D the cancer of the role-play genre, a blight upon tabletop gaming.... F D&D...

Its a classic

This is not a fun game and never has been in my opinion. It’s clunky, slow, and tedious. One-sided with enemies shooting AOE spells through walls, which you can’t do. Mage enemies teleporting around the battlefield constantly, which your own mage can’t do. Status effects that are a pain to deal with. Instant death effects such as petrified in places you don’t expect them. 

Finally, it’s very dated by today’s standards. Having your party get stuck is a constant annoyance, or simply having them bump into each other constantly. The team members in the back not attacking and instead just bumping into the one in front is a good example. Or get stuck bumping into each other when you’re trying to zone.

I keep coming back to this game because I want to finish the first two games in the series for lore reasons, but I’ve only been able to slog through the first game once, and the second game never. I keep hoping this time will be the one, but the game’s so incredibly tedious and annoying it’s hard to see that happening anytime soon. (2/10)

This game is a cult classic for a REASON. Brilliant storytelling, still captivating gameplay, and wonderful customization options! It is so easy for me to forget the dated graphics -- in fact, it only crosses my mind now, in reviewing it, because it may negatively impact people's willingness to try the game. TRY IT ANYWAY.

Ok, I leave this review with all due respect as to what this game was and how it has indisputably shaped the CRPG genre as well as being the macdaddy of most RPGs on the PC for over 2 decades. Playing this game in 2024 is rough. 

The game itself is beautiful and the graphics have actually (in my opinion) aged well. The writing is timeless and the voice acting, while corny at times, is still phenomenal to this day. 

Unfortunately, the gameplay is absolutely janky by modern standards, even those of a decade ago, and because of this I cannot recommend it. I spent more time in my playthrough fighting with the UI and getting my characters where they needed to go than actually playing and feeling immersed in an RPG. At the same rate, the difficulty has no indication of when it will spike, and i found myself constantly save-scumming to finish quests and fights. If you like quicksave/quickload and praying to the RNG gods, maybe this is for you.

At this point, however, I cannot recommend this game other than for throwing the game on story mode and seeing what this paragon in the genre brought to bear.

Charming, old school game. Can't comment so much on the mechanics of fighting, because I'm that person who's really just there for the exploration, discovery, and helping out as many NPCs as possible. With a lot of stealing of books.

Though there are a surprising number of outdated joke references... :D
It brings the world of D&D to life in a unquie way.

Ok, I couldn't have asked for a better introduction to the universe of Dungeons and Dragons, given that this game tries its hardest to simulate the experience of playing tabletop. I admit I wasn't ready for how much it does that and it took me a while to figure things out, but as soon as I did, it was glorious. It shows it's age in more ways than one, but it's nothing that you can't look past and once you do... you're in for an amazing experience. The DLC are especially good, at least the ones that come with the enhanced edition, I won't be trying the Beamdog one any time soon because here in Brazil it's priced the same as the second game, and the choice is easy in that regard, at least for now.

Disclaimer: I played with easiest mode possible
I have come to understand that when this game was released, it was considered cutting edge to attempt to realize DnD 2e in real-time. These days this may feel chaotic and disorganized. I prefer the more turn based combat of the third. 
With this personal preference in mind, I found with easy on, the game was fun, funny, and I enjoyed the ability to upload my custom portraits (drew them myself :)), and used the journal extensively for RP purposes. By the time my high elf reaches BG3, shes going to have such a clearly established background and history. The more invested in the world and role playing you get, the more rewarding you will find it. 
As with most RPG's of this scale, it requires a little self direction. If the new zelda games confuse you, and you feel like you can't figure out what to do, this game might not be for you
If you like the old battle system, and/or are creative and enjoy getting invested in a world and RPing, you're going to have a blast

Baldur’s Gate is one of the best simulations of the AD&D 2e experience. This is both a compliment and an insult. Ultimately, I think this is a good game and worth playing if you can get over a lot of the dated game design. But if you’re a total newcomer to CRPGs, especially those of the late 90s, this game is a trial by fire. I would not recommend this game to anyone who simply wants to play it for the story, because on top of it being just okay, this game’s strength is the way you interact with the world more so than it is the quality of the narrative itself and that means getting deep into the mechanics of the game.

To start positively, Baldur’s Gate is great at presenting the Forgotten Realms D&D setting. If you’re a lore nerd, there is a lot to dive into here. There are countless books explaining the history of the region, its gods, and the politics of the kingdoms hidden all over the place. Bartenders will tell you rumors if you buy drinks from them, and each powerful magical item has a story in its description. There is a decent amount of environmental storytelling in the maps as well, moreso in the Tales of the Sword Coast expansion pack than the base game, which are beautiful and colorful and look like you’re playing in a painting. It’s a unique feel of 2D and 2.5D isometric sprite games like this can provide that you just can’t get from a photorealistic 3D rendering. Unfortunately, the character models on the other hand range from okay to “what the fuck am I looking at?” and the lack of a unique visual profile on most of the humanoid sprites makes it tough to pick out important targets like spellcasters when the combat starts.

The plot of Baldur’s Gate is fine. It’s a pretty bog-standard D&D adventure of discovering an evil bad guy’s plot to take over a kingdom and eventually saving it. There is a bit of interesting in-game politics that sets the backdrop for the campaign and ties into the characters, but it’s not by any means some deep or thoughtful narrative. The real strength of the story comes from how you can interact with it via choices made in dialogue, combat, party composition, etc. Outcomes of major plot points aren’t going to change, but side quests can be much more open ended by simply having the right (or wrong) companion in your party. And the side quests are so numerous and wide in scope that many of them will have direct connections to the main quest, even if they aren’t necessary to progress. Combine that with the sheer amount of companions in this game (29 in total) and the way they interact with each other while in the party, and there is simply no way to see it all in a single playthrough.

The only real issue I have with the narrative, outside of it just stopping instead of having a proper ending, is that its pacing is crippled by the side quests and gameplay in general. There is a calendar in the game keeping track of the time you have spent on your adventure, but it is never important outside of certain companion’s quests. The big bad evil guy will always be about to reach his goal, no matter if it takes you 2 in-game days or 2 in-game months to find him; and you will be spending months preparing for that next step. Following the main quest alone will leave you severely underleveled and you have to grind side quests, which is time consuming both in-game and in person. Healing and recovering spells means resting for at least 8 hours at a time. And if you don’t have many healing potions or spells, that means you could be spending literal in-game weeks trudging through a dungeon. All of this makes it almost impossible to avoid ruining the pacing. Maybe it’s a testament to everything else that I find this is immersion breaking, but it is nonetheless.

The reason you will have to do some grinding is that this game is HARD. Part of this is AD&D 2e’s design, but some of this is on the game too. Characters, especially early on, will have very little HP depending on the class. A martial focused class like a fighter might be able to take a hit or resist being hit in the first place, but god help your mages who can easily be killed by a single arrow until around lvl 5. And since combat plays out in real time, characters can be obliterated in the blink of an eye.

I don’t think it’s a bad thing that combat is this hard, even on easier difficulties. I do have a problem with it playing out in real time though. The pathing AI is atrocious, and the pace at which it plays out is fast. Thankfully you can pause combat and still choose actions and even set up auto-pause triggers for certain events, but it’s not easy to get the hang of nor all that satisfying once mastered. I never felt like any of my successful battles were a result of my immediate tactical decisions like it would in a game like Xcom, mostly because there isn’t much you can do while watching them play out. Most of the strategy has to come from knowing what you’re up against ahead of time and preparing before the actual fight.

AD&D 2e has this, quite frankly, terrible spell slot memorization mechanic in which every spellcaster must choose their spells for each available slot on a short rest. For example: if you have 3 lvl 1 slots and want to cast magic missile 3 times, then you had to have already memorized 3 magic missile spells during your last rest and you won’t be able to cast any other lvl spells that you’d know until you swap slots on the next rest. It forces you to plan ahead for encounters and dungeons, except there is no way of figuring out what to expect on your first playthrough so your best bet is to just Edge of Tomorrow your way through the game. This isn’t the only complaint I have about AD&D 2e either. In this system, the thief class is the only one capable of disarming traps (of which there are a lot in this game that are unavoidable and will only trigger for player controlled characters for some reason), mages can fail to learn spells from scrolls on a dice roll (which easier difficulties at least disables), THAC0 exists, the list of shit goes on. It’s an outdated and unnecessarily complicated system on its own, and translating it into a video game only serves to highlight its issues.

Then there’s the gameplay elements outside of the AD&D system. You know all those cool companions that you can form a party of 6 out of? Well you’re gonna have to remember where you left them because they are going to remain scattered across the world if you talk to them and decide to swap party members. Only a few of the Enhanced Edition characters will hang out at a central location. Companions not in your party are not getting experience points either, so you better be happy with your decision on who’s in the party and pray they survive. You’d think that the game wants you to replace dead characters based on how many there are, but I am not going to spend 30 hours grinding up a replacement when they are 7 levels behind. And I’m certainly not gonna waste my time trying to revive the dead because they don’t come back with their stuff, and I’m not about to spend 40 minutes trekking back and forth to get everything with how annoying this inventory system is; being that individual characters need their inventories managed separately. Some of this is easier to overlook than others, but I have to call it out because it’s clearly a problem that was fixed in future sequels and expansions.

Obviously, I wouldn’t say that all of these problems make the game unplayable; I’m still recommending the game after all. I do think it’s important to mention though because it’ll backhand slap any newcomer across the face and probably deter them from sticking with it. It almost kept me from doing so, until it finally clicked for me in the final chapter of the game. Perhaps on a replay, now that I know what I’m doing and what to expect, I will have a better experience. I just wish that better experience was something I could’ve gotten the first time.

The first Baldur's Gate game was one of the most fun RPGs of its time. It has aged since then and some of the gameplay mechanics that used to be fresh won't feel new to those who are familiar with similar games that came afterwards. It's still a very fun RPG though, with a fantastic lore thanks to the DnD universe.

The main enemy, Sarevok, is a very cool antagonist. You and him are tied by fate and blood which makes the rivalry personal in nature, which is great. But the fun part with this game, especially compared to BG3, is that the main quest doesn't have that much of a grasp on your journey and you can therefore focus on many sub quests in plenty of different areas if you want. There is no time limit breathing down your neck either, so you are comfortable at exploring the world and completing tasks to make your characters stronger before facing your Bhaalspawn step brother.

Storywise, it's a pretty simple tale. People get murdered and you murder the murderers most of the time. I'd say it's "Conan-esque" as you will usually get into combats to prove your point, but that is the nature of the Bhaalspawn, after all, so it makes total sense.

There's a solid amount of different enemies and locations, enough for the game to never feel dull. You can go pretty far in terms in leveling up, far enough for you to learn very fun spells or techniques.

The game uses an old version of DnD rules so the 5th Edition-familiar players may feel a bit lost as some spells and abilities differ from what they know. It's also a game that has a very steep learning curve for non-DnD players. However, just like BG2, there is an instruction manual in the game files ( judging from forum posts, it seems a lot of people don't know that ). You may want to refer to that and not to wikis unless you don't mind getting yourself spoiled by mistake.

It's a bit emptier than BG2 overall, of course that is to be expected ( back then sequels always felt like their original counterparts but with more content, those were the good old days! ). There are less engaging dialogues, romances are nonexistent, making your companion characters feel like random generic NPCs. This hurts the game quite a lot when you compare it to BG2 and BG3 which both have fantastic dialogues.

Traveling across the land is less eventful than in BG2. In BG1 you will go through certain areas a few times, and once you've cleared them, there won't be a lot to do but you'll still have to go through them to reach specific locations. BG2 got rid of that issue with a clickable world map, allowing you to go exactly where you want and bypassing those wilderness maps.

The music is very good. Not as good as its sequels though. But still good enough to have some tunes sticking in your mind for a while.

A very cool aspect of this game is that once you finished it, you can import you character to the sequel, along with its accumulated levels of course, allowing you to have a more complete journey if you want.

Overall it's not the game I'd recommend to play first if you want to get into the Baldur's Gate franchise. I would recommend BG3 if you can't stand old graphics and want a more complete experience. If you can tolerate old games, go for BG2 first as it has better overall content and explains the BG1 story with enough detail for you to know enough but not everything, which is cool if you ever want to go and try it one day. I personally got into BG2 a long time ago before playing the first one and I got hooked instantly, so I suggest you take the same guaranteed path. But this one here remains a cornerstone in RPG gaming, so if you are not satiated yet, go for it. It's pretty fun still. Plus, there's a few mods that add content ( ex: NPC interactions ).

"So hard to find decent GAMES nowadays."
Allow me to start with a semi-quote from Firebead Elvenhair, a minor character.

Actually there are quite a few good recent games, but BG is easily the reason why they are available, as it is one of the first isometric RPGs ever made, back in the '90s; the others just followed its path.

The story takes place in the Forgotten Realms™ and follows the adventures of a young orphan, unveiling the mistery of their birth and trying to prevent a war breaking between two lands.
The setting is a faithful adaptation of AD&D rules: races, classes, skills and all that.

This EE boasts improved graphics, several subquests and even four new characters (each with a definite backstory).
Bottom line: a must if you're into this genre!

If BG1 is THIS good, I can't begin to fathom how awesome my BG2 experience would be. What a roller-coaster journey of emotions - taking me from novice adventurer wandering the wilderness to demon-slaying hero at the end. It was interesting to find out the lineage of my character and I had a lot of fun reading the lore books in the game. Actions have consequences in this game. The game is much more difficult when you have a negative reputation. People shit on the Siege of Dragonspear expansion but I really enjoyed the story, funny party banter and new companion quests. (LOVE YOU GLINT! BOO FOR NO XAN IN SoD!) I played on core rules and got TPK many times throughout the game (lol thank you save scumming). The outdated user interface is definitely a major issue - it makes equipment upgrades and inventory management a huge hassle to navigate. I suggest people just play on story mode if they can't get into the combat or gameplay system, for this game deserves its place in the pantheon of CRPGs.

For context this is a review from someone who was raised on AD&D but just never played any of the BG games until now so the Enhanced Editions are all I have known. As an ongoing project I am taking a character from BG1-BG3 in chronological order of events after completing a play through of BG3 and wanting to get the full context of the story.

If you are not familiar with AD&D getting to know the system might be the biggest barrier to entry. There are a number of things that are not apparent and I don't believe they are ever explained in game but I think most RPG players can intuit enough to get through the game (like lower AC and THAC0 is good). If you are willing to look for some info online there are good explanations out there that helped me out in my play through. 

The best part of this game has to be the feeling of open exploration. You can wander around sword coast getting into random encounters and finding quests just like you might in a hexcrawl on the table top. All of this is facilitated by the real time with pause combat. This game is the first that I have really enjoyed that style over turn based but it does make sense for the game flow here.

The story of BG1 is decent and ties the adventure together but it really didn't feel like anything special to me. The stand out story moments pretty much all involve the main antagonist who is introduced surprisingly late in the game but is a certified badass. The companions are pretty basic and don't have much interaction outside of their combat and idle quips. 

In combat your character is generally the star of the show since they are the only one you can really customize and your friends have surprisingly bad stats for their roles which is VERY important for your survival in low level AD&D. You will want to optimize your character at least a little bit or the combat can be rough. Once you make it out of low levels to around level 5 and have some decent gear the combats get much easier. For my run the only significant challenges were the final couple of fights which all involve high level magic users
It's great. I've played it before off steam, and now I'm on it again here.
I very good old style D&D game.  A true classic.

Baldur's Gate had been my favorite game for decades. There's a certain scent to summer that harkens me back to desperately trying to remember, and find all the easter eggs and charting everything in pen and paper on a notebook, as I switched between six cds like a dj, because that was state of the art technology for the time. I've played it 20+ times, as 20 different characters, and roles and combinations, I still doubt I've found things, and I still get blown up by traps I've forgotten the precise location to even with 110% on find traps, because I move too quickly down corridors, and they all look the same. The characters are like best friends, and indeed, all my best friends IRL I've played multiplayer with since I was in high school, 25 years ago. Once upon a time, I also posited Baldur's Gate as the forefront of RPGs, and fantasy, and drove my Bethesda fan friends mad, much to gloating in 2023 with BG3 vs. Starfield. My whole childhood I struggled with 2.5 D&D rules to play with my Dad, until Baldur's Gate made it like breathing for me and now my brain still "soft" resorts to it on a regular basis. There are no quests I don't enjoy, and it remains endlessly quotable.

HOWEVER:

The Enhanced Edition is truly absolutely abysmal. The multiplayer servers are crap. While I dislike changing the fire arrows to +2 (instead of + 1  + fire) because it makes the low level kobold commandos unreasonably deadly if you don't fireball them like a Megumin addicted to explosions, and I dislike changing the art for composite and regular longbows (it's just so unnecessary? WHY?) these are admittedly minor enough to be ignored. But the UI I literally *cannot* use, it actually hurts my vision, and I have no choice but to revert back to the original via finagling. How do you even do that? I have no other remasters that give me this problem, including the glitchy HoMM3 HD. The glitches are also rather unforgivable. There's no telling what will make it struggle, and it forever seems to be a case of their lack of investment either emotionally as fans or monetarily in a long term vision.

Beamdog's added characters are jarring with the original cast, Dorn can't blame his evil alignment for being annoying and patently *un-fun* to take along, because Edwin is evil and hilarious, and even Montaron and Xzar have some charm points about them, and that's not even my nostalgia goggles talking because I never did that back then. Chandra is a little too Manic Pixie which emphasizes how her spells are going to backfire and possibly kill your whole party. I never take Xan because he's such a downer, but I found myself doing so for just a dose of normalcy recently.  Don't even get me started on Siege on Dragonspear. It seems not enough of Beamdog's writers actually ever ENJOYED the original, so they had no idea how to help bring it into the future, and more's the pity. Baldur's Gate has a very loyal devoted fandom of decades, and they literally could have hired better mod writers by just asking any of the forums.

I can't in good conscience recommend the enhanced edition, even twisting myself into pretzel knots. The only thing I can say about it is at least the core game is SOMEWHERE buried under the other poop, even if it takes a powerwash to get it clean, and the multiplayer is NEARLY unusable. For BG3 fans, absolutely Jaheira, Minsc, Imoen, the originals are all here, but you can see which parts are Beamdog vs. the original by quality alone tbh.

10/10 original. 3/10 Beamdog get your act together. You have an opportunity now to make millions. Take it, or forever regret it.

The story/roleplay aspect is decent but good god this must be one of the worst combat systems I've ever seen. You just click attack and then watch the fight automatically happen and it's all down to random chance and you can't influence anything except use potions when you get hurt. I ended up putting the game on Story Mode which gives you godmode, so I could actually enjoy the story and not have to repeat every area 10 times waiting for the right RNG.

I HATE Neera, not just her annoying voice\accent but the fact she wiped us out with her stupid wild magic, daemon summoning, hiccups etc. countless times. At times I rage quit. Then her arrogance at some point saying without her we wouldn't get far...and her constant romantic harassment like I'd choose her over Immoen...argggghhhh!!! Rasaad is completely useless he can punch and throw darts, that's it.

So re-rolled my favourite class = pali but went with cavalier. Chose the old favourites: minsc, dyna, khalid, jaheera, immoen...much more fun!!! Actually feels I can complete it without reloading 6 times every toughish encounter.

To conclude: obviously games have moved on and doesn't have the same impact it had back then, but still very playable and enjoyable. Definitely worth playing if you want to experience BG3 in its entirety.

BTW about 200 hours of game time is because I fell asleep at the wheel..I work long shifts. So actual game time is around 60-70. Thank the lord for auto-pause!

I really like this game. I'd even say that I love it. Some of that might be for nostalgic reasons with it being the first RPG of this type that I played several years ago when I was like 14 years old, and the game reminds me of better times, but in saying that, back then I was terrible at the game. I just constantly died and didn't really understand the mechanics or how to do combat effectively.
Nowadays, I'm much more aware of how to play the game effectively and I find the combat fulfilling and tactical - especially if you use the SCS mod, which makes the enemies smarter and more difficult to defeat.
Ultimatley, I would highly recommend this game, but I think a lot of the younger generations might have trouble with it. The graphics aren't amazing (though the art style itself hasn't aged so badly, because they were all handrawn backgrouns), but I think that younger generations are wanting constantly eye-catching, explosively dynamic, cinematic experiences, and that's not this game.
If you're happy with an amazing RPG with a great combat system, in the style of back in the old days, then this is for you.
If you're looking for a cinematic MMO combat experience, then this isn't for you.

For me though, it's one of my favourite games, and I have way more hours spent on it, than the hours my Steam says. I used to play this game a lot before Steam even existed.

My first complaint with the game is definitely how poorly you are introduced to the bizarre, unintuitive D&D system.
The tutorial at the beginning essentially only tells you how to move around and talk to people, and throughout my time playing the game, I would have to look up several guides to understand what the stats in the game ended up doing and wether or not it made sense for me to invest in them. All you can do is use the manual pdf which is buried somewhere in the gamefiles or use unofficial guides, as the game's mechanics are not intuitive at all.

What makes the gameplay somewhat sluggish and uncomfortable are issues regarding the UI and the controls of the game. The pathing of your units is abysmal, probably the worst I have ever seen in a video game so far. The UI often fails to properly display casting animations, which can be confusing, as you won't be able to tell wether your character has begun casting their spell yet or not.

These issues, although being annoying, are mostly due to the game's age and don't ruin it entirely. Unfortunately, there are other flaws in  the game's design that with prolonged playtime gradually made me want to stop playing it. These flaws have a great influence on gameplay and cannot be avoided or ignored.

Everything in the game is based on RNG. You can barely influence what actually happens in combat. The game will punish you heavily for things that you have no control over. Often, your characters might die instantly due to some invisible trap you could not have possibly seen, or due to some poorly balanced mage boss that kills them with a single spell, without giving you any possibility to prevent their deaths. When you are facing off against the tougher, less balanced enemies featured in the game, the progress you'll have made by leveling up won't matter too much, as it mostly rewards you with additional HP and stat upgrades. 

These will prove to be useless against most mages, who can make your party run away in terror, kill your less beefy characters with a single spell, or turn the one character you have based your entire strategy on into a literal hamster, all without giving you any chance to do anything about it. The mages you frequently end up fighting in the game generally seemed to be pretty overpowered.
 
As you can only swap out your dead party members with new ones or revive them at high costs that scale with their level, and as their inventory will remain on their dead body, a dead companion will often force you to lose a lot of gold, items and -most importantly- time. It is a lot more bearable to quicksave and reload every time somebody dies. This means that you will spend a lot of time fighting the same enemies over and over again, praying that your RNG is favorable, so that your characters manage to stay alive. When one of them kicks the bucket eventually -due to some arbitrary dice roll- reload and start over. This is what fighting any mage or exploring any dungeon that features traps in the game boils down to. Either that, or going through the aggravating experience of trying to distribute your dead companions' loot on the rest of the party.

The game clearly has some strenghts; I really liked how most of the enchanted items felt unique, there were interesting environments to explore, and the character progression is also fun; however, the core gameplay will most likely make you want to kill yourself. Unless you really don't care about your mental health, I don't think this game is for you. It is one of the most overrated games I have ever come across.

Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 are some of my most nostalgic games and among my Top 10 Favorite games of all time, i could play the original version over and over again and never get tired of it, thus i bought the Enhanced Edition of BGEE1 which is a great "Remaster" of the Original game which at times honestly feels like a remake even if it technically isn't

+

Character Creation: 
This is one of my favorite parts of the game, creating your character.
In the original Baldurs Gate there already were tons of diffrent ways you could create your characters.
The Enchanced Edition however includes the Class Kits from Baldurs Gate 2 and with Multi-Classing and Dual Classing (which if im gonna try to explain the craziness of that this review would be twice as long) it makes for an insane ammount of replay value.

Gameplay: 
I'v heard people say that this game is complicated  . .to which i say . . compared to modern versions like the Dragon Age games it kinda is, it can get really hard at times too but thats part of why i love Baldurs Gate and other D&D Games.
Its not the kind of game you can just rush through, you have to have some strategy, pay attention and sorta "learn" the game.

Music: 
In general a Good soundtrack, don't have much to say here honestly, there's nothing really specal that sticks out.

Characters: 
Apart from the character creation and having lots of diffrent dialogue options to choose from, there's a total of 29 party members to choose from in the game including 4 new ones added to the Enchanced version which is a nice addition.
You don't get to interact with them as much as you do in for example the Dragon Age and Mass Effect series and even though some of the Party members are more useful than others the ammount of people you can choose to have in your party alone makes for lots of replay value.

Story: 
Bioware and Black Isle(Known as Obsidian Entertainment nowdays) have a talent for creating some great and intresting stories in video games and Baldurs Gate is no exception. It's one of the best things about this game in my opinion(dont wanna say much here because i dont wanna spoil anything)

Graphics: 
May not look much compared to Modern games like the Dragon Age Series but(then again it is nearly 20 years old) back then i thought this game looked great dispite the awful resolution in the original version.
Thankfully the Enhanced Edition puts the BG2 engine into the game and makes the resolution extremely nice.

-

The AI in both BG1 and 2 is really derpy at times, there have been plenty of times when i'm in a narrow dungeon and some of my characters go somewhere completely diffrent than what i told them(or even worse goes the wrong way right into a trap or an ambush).
But thats a nitpick for me honestly.

And then of course the thing everyone talks about the Siege of Dragonspear update, oh boy oh boy.
While i don't like the new cartoonish sprites, they look really out of place in the game but i can tolerate that because at least you can disable them.

There might be a couple of bugs here and there but i can forgive that.

The new UI in both BG1 and 2 i thought was Ugly compared to the original which was just fine and i don't understand why someone would even think of changing it.

Final Verdict: 10/10
Even though i i at first got turned off by the New UI when it was first released, after i sat down and replayed it... again i got used to it, Old Ui SoD Ui this is still an epic game.

Even after all these years Baldur's Gate still holds up as one of my Top 10 favorite games of all time, i could play this game forever and never get bored of it.

This game is basiclly one of the reasons why games like the Dragon Age series exists today and if you like me enjoy any RPG made by Bioware or RPGS in general this is a must buy.

This is a good game.  It uses and adheres to the rules of D&D which means that this game can be at times odd.  You are in the middle of a fight and everyone is missing every swing of the sword and every arrow flying, or it is over in a heartbeat as someone as rolled a critical hit on a low health enemy.    This is very prevalent early one in the game, you do a lot of menial quests while the main story might be on hold as you might find you are under levelled for an enemy or a group of enemies.

It is slow paced and if you are not prepared to put in the hours to see it through you will miss a very satisfying story.  But so often you as the player character can be quickly out of the game all thanks to a dice roll and it is then game over.  But once the characters are getting a few levels under their belt and you have an OK amount of coin (money and inventory pace is almost part of the difficulty) it will get easier.  

Pausing the game often during combat is your friend and assess the situation, changing orders, drinking potions.  Taking damage is not a trivial thing, you can heal by resting or potions or temples but they all cost, resting in the wild, ambushes, in an Inn, you could be attacked, potions aren't cheap and temples aren't either.

But I would highly recommend this game, the story, the sheer depth of everything, the hundreds of hours you could pour in on a single play through and then trying a harder run using the more difficult player classes.  This is a great value for money game if you are willing to stick with it after the opening few hours.

Let me state my incorrect opinion first. I think this is a better game than Shadows of Amn. Not necessarily just the enhanced edition, but the original Baldur's Gate too. I will bear that scarlet letter for the rest of my days with pride.

I love low-level fantasy RPGs. I love low-level D&D. I love low-level just about anything. It's more of a level playing field. Mages are just starting out and still quivering in fear, soaking their special magic-man jammies in nervous sweat as they watch a fighter stroll up to them with a big 'ol ax. Ranged combat is king because it's all about offense, and every second they take to trundle over to you is a second you have to make them a living pincushion. Even backstabbing feels worth it. x2 damage means a lot when you're dealing with 1d6 shortswords or 1d4 daggers. The whole game feels more dangerous, more open, and you have to build your party slowly while dodging the entire ecosystem of the Sword Coast (which seems to have a vendetta against you). 

I don't want wizard chess. I don't want fifty abilities. I don't want to have to memorize so many spells that I have to read a novel of descriptions just to figure out that if I cast fireball, my dudes will all die unless I nudge the AoE gently to the left. What I want is simple. I want man with sword, man with bow, man with stabby-sword, man with lightning bolt fingers, and man with touchy-touchy healing powers to wrestle their way up to becoming the heroes of Baldur's Gate - fighting for every inch.

That's not to say that I'm a hardcore player or super into min-maxing. I'm not. I couldn't play my way out of a paper bag. I am a big baby. But levels mean something when your hit points double from four to eight, when you get that extra spell and suddenly you can clown on all those kobolds who bullied you in high school, and when you come out of a fight down four party members and barely hanging onto life and that's a GOOD outcome. Higher level play just... doesn't do it for me. This is a straight-up power fantasy, and it's great. That's what makes Baldur's Gate 1 so special to me.

Most of all, it's a great modding platform. The community is what really makes the game, and Beamdog has been great in facilitating their creativity and know-how. I've never seen a developer of this size working so closely together with modders before. It's great. The game isn't unplayable without mods but even purists are missing out just with QoL and graphical tweaks alone. Could I play without unlimited arrow stacking? Yes, I suppose I could. Would I? No, I'd rather shot up by a hobgoblin drive-by squad toting poison arrows. (I'm still bitter...)

In any case, this game good. Other game? Also good. This game better. You play!

An interesting story with some relatively good characters and an intriguing world plot. Despite the mechanics and combat being the landmark used in countless similar RPG titles, they are admittedly obsolete now and aren't up to par with others of the genre, more modern ones. I guess I recommend it, however the main, obviously game-breaking issue, is the unacceptable path-finding. Unironically more than half the times, both in and out of combat, the characters cannot, for the life of me, find their way to where I tell them to and get stuck either with each other or on onjects. So basically constant need for micromanagement in movement makes this a very unenjoyable experience.

All in all, with patience and many reloads, it can be fun. Also, the SoD expansion adds a higher quality story, richer and more intriguing and some challenging, if not slightly too much, combat.

Replaying this game after about 20 years, and it still hold up very well. The general gameplay is still very enjoyable and the story is interesting and engaging. There are a ton of class/race/subclass combinations available which greatly adds to replay value, and most (if not all) of the quests have different options or paths through them for the player to try out.

There are a few things that the player needs to know in order to make the experience of playing smoother though - like setting up autopause options and changing the custom AI scripts so that your characters aren't being dumb in combat (like squishy spellcasters going into melee, or wasting spells on trivial encounters).

There are also a few minor annoyances that show the game's age, like pathing issues and characters getting stuck on each other when trying to move around, or the tedious inventory management. And it has to be said that the balance is atrocious - some of the spells that are acquired at very low levels stay absolutely broken overpowered for the duration of the game and others (even higher level spells) are utterly useless. 

My major (personal and subjective) complaints about the game are firstly that I find the trap system very annoying - some dungeons have hidden traps in them which must be detected by a thief, but trap detection range is very low and it "ticks" only once every 6 seconds which forces the player to very slowly move one of their squishier characters through a dungeon at the front of the party, stopping every few steps and waiting 6 seconds at a time. Failing to spot a trap can easily result in party member death as some of them deal huge amounts of damage and can hit multiple targets.

My second major complaint is the fact that BG1 seems to have started the CRPG trend of having a large part of the latter section of the game take place in a big city, which is never as interesting or engaging as the areas that preceded it. Going from exploring an exciting fantasy open world to trudging through identical copy/pasted buildings or a literal sewer kills my desire to keep playing 100% of the time.

Overall though, if you can look past those little gripes and you don't share my own subjective complaints then Baldur's Gate 1 is still a great game worthy of it's place in the RPG hall of fame, and definitely worth playing.

I find the gameplay and story in BG1 to be very dull. There is next to no companion interaction, and you mainly walk through an empty forest peppered with enemies you cannot talk to and can only fight. The first 3 towns have almost nothing going on, and the only quests you can take on involve fighting a group of enemies, with either little to no dialogue. I can count on one hand the amount of times i used my charisma stat in dialogue. The only remotely interesting thing to happen in the 7 hours i've played was Sarevok killing Gorion, but nothing has happened since. Maybe it gets better when you make it to the city proper, but playing through 20 hours of boring gameplay and dialogue to get to the good part is not indicative of a good story. If you want an engaging story and game i'd recommend skipping straight to BG2 and then BG3.

I played this game for a short while a long time ago and upon starting Baldur’s Gate 3 I felt the urge to come back to this one to see what I might be missing.

Short Answer: I had a dang good time in both the original and new content!

Pros: 
-The characterization is excellent, BioWare and Beamdog really know how to bring a clump of pixels to life.
-The stories are varied and engaging. Some are kinda dated, but they made the effort to make this “your adventure.”
-The large selection of companions was overwhelming at first but now I can appreciate the variety they add to multiple playthroughs.
-I appreciate that the game as a whole accommodates a lot of play styles, letting you be heroic or villainous, and having companions who can aid/enable you.
-The major villains from the original game and the expansion are excellent nemeses for the protagonist, with some NASTY final battles in both adventures.
-Now that I have started BG2 I really appreciate what work put into Siege of Dragonspear to make the transition to BG2 a little smoother than “and then you were captured.”

Cons:
-I don’t think I would enjoy playing ADnD in real life (thankfully BG does all the math for me). It is somewhat impenetrable and inaccessible (a +1 means -1 except where it means +1, still not entirely sure what a THACO is).
-Pathing has killed me a few times but building impeccable pathing is pretty much impossible anyway, since it can’t read your mind. I still tear my hair out when my character walks the direction that leads into a trap or ambush but that’s what save-scumming is for.
-The first few hours of the game is rough on a new player who has to learn just how many hard-knocks this school can have, but once you get going with gear and spells and party composition it lightens up. This does require you to know how all your party’s classes work, which requires more onboarding.

Overall, I spent about 140 hours to finish both the original game and Siege of Dragonspear and I am considering another playthrough as another class already.

A classic for a reason. Absolutely worth playing if you can get into the 2nd Edition D&D rules, which are admittedly pretty clunky in their old age. Unfortunately, the game doesn't do anything to help you learn those rules, so I'd recommend watching a beginner's guide if you're new to the system. Mortismal Gaming has a good one at :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tgPyY0X5jmg
The story and setting are both top-notch, and it's a pretty great low-level campaign. The Enhanced Edition is a perfect way to experience this story; install and go with no hassle trying to modernize the old aspect ratio or non-scaling UI of the original. It also adds a few characters and quests, which you can safely ignore if you are a purist.
If you enjoy the base game, I'd even recommend trying out the Siege of Dragonspear expansion. Reception to it was pretty mixed, but I had a lot of fun with it. It's set between Baldur's Gate 1 and 2, and attempts to fill in the story gap (not that it was really needed). While only a few quests reach real brilliance, and it does kind of feel like "fanon," they did a good job giving you multiple ways to solve problems in a number of sections, and your actions do have consequences even if they aren't drastic.
In the end, if you love CRPGs, you'll want to experience both this one and the sequel.

I might be far from finished with this game, but I can wholeheartedly recommend it.

The short version:

- It is old. So the graphics are rather simple, and you might be annoyed with some control features
- The amount of content is huge. You will have enough to do for weeks.

Now some info and recommendations for this type of game:

- It is a Dungeons and Dragons Style RPG. This means three things:
1: You cannot be good at everything. Carefully consider who you wish to be and what your skills are. That also includes moral actions. You cannot be a dick and a saint at the same time. 
- Save regularly. Fights are dependent on a random number factor. This can kill you in a second, or let you win with ease.
- You cannot complete every quest in one playthrough. Some will only be available if you're aggressive or an ass, or if you pick the corresponding companions.

Some recommendations for the game itself:
- Maps / graphics are static and cannot be viewed from a different angle. Move your cursor around to find hidden entrances and stuff to click.
- Check the loot of every enemy you killed. Quest items are not always marked and WILL disappear after a while.
- Look into every house / interior and talk to everyone. Many quests are hidden this way.
- Leaving any area in a specific direction actually matters. Leave an area upwards, you will find new places in that direction. Same to the left, right, etc
- lower or negative stat values from an item CAN be better. Just see which values turn green (better) or red (worse)

Baldurs Gate is an older game and definitely not as good as BG2 and I am sure lots of new players are coming in from BG3, and i would say, very kindly. Dont. 

Unless you are a crpg fan, BG3 is a very specific flavor of CRPGs (because its Larian.) and you will not get the same gameplay. there isnt a turn base system in BG1 or 2 and there is no pushing or throwing or enviromental hazards outside of spells and traps. no oil barrels. 

BG uses 2e I believe (correct me if i am wrong) and BG3 uses 5e, which means very different systems further contributing to a different experience. 

The game gets punishing for murder hobos with bounties and flaming fists coming for you for some really brutal fights unless you are on story mode. 

I am not discouraging you from playing because i dont want you to, but because I do worry about you expecting an experience thats not there or feeling like you wasted money. You dont need to play BG1 or 2 to enjoy BG3. But if you are still interested in playing, just know you can transfer your save from BG1 to BG2, which is a bit more enjoyable imo, and I would encourage getting both for a full experience. 

There are also a lot of reviews here that give some amazing tips from veteran fans and i encourage you to read up on that stuff too if you havent already.

Baldur's Gate and the original Fallout are arguably the most important RPGs ever made, everyone who is interested in this genre of video game owes it to themselves to play Baldur's Gate. Baldur's Gate is a very long game and doesn't really hold your hand at all, but after a few hours, you will have picked up on most of the game's system to plan effectively for combat encounters. The story, in my opinion, is the best of what Baldur's Gate has to offer even though it is a very by-the-numbers fantasy adventure, but that is exactly what most D&D tabletop games end up being so it is faithful to its source material, with all that being said the story is interesting enough for you to want to keep playing to see what happens.

The main issue with Baldur's Gate is the filler content. Many side quests are just uninteresting which in itself is fine because you can't expect every quest to be a hit, but most side quests come down to simple fetch quests. I found the content added in the Tales of the Sword Coast to be very uninteresting, it has fetch quests that are even more drawn out. Tales of the Sword Coast has quests you'll do for the XP boost, but not the actual content of the expansion. It might seem like I'm really tearing into this game now, but Tales hardly brings down the overall quality of the game, skip it if you want.

This is the Enhanced Edition of the game and I think it accomplished everything it set out to do very well. This port ran great on my machine, never had a single crash in my first play through which lasted over 60 hours. I thought the content added in the EE was good, maybe it would stick out if you played the original game back in 1998, but I didn't so it worked just fine for me. the only way I could tell that it was new content was that most of it is voice acted which isn't a bad thing.

Overall, Baldur's Gate is a must-play for RPG fans, I'm glad that I finally got around to playing this and I'm excited to jump into Baldur's Gate 2 when I'm ready for another long RPG to play. Give it a try.

This wasn't the first PC game I played, but it is the oldest game I am still playing to this day. Twenty five years after it was released, and I'm still trying to find new ways to play the game. That fact is likely more eloquent than anything I am likely to write, but I'll try nonetheless.

While the gameplay will same dated to some, it certainly did not feel that way at the time. Largely true to 2nd Edition D&D, it did not go out of its way to make things easy for players. Spells did not refresh in 10-30 seconds, but only after your party rested for eight in-game hours. You did not heal while running around the map, but instead had to use magic or spend days resting at an inn. Don't have the right weapons or spells? You might find yourself entirely unable to defeat an enemy. When you beat the game, you felt like you earned it. If it took 80 hours to do so? Well, that was normal.

The real standout for me, though, was the NPCs. In BG1 and later BG2 the companions you recruited to take with you on your journey - and there were plentiful options - were given real personalities and goals of their own. From the girl next door (and honorary little sister) Imoen, to psychotic megalomaniac Tiax, these were characters you could not help but remember. You just had to remember not to bring companions with opposing perspectives together, or they might try to kill each other.

The overall story for both BG1 and BG2 were perfect high fantasy. It all starts in a fantastical world, which had been under development for decades before the notion of a game called Baldur's Gate ever even sparked into existence. A young, inexperienced hero starts their epic journey, gaining in power until they are able to defeat the evil, bigger-than-life villain. Well, some villains. You might be recruiting some villains to help you. Your call. 

I'll no doubt come back and edit this to make it more coherent. I'm full of Thanksgiving dinner at the moment, and my brain is getting a tad sluggish, but if I was going to write a review for any game on Steam, I wanted it to be this one.

Plenty of hours with the original before purchasing on Steam. Still enjoy the classic RPGs with stories and characters and appreciate what Beamdog has done to keep this around and functioning on modern systems. QOL additions (gem bags, potion pouches, increased stack sizes, etc..) have been lifesavers for inventory management.

The original Baldur's Gate is a classic of PC gaming and an early sign of BioWare's story and character writing prowess. However, it is also a game that came out in 1998 and it shows. It was absolutely a game that benefited from this Enhanced Edition. The HUD is more manageable, the character textures sharper, and the turn based gameplay mostly unchanged. I also like that the game updated the D&D rules to allow for more classes and weapons to be used in-game. Basically, I felt like I was reliving my childhood, just with a few surprises in store.

My main issue with the remake is the new content. While it was great to hear the original cast back in their iconic roles (RIP David Warner), and it creates a nice bridge between Baldur's Gate and Shadows of Amn, the writing lacks the BioWare touch. Characters such as Neera, Rassad, and Glint do not fit into the game because their dialogue is written in sharp modern contrast to the original game's dialogue. It can be jarring as a result. It does not help that you can automatically tell which dialogue options are listed by alignment (1=good, 2-neutral, 3=evil). 

Overall, I enjoyed this game. The importance for me was how I felt playing this remake, more specifically if I felt the same awe, wonder, and fun I had playing the original way back when. And despite the new jarring dialogue, and characters, I felt like a kid again. If you like Dungeons & Dragons and want a 90s trip down memory lane, this is the game for you.

Overwhelming and punishing for new players but if you can get past the steepish learning curve, Baldur's Gate is a rich and rewarding game. I wasn't sure if it was going to be my kinda game to start off with but now that i've been through the entire main story, I definitely "get it". 

I can see why this game is considered one of the all time classics. At the time of me sitting here typing this I've only clocked up 14 hours game time and I absolutely intend to start on BD2 as soon as I see it come on sale. 

My advice for new players... Don't skip the tutorial, complete it and pay careful attention to everything. It's extremely useful for getting you started.

This is seriously one of the best RPGs I have ever played in my life, everything down to the last minute detail is perfect and I would not change a thing. You want to be a generic human fighter? Go for it. You wanna be a psychopathic orc wizard and flay thousands? You can if you'd really like it. The options you are presented with to roleplay your character are nearly endless and it's impressive for a product of 1997 (with some modern updates with this edition).

You start off by building your character in a very detailed creator, you may be a human, elf, half-orc and a few other races. You also have a variety of classes and kits within those classes to pick from so you can be essentially whatever playstyle you can imagine, even down to the detail of it complimenting a good or evil character. There are even over a dozen fun voices you can give your character that add all the more personality to them. Then you are thrust into the world of the Sword Coast.

Whoever your character is, they have a pretty privileged life as you reside in a castle world famous for its library, but one day tragedy strikes and you must run away for your life and explore the harsh world around you. This epic journey to discover yourself brings you from tiny mining towns to rugged mountains, stormy coasts and green plains until eventually you reach the famous city of Baldur's Gate itself. Baldur's Gate really gives you the authentic urban experience as you must deal with petty criminals, attempted murder and overzealous law enforcement, but the walls contain the great secret you are searching for.

The main story is beautiful and gets a 9/10 from me as it has relatively few flaws that can actually ruin the experience for a new player. Now onto the expansions

Tales of the Sword Coast adds a village wherein you can undertake new quests if you so desire, including but not limited to icy islands, quests across the sea and discovering ancient evils that were locked away for good reason. Depending on your morality and what you enjoy doing this may not be the longest expansion ever but it adds good content and adds some replay value if you want those achievements.

Siege of Dragonspear is the big selling point Beamdog made with this edition, does it hold up? First to address some ancient controversies that may turn off some people, a specific individual who caused controversies and review bombings is a relatively minor character I spoke to like twice and doesn't bring up a certain topic unless you really pursue it, so do not worry if that concerns you.

SoD is in my opinion a really well made expansion that added some context to the setting of the second game, expanded on relationships made in the base game and makes for some dramatic storytelling that kept me engaged the whole way through. There are also new companions who are added as well, if you enjoyed the really clever and fun companions before then there are a few new people you may be pleased with, and if you don't like them then you may avoid the majority of them as most are not relevant to the plot.

After winning the events of the first game your retirement is interrupted by an invading army that flooded the city with refugees and is now threatening you, so everybody bands together and marches on dragonspear castle in an attempt to thwart this so called crusade. There is a ton of tension and drama going on behind the scenes so you will get a kick out of this if you are into it.

The basic setting is essentially the same, you won't really find yourself in too many strange environments that differ from the base game but in a brand new region. On top of all the new content you also have a myriad of fun new side quests to do that I found to be just as strong as what you would find in the original product. SoD is truly a work of love and I really enjoyed my experience with it!

The other expansion is a relatively short one known as the Black Pits, you are a captured fighter in the Underdark fighting for the entertainment of depraved Drow. Not much to add here other than its an arena and you must fight for your life against ever increasingly difficult foes.

All things considered this game is a masterpiece of a roleplaying experience and I very strongly recommend this, even if you know nothing about DnD you will have a fun time with this game and the drama you will be found participating in.

This is a very good game and a must-play classic for any RPG or Bioware fan. However, if you are expecting any character interaction like in Bioware's later games, this one unfortunately doesn't have that. This would change in the second game as it has more of a focus on its characters, but there is still an interesting story here, and I'd recommend you play this one first before you play the second. They also added a new "difficulty mode" called story mode, or, as I like to call it, game journalist mode, where the game literally plays itself. Look, this game can be a cruel mistress and is very difficult at times, but I'd recommend looking up guides on how to beat certain encounters that are giving you trouble. You'd be surprised at what you can do if you play your cards right. This game is very rewarding when engaging with the rule set, but playing in story mode ruins the entire game and experience. You might as well look up a playthrough online, as you would get the same experience. As for the difficulty as a whole, I'd recommend Normal for a first playthrough and Core Rules for later playthroughs. Any difficulty above Core Rules just adds more health to the enemy's and makes your party do less damage, which is a very lazy and artificial way of making the game harder. There is one problem with this version of the game, and that is that the new 2D movies by Beamdog don't disseminate the information that the original movies do. I'm not sure why they changed them in this game because they didn't in the second. Also, the new companions are terribly written and clearly not part of the original game. There are two mods that reconcile these flaws. The first to remove the new companions is Convenient Enhanced Edition NPCs; the second to restore the original movies is BG:EE Classic Movies. Both can be found on GitHub. The most recent version of Convenient Enhanced Edition NPCs is 4.3, and the most recent version of BGEE Classic Movies is V2.3.1. Extract them separately with WinRAR or 7-Zip and drop them into your games directory. Run the executable for both. The original movies will be a simple matter of running the executable, and for the NPC mod, choose to remove all NPCS and enjoy.

A lovingly crafted isometric active w/ pause group-based RPG that was a standard bearer back in its time and still holds up very well today as one of the best RPG's ever made.

Harken ye back to the time when games were made by gamers for their fellow gamers, and it shows. The land is varied and liberally sprinkled with notable NPC's, quests, hidden mini-adventures, and hidey holes.

Group mates banter, and if opposing alignments can end up fighting each other to the death, or leave the group if they don't like how you're progressing or doing things. Or you can create your own party at the beginning, but you'll miss out on the organic nature and camaraderie of the legendary notable AD&D characters you can recruit along the way.

Even on easier difficulties you can and will die multiple times if you don't pay attention to the environments and enemies you're facing.

Loot is varied, helpful, and allows your characters to progress, such as gaining new spells, special enhancements, new ammo types, ect.

Yes, it's old-school, and clunky in places, but it has charm, it's organic, well crafted, and made to high standards that is sorely lacking in many modern day RPG's. It was made by people who cared about what they were producing and had a deep love of the source material, and it shows.

As much a masterpiece today as it was in its heyday, and well deserving of its place in anyone's RPG library, offering hours and hours of rich, handcrafted adventuring alongside the legendary characters and heroes of the AD&D world.

It took me three tries to get into this game properly and I want to share some tips for new starters that I had to learn through trial and error.

First things first, for the love of God, if you have never played ADnD before do not play on core rules setting, or frankly even normal difficulty. Easy or story mode is the way to go. Easy provides enough challenge for the new player to sink their teeth into, story basically turns the combat into an automatic affair, which might seem boring but is absolutely preferable to being murdered constantly without really knowing why or what to do about it. I played my first playthrough on core rules thinking I would get the 'authentic' Baldur's Gate experience, and, frankly, I wish I had given myself the grace to lower it at some point in the process. This is true for every game, but it is especially true here; there is no shame in pushing that slider down to whatever level feels manageable. 

Second, autopause is your friend. With exception of maybe damage I recommend turning basically all of them on at the start and then get rid of whatever ones annoy you most as time goes on. 

Finally, remember this game is largely a slow and relatively low stakes adventure, especially in the mid section. Mess around, go exploring, find out what you like. Learning how to take your time is key to enjoying the experience. Listen to the birds, appreciate the environments, grow to love the sound of your characters' footsteps. Games that operate at the pace this one proceeds at are rare these days, so learning how to slow down is, I think, maybe the biggest hump to get over before you can really fully fall in love with it. Level ups, story info, new areas, everything comes slowly in this game. Breathe out and take your time, there's no rush.

Take these going forward and I think you'll start to understand what it was people fell in love with back in the day. As someone with an interest in gaming history and a love for modern CRPGs, I went back into this without a clear vision of what to expect and it took me a while to see the sparkle through all the esoteric mechanical elements. Work with these strange features and they'll do you wonders, though.
