This is an old game but one of the all-time classics. Despite it`s 1990`s era graphics it still holds up against more recent games with a good story and some memorable characters. This is the game after all that introduced Minsc and his minature Giant Space Hamster Boo to the D&D universe and also has cameo appearances from Forgotten Realms stalwarts like Elminster and Drizzt.
This enhanced version replaces the old CGI cutscenes with new ones more in keeping with the style of the later games in the series but I kind of miss the originals. There are a number of new characters to meet and the Siege of Dragonspear add-on fills in the gap in the story between the end of this game and the start of BG II. So you can now start a character at 1st level then continue all the way to the end of Throne of Baal as a continuous narrative. All they have to do is do an add-on for BG II based on the D&D adventure "Murder in Baldur`s Gate" to complete the Child of Baal arc.
This is a landmark game in computer game history and probably one of the best games ever made, so if you havn`t played it, why not?

Your party will be fairly weak until later in the game so you may want to save before even a seemingly easy battle.
If a character joins up and tells you that they need to get somewhere, try to head that way as soon as you can. It's easy to get sidetracked and that particular NPC may leave you for good.
Try not to miss out on the powerful artifact just east of the Friendly Arm entrance and the very useful item hidden in the farm fields in Nashkel.
Your party should include at least a Cleric, a Wizard, a frontline fighter, and someone with thief skills. Most of these roles can be multiclassed if necessary (a Cleric/Mage is fine, for example.)
Don't hoard your consumables, use them whenever things get rough.
The Golden Pantaloons can be carried over to the sequel and doing so while also finding and holding on to that game's set of Pantaloons will eventually net you an interesting reward in the sequel's expansion.

Character Stats

Attributes: Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma. Most attributes are very top-heavy, 17/18 is where they start having real impact while the difference between 10 and 14 is minimal.
Armor Class: Lower is better, 10 is the worst. Your defence against physical attacks that's based off your Dexterity bonus, armor, shield and any magic protective spells/equipment.
THAC0: Lower is better, 20 is the worst. Your attack rating, equal to the number you need to roll on a 20-sided die to hit 0 Armor Class.
Saving Throws: Lower is better. Your non-physical defenses against magic attacks, poison, etc. To succeed at a save, you need to roll equal to or above your Saving Throw value on a 20-sided die.


The clue’s in the name. Baldur’s Gate: Enhanced Edition isn’t a remake of the famed RPG classic; instead, it acknowledges the many improvements modders have created over the years while seasoning the content with some worthwhile content additions. Despite a dearth of immediately obvious changes, Baldur’s Gate has aged well, and new players will find many hours’ worth of fun if they approach it with an understanding of its increasingly antiquated framework.

You can have a dozen reviews go on about how this is a classic of the RPG genre and considering what the genre looked like before this, there absolutely is no denying its impact. For all it's done for RPGs, however...it's not a good game. The gameplay is based off of the AD&D rules, which are bad but in the opposite way 5e is bad. What especially drags this down is the usage of Real Time With Pause combat, a system where you spend most of your time telling your wizard to stop rushing into the frontline, as well as dealing with devs who think "oh, RTWP makes combat go by real fast, so let's put in absolute trash fights every 5 metres, this surely won't waste the player's time."

The writing isn't much better, and I'd even say that modern Bioware hasn't yet sunk this low. Characters vomit walls of text with nothing meaningful to say, all the companions just have a personality gimmick and that's it, and the world, set in the Forgettable Realms, is just your standard generic euro medieval fantasy. Enhanced Edition added some content and the writing is just as bad there, just with more voice acting. Visuals are pretty if also generic, the soundtrack is just another generic symphony, and so on. Unless you're really particular about experiencing RPG history, skip this one.

Do you often fantasize about being transported from this world into another. Maybe a realm of fantasy created by the lore of Dungeons and Dragon. Well this is the game that will take you there. This game is by far worth the experience, I've had a blast and would still pick it up and play today even after experiencing new modern RPGs like Divinity Original Sin 2. There is a certain charm to Baldur's Gate 1 that gives you that authentic feeling of DnD you are searching for.

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is a classic RPG experience that, in many ways, surpasses even the highly anticipated Baldur's Gate 3. Here's why Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition shines brighter than its successor.

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is a modernized version of the beloved 1998 classic, preserving the essence and nostalgia of the original far better than Baldurs Gate 3 does while offering enhanced visuals, improved mechanics, and various quality-of-life improvements. It remains true to the original's spirit, delivering an experience that captures the magic of the past. The original "Baldur's Gate" narrative is renowned for its depth and complexity, far more so than that of Baldurs Gate 3. The story in "Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition" is a testament to the art of storytelling in RPGs, featuring intricate character development, morally ambiguous choices, and a world steeped in history. It's a tale that immerses players deeply within the Forgotten Realms universe. Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition includes the original game as well as its expansion, Tales of the Sword Coast. The wealth of content and side quests provides countless hours of gameplay, ensuring that you'll never run out of adventures to embark on. The modding community for Baldur's Gate is thriving, with numerous user-generated content and enhancements that can be added to the game. This level of customization far exceeds that of Baldurs Gate 3 and thus allows players to tailor their experience to their preferences, extending the game's longevity and replayability. Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition has had years to mature and develop a dedicated fan base. The result is a polished and refined gaming experience with patches and updates that have ironed out many of the original game's issues unlike that state Baldurs Gate 3 is in at this point in time. The continued success of Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition has solidified its status as a timeless classic. It has consistently received praise for its ability to capture the essence of the original game while making it more accessible to modern audiences.

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition stands as a testament to the enduring greatness of the original game. It not only respects the legacy of the Baldur's Gate series, Unlike its contemporary counterpart, but also enriches it with modern enhancements and accessibility. While Baldur's Gate 3 certainly does hold some promise and potential, Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is the definitive choice for those who seek a classic RPG experience that has already proven its lasting appeal and brilliance.

The original Baldur's Gate was an enjoyable experience for me, particularly the brilliant intro movie it had. When I heard the game was getting an Enhanced Edition, I had to get it, especially with the chance to play the expansion content, packaged into it, that the original game got, which I never played through until I got this.

I really love the improved UI system, and how it incorporated the extra features for the character creation system that Baldur's Gate 2 introduced, as well as adding new difficulty levels - story mode for one thing. But the best bits are the new characters, as well as the new locations you can visit.

I will say that the new DLC for the game, Siege of Dragonspear, really adds to the fun. Love the storyline of it, and the additional characters and locations it provides. I particularly love it from being a bridge between Baldur's Gate 1 & 2 - I never could understand why the original developers never thought to properly do that before.

Overall, this is a must have for all those that loved Dungeons & Dragons and isometric RPGs, whether you're a veteran of Baldur's Gate or a newcomer. The fun is still there, and its great to replay this since I first played the original back in the 90s.

Very good game with a steep learning curve. Would recommend a Youtube guide that describes BG combat as it uses the AD&D rules, as a number of things are counter intuitive to how you would think it would work if you are more familiar with modern D&D. For example, AC is based on the overarching THACO system. So as you put on better armor, your armor level goes down, which is confusing, but that's what this game wants. You want to get your AC into the negatives as that means you are harder to hit.

The Beamdog additional companions suck. Neera is a god tier companion in BG2, but in BG1, she sucks, same with Rasaad (literally worst battle companion in the game), the edgy Orc Blackguard (he big and mean, that's his character). The writing of all these new editions completely clashes with a game remade 18 years after the original. The tone is completely different, you can tell the writing is being done by a person who was 3 years old when BG1 released.

The plot is very intricate and requires you to think about the greater context of the world other than chasing down the bad man with the horns. It has a lot to do with the war economy, trying to inflame tensions between two nations. and that's all I'll say. It's a smart political story that most developers today would not trust the audience to understand. 

100% recommended, but just watch a guide to understand why combat works the way it does. Yes, the best guides can be over an hour long, but it'll make your next 80 hours much better,

A bit of a mixed experience, an instance were a rating between thumbs up and thumbs down would be helpful. 
A good example is that BG1 has one of the best dungeons in any game I've ever played as well as some really bad dungeons which are made worse by the games horrible path-finding.

At its core the game is an old school game based on an old school RPG, its tough and rewards preparation and a certain level of paranoia. Some enemies can instantly kill you (the game signposts this relatively well), you can stumble into encounters way above your level and many of the crowd control spells are brutally powerful. 
Where the old-school feel works really well is wandering around the wilderness areas finding items, quests and characters to join your party. 
I've got complicated feelings about this game and could write a long rambling review but I'll just note down some key points.

Story: Great idea decently executed but let down by uneven writing quality and the occasional exposition dumps.
Game-play: Satisfying combat held back by middling to poor encounter and map design. But when it's fun, it's fun.
Characters: Base game the NPCS are very basic and although they are often elevated by fun voice acting performances I would highly recommend trying the BG1 NPC project mod. This gives some dialogue with the characters which is overall very good with some hiccups here and there.
Music / Sound: Very good, helps make adventuring in the wilderness a lot of fun
Graphics: Character models and animations are fine but the wilderness backgrounds look great, urban environments are so-so.

If you are into classic RPGs and haven't played this I would say give it a shot but it's not a must play in my opinion.

This is the first time i wish Steam offered the option of something between a thumbs up or a thumbs down, but since it doesn't have that option and i had more frustration than fun with the game, i will go with a "Do not recommend".

So, if you are curious about trying this game because its a classic, i won't stop you and i would actually recommend to TRY IT, but the moment you hit some frustration or you feel progression slowing really down, to drop the game and never look back. You should be able to get a good 10 to 20 hours of decent fun. 

I guess i'll start with the good stuff. The charm of the game is still present decades later. Its impressive how much life the developer were able to inject in the game with limited resources that they had. For that alone, it is worth experiencing. Some of the characters quote has been literally etched into my mind forever. The story is still good by today's standard and the world feels large even though it is split by map. Really, i can't stress enough how much on the presentation level, lore and immersion, i have nothing but praise.

The problems lies in the difficulty and the progression. This game is EXTREMELY punishing, even a bit too much. Lets say you are a party of 6 against a warrior, a mage and two archer. Chances are, you are about to get fucked unless you get godlike rolls. The best approach to any fight that has a large group of enemies is literally to cast Horror 2 times and hope a good portion of the enemy group start running around. If that doesn't happen, well GG tough luck, better reload. Another example, you are fighting a strong mage with two minions. You try to put him to sleep and charm it. Tough luck, your two rolls missed and the mage cast a bouncing lightning bold and 3 member of your party is dead. Welp, better reload since its pretty much over. And example like this i have a ton of them.

Then, there is the randomness when resting or travelling. Why on earth does every time we rest and or travel there is chances of enemy encounter in a game i can reload whenever i want ? And i know the dev knows this is stupid, because in the last area of the game, guess what, to make it easier to reach the last boss, you can rest 100% guarantee no encounter (at least, it felt like that). Why is this activated at normal difficulty i do not know. And with encounters this punishing, guess which option the player is going to choose.

Also, talking about punishing, i never used the resurrection in the chapel and i don't see the use of it. When a party member dies, you can resurrect it at a chapel, but you need to transport ALL of there stuff back to a city, since all when they die, they keep the stuff on the ground. Why on earth would i do that instead of reloading. ?

Finally progression. So for the first 10-20 hours of the game, you met new companions, you level up, etc. Progression is a bit slow, but comes at a steady pace. But, once you reach the 25 hours mark or around level 5, progressions start to slow down to a crawl. Barely any new companion, levels takes forever and better gear is rare. Feels like you start to stale a bit and you feel you have to grind in order to keep up.

So as you can see, i have some gripe with the game. I think im glad i played it, but at the same time, i felt i wasted my time. Maybe with BG 2, i can feel the first one was worth going through since you can import you character from the first game. But has is, i only recommend for people to TRY the game, but to not finish it. Create a character, reach level 4 or 5, get some party members and do some quests, but the moment you start to feel progressions is too slow or the game is too frustrating, drop the game and play something else.

It took me like five attempts to get into this game. So many times I bounced off, and for good reason I think. The UI is ancient, and hasn't aged well at all. The same can be said of AD&D itself. The voice acting is god awful, there are basically no meaningful party interactions, and there is far too much empty space in maps.

But I've also played this game for 80 hours, so what gives?
Despite all of that, the game is really, really fun. BG1 is excellent, and it's easy to see why fans have been playing it for decades. Modern CRPGs like Pathfinder, PIllars of Eternity, they all have their roots in this very game. I'm not going to tell you to play it out of a sense of obligation, you should play it because to this day it's an excellent world to explore, with a genuinely excellent story.

I played the original Baldur's Gate back in 1998 when it first came out.  Having played D&D in my youth, this was the perfect game to get stuck into, and I loved it!  For some reason, never finished it back then.  It was probably something to do with having a young family, moving countries and other little life events, so when the Enhanced Editor became available on Steam, I jumped at the chance to play it all again and finish the main game and all the expansions.

Overall, I'd say Baldur's Gate II is the better game, and Baldur's Gate III has set a new standard for CRPGs, but if you want to experience a first class adventure with memorable quests and companions with a lot of personality, then I would still recommend this game to see where it all began.

Baldur's Gate is the gold standard for fantasy roleplaying games even 25 years on and I'd highly recommend it to anyone looking for either a CRPG or a faithful D&D experience. I enjoyed more than 100 hours of the main campaign on both Core Rules and then Legacy of Bhaal difficulty (which acts as a NG+), and could easily go back with a new character in the future.

Magic felt excellent, character development and choices were slow and impactful, and it really felt like playing through my own D&D campaign. Even the combat system is 20 years ahead of it's time.

Having said all that, Beamdog are lucky this is going down as a positive review rather than a negative.

'Enhanced Edition' is a misnomer - the newer content added by Beamdog sticks out like a sore thumb as amateur, poorly written and not well integrated into the main game. This should be optional, instead they've rewritten a game and altered history to better suit themselves. Fortunately not much of the main campaign was touched, bar a few goofy characters and pointless side quests, which I promise you you will not miss. In fairness, the quality of life content such as a potion bag was appreciated.

However, the expansion they added - Siege of Dragonspear - I highly recommend against playing and just moving straight on to Baldur's Gate II. I can't adequately describe how bad the writing is in Beamdog's own creation. The SJW nonsense hits you in the face right out of the gate - all the men are bumbling idiots for example, whereas all the women are filling traditional male roles and are strong, ruthless and obnoxious.

That aside, the story, dialogue and quests are clearly written by somebody who did not know what they were doing and had no respect for the source material. It reads and feels nothing like the previous excellent game we'd played!

Previously excellent characters have had their entire personalities altered to suit MODERN AUDIENCES and what these people think they want. A previously fearless barbarian companion, famous for his pet hamster and battlecries, was reduced to a bumbling idiotic sidekick who all the others constantly made condescending comments about. Anyone making those kind of comments in the first, true game would have been beaten to death with his huge hulking fists (S 18/93).

One of the first quests I received was 'Cheer up Torpil' - what the hell are we concerned about the emotions of a sulking background NPC, and why is my epic high fantasy roleplay being written like a twelve-year old's text messages?!

I could go on for hours, however it's not fair to focus exclusively on the piss-poor job Beamdog did 'enhancing' the world. I said earlier 'the first, true game' and that's exactly how it will go down in my memory. Don't let these people take what we love from us. 

Baldur's Gate remains an excellent game, and truly worth a playthrough or two, especially for those too young to have enjoyed the original release.

Would you recommend this game to other players? Yes
Would you like to write a review? No, that wasn't the question I pressed yes on.

My first time going back to play an older CRPG and I was surprised how good it was. The writing and the world building is quite good, love the array of characters and various NPCs that populate this world.
I was also a big fan of the exploration aspect of different maps of Baldur's Gate 1 main game, was always intrigued to find out if I'd find a NPC or a new type of enemy. 
The combat and the RPG character building aspect did confuse me a bit as I'm not familiar with D&D, but I had a friend help me with it. I quite liked the abilities each class had and it was always exciting to identify new types of loot for use and how they might change how I play (Keep in mind I played BG1/Sword Coast on Normal and Siege of Dragonspear on Core Rules).

The Sword Coast DLC was really enjoyable addition, I especially like the Durlag's Tower dungeon, which is easily the best dungeon in the game. Good mix of puzzles, story and combat encounters. The other stuff in the village is also fun with the getaways to the mage dungeon or Balduran's Shipwreck Island.

Siege of Dragonspear was another addition made my Beamdog in the last decade and I really enjoyed the story in it. I love the increased focus on the Bhaalspawn aspect of your character and how they elaborate on that. The additional dialogue from companions is also a great boon. 

I will be going back to play more older CRPGs now and I cannot wait to play Baldur's Gate 2. 

Highly recommend it to RPG fans :)

[h1] A classic CRPG, if a little intimidating [/h1]

I'll admit, I didn't expect much from [i] Baldur's Gate [/i] going in. [i] A top-down, initially PC-only RPG from 1998?[/i], I thought. [i] How good could it possibly be?[/i] Well, as it turns out, this game is very good indeed. I picked it up on sale based on a friend's recommendation, and as you can see by my hours played, I've been thoroughly enjoying it.  For one thing, it's a D&D game, with all the classic high-fantasy adventure and aesthetics that description implies. As a 5th Edition D&D player myself (and a longtime fan of J.R.R. Tolkien and the Conan stories of Robert E. Howard), my interest was piqued when I learned of this connection. With swords and sorcery aplenty, this is a great game for fantasy fans, even if the story isn't terribly deep or complex. Secondly, the combat and experience systems are really well-done and simple enough to understand once you read up on it, or if you happen to have played old-school D&D. Thirdly, each party member is unique and has lots of personality. However, it did take a few abandoned playthroughs for me to reach the point where I liked this game. The interface is more than a little clunky by today's standards, particularly if you're not very used to a mouse-and-keyboard interface (as I wasn't when I bought this), and all the character stats can be a bit confusing at times. It didn't take long for me to see what all the hype was about, though, and why my friend gave this game such a great review.

So truth be told, this game is a bit of a chore to get into. But around hour 15-20... things start to get weird. You start to understand the mechanics. You start to realize how ridiculously powerful your character can be if built correctly. More importantly, you look up how to cheat in a bag of holding. This game holds charm, but only for the those that are willing to persevere through its initial difficulty and ancient mechanisms. 

I would strongly suggest this game, and I would also strongly suggest you build a fighter/something else. I played through with a fighter pure first, and decided I didn't enjoy it enough so went back and did fighter/mage/thief and I am now having a blast. The story is fun, and the items are sometimes very powerful. I think my favorite part of this game is when I see a mechanic that exists in modern games, because I now know where they got it.

Also quests have timers, side quests are very short usually a few ingame days. Main quest thankfully has no limit on it. So once you start a side quest you better finish it, also companion quests are the shortest timer on them so always prioritise them.

Also the main quest is very short I assume because of the remaster (EE) since the journal and map pretty much show you where to go, but the meat of the game is the exploration and different outcomes.

Overall pretty fun, I love the open world. I can see why this was so big when it first came out.

If you're a newer gamer or haven't enjoyed oldschool CRPGs before, well gather round the fire sonny and listen here! This a grand adventure in storytelling and well worth it if you're willing to be patient and suffer through brutal abuse. Starting off at lvl 1 with DnD rules is no small feat so prepare to die as if you were trying to cross a river in Oregon trail...or wait...do kids even know about that reference anymore? The horrors of Dysentery?! I suppose not, so I'll put it this way, this game will have you save scumming constantly at first, which is a critique I had decades ago and what I think is its biggest barrier to entry now. 

If you persevere through the first few hours you're in for a treat. If not, I suggest playing bulders gate 2 first or lowering the difficulty to story mode. The rewards for the patient are vast but if you're opposed to old graphics, reading, grand storytelling, and some tough adventure...well...this probably won't be your cup of tea. Many are coming here from Bulder's Gate 3 wondering where it came from and I'm here to tell ya its a different experience. A great experience but different...don't be surprised if it doesn't clique with you immediately. I adored this game in my early teen years and I still get thrown off by the "charms" of its age when I come back decades later. Give it a few hours and if you still don't like it, try bulders gate 2, neverwinter nights, or another oldschool CRPG that might tickle your fancy.

Again, they don't make games like this anymore (with some indie exceptions) but if you want to experience where Bulder's Gate 3, most of Bioware's games, Obsidian, and some Bethesda titles came from...this is the granddaddy of them...and he won't just threaten to whup your ass while walking 4 miles, with no shoes, during an ice storm in the winter. He definitely will and you'll definitely gain character for it. So level up your gaming and history skills and give this game a ride. It's a great time.

A time capsule worth your money and time.

BG1 is still well worth playing, although you see how time passed regarding world building, quest design and combat-story balance. You'll enjoy it more when you don't try to compare it to today's standards, as through today's perspective, the game is unnecessarily grindy while at the same time having an annoying exp cap too far before the end, and, in my opinion, the story doesn't really deliver and the side quests remain superficial for today's standards. Just the Add-On content gives a hint at what Bioware would create with BG2. 
Still, it is an enjoyable experience, especially seeing it as a time capsule of the first steps in actual modern RPG design, and of course paving the way for the legendary BG2:Shadows of Amn and ToB, which are masterpieces that definitely withstood the test of time (I still consider BG2 one of the best games ever made).

The Beamdog-made add-on Siege of Dragonspear in my opinion took a lot of unnecessary crap. It is - of course - better done than BG1 as it is more modern, and the story quality is somewhere between BG1 and BG2, making it a nice interlude with some memorable moments. In my opinion, it also doesn't spoiler too much. Instead, it triggered just the right amount of nostalgia to directly jump into Baldur's Gate 2 again, and I appreciate a lot seeing how much effort people put into a game that wasn't even necessary, but still fits well in between part 1 and part 2 and gives it a kind of canonical connection. I noticed a few bugs and SoD makes it hard to play an evil party, but who cares. It was a lot of fun.
At the time of writing this review, I just finished playing through BG1 and SoD and it took me more than 90 hours for one playthrough, so this is also value for money regarding the time and fun you get. Please don't forget that you can import your character directly into BG2!

Too bad that Bioware started to go downhill after that. Both Neverwinter Nights and Dragon Age: Origins were without doubt great games, but they never again reached the level of perfect writing both in story and party interaction. Dragon Age died with part 2, and Mass Effect died with part 3. It's always sad to see great studios go down, but well, thanks to CDProjekt RED, Larian Studios and others, there are still great RPGs out there.

I'm replaying BG1 and BG2 to get the whole experience and brush up my memories, to enjoy Larian's Baldur's Gate 3 even more than I already do. I recommend you do the same :)

Better than BG3

RPG games in essence exist to give you ultimate self-expression. with the coming of BG3 I thought to myself this is just another half-made semi RPG that marketing boosted. than I saw other game devs attacking it and thought allright this might actually be an RPG. just played 1 so I still don't know about it but from what I have seen here. They do not flee of hard work. 

the game really tries to immerse you. there are no waypoints or absence of gore in story or in mechanics. EVERYTHING has consequences. npcs and side characters has wants and needs and will demand them of you. the fights are challenging. (although I played in story mode it was clear to see) the game has puts lots of effort. and if you also install npc project mod. you will be overjoyed.

I played dragon age origins before this and I did enjoy the story but the many slow pace factos drew me away from the game. my problem with these kind of RPGs are that they are painstakingly slow. we have 6 slots for characters and when you ahve 6 you share the same exp. that was something I learnt from a video while playing dlc... there are many secrets, expolits, and many more that you need to learn. the game is way too wide to try to do all the missions in one playthrough. this is common for a real RPG tho.

but my problems with dragon age continue here. even while selling items I have to sell them one by one for each character. and although the game is old, there is no stash... and when you have full inventory you might suffer the same fate I did which is losing your items because the game replaces your item with the quest item hence dropping it to the ground hence it will vanish after a while hence you will either be stuck in a quest if it was a quest item or you might lose a container that you cannot acquire again like I did. tbh with you this was tilting as hell. the game I played more than 40 hours means nothing no more. even my save is worthless. I can't bring this to the 2nd game anymore. not only that but when dlc starts they dispense all your side characters with their inventory. meaning all the valuable items you had on them is gone now. there are some empty buildings people use to stock items as stash. as I did I put most of the unique items or very strong items in game to such stashes. and what do I now? the dlc won't allow me to travel back there so yeah my save is busted yet again. 

the game is handcrafted, wide, thought provoking, immersive these are all true. but the flaws... there are many a dialogue in which you will think your characters are talking to brick walls instead of each other. this is not a common happening but I played with more than 1 mod meaning this probably happens a lot more. in the dlc there wasn't much of a mod so I ve seen it much more and I must say this is a big minus on the game. what is the point of making a system that you will have to put many an hour, slow the pace of the game to the hellpits and don't make it right so the immersion is gone either way. 

look although the game was hard to play as it was old I still enjoyed the game and I would have played it again even if I had known all of this before. many of my problems stem through the game's choice of prioritizing npcs. npcs that you can get in your group might force you take another npc or leave, might want to do something and you would need to promise to do it and if you don't do it for a long while they might leave. a good natured character might argue with a bad natured one and leave. a good natured character might flat out attack you for a bad action you took. 

so the main source of the story is not you it is the npcs and I would have no problem with that except we are still playing a game with an end. with everything I have said above this makes everything very very painstaking. the details are lost, the bugs are lost many things the devs couldn't have gone through to give us such a wide world. this is of course what many a people will ignore to experience such a living world.(way better than skyrim on that part) but the point stands that the pros comes with cons and this is not a game that is for everyone. I really aspire to play an RPG game that will blow my mind and this wasn't it. I would still prefer this over a generic assasins creed game but there I knew what I was getting as in here, I face many a stupid things as burning my save as aforementioned. 

the game was hard on the cons than the pros and I haven't even got to why I couldn't finish dlc off of a bug. but alas I don't have to. from the first achievement of the dlc to be a rare one it is clear people didn't like the dlc anyways and I can understand. so I won't suggest the dlc but the main game.

I haven't replayed Baldur's Gate since the late 1990's and I amazed at how well the Enhanced Edition holds up.  I've played the more modern CRPGs (Pillars of Eternity 1&2; Torment Tides of Numenera; Tyranny; Patherfinder Kingmaker), and while they were enjoyable, something was missing...  I can't put my finger on it, but Baldur's Gate is just magical.  Kind of reminds me of trying to compare the original Star Wars trilogy to the more modern Star Wars movies - something is missing.  It is a pleasure replaying this game.

[h1]You must gather your party before venturing forth. [/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Baldur's Gate is a 2D isometric CRPG from the golden age and critically acclaimed as one of the best of its genre ever made. With the original hailing from 1998, the game needed some work. The enhanced edition provides several updates, such as native support for current high-resolution monitors and over 400 improvements to the original experience.
But does this time-worn classic have what it takes to stand amongst the pantheon of current CRPGs, or has it been slain and left in the dust?

[table]
[tr]
	[th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
	[th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]🟩 A lengthy and well-written story sprinkled with plot twists, betrayal, difficult decisions and companionship. You will be hard-pressed to find a more immersive journey.

🟩 Character customisation isn't visually substantial, but there are quite a few class options and character-specific details that you can augment to make them your own.

🟩 There are over 25 companions you can potentially recruit to your cause, all with unique personalities, motives and morality. You can't hope to align yourself with them all, so decisions make a difference not only with the story but also with who will choose to follow you into it.

🟩 The map is substantial for its age, and there are a lot of places to discover and explore, with incredible rewards awaiting those diligent and powerful enough to wrest them from their hiding places.[/td]
	[td]🟥 The 2nd Edition Dungeons and Dragons ruleset. For a whole heap of reasons.

🟥 There are few skills to turn the tide of combat, especially as a melee character.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
Having spent your entire life behind the thick and sturdy walls of Candlekeep, you have little experience of the world beyond them. Your foster father, Gorion, has done everything in his power to keep you out of harm's way, but as mysterious circumstances unfold, fate forces you to flee and leave your friends behind.

It is here beyond the walls of your former home that tragedy befalls you both.

Now alone, you, "Gorion's Ward", as the game refers to you, are drawn into a conflict that threatens to plunge the entire Sword Coast into war. With little more than vague directions from Gorion, your journey begins.

Baldur's Gate is one of the few games that captivated and enthralled me within the story for the entirety of the campaign. The narrative is well-written, the conversations feel honest and realistic, and the general world-building brims with impeccable detail.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Your life ends here.[/h3]
Combat encounters in this game are a double-edged sword. All of them are engaging and story-driven moments within the world-building, but they can become incredibly tedious due to the 2nd Edition ruleset. I won't cover the ruleset in great detail, but quite a few resources online explain it far better than I can under such character limitations.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3039637204

Engagements begin upon encountering an enemy, and usually, there is a frontal dialogue to detail the reason for the fight with your new enemy before the battle begins. There are very few abilities to utilise here, especially for melee characters, and they will tend to engage and swing at the enemy until it dies. Casters are more complex and require a little more prep work to be effective in encounters. You need to memorise spells from scrolls and then rest overnight to be able to use that spell, but once they learn the magic, it is theirs forever, and they will only need to rest to replenish its uses.

Buffs for your party are critical within Baldur's Gate because many enemies are immensely mighty, and the odds are often heavily stacked in their favour. Buffing your party with haste, armour, and stat increases will help level the playing field, providing you with a fairer position to fight.

[h3]There are s-so many places I would rather be.[/h3]
As with any RPG, regardless of its format, exploration is critically important to improving your character through experience and rare loot. Baldur's Gate 1 is no exception, as the best items are hidden off the beaten path and usually in the hands of deadly foes. The diligent explorer will comb the world for these items and attain rewards for their prowess with riches and powers beyond description. Steel yourselves, as these enemies won't hand over their treasures without a fight.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3039636862

[h3]Yes, oh, omnipresent authority figure?[/h3]
There are over 25 companions to choose from within the world. Each of them is unique in that they have their own personalities and moral compass and may choose to accept or decline your invitations based on what they know of you, and may even decide to leave you if you deviate too far off their moral compass. There are clear synergies to factor in, as some group dynamics work better than others, and that should be considered before inviting someone new to your team. But it's all about experimentation, and as a worst case, if you decide they aren't a good fit you can ask them to leave, but be aware if you do ask them to leave, they may leave for good.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
Baldur's Gate isn't going to blow you away with cutting-edge visuals and a crisp resolution, but it does, however, look exemplary for its age. The environments have a clean visual style that doesn't overwhelm your senses but lets you appreciate the world around you. The improvements of the Enhanced Edition did a lot to bring this game into the current era. But with that said, the camera is static and isn't freely controllable, so you will have to accept that what you can see is all you have.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3039637366

The above is also true of the audio, where many tracks have been lovingly restored or recreated to deliver a very nostalgic experience with a far more modern edge. Having the original soundtrack remastered is excellent because this has to be one of my all-time favourite soundtracks.

[h1]PC Performance and Specifications[/h1]
This title is originally from 1998, and I will safely assume everyone with a modern system will run this game flawlessly. There are no graphical flaws or issues to report.

[h1]Final Thoughts - Excellent[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
Baldurs Gate is defined as one of the greatest CRPGs ever developed, and rightly so. It is everything you want it to be and more, allowing you almost true freedom to complete objectives how you desire to and providing substantial consequences for those decisions. With a likeable retinue of characters and a dense, well-written storyline, Baldur's Gate has well-earned its crown and I look forward to seeing the games that try to contend with it. This game is worth its already discounted price, and if you're a fan of the genre this is one you cannot miss.

[quote]Sharpen your blades, embody your armour and venture forth into the sprawling wilds of [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43064204/] Hell, Purgatory and Paradise[/url] where every review is a journey worth taking.[/quote]

Great game but if you're looking to rely on cloud saves, keep in mind that you must have the feature enabled both in game and on the steam client simultaneously.

To enable on steam:
1. Right click the game in your library
2. Click properties
3. Click general
4. Enable cloud saves.

To enable cloud saves in game
1. Launch the game
2: Click options
3. Click gameplay
4. In the menu on the right side of the screen, make sure "Enable cloud saves" is enabled by ensuring that it is a brighter shades of red than other options in the same menu.

Baldur's Gate Enhanced Edition is a good cRPG that's worth playing. Yet simultaneously parts of it have not aged well, despite the Enhanced Edition, and will turn some players off.

In comparison to more modern cRPGs, Baldur's Gate is very freeform in how you can approach things. The story is there, largely well-written, and frequently referenced, but for most of the game you're free to go and explore anywhere you wish. You can kill just about anyone you meet, or help them out of course. And there are something like 20-30 potential party members, so that no matter what alignment you end up on you can always have a useful party along for the ride.

The 2nd edition D&D rules the game is based on are quite archaic, but do offer a huge amount of variety. There are a lot of classes and sub-types to play around with in addition to dual- or multi-classing. A fair few races with different bonuses. A bunch of stats (although charisma/intellect/wisdom largely don't do much). Loads of different weapon types. Absurd amounts of spells, scrolls, potions, etc. It genuinely feels like a D&D adventure in game format, especially at the start with all the exploration.

The quests, exploration, and story are the highlights. Though this game is story-light compared to something like Planescape Torment, what's there is still very interesting and sets things up for some real strong potential in Baldur's Gate 2. It's an all-around good game. And if you can suffer its shortcomings, well worth a playthrough.

There are those shortcomings though...

Baldur's Gate 1 most clearly shows its age with pathfinding. It's atrocious. Wanna see party members banging their heads against each other for 5 minutes straight, no matter how often you click for them to move apart? You can, in this game. It's infuriating when it happens, but also not an insurmountable problem. Party AI in general is also very rudimentary, but that can also be said for more modern games like Pillars of Eternity...

Similarly the user interface leaves a lot to be desired. Only being able to quick-slot 3 items and 3 spells? One of the most obnoxiously limited and clearly dated inventory systems in the RPG genre? Sure, Diablo 1's is MUCH worse, but that's literally as low as that bar can actually go. A UI that on a 21:9 by monitor can only be toggled between "you-must-be-blind" and "please-wear-a-telescope" sizes. This on top of everything important being communicated in a dialogue screen with oversized text. Wanna know what that enemy mage cast, or whether you're even hitting your enemy with basic attacks, or whether your spell even did anything? Scroll through the lines in that dialogue screen...

The game only runs at 30 fps, because gameplay logic is tied to that frame rate, which turns into an absolute stutterfest when panning the camera. The environment design is generally very simplistic. The end was clearly rushed as the environment design is largely atrocious, the encounter design even more all over the place than the rest of the game, and the quests barely there at all. The writing at the end was good and definitely made me interested in BG2 though...

As mentioned, the encounter design is all over the place, which is common in cRPGs. Surprisingly I thought BGEE was actually mostly... too easy. On Core Rules difficulty. Get some magical (+1) weapons and ammo the moment you can afford it and there goes your level 1-2 party demolishing most level 6 groups trivially. There are some hard encounters, even brutal ones that subvert the game mechanics, but they're few and far between. Mostly either at the very uneven end, or in the Tales of the Sword Coast expansion content. And even those were far easier to deal with than the nastier fights in Pillars of Eternity 1 & 2. This was a bit of a problem as the endless easy fights combined with slow walking speed pre-Haste-spell meant the middle of the game dragged. It didn't drag nearly as much as PoE though, and only for a while. Haste fixes things nicely!

There is some more archaic design holding the game back, like no respecs. An issue if you put proficiency points into the wrong weapons, or you're a sorceror and picked the wrong spell. Saving a lot helps. On that note, the quick save system with multiple rotating slots is actually much more convenient than in most modern cRPGs!

The writing, while overall quite good, is a bit shaky. It doesn't have the same tone throughout, even if you ignore Beamdog's anachronous additions. Some areas of the game are much more fleshed out than others. And the end of the game is very rushed in encounter and environment design, although the story is quite compelling at that point.

With the right perspective there is a lot of fun to be had here, even for a newcomer in 2023. I had a great time playing through BGEE and the ending made me look forward to booting up BG2. I suspect that game will truly live up to the classic status, with what's been set up here, while I think BGEE is more just a great game held back by a lot of minor annoyances and it being the first RPG of its kind for BioWare. Planescape Torment is a big step above for me, although that game is more story-heavy where this is gameplay-focused.

If you think you have what it takes to look past the annoyances to the gem underneath... pick this up and give it a go. You might just have a really great time with it.

The main campaign was pretty great. The only one of the bunch that kinda fell flat to me was the Siege of Dragonspear campaign. The start is really good but it starts to fall apart pretty quickly. It starts falling apart to me [spoiler] when it loses any and all continuity with what happened in your main save. In my main save I failed to find Dynaheir entirely and Minsc attacked me for it, leading to his death, but in Siege of Dragonspear he's alive and Dynaheir is free. On top of that, people you traveled with can just, not know who you are. Prime example with my save being Dorn Il-Khan. Traveled with him almost the entire main campaign, then it basically made it to where he had no idea who I was. [/spoiler] Aside from that, the campaign was honestly pretty great as well until the ending. The ending was just, not great. I understand it's meant as a bridge between BG1 and BG2, but it just felt bad [spoiler] since it disregards pretty much everything you've done and forces the "canonical" party onto you, even if you never even used any of them. [/spoiler] Even with that said, I still recommend the game. Very enjoyable story wise.

Baldur's Gate sets the bar high for what an RPG can be, and if you have even a passing interest in the genre, this is one journey you don't want to miss. While the Enhanced Edition had its share of early criticisms, it has since matured into a solid experience that adds real quality-of-life improvements to an already epic game.

I tried. I really did.

I can get past the outdated graphics and the crusty UI. I can handle the dubious pathfinding and the clunky combat. I can even tolerate the annoying inventory management and inscrutable magic menus.

What I can't get past is the AD&D ruleset. Hope you like rolling for stats until the random number god gives you enough points to not be useless. THAC0 is one thing, but insane one-off rules like having exactly 18 strength giving a 1d100 bonus to the stat that are never explained or hinted at mean that going in blind you are [i]guaranteed[/i] to build a character who is not merely suboptimal, but an active hindrance to your party.

I've heard this game's writing praised for decades, but I guess the nostalgia goggles are firmly set on people's heads because I'm 6 hours in on my current attempt and there's scarcely any story to speak of. Quests amount to "I dropped my knife in the woods, please fetch it for me" or "kill wolves and bring me their pelts". Character interactions aren't a thing after you recruit them. Fan-favorite Minsc runs around barking combat shouts about "butt-kicking for goodness". Maybe this seemed like Hamlet when you were five years old, but it doesn't cut it today. Dialogue choices amount to "yes [good]", "yes [evil]", and "I should go".  Maps are huge and [i]empty.[/i] You're stuck at such a low level that combat amounts to coin flipping whether you get instantly killed on the first turn or not.

I'm sure this was mind-blowing in 1998. Anyone considering playing it for the first time today should steer clear.

This is THE classic D&D computer RPG, and it still holds up pretty well even today. Some of the second edition rules are probably quite weird to someone who's coming from playing 4th or 5th edition (THACO being among the most odd mechanics) but there's nothing really that hard to figure out if you have patience (which you should if you are a RPG fan).

The overhauls put in by Beamdog are, for the most part, marked improvements over the original version although some might miss the old aesthetic (there's always GoG for that...). Some people have complained about the new characters/content not completely meshing with the old but I saw nothing really that jarring IMO and I think they did a decent job integrating things. At this point most if not all lingering bugs have been patched, which is a nice bonus, and the UI/AI enhancements are really quite good.

The net result is that this version of Baldur's Gate retains all the greatness of the original while being more accessible to newcomers so that, hopefully, the fan base will continue to grow in the years to come.

This is an oldie but a goodie. Usually, I'm not a fan of turn-based games, but this one is not bad at all given how old the original version was that I played when it first came out. The story is good and the characters are well-rounded and thought up well.

Honestly just a stale setting and hook. If you feel like you have to play this because it's a classic, that's a little silly. Overall a very average crpg when you play it today.

I'm not going to compare it to vanilla BG. I consider them to be two distinct games. That said, if you liked the original one, maybe give this one a go. It retains much of the original's charm while offering a ton of QoL improvements. I tend to switch between them depending on the mood. (Yes, I play a lot of Baldur's Gate)

From what I have heard about Baldur's Gate 2, and after playing this game, it almost feels like a very big tutorial for something greater.

This is not to say that there is no fun to be had with Baldur's Gate 1, but when I found that the boss in the Cloakwood mines was the hardest for me personally, and that the traps are usually what get you killed, it doesn't seem like the best work. However, this was their first go with this engine and the game is absolutely fantastic given that fact. I do wish that some of the fights were more organised on the side of the enemies since it just seems like everyone is just standing around, excluding the final fight where it does seem a bit organised. 

If you are new to this series or type of game, I would strongly recommend understanding AC and THAC0, and apply your weapon proficiency slots wisely. I also highly recommend the following classes when starting the game: Cavalier, Berserker, Priest of Tempus (if you don't plan on taking Branwen), Skald, and Swashbuckler (if you don't plan on taking Imoen or the other thieves), more or less in that order.

 I do plan on playing all of Baldur's Gate 2 soonish.
yeah, s'pretty good

I used to play this game a lot back when it first came out. I never got very far, but I always loved just making a character and exploring around. The hum of my CRT monitor and the whir of my old Gateway PC doing its best not to implode. It was a great time.

Over 20 years later I decided to replay this game since the Balder's Gate 3 has come out. I have now finally beaten the game and it was a blast. I played on story mode because I just don't have the time to constantly reload every time the dice decide I need to die in battle. If you have the time there's some fun combat and little tricks you can do. If you just want to see the story you can still get a ton of fun out of this game just due to the amount of role playing it allows you to do. 

The graphics in the base game certainly have a late 90s charm to them. Their have been improvements to the UI, but he graphics are pretty much the same as I remember them. It can make it a little bit difficult to see everything you can interact with, and some parts do look pretty bad. Still after a few hours I kind of forgot about the graphics and just got sucked into the story. One thing with the UI is you do need to start a playthrough, go into the settings, and there will be an option to scale the UI. If you don't click on that the play area will be zoomed out to oblivion and the menu options will be shoved as far to the side of the screen they can go.

The endings of the game don't vary too much, but the way you get there can go a surprising number of ways considering the age of the game. If you want to just get lost in the lore and dialogue trees there is more than enough to keep you entertained on the Sword Coast. There are a bunch of side quests, a stupid number of interesting NPCs and companion characters to talk to, and if you feel like it there are oodles of documents and books to read. That's not even considering how many different dialogue options you can get depending on your rep, previous decisions, player class or race, and how funny you decide to be. 

I recommend this game for the most part. The combat rule set can be fun, but it is incredibly unforgiving and can quickly become frustrating. People that understand, or even like, 2nd edition AD&D rules will have a good time with the combat. If you don't like that rule set it can be a lot to dig through and kind of a pain in the behind. Luckily there's a bunch of difficulty settings to dial in the challenge to be as high or low as you want it. And if you just want to see the story of Balder's Gate that by itself is worth the price of admission. I definitely recommend this to people that want to sit down and just enjoy a deep old as heck game. I do not recommend this game if you don't have patience for wonky graphics, frustrating rule sets, or don't want to read a lot.

A classic must-play RPG. I always thought the story is kind of garbage to be honest, any old pulp fantasy book is usually ahead of this. That doesn't mean it's not fun to play though, the characters are fun and some are quite well written. 

Could've been updated better in terms of the 2D graphics, there's absolutely no reason for any 2D game to look bad resolution wise these days, the graphics here could easily look twice as good with not too much effort put into it. 

Not as good as BG2, but a solid start that shouldn't be missed and absolutely playable and fun even in 2023.

Even with mods and third party programs, the original Baldur's Gate does not work very well on newer systems at higher resolutions. You can get the game to work well enough with DXwnd but every time you talk to someone the screen will have to scroll to centre the characters in the top left of the screen.

If it wasn't for this, I wouldn't recommend the Enhanced Edition. Instead of just updating the game to run properly on newer systems and adding some quality of life tweaks (they did do this and a good job they have done in this area) they also saw fit to replace and add many things to the detriment of the overall package.

Most critically, like other older methods of updating the game, this release essentially ports Baldur's Gate 1 into the Baldur's Gate 2 engine. This changes some of the core mechanics, changes the spell effects to be a bit more flashy and in general you are not getting the original experience. The changes are not radical, but it's worth keeping that in mind.

Similarly, the new cinematics are not only less numerous than in the original, they also brush over important details found in the original FMVs. The ending cinematic in particular is almost incomprehensible and you'll want to look up the original on youtube once you complete the game as the replacement will leave you absolutely puzzled as to what has happened.

The majority of new content and characters are poorly written and even more poorly voice acted with no option to remove it if you want the vanilla experience. Most of it is easily ignored and I do wonder if it only sticks out to me because I'm so familiar with the original game.

The new UI is uglier and feels like it has had much less love put into it than the vanilla game, tool tips no longer have a nice scroll opening animation and instead you just get a fairly ugly flat scroll texture with text in it. The journal looks unfinished but I will concede that it is better organised in the enhanced edition.

Other graphical changes like sprite outlines, sprite smoothing and character selection circles are painfully ugly and turned on by default. Some people may like these but to have them on by default is going to give some people a very bad first impression, especially people who have played the original game.

**
I recommend turning off sprite outlines and filtering in the graphics options, and in the feedback menu turning on classic character selection circles. This will go a long way to making the game look like it once did.
**

A further odd choice is a filter that is placed over the background art, making it look blurrier than it should. Zooming out one click and zooming in actually removes this and it looks much nicer. Clicking the middle mouse button to reset zoom will reintroduce the filter. It's very odd. I found that zooming out three clicks on the scroll wheel resulted in the cleanest look and luckily the game will save your zoom level so it's not a huge deal. [An update allows you to toggle this filter so this paragraph has been rendered moot somewhat.]

For new players there are additional difficulty options to make the game easier which you can ramp up on the fly once you get the hang of things and veteran players will like the higher difficulty modes that are available.

So, in conclusion this is probably the best way to play Baldur's Gate on a modern computer but it will take a bit of digging around in the options menus to get everything to your liking and it is just not as faithful to the original game as I would like. The new content is not very good but can mostly be ignored and in the end, the core of Baldur's Gate is still here, one of the best CRPGs ever made. I wish Beamdog had been more respectful of the original developers intentions when adding content and making changes but the core game still shines through.

A classic, brilliant game. With so many options. It is a must play for every single RPG fan out there. 

For those coming here from BG3/newer D&D, some advice. Look up the THAC0 system. This game uses it instead of Armor Class. It's a good system but also very confusing when first starting out. Additionally, damage immunity is common. Your wizard is going to need spells to strip it away. It's a *very* hard game.

Wow, what can I say. This game is, on the one hand, a snapshot of CRPGs in the late 1990s, and on the other hand: a fantastic and engaging romp through a traditional D&D world. Note: this is by today's standards a clunky game with a lot of inconvenient game mechanics that tend to slow down the game-play and prolong the encounters and progression of the main story. However, this also adds to what makes the game so charming and also hardcore. For instance, if one of your party members dies they must be revived at a temple. This can mean lengthy backtracking through various areas and potentially losing more companions and expending resources. I think that this adds a terrific amount of risk to the encounters that makes you think more tactfully and play more carefully when you can't just blast your way through enemies, for the most part that is. I really don't want to say too much about this game though, if you like any kind of RPGs buy it, if you like games where choices matter and there is a strong emphasis on writing: buy it, if you're in your thirties like me and remember the 90s fondly you should definitely buy it...

Second, mages and sorcerers have such low health that unless you have a good constitution score, YOU WILL DIE. The gameplay itself is good and so is the story, but I really do think that the text box at the bottom of the screen should be doubled in size, or players should at least have the option of making it such. The game is actually quite a gem and I would recommend it to any RPG lover.

Baldur's Gate 1: A Captivating Odyssey into a Rich Fantasy Realm

Baldur's Gate 1, developed by BioWare and released in 1998, stands as an enduring testament to the profound impact that video games can have on immersive storytelling within the realm of role-playing games. This venerable title has carved a niche for itself within the pantheon of gaming history, earning commendation for its intricate narrative, strategic gameplay, and meticulous attention to detail.

Set in the iconic Dungeons & Dragons Forgotten Realms universe, Baldur's Gate 1 unfolds within the Sword Coast region, offering players a chance to embark on a compelling journey filled with danger, discovery, and camaraderie. Its narrative is characterized by a rich tapestry of lore, replete with diverse characters, intricate subplots, and a meticulously designed world that beckons players to explore its every nook and cranny.

At the core of Baldur's Gate 1 lies its gameplay mechanics, which seamlessly meld tactical combat with interactive storytelling. Players are presented with a myriad of choices that influence both character development and narrative progression. The isometric perspective allows for strategic maneuvering during battles, while the implementation of the Advanced Dungeons & Dragons ruleset ensures a deep and rewarding experience for those who relish in intricately crafted systems.

Graphically, Baldur's Gate 1 showcases its age, yet its visual charm is far from diminished. The hand-painted backgrounds and character sprites evoke a nostalgic allure, capturing the essence of a bygone era in gaming. This timeless aesthetic contributes to the game's unique appeal, serving as a testament to the craftsmanship of its creators.

However, no masterpiece is without its blemishes. Some players may find the initial learning curve of the game's mechanics daunting, and the user interface, although functional, could be considered less intuitive by modern standards. Furthermore, while the game's immersive world encourages exploration, certain areas may feel unnecessarily sprawling, potentially causing pacing issues for some players.

In conclusion, Baldur's Gate 1 stands as a compelling entry in the annals of gaming history. Its captivating narrative, strategic gameplay, and atmospheric world-building have solidified its status as a classic within the role-playing genre. While its age is discernible in its visual presentation and interface, these aspects do little to diminish the overall experience that the game offers. You may find Baldur's Gate 1 to be a thought-provoking study in interactive storytelling and game design, showcasing the potential for immersive engagement and narrative complexity.

The combat is just so lame in BG I. I find that the "real-time action" thing just highlights the fact that nothing is actually happening most of the time while the actual action is being described in a tiny text window where events fly too fast for you to see and keep track of. It just doesn't work and definitely is not a step up from traditional turn by turn RPG combat. Moreover, walking around takes forever. Apep, also known as Apophis, was the great serpent-god of chaos in ancient Egyptian mythology. Some stories say that he has his origins as the severed umbilical cord of the god Ra. Ra was the foremost of the Egyptian gods, having domain over the sun and therefore all life.

In ancient Egyptian mythology, Ra, the god of the sun, was believed to battle Apophis, the god of chaos and darkness, every night as he journeyed through the underworld. According to the myth, Apophis was a serpent who would try to swallow the sun each night, plunging the world into darkness and chaos.

Each night, Ra and his allies would battle Apophis, and each night, they would emerge victorious. However, the battle was never truly won, as Apophis would always return to threaten the world once again.

Well-written, compelling old-school CRPG based on an older edition of the D&D ruleset. It lacks a lot of the character progression systems we see in more recent TTRPG-based CRPGs like the Pathfinder games from Owlcat (or Baldur's Gate 3, even), but there's still a lot to enjoy here. With a few good community mods to expand companion interactivity and romance, this is a fun and engaging game to tide you over till BG3. Having just finished it with 44hrs played, I already know there was a lot more I could've seen if I'd looked. But the main story kept me glued to my screen, so much so that I didn't bother trying to complete every side quest as I normally would in a game like this.

Baldur's Gate 1 is very, very old now, and it will almost certainly not appeal to modern RPG player preferences in terms of gameplay... But the story hits as hard as ever in 2023, and will truly make you feel immersed in its world. The humor is also on-point: many of the dialogue options you can pick are downright sassy (but still perfectly medieval), and characters like Minsc add a lot of heart and levity to the game without ever ruining the mood. 

Looking forward to diving into the sequel afresh next, and then BG3 when it releases.

This is probably not a popular opinion, but I like BG 1 more than BG 2. 2 is still good, it has much better companion characters and a more impactful story overall, but 1 has some advantages as well. In 1 working with a low-level cap means that enemies never feel out of place. Bandits never have better gear than the guards of the big city, and regional bosses are powerful compared to what is around them, and you never so out level them that it becomes comical when they think they can best you. Companions are not overly written, their more an idea of a companion, the mad wizard, the sultry rouge, the naïve paladin, the brooding ranger. Some are interesting concepts like Minsk, a standard altruistic fantasy character type, but everyone thinks he’s only that way because he has a brain injury. This is a strength of the game, not having overly complex backstories and emotional reasons to be fighting the same evil the player allows you to switch between then as needed to suit your party. Their stats not people, and you never need to feel bad about taking the ranger because you need someone with a long bow, and risk missing out on some important side quest or story element. This is important because one of the games greatest strengths is the class building. There is a lot to choose from and its fun to just mess around with it in character creation. Most weapon and gear types seem to have at least a few good options in game, and it being low level even if you're stuck with a plus 1 weapon till the end game you won't feel under powered, Because the enemies are not high-level requiring lots of abilities and a minmaxed party to beat. The story is alright, you get the most out of the moment-to-moment gameplay. Which is good, the scripted enemy encounters are well made, the side characters are fun, the whole game has a lighthearted feel to it, and you encounter colorful characters that might be out of a story book again their ideas of a character not people. It's an adventure is the best way of saying it, not a world ending life or death struggle, and adventure that you can feel accomplished for completing. One criticism I do have is that the evil options are lacking. It's almost always better to do the good option both in xp and item rewards than to do an evil choice. The companion characters are also kind of limited, and basically need good, aligned ones to balance the party, a problem the good characters do not have. The good news is that being good or evil is irrelevant and you can for the most part freely mix and match character alignments, there also a lot of one hit kills in the game, not a fun mechanic and not much way around it. Overall, I recommend this game, and I recommend the enhanced edition.

You'll find plenty of endorsements for the main game here. Suffice to say that the sheer diversity of intuitive and creative play possible in a 25-year old game that was the sophomore project of an understaffed developer trying to figure out a novel way of translating tabletop play and old-school Leiber/Vance-style sword and sorcery aesthetics into video game motion in a completely new engine (originally built for a failed RTS), is well worth experiencing for anyone with any serious interest in the genre. It doesn't just "hold up" - something has most certainly been lost for RPGs in the move towards streamlining and spectacle in the quarter century since then, and I honestly believe BG1 is still one of the best demonstrations of the creative potential of real-time gameplay in RPGs. Chapter 6 of this game moved me more than pretty much anything in Mass Effect 2/3 or Dragon Age Inquisition.

But again, you'll find enough recommendations for BG1 here. The real surprise is Siege of Dragonspear - having been set up for disappointment, it has been a joy to discover a genuinely interesting interquel that balances - in fact, harnesses - its limitations for some very impressive use of this creaky-yet-shockingly-flexible engine for storytelling. It's not Baldur's Gate 3, but it certainly makes me want to see what Beamdog's BG3 could have been.

Works fine on Deck, though you may want to do some controller setup since it's just emulating keyboard and mouse.  If you want to mod it on the Deck, the easiest way to do it is empty your BGEE folder (but keep the dir) on Deck, then mod the game on PC, and copy the BGEE dir from your PC to your Deck using something like Warpinator (which gives me problems sometimes) or SyncThing (which takes a bit more to set up but seems to work better + transfer at higher speeds).

Has some oldschool (aka bullshit) mechanics to it, especially at the start when you can hardly hit anything and can chance into overpowered random encounters (so quicksave and hardsave often), but still worth checking out.

Also make sure you go into your documents\Baldur's Gate Enhanced Edition folder and edit the .lua file (open it with Notepad) so that the Maximum Frame Rate setting is higher than 30, otherwise the game runs really slow.  I set it to 45, this seems to be a good compromise between speed and playability.  I've tried 60 and it's just too fast!

An incredibly deep RPG, both in terms of interactivity, combat, build variety, party composition, etc. An endlessly replayable sandbox that captures the magic of old-school "simulationist" D&D modules. Old-school D&D has three axes, as I see it: roleplaying, free exploration, and flexibility. BG1 is the peak of the 'free exploration' axis; its sequel is the peak of flexibility; and Planescape: Torment is the peak of roleplaying. All three of these games form a shrine to the first thirty years of D&D, a near-perfect triptych in my view. But very few RPGs capture the experience of entering an empty map full of truly dangerous dangers, and truly rewarding rewards, like Baldur's Gate. The entire gaming space owes Beamdog a debt of gratitude for making this masterpiece playable by a new generation (even if I don't care much for their new content). 'Preservation' of classic games is as important to our medium as it is to film, and projects like the Enhanced Editions -- more ambitious than a simple rerelease, but with deep respect for the original -- are needed for other classic titles.

It is almost impossible to softlock yourself in this game, so don't worry too much about optimizing your party. The right strategy and the clever use of consumables and magic items are more important than your build. Just pick a class that sounds fun, roll with the game's punches (even NPC deaths; they are ALL expendable, trust me), and avoid save-scumming if you can -- the sense of reward when you finish the game will be huge. Highly recommend the 'Sword Coast Stratagems' mod, which in my view best approximates the experience of playing AD&D with an intelligent dungeon master.

A Response to the Other Reviews:

I don't post reviews often, but it appears that the lowest common denominator has decided to be very loud with regard to this game. It's a fun game, and it deserves a fair shake.

GRAPHICAL UPDATES:

People complaining about cartoonish graphics have no place posting a review on the Steam market. The thick black border they're talking about, a simple graphical update that makes the game easier on the eyes at 4K and other modern resolutions, is entirely optional. In fact, the option is in Graphics settings and couldn't really be easier to locate. Other than that, the only updated assets are textures that were blatantly unable to survive the HD transition (the original Baldur's Gate used an actual picture of coffee grounds to appear like the ground/road, for example, an interesting choice that can only work on the old, blurry 800x600 CRTs of yore.) The replacement textures are high-quality, tasteful, and lore-friendly. 

USER INTERFACE/USER EXPERIENCE (UI/UX) UPDATES:

The UI recieved one update of any consequence at all: Journal entries now appear at the top of the screen to alert you to the fact that you've acquired a quest or learned something new about an important, ongoing chain. This is ultimately a useful feature, but on this particular issue I can see why some people might be annoyed. The UI element is a little noisy, and given that this is the sort of game where one could understandably have purchased a real-world journal to track activity, it does markedly change the experience from the original. I'm personally of the opinion that the improvement is a complementary one, mostly to make the game enjoyable for a generation of gamers born into quest markers. This should be an optional feature, probably, but it's presence doesn't render the title the sort of hyper-active, dopamine-fueled, flashing slot machine that other reviewers make it out to. This is still a far cry from Hearthstone.

REBALANCED DIFFICULTY:

There are more options, one of which brings the ruleset into alignment with Baldur's Gate 2, making for a smooth transition (much like the options offered by the WeiDU tweak packs for the original or the BiG World Project.) This is strictly something you can't complain about. The original difficulty settings were notoriously limited and once the system was mastered, woefully inadequate. As a long-time veteran of the series who obviously cares way too much about it, and as a game developer who's worked on RPGs in the past, this is the one change that should not interfere with your decision whether or not to buy this game. 

POLITICAL ISSUES:

Why this ever needs to be a section in a game review is beyond me, but the current state of affairs makes it necessary. Brace yourself for stupidity. A large reason for the negative attention this game has garnered recently is... The expansion contains a transgendered character. *GASP* Lock the kids indoors, shut the shutters, draw the curtains, as from the state of things, you'd guess Strahd himself descended upon the town to wreak havoc. In reality, it's an inoffensive NPC with an aside that points to a gender transition at some point in their past. Why is this offensive? Well, never mind the Girdle of Masculinity/Femininity, an item that has changed the PC's gender since the game's release. Never mind that Eliminster, iconic wizard extraordinaire of the Dungeons and Dragons universe, lover to Mystra the Goddess of Secrets, Survivor of the Time of Troubles, and WotC's best sales-driving cover man since Drizzt Do'Urden, spends a good chunk of time walking the earth as a female and makes several appearances. (Let's all be honest about what we'd do with Polymorph Self.) Anyway, in summary, the idea of magically changing genders is not new to the series and has somehow offended a humorless group of teetotalers. 

***NOTE***
This game is very old. It contains a number of bugs. Some of them have been in the game since Black Isle held the reins, some are a natural consequence of working with a game from the 90's, and some of them are indeed derived from Beamdog itself. However, it's worth noting that they seem to genuinely care about this game, and as someone who has worked in the soul-sucking industry for several years, that's a pretty rare feat among developers of largely-known IPs taken as an aggregate. They regularly patch this game, developed a new expansion, and provided free, substantial content updates of high quality. They easily could have released this game, made a quick buck on the brand recognition, and abandoned it. They easily could have gotten away with reserving the content updates only for those who bought the expansion. I highly recommend supporting Beamdog as it currently exists, if only to encourage more genuine passion in an industry that's in sore need of it.
