[h1]Enhanced Edition Review[/h1] 
Prior to playing the enhanced edition i used to play the original version as a young teenager and i barely remember much of the game. In itself i dont really have much nostalgia for the game nor do i think that you should excuse any issues a game have, except its graphics, with the phrase oh well its old. Baldurs Gate is definetly a good game but i just want to point a few things out that might turn off some people already but i will also mention the many good things that might attract new people to this game.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
As a "real time" strategy game baldurs gate tends to be harder than it actually is just because of some design issues. You dont really have to understand what the numbers actually do except that you have to know which number is better. The lesser armor rate someone has, the better as base armor rating is 10 and a platemail will lower it to 1. While other numbers like weapon damage are better the higher they are. Some things dont even do anything in the game like infravision or some spells.

Also when you start a game you might be overwhelmed by the many different classes. But this is actually where the most fun lies. I often had my most fun creating a different class and testing out new team compositions. There are probably over 40 classes with 10 or so primary ones. There are lots of different weapon types to skill on and they do all have a porpuse despite some being clearly better than other ones. As an example bastard swords are the best one handed weapon type. But the problematic thing is that in baldurs gate you can only get better gear really by buying / finding enchanted magic items. There arent that many enchanted bastard swords in baldurs gate, but lots of longswords. Some enemies are immune/resist certain weapon types.

Therefore a variety is needed which is something the game doesnt warn you about. Another example is that the archer can choose a nemesis, an enemy type he is better against. The game gives you the option to choose dragons and so on. But there arent any dragons in baldurs gate at all! These things are just plain bad game design. Many of these issues could have been removed if the game wouldnt have sticked to the pen and paper ruleset that strictly.

Combat itself is incredibly fun. Well in early mid to lategame at least. Because in the early game you wont have any options really to do much as you are still collecting party member and slowly gain skills and stronger enemies will be fought. Each harder situation needs careful planning and execution. You are annoyed by small fry and dont want to click the whole time and control every class yourself? There are lots of premade scripts you can activate that does this for you. Class restrictions on armor and weapons add another layer of depth to the game.  

Some classes are clearly better than others. As an example you dont want to play as a wizard slayer on your first run as he cant wear almost any enchanted gear and his stats dont make up for his negatives. Some classes are starting to get good only in baldurs gate 2 because here your max level will be around 8. Its fun trying out new things and still being able to win with classes that are more complicated and worse than other ones. You could see it as an additional difficulty option. While starting first on the D&D difficulty rules may be intriguing it can be quite difficult on your first run, with lots of reloads but being quite doable with some preperation. Highlights where for me the various special encounters that can be really though and require you to prepare a lot for.

[u]Enhanced Edition[/u]
The launch of the enhanced edition was one of the worst launches i have witnessed. The game features lots of bugs and foreign languages that the original game had werent included in the game. Over the time many bugs are fixed yet still many persist. These arent game breaking but pretty annoying. Like a click above an item may even delete it at times. I still prefer this version during a sale over the original.

Now the enhanced edition did add some smaller "nice to have" things into the game. Just some smaller stuff that made the game overall more comfortable. I still wish there would have been an option to turn the game into vanilla mode via one click and just add the widescreen support mod.

The big new changes are the 3 new characters with their own quest lines and the black pits.While the characters itself are a great addition i personally never use them in my parties except maybe dorn. Rarely i take the new mage with me and never the monk because its low level dungeons and dragons. Monks are just complete lategame heroes and they are just a complete burden in the early levels.



[u]Multiplayer[/u]
Multiplayer can make a lot of fun in this game if you and your friend both are on the same mindset while playing the game as you either want to skip all the dialogue/read only the main stuff or really want to read every bit of detail. If one of you is on a different mindset it can really be annoying or a borefest for the other. But overall multiplayer is a good reason you might want to pick it up.

[u]Black Pits[/u]
Probably my favorite part about the enhanced edition is the new story campaign. Its a simple battle arena story where you get money train your fighters and try to escape the whole situation. You level faster and the annoying early game is basically not there anymore. I have some complaining to do. The whole campaign is way too short and some of the later fights are just plain idiotic to add in here. Some might rage quit at the trolls as some people dont know that D&D trolls are only killable trough fire. Another thing is one of the very last matches puts you up against clay golems. Which are immune to anything except enchanted blunt weapons. That would be fine but they give you around 5 of these to fight at the same time. Not really doable on harder difficulties if your whole party isnt prepared/ build around this fight. Multiplayer wise Black Pits wont work. After each chapter the game will get stuck in an arena. Sad beamdog.

[u]Story[/u]
In itself i always tought that people overhype this story. Its average fantasy stuff. I didnt really personally like the story but didnt hate it either. Its mostly that the main story is just badly told. Generally speaking what sets the game apart and makes it stand out are the various characters you meet (around 26 companions all with more or less fleshed out story/personality) and the fantastic writing. There are lots of situations where i burst out in laughter as the game itself is actually pretty serious but the hilarious jokes dont break any of the immersion i had. The whole worldbuilding is great too as ferun is pretty credible.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Baldurs gate static backgrounds still look pretty good. You shouldnt zoom too close to your player characters tough.

[u]Sound[/u]
Often my second favorite thing in games is a good soundtrack and a good atmosphere. There are lots of fantastic tracks from the famous title music to the calming yet mysterious night tracks. I love it.

The voice acting is, for the most part, great too and the enhanced edition adds some new fantastic voices aswell.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
I did have much complaining to do, partially about the enhanced edition, partially about some general game design issues too. But that doesnt mean i didnt like the game. Infact its one of my favorite games. But there are some clear issues with early game combat, non explained gameplay features and some things just being fluff and not having any ingame porpuse. But the whole gameworld is just so incredibly immersive combined with the fantastic OST and as the game goes on the midgame is so incredibly rewarding and boss fights are so perfectly challenging that for me it was a really good game inspite of its flaws.

Baldur's Gate 1 is a great game.  Although it is very old, the writing and pacing feel very fresh and ahead of its time.  This is a game that makes you feel for your childhood: that sense of wonder and endless possibility, having to face greater responsibility and rise to the occassion.  This is my fourth-favorite cRPG behind both Pathfinder games and Planescape: Torment.

A note for the vast amount of people who have bought this game and have it sitting in their library for years like me, or people wanting to experience this classic and its sequel before diving into the third game (or just want to play classic cRPGs).  

The main story is very short and very intriguing.  You could blaze through it in 10 to 12 hours.  There is a LOT of side content, most of it are one-off little segments into the lives simple characters in this world with no narrative consequence.  There are a lot of sub-maps each with one to a few of these little diversions.  The UI is servicable for a modern audience.  Don't let it overwhelm you.  Most of it isn't very relevant aside from the journal and inventory screen for general gameplay and the character screen to level-up.  

My recommendation is if you're hesitant to start a massive 75hr experience due to real-world time constraints, then you should set the difficulty mode to story and focus on the main story (which does well to guide you throughout) while dipping into some of the side content every now and then.  Story mode lets you bypass all the challenges of this 90s cRPG and enjoy the world and writing.  You may also consider playing a fighter or monk (or any heavily-melee focused character) as to be able to enjoy a more simple combat experience.  With story mode, creating the most powerful character is irrelevant.  You can play whatever class you want, however poorly you want because your victory is guaranteed.  If you're feeling confident on the gameplay front, you can at any point switch story mode off for as long as you want.  

You'll find a very tight first half of the game until you get to Baldur's Gate where you narratively given a chance to investigate things at your own pace.  You'll also find a whole host of companions in their proto-typical form to modern companions.  They are more-so ideas of characters with very little to say or do besides act as mechanical and combat support to the player.  The Enhanced Edition adds a few companions who have some of the only rudimentary character arcs in this first game.  It is not important you who want to roll with, just pick them up, see how you like the "idea" of their character in your group.  You can for the most part kick anybody out of the group with little consequence.  The only time there is minor consequence is in the first quarter of the game where you will meet two groups of two who each want to join your band for the first major quest.  They make it very clear what their goals are, so it will be hard to miss.  I did not bring one of the pairs along, and overall it did not matter.  

Give this game a chance.  It's a classic for a reason.  Meet the game half-way on the overall naivety of its world.  This is the kind of game you look back on and remember the heart-warming feelings it gives you more than anything.
Great story, and fun game play!

If you like D&D and understand how this version of D&D works, this is a must play game. With that being said, if you are not ready to strap yourself in for some BS (play a wizard is makes so much of the game easier imo) I would probably just wait until BG3 or play more modern games like Divinity. The combat system will throw some silly fights at you and if you are not ready, there will be some headaches. 

The music is great, the characters are great, combat is mostly great if you play it turn by turn, and the choices you make really feels like you are making meaningful choices in this world. The overall story is pretty cookie cutter, but for a game this old, it probably felt more fresh back then than it does nowadays. 

Overall, is the game worth picking up at full price? Yes! You can easily dump 60+ hours into this game and it is regularly on sale for under $10.

[h2]Baldur’s Gate I Enhanced Edition Review[/h2]

[h1]Good things:[/h1]

Baldur’s Gate is an cRPG that is based on Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd Edition and for many people like myself was the first cRPG game they ever played and was the game that made many people love cRPGs. It is also the first game in The Bhaalspawn Saga and it is great because it starts with mystery and it makes the players experience the D&D system from an early levels making them feel weak at start and really feeling more powerful with each level as they grow in experience and power and with time game unlocks new areas for the player with more powerful enemies so the player can test his new spells and weapons.

If you liked Baldur’s Gate as a kid you will love Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition even more thanks to quality of life improvements. You no longer have look for certain X and Y on the map or to click every chest and barrel and stone and everything just to be sure you didn’t miss any treasure – now you can have all the lootable containers highlighted, and you can pick items from defeating enemies without having to check each body separately as all items laying on the ground in a certain radius near your team are shown on a special interface that lets you loot them directly.

Enhanced edition also added half-orc race and classes from Baldur's Gate II like barbarian, sorcerer, wild mage and all the Kits for all classes so now you can play as berserker or kensai or archer etc. in Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition and import your hero to Baldur's Gate II: Enhanced Edition to continue your story. They even added some new kits like blackguard – an evil paladin or dragon disciple – a sorcerer with dragon blood or Tyr and Tempus to Cleric kits selection and Shadowdancer for Thief or 2 kits to choose from for monks. They even added a completely new class available only in Enhanced Edition called Shaman that is a spellcaster that uses druid spells but learns them and casts them like a sorcerer and has a unique ability to dance during combat and summon spirits to attack his enemies for him.

And for you that did not ever played the original Baldur’s Gate the most important info is that it has great story. The main villain is someone you hate from the start but the more you learn about him the more you understand why he is the way he is and what made him be like that and that there was a big chance that you would be in his place and he could be in yours. The more books and letters you read in game the more deep the villain gets and that is what makes this villain great. He is not just some Mr. Bad Guy just for the sake of being bad – there are reasons behind his actions and he become who he is because of his upbringing. The more you learn about the game world and the villain the better the game gets. At the end of the game I almost felt sorry that I have to kill him. Also even side quests have different ways of solving them and things you can miss if you don’t pay attention to details so you can end up helping someone evil without even knowing it.

If you love cRPGs in general you will also like this one. It is older than many other cRPGs you played so far but it is great and this game is one of the reasons why cRPGs become popular. But this edition is full of improvements over the original game so if you really never played Baldur’s Gate then this is the version you should buy and play to experience what others have experienced because you are really really really missing out if you haven’t played and finished Baldur’s Gate in your life.

[h1]Bad things:[/h1]

If you have any antivirus and I mean any at all even a basic one in Windows like Microsoft Defender you will need to google how to set everything in a way that it will let you make saves to the cloud and will read the saves from cloud otherwise it can jump between cloud saves and saves on your PC making playing the game difficult and it can even reset any changes in the setting you made.

There still exist a bug where party members can get stuck on each other and you have to pause the game and click the STOP button and move one of them away. In some locations it happens much more often than in others and it makes them more frustrating to play.

Baldur’s Gate I was never made with the intention of you playing as the bad guy so even when some quests can be finished in an evil way they most of the times give worse rewards and also drop your reputation increasing prices in all shops and if your reputation drops too low you will be even attacked by paladins and town guards all the time. Most of the time roleplaying as evil guys is just about doing quests in the evil way and then paying the clerics in temples money to fix your bad reputation so you won’t be attacked by paladins and guards. You can’t really be truly evil in this game and playing as evil is almost like playing as someone neutral. Enhanced Edition didn’t do anything to change that so you still will have to balance your reputation all the time to not make prices in shops be too high but also to not be too good and not make evil characters leave your party. In the end just playing as the good guy fits the game and whole story much more than being evil and is more satisfying.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
You must gather your party before venturing forth.
Baldurs Gate is a classic and a masterpiece, and the same can be said about its sequel. Bringing in thousand and hours of immemorable gameplay and the RPG experience.

While not the first Infinity engine game I've played (that honor goes to Icewind Dale), this is all the more impressive since it was the first one released. And with this recent replay, where I tried to exhaust most everything it has to offer at a digestible pace, as opposed to my actual first playthrough, where I felt overwhelmed and rushed through a few of the chapters; This one impresses quite a lot. 

It's also impressive how well these games have aged, even though they did receive a visual touch-up from the Enhanced Editions (really sad how IWD2 will never get the same benefit). But the 2D art especially is pretty much proven to be ageless. The one area that hasn't aged all that well is the huge amount of party micromanagement with regards to items, containers, and everything in-between that. It's honestly another game within the game. Just moving items around, to min-max all the space you have available, with different party members able to carry only so much, moving unidentified items around, potions, arrows. It can sometimes be very annoying. 

The other area that hasn't aged well is the path-finding of the party members, but this was an issue in all Infinity engine games, and is well known, so no point in beating a dead horse. The enhanced editions, or if I'm just not remembering it right maybe even the originals, seem to have another issue with path-ing where sometimes 2 or 3 party members stack up onto each other and then it's a real pain to get them unstuck. But this is all sort of nitpicking in a very impressive and great rpg.

Other impressive things about the game is how open it is, and even reactive in its narrative in sufficient places. Even though the main story beats are the same, it is still impressive how they put the work in, even originally, to coerce the storyline back to those intended beats. I never got too far in Baldur's Gate 2, an error I intend to correct after being done with Siege of Dragonspear; hopefully in time for BG3; but I hear BG2 is a lot more focused in its narrative and what it allows you to explore.

The gameplay still remains the same old real-time with pause. Probably my most favorite of systems. This has also aged very nicely; if you like the system that is.

Otherwise, not much else to say about this one. It's very impressive for what they managed to achieve back 25 years ago. And thank the heavens for the enhanced editions.
It's also impressive how it's a stronger rpg than most rpgs nowadays, with very few exceptions. 
Also luckily the genre has had a resurgence recently, with the Pillars of Eternity and Pathfinder rpgs. And we hope it manages to keep on going.

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is an updated version of the classic 1998 role-playing game developed by Beamdog. The game is set in the Forgotten Realms universe and features an epic story, memorable characters, and a deep and complex RPG system.

The enhanced edition includes updated graphics, improved UI, and new content, including new characters, quests, and areas. The updated graphics are a significant improvement over the original game, making the world of Baldur's Gate more immersive and detailed. The new UI is also more intuitive, making it easier to manage inventory and navigate the game's many menus.

One of the strengths of Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is its deep and complex RPG system. The game features a robust character creation system, allowing players to choose from a wide range of races, classes, and abilities. The game also features a complex alignment system, which tracks a player's moral choices throughout the game, affecting how NPCs interact with the player and ultimately affecting the game's ending.

The game's story is also a major strength, featuring a vast and immersive world with an intricate web of storylines and characters. The game's main quest involves a search for the player character's true identity and the uncovering of a larger conspiracy, but there are also many side quests and subplots to explore. The game's characters are also well-written and memorable, with unique personalities and backstories that make them feel like real people.

Despite its many strengths, Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is not without its flaws. The game's combat system, while deep and complex, can be slow and tedious at times, especially in the early game. The game's interface can also be overwhelming for new players, with many menus and options to manage.

Overall, Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is an excellent update to a classic RPG, featuring updated graphics, improved UI, and new content while retaining the deep and complex RPG system and engaging story of the original game. While it may not be perfect, it is a must-play for fans of the RPG genre and an excellent introduction for new players.

Baldur's Gate is the quintessential isometric RPG series.  Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn is a regular on any greatest games of all time list with critics noting the improvements to story characterization setting party dynamics and gameplay.  I don't disagree.

This praise can sometimes lead people to imagine the first Baldur's Gate is skippable and that is what I want to correct.  Not only would a run of two be incomplete without a play through, the first is worthy of serious attention.  Many complain of the inferior gameplay but the enhanced edition brings it up to being fully on par with SOA which just makes sense.  SOA was refined from the missteps of 1 any remaster should apply those same lessons where it doesn't disrupt the story and core mechanics and so they did.  

The characters are less dynamic then in two which in my opinion is what sets that game apart and where much of two's praise and influence comes from.  The world is larger and more rural and empty.  The real color beyond the maps themselves is in the writing which tends to vacillate between jokey 90's references and overwrought melodrama.  When it's in it's stride it tends to be confined to certain very memorable quests which rival and in one notable case exceed anything in Shadows of Amn.  I am of course referring to Durlag's tower.  Durlag's tower is indisputably the finest dungeon of this medium relative to the time it was released.  The tower is itself a meditation on the constitutive psychology of a contested life, a life of greatness, of cruelty, a life indeed of violence.  Of course Baldur's Gate itself is themed on this question of violence as human nature and the dream sequences communicate this thoughtfully but they never manage the perspective of Durlag.  In a way this seems unavoidable.  The main character despite whatever can be evoked through setting and reaction is and feels like a largely blank slate.  Durlag is a person, a hero and legend, who lived has a definite end and details and whose thirst for attention in life now has you exploring everything including his deepest failures secrets and humiliations in death.   With tasteful nods from literature to the holocaust and complimented with probably the greatest in-total challenge of the first game players would be seriously remiss to skip this entry.  To trespass the deepest regions of the tower as you do layers of Durlag's psyche you will ultimately recover the Macguffin dagger: Soultaker.  Inside that dagger through some strange alchemy is the soul not of Durlag but of you.  Seeing it's contents is a kind of loot that you will carry in real life forever.  

That is if you don't just click through the fuckin text boxes you illiterates!

Finally completed the game and expansions – in a 100 hours playthrough – to import a save to the sequel... there are grim deeds yet to come!

It's a nostalgic trip to a time when the gaming business was smaller, but it seems to have had more soul. Many of the mechanics are dated and it takes some time to learn the game if you want to play "Core rules" and above, but it's a journey worth taking. The magic is still there.

It's fun, the story is pretty engaging and you have a pretty solid amount of options for your character.
The game does show its age a bit when it comes to controls and gameplay when compared to newer entries in the genre, which might be a dealbreaker to some. I also have some issues with the game system it is designed around (like why is 18 strength different for different characters).

Worth a try if you like RPGs or D&D.

This is still one of the 50 best RPGs of all time, and one that every enthusiast of the genre should play to understand how we got to the modern RPG. One day I'll get around to chasing down every achievement in this game.
Possibly the best rpg ever created.

Baldur's Gate is a re-release of a grim fairytale that features a lengthy and compelling story. This story takes place in a fantasy realm, where there is a strong emphasis on imaginary creatures living in a world inspired by folklore and magical constructs, and explores the absolute polarization between good and evil.
The narrative frivolously makes use of comedy and drama, but has a relatively serious undertow. The story lore follows the same principles that are exhibited in classical and similarly themed works of fantasy literature and classical role playing games. All of this takes place in a magical and seemingly medieval setting, fully realised by making use of renowned fantasy lore and role playing mechanisms.
The story features a protagonist who's heritage is initially obscured, and takes place in a land that surrounds the city of Baldur's Gate. This land is a grand stage, that may freely be explored, and also directs the protagonist and a chosen group of followers towards their destiny, and the plot unravels during play.
Each storyline is unique, because the story is played out by decisions that are made during play. The story ultimately leads to a climax that is preset, but the storyline that is followed and with whom, may freely be decided. Other characters also inhabit the world, and everything exists in an imaginary fantasy culture, which may be derived from classical works of fantasy literature, but is fresh nonetheless, and supported by original and creative ideas, which are enjoyable to read and immerse oneself in.

The protagonist's appearance must first be chosen and may be customized; by choosing a gender, a race, and by assigning personal proficiencies.
A party of friendly companion characters may accompany the protagonist, and may be recruited during the adventure. Their skills and abilities are developed during play as well, and every character has their own inventory. Companion characters may also use artificial intelligence to further customize and direct their potential. These characters are capable navigators, who may switch between equipment at any given time. They may also engage in conversation, trade with other characters, and the group of adventurers may have a certain reputation in the world based on their actions or who they recruit. A total of six companion characters may travel together at the same time, but there are many more that the protagonist may come across.
The viewpoint on the world is displayed from a bird's eye perspective, showing a landscape from a certain altitude. The distance from which this landscape is seen, may be drawn nearer and further away by zooming in and out. This viewpoint displays a landmass on which the protagonist or the companion characters may freely travel, if directed to do so.
Controlling the action is made possible through an on-screen and enabling interface, which is used to direct companion characters by pointing and sending them to a location in the world. A world which they occasionally may interact with. The action may, (and should,) be paused at any time, in order to issue commands to each individual character. This enables to swiftly micromanage affairs. How companion characters are positioned and under what circumstances, is of tactical importance. This encourages deliberation and weighing off one's chances.
Companion characters are meant to adventure across the land together. These characters all have three hundred sixty degrees sight around them, and reveal the limited radius in which their vision may be observed. Unexplored areas on the map are blackened out before they are explored. Once explored, these areas remain visible, and may be freely revisited. What exactly takes place at a given location may only be directly observed by positioning a companion character near a location, otherwise whatever takes place at those areas is unseen and obscured. These maps are predetermined environments where non-predetermined events may take place. Adversaries and side-characters may occasionally appear, and there is a sense of unpredictability to these encounters. The outcome of these engagements has a degree of randomness to them as well, and may be tactically and strategically managed through the use of various items, that may be gathered or stored in containers. Additionally, there are day and night cycles and weather conditions, such as rain and thunder taking place in outdoor environments, which may affect what is taking place there at different time zones of a day.

The environments are artistically crafted, and contain a wide variety of realistically drawn (two-dimensional) art assets and details. Texts are well written, and characters are voiced with enthusiasm.
Companion characters play a large role towards enjoying the play, they have abilities that may complement each other. Competently using their abilities plays an important role, and their miraculous effects each have their own distinctive designs, synergies, graphics, and sounds.
There is a wide variety of locales. These places have a specific purpose in the world in relation to the storyline. They encourage exploration and are accessible from a larger map. This map enables the party to immediately travel to those locales.
Companion characters may also have banter, which may play a relevant role during the story, or they may spontaneously comment on certain situations. These companion characters are all prominent archetypes, who may have conflicting agendas, and with enough encouragement, may show romantic advances, or may prefer to leave the group. Their needs should not be ignored.
A relatively large amount of classical and orchestral sounding music and other sound effects breathe further life into the world. Some musical notes are reoccurring, and therefore the music is thematic. Many environments have their own musical scores, and may play more dramatic melodies when there is action taking place. Environmental sound effects, such as birds singing or water splashing, may sometimes be heard when observing certain areas on a map, which makes most maps immersive to navigate through and travel across.
Lastly, the story is expanded after a decade of real-time passing, which is a unique happening. This downloadable content closely follows the original work, and progresses the story, which may be saved in-between titles, and may also carry over to the next instalment.

Old, but gold !

There is a pretty steep learning curve at the start, because the game is based on an older version of the DnD ruleset. It is however very rewarding to start steamrolling encounters when you get a good grasp on the rules and mechanics.
I really appreciated the story, it's very lowkey, which is something I love with lower to mid level adventures.

My main gripes lie in the combat encounters and the class balance, which all boils down to the edition used for the ruleset.
I have to highlight here that I only played on Core Rule difficulty without any mod.
Combat encounters aren't particularly exciting. Open with CC and slaughter the poor sobs, rinse and repeat. Higher difficulties probably change that giving ennemies better saves against CC, but I felt the damage bonuses were unfair.
The class balance is a whole other can of worms. Casters have the best gameplay, period. They start out relatively weak and later become gods of war, which is why most "optimal" builds dual or multiclass into mage. There is no meaningful decision to take on physical damage dealers during leveling other than proficiencies. But as I said, this is an issue with the ruleset used, it's not the fault of the game.

I thoroughly enjoyed playing the game despite my gripes about some of its systems.
I highly recommend it to any fan of cRPGs. It is truly a classic and it's nice to see where the genre comes from and how far it has gotten nowadays.

So, there's really going to be 2 reviews here: (1) the game, and (2) the enhanced edition.

For the game itself: its incredibly good, as long as you are patient enough to actually sit down and understand how the systems work. This is a much larger task than it initially may seem - 2E/AD&D is exceedingly non-intuitive to people who only have knowledge of the modern systems - so actually learning the game may take some time. Once you get past the initial hurdle of answering the question "Why do I get hit so much" [hint: THAC0], it becomes easier with time. Obviously, with the game being as old as it is, there are many *questionable* design choices that will absolutely frustrate you when you first start out, but over time you get used to it. Aside from gameplay, the story is obviously amazing and will keep you engaged throughout. I recommend that you go in blind the first time through and piece it together, then read a synopsis later if you truly can't figure it out - that's how it was meant to be played, and not doing so takes away from the expeirence.

For the enhanced edition: Similar to the game, its well done. The game is very stable, and I can't recall any crashes or bugs that I ran into during my runs through. I will say that the UI changes from the original are a bit irritating - I'm not sure why they would add what seems to be a mobile device-like menu into a PC game - but you can largely look them, especially if you never played the original. 

Overall, the game is great and absolutely worth the full asking price.

One of the all-time great turn-based RPGs. While it shows its age, even enhanced, it is nonetheless a well told story full of exciting combats, iconic villains and NPCs, and unforgettable moments. A must for a fan of D&D or of turn-based RPGs.

It's the Forrest Gump CRPG that's like a box of chocolates: you never know what you're gonna get. That next door -- a generic NPC home or a basilisk-infested hellhole? That dialogue option -- a lead-in to a quest-line or something that NPC interprets as an irrevocable insult? And so on. I can see why some find it charming. I found it increasingly annoying and my playthrough was a series of save/loads.

I'm often a fan of diamonds in the rough and I consider myself more tolerant than average of jankyness in old games. But I guess I just didn't find enough good things in this one to look past the roughness. Maybe it's just me and high fantasy like this: nothing really captured my interest or excited my imagination.

"The classic adventure returns!" (With a bunch of weird rules, terrible path-finding, and graphics that will make your eyeballs roll back in your skull in a desperate attempt to escape the horror.)

I'm a big nerd. If it's even slightly nerdy, count me in. Star Trek, pointless flame-wars over things that don't exist, Linux, talking to my cat because I find interaction with members of my own species profoundly disappointing, and Dungeons & Dragons. I don't have a beard that makes me look like I've grafted a shrubbery to my face, but there's still time. Ray Muzyka and Greg Zeschuk are big nerds too, and before BioWare was assimilated by the malignant, cash-harvesting, game-ruining behemoth we know and despise as EA, they almost single-handedly revitalised the then ailing CRPG genre with 1998's Baldur's Gate.

It came in a giant box, on multiple CDs, and it included a game manual so hefty you could beat someone to death with it. It was an actual thing you held in your hands, caressing it gently like a newborn, inhaling that "new game smell", and poring over the manual like it was the Gospel of Christ. Who needed a girlfriend when you had a freshly-minted copy of Baldur's Gate in your sweaty, Cheeto-stained paws? Certainly not me.

But time marches on, you get fat and old (and married), and triple-A gaming becomes a depressing creative wasteland controlled by vultures in suits whose only real interest is in the abomination that is "live service", and getting kids to bankrupt their parents through pre-orders, endless torrents of DLC that should have been included in the base game, and loot boxes. Because, you know, who doesn't love being shafted over and over again by Kotick The Hutt, and Android Wilson? Am I bitter? Yes. Yes, I am.

Anyway, Baldur's Gate... it was great back in the day, and it's great now. Mostly. If you've played Pillars of Eternity, Divinity Original Sin, or Owlcat's Pathfinder titles, you'll be used to a whole lot of quality of life additions Baldur's Gate doesn't have. Despite Beamdog's best efforts, you can't turn a run-down hovel into a stately home, and it shows. This may or may not be a problem for you, depending on how tolerant you are of unintuitive interfaces, clunky inventory management, and 2nd Edition AD&D... which is just bizarre. Want your mage to use a crossbow? Computer says, "No!" If your AC is -10, you're bullet-proof. If it's 10, you're going to get slapped around like a red-headed stepchild. Also, THAC0 (To Hit Armour Class 0), which I still don't properly understand, but it's a thing, and it matters. Read the manual. I mean it.

Beamdog have thoughtfully provided an array of configuration options in the main menu, including a selection of difficulty levels which you should absolutely make use of if you're not a masochist. The game can be brutally unforgiving if you're not prepared to micromanage weapons, spells, and tactical positioning. If you'd rather cruise around the Sword Coast at a leisurely pace, concentrating more on exploration and narrative, Story Mode is probably for you. It gives your party massive buffs, and seriously hobbles enemies. Also, you can't permanently die in combat. On anything above Core Rules, the game will basically break into your home, eat your pets, emotionally cripple your children, and then set fire to everything. This is a classic, no-holds-barred CRPG experience, and it absolutely does not care about your feelings.

I can't say too much about the story without spoiling things, so I won't. It's generic sword and sorcery shenanigans set in Ed Greenwood's Forgotten Realms, so expect to run into a few notable characters, including a crotchety wizard whose name begins with 'E', and a Drow who is very handy with a pair of magical scimitars. Accompanying you on your grand adventure are a varied selection of joinable NPCs, some of whom the game obviously wants you to take with you, but party composition is not forced, and there are no penalties for choosing one NPC over another.

Beamdog have added three new, fully-voiced, NPCs to the mix, so you're provided additional options not available when the game was originally released. They all provide running commentary on what you're doing at any given time, but you can tweak this in the options menu if you'd prefer them to shut the hell up and just haul your crap around for you. (Seriously, having Xzar or Montaran, I forget which, continually bellowing "I am become Death, destroyer of worlds!", every time you fill a gibberling full of arrows gets extraordinarily annoying after an hour or so.)

The game takes an open-world approach to exploration and you navigate via a series of expansive zones accessible from a larger world map. Freedom is only really curtailed by either the story (several zones are inactive until certain narrative events take place), or your party's ability to handle whatever hostile entities inhabit a given area. In a very general sense, the further North you travel, the tougher things get, until you reach the bustling metropolis of Baldur's Gate, where the narrative threads converge and things get really interesting. (One map is fairly crawling with basilisks, so... have fun being petrified all day long at level five.)

There is no level-scaling here. Bite off more than you can chew, particularly during the early game, and you will die a horrible, grisly death. On the very first map after leaving Candlekeep, there's a black bear. It's not hostile until you antagonise it, but if you want that sweet, sweet XP, you're going to antagonise it. If that bear gets a lucky dice roll, it will one-shot you. Running around shooting arrows at it is a better plan, provided you don't run into the wolves and gibberlings on the same map. If you're smart, you'll set the game to auto-pause whenever you encounter an enemy, (or trap, because those will effortlessly kill you too.)

The music and sound design are both fantastic, with some great voice-acting from major NPCs. The graphics are... the opposite of fantastic. 1998, remember? Now, this is the 'Enhanced Edition', so you've got coloured character circles, better paper dolls on the inventory screen, smoothed sprite outlines, a reworked UI aesthetic, and the ability to zoom in or out at will. BUT... zooming in on a game that was originally played at a resolution of 640x480 has predictable results, with the once-gorgeous painted 2D backdrops reduced to a blurry, pixelated smear. Zoom out on your fancy widescreen HD monitor and your characters are basically six badly-dressed mosquitoes buzzing across a vast green field, so you're going to have to fiddle about a bit to find the sweet spot. Fortunately, Beamdog have given us a scaleable UI, so you won't spend hours squinting at the character screen like Mr. Magoo, desperately trying to decipher text three pixels high.

The weakest aspect of the Infinity Engine games was always the path-finding, and it's still terrible. Expect your party of six clueless adventurers to take wildly disparate routes to any destination unless you micromanage them like a flock of wayward sheep. Inside the cramped confines of a trap-laden dungeon, this can be infuriating. Navigating Durlag's Tower while Minsc wanders obliviously into a fireball trap, or Jaheira strides purposefully into a room full of ghasts will have you using a selection of words likely to make a sailor blush. It doesn't ruin the experience, but it is something you're going to have to learn to live with.

Baldur's Gate Enhanced Edition gives you a lot of game for your money. The original title plus the official expansion, Tales of the Sword Coast, and Beamdog's own campaign, Siege of Dragonspear. There are hours and hours of classic RPG goodness here, and despite it being very much a product of its time, Baldur's Gate tells a rollicking tale and remains hugely entertaining provided you can get past the less than stellar presentation. Recommended.

I think NCG summed it up very nicely in that the old Infinity Engine games, while great, were... irritatingly brutal. The AI is programmed to just fucking murder you and your party at all times so you have to mash that quicksave button like a sous chef on cocaine because one missed saving roll on your PC is probably going to kick you back to your last save. So (thank God!) there's Story mode, meaning you get to auto-resolve some of the more unbalanced combat encounters, rather than being forced to do what I did as a teenager and have one or two tanks kiting aggro and running around in circles while everyone else shoots/throws projectiles at the enemy until they die.

That said! I really believe that BG is unfortunately, and maybe even unfairly, overshadowed by BG:SOA, yes SOA ups the voice acting, character interactions, score and story. And the D&D mechanics inherently make the combat, well, just much less boring because you have so many more buttons to push and your fighters miss far less often. BUT! BG has "impeccable vibes".

There's a real open world game energy here before open worlds were at all a thing, and the amount of exploration and weirdness hiding on each blank field map square is so much fun. Let alone that feeling of finally reaching Baldur's Gate itself after bumpkin'ing your way around the country and tiny villages. Man, it's worthwhile. Kevin Michael Richardson the GOAT also.

If you want to play a classic D&D game; like many of us do, then Baldur's gate is the absolute best.  It is challenging; and at the same time, there are multiple story lines to follow.  The quick save feature never fails; so even if you have a hard time during a fight or you miss something, then you can retrace your steps.  Some battles are excruciatingly difficult and you may have to use multiple potions or different tactics to navigate.  By modern standards, the graphics are average, but hold up to the test of time.  Your main character is your bread and butter. so go ahead at the start up to beef his ability scores up the best that you can; take your time.  You will find NPC's along the way to help you.

This is the only game I have owned multiple times over. I played it on my blue-top iMac back in 2000. Then on PC (with a Pentium 4 in it! Hell yeah!), then the Steam version, tablet version... same story for the sequel. By numbers alone, this has to be my favorite game and game series of all time. 

2nd Edition DnD hasn't really aged well. There are clunky mechanics we have rightfully left behind. (THAC0, The way spells work...) but that doesn't matter. The sense of adventure and the feeling that there's always another surprise right around the corner keeps me coming back. There are so many character builds and party combinations, it feels like a new experience every time you play. I'm still positive I haven't seen everything in this game.

To be fair, while the graphics and gameplay are ludicrously ancient, there is a very large and engrossing story to follow, a couple dozen interesting companions, and a well-realized world. The character builds are huge in variety (but woe unto those who don't know how to build properly), leading to a wide array of options. Because of its age, I can only recommend this game to those with incredible patience--it's text heavy, you move very slowly and the AI pathfinding is abysmal. I won't give it a score...it's not appropriate for such an old game with a specific audience.

This game is important for lovers of the fantasy RPG genre for both its story-telling and its place in the lineage of the genre. Many games have claimed to descend from Baldur's Gate, either literally or in spirit. This is one of two-dozen must-play games, particularly in this modern release.

My thoughts are based mostly on the early hours of the game because it was such a disappointment to me that I didn't come close to finishing it. Maybe my expectations were set too high based on all the praise I tend to hear about it, but even that aside, I would not have enjoyed the game.

As a role-playing experience, it failed me. I rarely if ever had the chance to breathe life into my character through interacting with NPCs and quests, because NPCs just spat their life story at me, wrote some objectives into my quest book, and sent me on my way. I remember only one time I was given any kind of choice, and it was one of the last quests I tried. Even RP aside, the writing was really boring to me. I have heard of a later portion of the main quest which I found interesting, but nothing to encourage me to keep playing.

What about the gameplay though? Well, this game helped me realize I cannot stand isometric, real-time RPGs. Or strategy game, I almost want to talk it. I wouldn't call it's mechanics bad, but they're definitely not for me. Maybe I'd enjoy it more were it turn-based or were I already a fan of AD&D.

Basically, if you're expecting an RPG along the lines of classic Fallout or a more archaic Dragon Age or Divinity Original Sin, you may be disappointed.

I can't count the hours I've spent playing this game over the years since the 1990s. I don't like the new characters added by the enhanced edition (dialogues and voices are too corny for me), but since I don't have to include them in my party makeup it's not a big deal. For grognard D&D fans of 1st or 2nd edition, this game is a must play; those liking 3rd+ edition may find the character skill system less free-form, but that can also be a positive since each character is unique and requires the support of the other party members. BG (and BG2) are my favorite computer games of all time, and the enhanced version adds some nice modern touches.

UPDATE: Encountered a strange bug. I have 0 mods, so this seems an enhanced edition bug. Went into the Jovial Juggler inn and Khalid and Monteron got stuck in the same spot during the area load, and would not move from that spot. Had to reload and was annoyed I lost a few minutes of game play....

UPDATE 2: I encountered Baeloth out in the wilds, a very powerful DROW magic-user. I was level 3. No matter my choice in dialogue I was forced to attack him which is stupid. He's a high level magic-user. Who in their right mind thought it would be okay to do that to a party? It's just stupid. Once again Extended Edition showing its inferiority to the original. The writing is off color and the character is overpowered. Baeloth is supposed to be a character in the Black Pits, not Baldur's Gate. Then, when I got really irritated and pulled out my best items to kill him, I got NO experience. Just the worst design decision and made me come on here to give a negative. No game balance. Stupid!

It's a hugely ambitious game, but very much "of its time". Your enjoyment of it is going to depend on how much you can look past its many shortcomings and frustrations.

The game does do a good job of letting you build a character exactly to your specifications, assemble a varied team and explore a huge amount of the Sword Coast. It also makes a solid attempt at bringing across the lore and atmosphere of the Forgotten Realms circa 2nd Edition, with a plot that follows on directly from the Time of Troubles as depicted in the Avatar novels.

That said, the game feels very dated to actually play, with extreme difficulty spikes, an almost total lack of guidance and feedback for the player, poor pathfinding and AI in general, and numerous other frustrations in its controls, interface and general gameplay. I knocked the difficulty down to Easy mode after around 20 hours and found some sections to still be a massive slog. I finished the main quest and was happy to put the game to bed with dozens of side quests and two entire DLCs completely untouched.

I've played the game thrice, and before this 3rd playthrough my 2nd was an awful experience  simply because of how annoying it was to just to mod original version to convert it to BG2's engine (to use BG2 features) and work on modern computers. EE port makes this a lot easier and pain free, what it adds overall and simply works on modern computers. If you don't like the new NPCs you can just ignore their writing and quests but they let you use a more varied party that compliments the original cast.

Sadly the port could never solve the issue with the game being dreadful and too long for its own good. The first Baldur's Gate is abundant with empty maps and the blandest of stories, it's kinda insulting that this game is regarded as a classic while its early and late 90s peers in the CRPG scene (Western and Eastern) were more interesting. Only play this if you're intending to play BG2, but even then you should probably *just* start with BG2 with a wiki/youtube rundown of the BG1 plot that can be summed up in 5-10 minutes.
I'm actually in awe at how my Planescape Torment playthrough was half in length, there's not much to really do in BG1, just a lot of moving around pointless areas, dealing with the brainless plodding of RTWP and doing banal quests.

Good voice lines though.

Also there's a lot of class and spells and stuff so it can pretty overwhelming at first, and you can't revert anything, if you put point in Long Sword for example and found a really good Bastard Sword you can't switch. There's area where you need silver weapon and the game only give you silver dagger, if you don't have anyone that can use dagger you're kind of fked because you will not hit anything with it. So I suggest another thing called "EE Keeper" it's a save editor, I only use it for purpose of reverting back some change only because I don't want to reload the save or replay the game again, I still have to roll back 1-2 hrs from time to time after I found out I missed some good items though.

25 years later, Baldur's Gate still stands as one of the best RPGs ever made.
Some people say the game is outdated, but I think that is subjective. I personally feel that it holds up very well for it's age, likely because of it's simple(and quite pretty) graphical appearance. 
Although it does literally use the outdated Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 2nd Edition ruleset, it is still very fun to play once you get accustomed to it.
The story is a masterpiece with dozens of memorable characters and locations. Rather than spoil anything, I will simply say that you should get the game and see for yourself. Even though it follows a 'linear story', there is still plenty of exploring available.
It should run on pretty much any modern PC, as it is certainly not a demanding game.
I personally prefer waiting for sales before I purchase anything because I'm cheap like that, but I can definitely see it being worth it's normal price.

After playing through BG3 Act 1 in the Early Access I discovered that Beamdog had released a new game Siege of Dragonspear, so I decided to play the full series again. I had only played the original BG1 once when it first came out but spent a lot of time playing BG2+ToB. I had played the Steam version of BG2EE but found it unplayable in just the first couple of minutes so refunded it but decided to give BGEE a shot anyway. 

If you're a D&D fan the game is as enjoyable as it was back when it first came out. I was slightly put off at first by how the game played and looked but after a couple of minutes of tweaking it runs perfectly good. 

I couple of tips if you're going to try it out:

1) Go to C:\Users\username\Documents\Baldur's Gate - Enhanced Edition\ open up the baldur.lua file and edit the line:
SetPrivateProfileString('Program Options','Maximum Frame Rate','45')
to 45 from the default 30. You can experiment with the frame rate but I found 45 to be just perfect in my experience. 

2) From the in-game options menu or by changing line "SetPrivateProfileString('Graphics','Scale UI','1')" turn on UI scaling. Game looks much better and character portraits aren't too small to see. 

3) I found assigning the WASD keys to camera scrolling and turning up Keyboard Scroll Speed to max really improved the playing experience allowing you to move around and click-to-move much more efficiently than mouse scrolling. 

After the above tweaks the game runs perfectly and I found it really enjoyable despite the fact that the original came out back in 1998. I can't wait to replay the full series before BG3 comes out.

Baldur's Gate often reads like there are plot elements, lines, and entire character personalities pulled right from a developer's D&D session. Reference heavy, characters with little dialogue other than enough to give a personality like crazy evil guy, butt kicking force for goodness, revenge focused guy with dead wife, lawful stupid paladin, etc. A single writing style or characterization for the protagonist is pretty much nonexistent as what kind of things you say are just all over the place. Usually giving a positive or negative (or good/evil) style response or with questions or a more neutral sounding affirmative but it's a mixture of serious, funny, ridiculous, pop culture references with near everything you say. A very large amount of NPC encounters or lines are references to Monty Python, X-Men, Judge Dredd, The Simpsons, the 80s Newhart show where the characters act as a reference to characters from the show and tell you you're from the wrong generation if you say you don't know who they are instead of asking for an autograph, plays, a dwarf says slightly altered lines from the song Sixteen Tons, the miners you find will cough and say they think they are coughing up blood but if this game released after Zoolander I have no doubt that would have been changed to a weaker sounding cough with the line changed to "I think I got the black lung Pop." It can certainly be entertaining at times but not as memorable narrative wise or as character driven as many stronger games in the genre.

There are some nice things about the old 2nd edition D&D ruleset and some of the mechanics in Baldur's Gate 1. The morale system where your enemies and allies (different NPC break at different levels) can break and have a panic effect applied is a nice way to add some realism to encounters, more than the typical everyone just is ok fighting to death all the time you get with basically every other game and your party leader's charisma or a bard playing music can raise that morale level. Weapons have speed values that make them attack slower or faster in each combat round, something gone in new editions and Pathfinder, that makes it so a lot of weapons just don't make any sense to use because they just do less damage or have less additional features (damage types/armor break/trip/disarm/etc). Hitting faster in the round can mean a lot if you end up being able to apply status effects, break an enemy's concentration on a spell, or outright kill them before they get to attack. I like that there are enemies that just naturally resist certain types of damage (slash/blunt/pierce) that is basically gone from new D&D and that even the armor or magic equipment you get might protect better or worse against certain types of physical damage. Punching people can knock them out which allows you to either steal things from the area without them seeing and losing reputation for killing them, charm person spells can also allow this or can change an NPC's dialogue and give you new information about them. Your charisma bonus (or penalty) is added to your reputation which can alter some conversations, rewards, and for some characters having a high or low enough reputation might make certain quests available or get you attacked by people that might have asked for your assistance. On the negative side of the old rules are the very low chance to hit low level characters frequently have, wanting a low armor value (preferable in the negatives) is odd, THAC0 is a more complicated system to calculate hit values since you want it to be lower and classes decrease it at different rates but magic items say they add to it even though they make it easier to hit, and everything about how stats work is completely different from how it is done from third edition on (like your constitution being over 16 for more health won't matter unless you are a warrior class and the bonus constitution health only applies up until a certain level or that the game says wisdom can resist spell effects but never actually added this to the game).

When it comes to changes made in the EE addition, the four new recruitable NPC characters (with one being a more of a secret find as he is the main antagonist of the Black Pits arena style add on) are all decent enough additions. They each give you a class type different from what you get in the main game for recruitable characters, though the monk character could probably have benefitted from better stats or unique items with how weak the class tends to be (especially in the low level environments of BG1). Either mistakes or problems from lack of models in the original game are often fixed here or changed such as characters casting spells they shouldn't be able to, characters with the wrong alignment, a massive amount of character that had the wrong model/gender or alignment (be it a issue of time, mistake, or just not having the model until later games) such as a quest where an ogre mage teleports to hell which has now been corrected by giving him a devil model, unique items for certain characters just not giving them the bonuses they are supposed to (taking a character like Alora from poor to the best thief in the game thanks to her rabbit foot item). A very positive change is in adding the new spells from Baldur's Gate 2 into this game, giving spellcasters more options and making the druid class more useable. They brought in the feature from later games with this engine where you can hold tab to highlight interactable objects in the environment, as well as adding a button to the UI that just toggles highlights on and off. Some new weapons and equipment pieces have also been added and some missing or nonfunctioning content or conversations have been added (most of these had to formerly be added with the Unfinished Business mod, which is still useable and still adds other content). Having potions and ranged ammunition stack at much higher number improves inventory management, as does adding in the Baldur's Gate 2 items that allowed you to store gems/jewelry, scrolls, and potions. An instant quick save and load and having the game in a digital format that doesn't need to swapping between six CDs is also a nice bonus.

Some of the class kit options added to the game that were from Baldur's Gate 2 give you almost no positive bonuses at low levels and don't add anything of value to the game, unless you plan to import the character you played through Baldur's Gate 1 into Baldur's Gate 2. Though they are still welcome additions. Pathfinding issues are still frequent, I don't know if it is new to this version but I don't recall having frequent problems where characters would actually walk inside of each other and get stuck. Limited character interaction, many don't have a quest or anything unique about their character or equipment, this makes it so a lot of them aren't really interesting or memorable unless you add mods into the game. The text box isn't handled that well, all the text being far too small by default (but that can be changed in options) and scrolling doesn't work well. With the enhanced edition, there was probably no real reason why certain weapons end up with much better items than others (two handed swords, long swords, daggers, and short swords tend to have better endgame equipment or frequent drops of magical versions compared to most other weapons) and it would have been nice if there were some store options or more extra equipment added especially considering they added Baldur's Gate 2 weapon proficiencies to each class. What hurts the gameplay the most -

I just want to say that the Enhanced Edition is extremely good. All of the new content is excellent. It stands out marvelously. My recommendation has nothing to do with Beam Dog.

...or maybe it does. Because the new content stands out precisely because BG1 is a big piece of shit. It's one of the worst cRPGs you could possibly play. It's totally linear. Every conversation and confrontation ends in a big, dumb fight. The combat is horrific--I know some maniacs out there like Infinity Engine gameplay, but I would sooner drink lava than sit through endless combat encounters in this game. Worst of all, the companions are nothing. There are no relationships. No conversations. No real dialogue trees. It's like a template for what cRPGs would later come to be, but nothing more than that.

I love every BioWare game. BG1 is the exception. This game is awful. If you want retro RPG, go play Fallout. Even Diablo is less linear! If you really, really want an Infinity Engine cRPG, though, choose any of them except BG1. BG2 is a good option. Or Planescpae: Torment. But if you're wondering if you should play this first game, here's my advice: GOD DON'T.

Cult Classic / Timeless Masterpiece... whatever you want to call it, there is a reason this game is considered one of the best RPG's ever made.

This RPG has probably the best feeling of exploration outside of the big Bethesda ones. Especially as you are weak af in the beginning and fleeing cowardly is sometimes a better option than fighting. Like in Skyrim your sneak archer just snacks those stormcloak soldiers, a pack of wolfs and some undead nordic guys right from the start. Here it's like one wolf - one crit and you (or Imoen) are gone. Don't be afraid though! The Baldur's Gate series is like THE most power trippy experience ever to be playable on a computer and if you know the system/party composition a bit, you will be unstoppable come the end. Archers are op(!!!!) in BG1, everything magic is in BG2. It's all a very clunky and dated experience of course - especially tiring are the random encounters with hordes of hobgoblins/gnolls etc. and the inventory system. BUT, if you can play old Pokemon games or such, you can probably play this as well. It's worth it 100000x if just for porting your buffed up BG1 char into the second game, which is even better.. And play it in English for the funny voice bits (especially Minsc and Jaheira), even though the German VO has an option to make your Baalspawn talk with a saxonian accent! PS: The inventory system, while shitty, is still easier to handle than most of the stuff Larian comes up with in this day and age :steamsalty:

Baldur's Gate is one of the greatest games ever made, and everyone interested in the RPG genre should play it, period. That said, the so-called "Enhanced Edition" is NOT the way to go. It barely enhances anything, and changes too much. If you want the true experience, you should find a way to play the original game. It comes bundled with the enhanced edition on GOG, for example, somewhere under optional downloads. If you really can't be bothered to get the original working, however, at least install mods for the "Enhanced" version to restore the original FMV cutscenes (instead of Beamdog's awful motion comics), replace the hideous Dragonspear UI with something more akin to the original, and whatever you do - avoid the new Beamdog fanfiction OC companions at all costs. This still won't fix other EE issues like the Icewind Dale spell effects (why did they do that?) or the snowflakes that are still only 1 pixel wide at HD resolutions. But either way, please do enjoy this excellent landmark in RPG history, the game that put Bioware's name on the map!

While the Infinity Engine games are some of the most seminal video games of all time, they have aged like milk. (Or, at least BG1 has.) 

Leveling is slow, exploring is tedious, and the game system is punishing. The photo-realistic-type textures make for a eye-burning experience. Any "style" has been lost to time. Realtime with Pause is [b]bad[/b] unless you grew up with it. If you have played (and enjoyed) any turn-based CRPGs, it will be intolerable.

I love older games as much as the other guy, but this game just doesn't feel worth it.

[b]BUT[/b], I could be missing something. Maybe I'm playing the game wrong. Maybe I just need to "git gud". But I generally prefer experiences and games that are designed to be naturally learned, that don't punish you for not min-maxing, that have mechanics and systems that are logical and intuitive.
This is the first cRPG I've played when I was a kid and it made me fall in love with the genre. While dated all these years later, it's still a classic.

I've played Baldur's Gate a lot back in the late 90s. It made me a fan of Dungeons & Dragons, CRPGs and this sort of Infinity Engine game. It did certainly breathe fresh air into the genre and was a first view into how party-based CRPGs would develop. And it was a proving ground for Bioware and their approach to story-telling and character interaction within the main cast. Looking back on it though, it is more of a prototype of what would come and it is of course surpassed by many games including its own legendary sequels, Baldur's Gate 2 and Throne of Bhaal.

This means, it does a lot of things less good than other games even within the Infinity Engine games. The combat encounters and dungeon designs in Icewind Dale are deeper and more rewarding. Planescape: Torment trumps it by a country mile in story telling, dialogue and writing. Baldur's Gate 2 of course brings it all together and defined what a modern CRPG to this day looks like.

Still, I love the first Baldur's Gate. Sure, a bit of that is nostalgia of me sitting in my room back when I was 15. Living in a really small village with less than 500 people, I would come home from school every day and play Baldur's Gate together with a friend from the neighbourhood. We would explore every nook and cranny, replay it with different party set-ups and even get us some tabletop Advanced Dragons & Dungeon sets to try our hand at traditional role-playing (adding his brother and other friends). 
And in the grand scheme of things, one aspect which Baldur's Gate still is really good at is emulating a certain part of low-level classic Dungeons & Dragons. No, you're not a legendary hero yet. You're roaming the country-side of the Sword Coast, exploring dense forests and mountrain trails while fighting low-level Kobolds and Hobgoblins. The rare  slightly enhanced magic user or special monsters like Basilisks or Sirens feel like little boss encounters. You really feel the level up from level 4 to 5 and a harsh level cap ensures that most of your characters won't see level 10 and beyond (lucky thieves though, eh). 
A lot of Baldur's Gate is walking through the wilderness and I understand for some people, that is boring. For me, it is incredibly relaxing. When you get to the nominal city of Baldur's Gate in the second half of the game, the pacing changes and it becomes more of a first look into how Baldur's Gate 2 would be with lots more dialogue, intrigues and decisions to be made. The included content of the add-on Tales of the Sword Coast then sees your party experience a proper and challenging several hours long dungeon-run into Durlags Tower. Durlags Tower, I stand by this, remains one of the stand-out dungeons of the franchise and an exciting high-point of Baldur's Gate 1 - even if it has nothing to do with the main story.

So should you play Baldur's Gate 1? This depends what you want out of it. My personal stance is: To properly appreciate Baldur's Gate 2 and the on-going storyline, you should give Baldur's Gate 1 a go. If you can't get into it, you might want to at least watch a Youtube story-explanation before going into its sequel. Before you feel like a god in Baldur's Gate 2 and your characters going Level 35 and beyond, it would be worth it to feel how the basics work with a level 5 group. You can import your character and some of your equipment into Baldur's Gate 2 for a feeling of one connected epic adventure. Many characters form Baldur's Gate 1 return and you will get more out of the sequel if you play this one first. 
I say you can still have a good time with Baldur's Gate 1 with the right mindset. And the Enhanced Edition helps in some ways... but hinders it in others to be quite honest.

So yes, the Enhanced Edition. This feels a lot like modding Baldur's Gate 1 in the early 2000s. It adds higher resolutions, some useful items from later games (such as bags holding gems, potions and scrolls) and even some magic, character classes and other features only included in later D&D games. Those quality of life-features help a lot with enjoying Baldur's Gate more. But even after years of patches, the Enhanced Edition still has some smaller bugs here and there, some glitches with sound and graphics. 
And then there is the completely new content: New characters (one even romance-able) and quests. While Beamdog tried to make them fit in naturally within the game world, I can't help but feel they are mostly out of place and not of the same style and quality as the original content. I liked Neera (a wild mage) the most of the bunch, but her quest felt unfinished. And the renewed UI, while technically improved, lacks a bit of the atmospheric texturing and feel of the original release. Speaking of: You can still get the Original game in a box set with Baldur's Gate 1&2 and all the add-ons in "regular stores" so you might consider this if you are a purist. I still do reccomend the Enhanced Edition for newcomers, though.

So in the end - Baldur's Gate is an important release, even if Baldur's Gate 2 is the actually essential game. If you are willing to jump head-on into those classic RPG-experiences, I would recommend to at least try Baldur's Gate 1 before going into 2 because it is a rewarding experience to play both back-to-back. Maybe do a run-up before going into Baldur's Gate 3 (which at the time of this writing is still in Early Access and will hopefully release in 5 months). It's what I am doing at the moment and I had a good time with this game and now I'm having a great time in Baldur's Gate 2. So I recommend Baldur's Gate 1 to anyone who wants to play the franchise, as a stepstone on your way to Baldur's Gate 2 and beyond.

What to say about Baldur's Gate...

This was one of the first isometric RPGs I played. Back in the day it was one of very few games that used actual D&D rules. Being able to create an entire party of characters was the biggest draw for me. It wasn't so much that I didn't like any of the NPC companions, but that I already had a party in mind that I wanted to use. But there are some annoying companions you can get, for sure. Some of them will even leave your party if you don't do their quest with them. It can be interesting to play with only companions, but it's nice that you don't have to.

The map is fairly diverse. A fair amount of dungeons, and a ton of open map area to explore. Lot's of secondary quests, so if you're having trouble with fights, just do a few of those to get "practiced up" and you're fine. The main story/quest is pretty good, too.

The Enhanced Edition really makes it nice. Some QoL additions like zoom scrolling should have been in the original to be honest.

An old school RPG legend with great ambience supported with gloomy visuals & beautiful soundtracks. If its your first 90s RPG experience, it can take a while for you to get used to the general mechanics of the game. After you get immersed in the lore, it becomes way more fun & addicting.

If you're eager to explore the world of Baldur's Gate and play the original game, you'll find the main quest to be engaging and enjoyable. However, there are a few things to keep in mind. Firstly, this is a low-level campaign, so don't expect to become a god in an instant. You can export your character to BGII though, so there's that to look forward to. Secondly, a significant portion of the game is made up of sparsely populated wilderness areas. While finding an interesting encounter is exciting, it can become tedious to clear each wilderness map. Additionally, many of the side quests in the beginning are lackluster fetch-quests that offer little reward.

As you progress through the game, the final city hub can be a frustrating obstacle to navigate. Completing quests becomes more tedious and annoying due to the hub's layout. The dungeons also present their own set of challenges. Some have very thin corridors that are difficult to navigate, especially when trying to disarm traps.

Lastly, the new characters added by BeamDog are not great, so keep that in mind when building your party. I haven't personally played Siege of Dragonspear, but from what I've heard, it's not well-received. Do your own research before deciding whether or not to give it a try.
