I have hear a lot of good things about the game. However, its age shows in the gameplay and i just could not get into the game style.

Beam dog has ruined some things and they could care less to fix them from what I got in the forums.

 Touch spells and in my case the ghoul touch spell. 
Original developers of BG included a +4 thaco when using ghoul touch.

Well guess what Beamdog decided to do.. yup they just took away the +4 thaco bonus this is completely irresponsible. They made the spell completely useless. 

Example: Its so damn bad now that I went as far as to make a Bezerker/mage and even with his thaco bonus the spell is still dog shT and cannot be used because its so unreliable and  you can't hit anything. 

This game which many of us hold dear to our hearts like me since I played this game on and off again my entire life well this game deserves to be handled better.

I don't think Beamdog should be able to just ruin things. 

They call it an Enhanced Edition but they just quite LITERALLY made this spell worse. 

I don't care about their reasoning they can tell me its because they "THOUGHT" it was a bug. 

It does not matter what you think it is you need to think if you are ruining something or not. 

I don't understand how the people who made this decision were not smart enough to think of this.

Imagine being the original developers of BG you know that DnD has a million rules and you know you cannot realistically fit everything in your  game. Especially in a timely mannor. After all time is money and they want to get the game out the door at some point.  

But  look at BG orignally it had things that were unfinished. But you know what they were also in a GOOD PLACE. So this means the original developers had made "good judgement calls", 

For instance they added the  Sorceror and it was not complete but it was also still in a good place. Its spellcasting ability was not reliant on charisma it is still intelligence. But who cares it still works right? Yes! They may not have had the time or money to finish that is what it came down to. But they made a good call because the stuff they finished was of higher priority. Because spending time on one thing means taking time away from another. 

So that example is kinda  what I imagine went on with touch spells. 

They did not finish them but they tried to give them a little something so they would be in a good spot. That something was  the +4 thaco bonus.

It would have cost them more time and money to add things for example possibly: Touch specializations that your character could invest increase his skill at using them. 

Or making your ability score modifiers improve your attack with those touch spells like may be dexterity or your casting ability score. 

I mean who knows what ifs, ands, or buts  

ALL I KNOW IS THE DAMN THING DOES NOT WORK IN BGEE NOW THANKS TO BEAMDOG RUINING IT.
Great game.  I have nostalgia goggles on though.

Consequences, story, lore, engaging characters, and a large world make this a true CRPG classic.

My first complete playthrough of the game (also played a little as a kid, but never finished), and it is an engaging world. Though the interface and general tech are dated, it still holds up. I played entirely on the Steam Deck and though at times challenging, was still a blast. This playthrough could be considered "rushed". I did mostly the main questline with some of the side quests. Definitely did not see all there is to see.

First and foremost I felt the weight of my choices and saw the consequences. I ended up being despised towards the end of the game because I killed some guards (who were attacking me because of my prior choices. lol.). Though the story is linear it does seem that depending on the choices you make the endgame plays out a bit differently, especially in terms of your standing with the different factions.

The story and lore felt very deep. I play D&D regularly (and recently finished a campaign in Waterdeep), and it was cool to encounter or hear of some of the locations and factions I have visited previously. Being based on and tied into such an expansive world as D&D felt good.

You encounter so many different characters, each with their own motivations. The number of party members you can recruit felt a bit overwhelming. I do feel this is a game that benefits from multiple playthroughs and taking your time finding the right balance.

Combat did get a little stale, as playing on the Steam Deck made it difficult to use individual characters abilities. Overall though, it still is one of the most iconic CRPGs and the combat fits nicely.

If you haven't played this game yet and are considering it, just know going that it is a bit dated, but very rewarding. It is one I hope to revisit over time and explore more of the content.

Is it possible to sing the praises of a title enough to grant it its deserved place among the highest echelons of gaming history? Because if [i]Baldur's Gate[/i] isn't already seated as an example of perfected games, it should be. Now, [i]ahem... YOU MUST GATHER YOUR PARTY BEFORE VENTURING FORTH.[/i]

[b]Baldur's Gate Enhanced Edition[/b] [i](BGEE)[/i] is a masterpiece. But it's also more than that. This game is why we don't have games like this anymore. The level of detail put into this game is so vast and widespread that you can easily play through the main story of the game and wrack up 100 hours of time well wasted. Mind you, that isn't for everyone. BGEE takes dedication and patience to play which is very much counter to modern titles. But instead of gushing aggressively over a title that has survived the testament of time with such an overwhelming degree of praise, I'm going to spend this review with fun tidbits and mild hot takes. On we go:

For starters, if you're the type of person that willingly plays a human, [i]you're boring[/i]. This isn't an opinion; it's a fact.

I'm fairly certain that this game can be run on a PC powered by a potato. I haven't tested this out, but I'm probably correct.

If you've never played table-top D&D, [i]THAC0[/i] stands for "To Hit Armor Class 0". Essentially it refers to the roll needed for a character to score a hit an opponent with an armor class of zero. Or more easily understood: the lower your THAC0, the higher likelihood you will hit your theoretical opponent. It's kind of one of the most important numbers to know.

There's so much side content in this title that 100% save files are something of legend.

There's actually more difficulty settings in the game than the established ones when you first start the game. What I mean to say is that playing the game as an evil mage is likely the hardest possible mode you can possibly make for yourself at any difficulty setting. Don't believe me? Try it out for yourself.

It goes without saying that Baldur's Gate is and will always be on the top of my recommendations. It's that good. At $20, it's more than a steal. Don't do yourself a disservice. Get this game and Baldur's Gate II. They're more amazing than you know.

I have played through the original edition about twice with each run pushing about 70+ hours. Now getting into the enhanced edition its still clunky and not intuitive starting out. Any back knowledge of D&D helps to lessen the burden but, it can take awhile to know how everything is done. It can be a lot to gather a party of six and have to in someways micromanage each to become successful, but stick with it get some armor and weapons or spells if you are a caster and just know that unless you know this game inside and out it is meant to be a rough start for a bit. When you start to get the engine going that will be your starting party it will become more immersive and you will get the flow of how it plays. Its a thoughbred CRPG in the fullest sense. Lots of reading and strategic thinking. It is still really combat heavy so always be prepared. It is an all time classic, and was how I learned to play these types of games. If you can play this game know that you can play just about any new CRPG with ease now.

I have beaten this game three times. No other game has made me felt compelled to beat it more than once let alone three times.

Sarevok is a dork and this is a must buy.

For reference, I just beat the main campaign yesterday. Aside from me having to get a bit scummy with some of the fights in the final chapter of the game, I thought that the story and quests were done well. The game has this almost cheesy type of presentation with how it showcases the world, characters and events that I honestly really liked a lot. Maybe I'm just used to more "gritty and grim" interpretations of fantasy worlds, but I thought that the way this game portrayed it's setting was nice and usually light, while still being able to have serious moments. As far as criticisms go...well it hasn't aged badly per se, but some of the gameplay still felt sort of off. I don't hate THAC0, but I wouldn't prefer it over the later systems. I admittedly prefer turned-based gameplay over real-time with pause but that wasn't something I found too much issue with. The main problem I had (aside from the pretty bad AI pathing from my party) was how random things can get despite me not doing much different. I am well aware that this is how the tabletop game has always worked, and to some degree how every RPG videogame works, but it would be a lie to say that I didn't find it kind of weird how I usually didn't have to alter my strategy to pass fights or obstacles but instead just...try the same thing again, this time with my party rolling better. I actually think this can be really fun at my tabletop sessions IRL, but in singleplayer game where I can just load a save after messing up or dying it feels a bit less impactful to fail and a bit more tedious. Still loved it and am onto the second one now.
I've never played D&D and this is the best D&D experience to someone new to that genre

One of the great things about Baldur's Gate is how they implemented the AD&D ruleset into the gameplay with their own little tweaks in it. 

Having 100% the game I can say that it's replayability is great for the amount of classes there are available. But, since this is a -low level setting- (characters cap their exp at 161k, around level 8 for a Fighter) you don't get access to the game-end level 7-9 cleric/mage spells later to be found in BG2, which it isn't an impediment at all. Level progressions feels natural, the spells available are fun and it's nice to figure out how to deal with some enemies.

Storywise it's ok, nothing too fancy about it. Sarevok it's a very fitting villian for the setting in which the game is set. 

Newcomers to the game might find the rules a little bit too complex and bloated, since you have to read though a lot of abilities. 
If you enjoy tons of dialogue, reading the Faerûn lore found in books, old-school WRPG mechanics and just having great party members (with a few exceptions) this is the game for you.

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition represents a classic role-playing game (RPG), originally developed by the company BioWare and published by the company Interplay Entertainment in 1998. This remake (2012) has been developed by Overhaul Games, a division of Beamdog, and published by Atari. Further notable remakes of the development studio are Baldur’s Gate 2, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, and Planescape: Torment.

[i] Pros & cons: [/i]

++ You could play as the stereotypical good guy with a team of righteous characters. Or, you abandon your mortal shell, and create a demigod by using import / export shenanigans after you have collected all attribute books. Break the game by importing your own group of min / max freaks, and commit countless atrocities that would make the former God of Murder proud. Embrace your destiny!

+ The remake introduces a ton of quality of life changes for the base game, which translates into more content and technical modernization including a glorious 4K resolution. An additional DLC and sandbox mode round it up.

+ Kudos to the Legacy of Bhaal difficulty. It transforms every monster into an abomination of unparalleled power blessed by the four chaos gods.

o The side quests are a mixed bag, you have the good, the bad, and the pick-up-the-item-I-just-dropped ones. My favourite quest develops around the boy Albert, who turns out to be a lesser demon from the Nine Hells. The problem: the quest can be done in less than a minute, and the surprise at the end remains unused. One of many wasted opportunities for great adventures.

- The majority of companions are basically mercenaries, and interactions between them are rare. I see them as a way to fill my ranks with like-minded individuals, while role-playing around my reputation. Because if they don’t like what you do, they will leave you in a heartbeat.

-- The amount of dead space in the outskirts can only be described as atrocious. Occasionally, the game sprinkles some trash mobs here and there, but it remains a tedious grind to search every corner of the world map. Again, those regions should have been filled with interesting side quests in order to incentivise and reward exploration.

[i] Summary: [/i]

A solid remake of the game adding more content and technical customization, and to my personal surprise it has held up well. More importantly, it allows the younger fan base to experience a classic title among the RPG genre.
Most of the negative aspects diminish the overall attractiveness, but do not break the immersion while exploring dungeons filled with the promise of untold riches.

Recommended for people with a fetish for a certain hamster.

[i] Achievements: [/i]

Estimated time for 100% completion: +80 hours

Singleplayer achievements: 129
Multiplayer achievements: none

Despite living in the shadow of the masterpiece Baldur's Gate II, this game is still worth a playthrough. I mostly play for nostalgia these days, but a first-time player will need to know a few things before picking it up:

- This is a low-level campaign. You're not going to become a god in this game (but you can export your character to BGII).
- A big chunk of the game is sparsely populated wilderness. This makes exploration fun when you find an interesting encounter, but can be tedious to clear each wilderness map.
- Many side quests in the beginning are underwhelming fetch-quests and are not very rewarding.
- The final city hub is a pain in the ass to navigate, making completing quests tedious and annoying.
- Some of the dungeons have very thin corridors and are a pain in the ass to navigate, especially when considering disarming traps.
- The new characters added by BeamDog aren't great.
- I haven't played Siege of Dragonspear but I haven't heard good things, do your own research on that.

If you're looking to dive in to the world of Baldur's Gate and want to play the original, you will enjoy this game if you can deal with the above points. The main quest has an interesting story and is fun to progress through. If you get annoyed or bored with the side quests or wilderness maps, you can skip them and focus exclusively on the main quest.

If you're not playing this for nostalgia, play it once as a warm-up for the amazing Baldur's Gate II.

I was really on the fence with this one. You're getting this to experience a classic with all its flaws, for most people with no nostalgia, there are probably better experiences.

I came in with no experience with this edition of DnD and generally dislike real time with pause. It was tough at first, I found the fights generally pretty boring. Eventually liked leveling the characters and learning new spells. Late game mage was fun. Despised dealing with traps. The randomness can really fuck you, some fights were just a slog with lots of reloads, others felt like they should have been harder. The UI is bad, Inventory management is tough, mods help here of course.

Overall, the story is solid, nice reveals setup well if you pay attention. The voice acting is fantastic, hearing people speak was enough to keep me going often.

Works fine on a Mac, it kept crashing on my Windows PC before.
It seems like a really overrated game to me, even though it clearly inspired many other games in the genre.
People complain about nostalgia goggles for games like Morrowind, but I think it's really true in the case of this game.

Gameplay-wise, you need to cheese to get anywhere, or use some jank tactics. There is also a really annoying mechanic, in the story, to do with iron mines, that makes certain weapons break- not sure what the percentage is, but it was frequent for me. For some reason wooden weapons are impervious but iron is like sugar glass.
Besides that, if you don't follow a guide regarding character creation, and roll a good set of attributes (painful), then it's likely you won't get anywhere, at least on normal mode. There's no cerebral challenge in the gameplay really, at least in the beginning, its like watching paint dry, roaming around an ugly canvas, until you get to 'the action,' then the combat is played in an awkward manner because the enemies are buffed to hell and the spell system is tedious.

Some party characters you can acquire will have like 4 health, others are not much better, which is abysmal considering the early game fights can do so much damage that even a meta character build can be one shot.
The class system is complex but there is a very finite number of viable options to get anywhere, not that you will get much out of that.

The story so far has been quite boring, it hasn't aged well. Its cheesiness is not endearing, and the characters are all irritating & very forgetful, and I feel like my face is being rubbed in the authors ideals rather than exploring anything interesting, or impactful. I'm not a fan of D&D, but Neverwinter Nights was more enjoyable, even though I gave up with that too.

There is a Unmached Experience in world of video games that is to play Baldur's Gate and export your character to continue playing in Baldur's Gate II and Throne of Bhaal. That got somewhat better in BG:EE, BG:SoDS and BGII:EE.

There are lots of people who will say this is a rip off, because you can still buy the original game for half the price and fans have been mod'ing it for years and those mods will give you many of the upgrades (plus more beyond what the enhanced edition offers). Those people are telling the truth! If $10 is that precocious to you (and you're doing single player) - you should consider it.

But if you don't want to spend the time setting up a twenty year old game on Windows 10+ or if you wanna play multiplayer with friends, I HIGHLY recommend the EE. Sure, BeamDog isn't Black Isle - they're a little cheesy and a little over-eager and their content sticks out like a sore thumb...but it's a very enthusiastic thumb and I, at least, forgive them their excesses.

This game is a classic for a reason and the wandering you can do through the wilderness as a low-level D&D party is enjoyable. The game can be pretty mechanically frustrating - it always was - but it's so juicy once you get into it that it's alright.

Some games grow with age, and flower into classics.

  Some games fuel the creative spark in a generation of future game designers.

     Some games stand the test of time, and embody best of what there generation had on offer.

       This game however as aged like a fine milk, and what 'charm' it once had, has vanished the instant there was any attempt at the same genre on offer.

          I would like to say it is a 'bad game', however doing that would be an insult to 'bad games'.  

             It looks terrible, the writing is atrocious, the voice acting is vile, the story is uninspired, unremarkable, regurgitated plot dregs dug out of the waste paper basket of an unimaginative seven year old.

   It is an RPG, that has no role play, no game play, and frankly, no game.  

     Did I mention it is also full of bugs, and crashes all the time.  

    Did I mention the save files get corrupted, and you often cant use them any more, for no explained reason?

     Did I mention the game glitches out, and just kills your entire party, for no reason?

     Did I mention that the game will crash, and then not allow you to use your save files, so you need to start everything over from the start again?

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is a remastered version of the classic role-playing game set in the Forgotten Realms. The game was originally released in 1998 and has been updated with new content, improved graphics, and new features to make it more accessible to modern audiences.
For those unfamiliar with the game, Baldur's Gate is a party-based RPG where players create a character and embark on a journey through the city of Baldur's Gate and the surrounding areas. The game features a rich and detailed story with many side quests and non-player characters to interact with. The game also features a deep and complex combat system that will challenge players to make use of their characters' abilities and equipment to their fullest.
One of the highlights of the game is its rich and detailed story that takes players on a journey through the city of Baldur's Gate and the surrounding areas. The game also features a deep and complex combat system that will challenge players to make use of their characters' abilities and equipment to their fullest.
The enhanced edition of the game also includes new characters and new content, including the Black Pits, an arena-style game mode where players can fight waves of enemies for rewards. The updated graphics and new features make the game more accessible to modern audiences and the game runs smoothly on modern computers.
Overall, Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is an excellent RPG that will appeal to both fans of the original game and those new to the series. The game's rich and detailed story, deep combat system, and new content make it a must-play for fans of the genre.

Fun but very difficult game. If you can look past the outdated graphics and a few other quirks, I think it holds up fairly well. When I say "quirks", I mean things like how dumb the pathfinding AI is, you'll often find your characters bumping into each other and getting stuck in tight spaces or going the looong way around to a destination. The early hours are brutal but once the ball gets rolling it becomes addictive, with the exception that this game has absolutely zero hand-holding after the tutorial. So if you're not keen on wandering through the map looking for trouble in order to level up and probably doing lots of reloads in the process, this game isn't for you, but if you want some pure DnD action and you know your way around an RPG: this game is still pretty good. Just be aware that it's definitely a game from a different era and it is in no way balanced the way modern RPGs are.

Absolute Classic.

[h1]Gameplay: 6/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 6/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 5/10[/h1]

✔️ A vast world to explore.
✔️ A huge amount of possible companions, who sometimes have interesting interactions between them.
✔️ Pretty rich character-building possibilities.
✔️ While the game is old, the graphics remain nice enough if you don't look too closely.

💭 The game is long, took me around 100 hours to finish.

❌ My biggest issue with the game is how little is explained inside of it - expect to spend a lot of time on wikis if you want to understand the game mechanics.
❌ Related to the previous point, a lot of situations are just extremely difficult (or even impossible) to deal with if you don't have the adequate preparation (the right immunity spell usually), which can cause a lot of frustration if you don't have sufficient knowledge of the game.
❌ While the Enhanced Edition improved the game's user experience, it is still pretty clunky. For instance there is no display of the areas affected by your spells - you have to try and "calculate" them yourself.
❌ The Enhanced Edition isn't completely bug-less.
❌ While the exploration is pretty free, the story itself is very linear. There are extremely few significant choices the player can make inside the main plot, aside from giving rather "good-aligned" or "bad-aligned" answers in dialogues (which usually don't really change the outcome). 
❌ Sometimes the direction of the main plot didn't feel very credible to me - in the sense that I saw no reason for my character to do what the game expected from them.
❌ While you have a lot of companions to choose among, you only get the opportunity to really level up a few of them - the companions not currently in your party don't level along with you. I find it pretty sad because the companions don't have that much reaction lines, and over time they tend to repeat themselves a lot, and allowing to swap companions at will would have really helped that.
❌ The inventory management is a pain, especially when like me you want to pick up all the loot you can, even when it's not reasonable, and you should really pass on those 1 gold piece short swords.
❌ I didn't play it much, but the multiplayer left me a negative impression - having to handle the pause-based gameplay is really a hassle, and the way the party is bound together left really little space for players to do stuff on their side, which left a lot of pretty boring moments.

Overall the game is old and clunky, but it also has some charm, and was pretty interesting to play around in solo play. Despite all the negative points, I do recommend this game if you're willing to tackle its weaker aspects and spend a while on the wiki (no seriously, that's important, I find the game extremely difficult to play without an exterior source of information). I really think the Enhanced Edition could have been, well, more Enhanced than it is right now though.

I'm sorry to say that, but this was one of the most disappointing gaming experiences of my life, and I can not really understand how this is supposed to be a classic. While the story (so far) is ok, the dialogues have charm and I actually like the graphics, the RPG mechanics are just trash.

I don't understand, how anybody could think that the D&D rules are acceptable. Everything is completely random, especially in the beginning, where everything (including you) will often die after one successful hit. The rules are quite complex, but that complexity serves no purpose whatsoever. Instead, there is a very specific rule for the tiniest detail, each level up works different, a lot of things including entire attributes have no meaning for all but a few characters and so on... But the worst sin that any RPG system can commit is still using the level value for calculating things. If you are sufficiently higher leveled than your opponent, he will never be able to even hit you, even if you are the worst fighter in the world regarding all other stats. But its not like you can really increase your stats anyway (and no, that has nothing to do with the time of release, Final Fantasy and Diablo for instance are older but allow you to customize your character during progress).

The final reason for me actually quitting is the ultra-slow pacing. After 16 hours I barely reached my fist level up. Maybe I just suck at the game, but probably the truth is somewhere in between.

As a last thing, the highly praised companions could not convince me. I was bombarded with new group members from the very beginning on which makes them feel rather random and exchangeable to me so far. It was still interesting to see how Bioware did that kind of stuff in their early days.

So in conclusion, the RPG mechanics are extremely weak and could not motivate me at all and for a purely story driven game the story, companions and world were too mediocre for my taste.
A classic for a reason. Still worth playing after all these years.

An inferior version of a masterpiece game.

This "enhanced edition" as it's called changes a host of things, but unfortunately it's for the most part for the worse.

They adapt many aspects of the second game into the first game without giving it any thought, thus ruining the careful balance of the first game. Changing the "big" weapon groups into single weapons makes the in-game experience worse due to the low amount of different weapons in the game, and thus you have to know what to choose from prior experience. Originally you could make a decent choice and get a nice selection of weapons, but here you MUST know which weapons are dropped and which aren't.

Another big change is the dispersion of thief skills, which is baffling. Originally the game had the two stealth skills under one skill, which meant that even at the low levels of BG1 the player could enjoy the various game mechanical effects of the thieving realm, but now you must invest double the points into stealth which greatly lowers your capacity to use the other skills.

They've changed some of the items to be super OP(frost arrows for instance), and added a slew of new, equally OP, items into the shops(elemental darts for instance, each does an additional d6 of damage compared to the 1d3 they usually do. Suffice it to say that this changes the power level of darts to an absurd degree, since not only do you do triple damage with them, they're super good compared to the other weapons due to a high fire rate, which means you do 3d3 + 3d6 per round. A regular swordsman still does d8 + bonuses). 

On the UI part they've clearly made the game worse. The icons and party member pictures and such are really tiny, taking away from both precision of clicking as well as immersion. The in-engine cut scenes are zoomed out to be ants, for some reason.

Graphically there's some huge immersion downgrades, changing from the admittedly poor quality 3d animations of the original into still 2d art. This in itself wouldn't be a problem if they hadn't made some massive changes to the feeling of these tidbits, thus removing the point entirely. For instance, the death animation of the original made it clear the player character had a special role as your death signalled the animation where your essence is drawn into a very sinister ghostly icon. The new version on the other hand has a simple disintegration that really doesn't tell you anything. Strange choice indeed, since you could easily have put the ghostly icon there as well.

In short, the people making the enhanced edition apparently haven't grasped the core concepts of the game they've changed, but have rather added stuff without much thought.

The only reasonable things I personally agree with are the higher stacking limits of arrows, and the auto-rest. 

Why the recommendation, then? It's Baldur's Gate 1, and it runs on modern machines. That in itself is a worthwhile thing, even with the many foolish design choices.

In the early '00s a friend of mine lent me all of the compact disks including the expansion. To date, I do not believe I ever returned those disks -- I was that friend, but unintentionally so. Foolishly, I thought "Baldur's Gate" was a hack and slash from the "Dark Alliance" series and was not much of a 'reader.' Loading up hacks and giving myself various, seemingly high level items and experience, I found that I could not just go around killing and getting more loot which measurably increased my ability to slay whomever I liked, as in, the RPG experience most are accustomed to.

In the latter half of that decade, I'd quit "World of Warcraft" with more than a year of my life "/played" looking for titles that would capture the immersion and roleplaying aspects of that addiction but something locally administrated and quickly decided that "Baldur's Gate" needed another fair chance. I was in that transitional phase, living with my parents. I believe I was in between two summer courses of conversational Spanish and epistemology, and my parents were going to Hawaii, so watching the house was my task. That week, all I did was play this very game, occasionally catching movies on television -- remembering in particular "Dante's Peak" -- eat frozen pizza, and sleep. Nothing else.

While most of its dungeons are lackluster, save for the often reviled "Durlag's Tower" (that is an excellent dungeon) the wilds and exploring of them is unparalleled. That week formally introduced me to Dungeons & Dragons, Ed Greenwood's "Forgotten Realms" and how it might have felt to play D&D in the early '90s and late '80s with its "2nd Edition" ruleset implementation. n.b. Read a brief on THAC0 before you play if you want to conquer "Core" difficulty.

Beamdog's treatment at times can detract from the original experience for some. If you have never played the originals as they were published, one would not be able to isolate anything amiss unless performing a careful examination of writing style and voice acting. Even then, it poses a challenge at times as the original version had an odd cast.

10/10 RPG; classic. Incredibly addictive, and immersive. If that is not enough, you may also export your character into "Baldur's Gate 2" and continue the journey.

If only I had an opportunity to play this game growing up, it would definitely leave a huge impression and a lasting influence on me, like many other games of my childhood. Unfortunately, all I had at the time was a few gaming magazines with articles on Baldur's Gate and the sequel. Being a small kid with nothing to do, I read them many times over, of course, wide-eyed and eager.

Fast forward to modern age - game graphics and design made a gigantic leap forward in just 10 years time, while I did the growing up part, leaving Baldur's Gate far behind and forgotten. Naturally, once I got my hands on it, I tried to play through the series, even started with Baldur's Gate 2 three or four times (thinking, surely, the second part has aged less than the first), but always dropped it an hour or two in.

Finally just a week ago, it dawned on me, that Baldur's Gate 2 starts where first part left off in a most literal fashion (always bugged me that you start at level 7 :D and, no, I don't remember a single word from those ancient articles I had as a kid). So decided to try the first game and, luckily, that went down a lot smoother.

Now, that silly intro aside, here are my thoughts on the game.

Pros
- Extremely cheap nowadays.
- Very lighthearted, humorous and easily digestible writing - which ALMOST ALL modern cRPGs lack (looking at you Kingmaker, with your walls of poetic dialogue text for every drunkard dimwit NPC you meet along the way).
- Starts at level 1 and serves as a very good introduction to game mechanics, which are expanded on in later iterations.
- Generate a full party or pick any from wide selection of companions you meet along the way. No less than 20 and some even have quests (although, pretty clunky to complete, if you want to 100% this, as switching party members is not very streamlined, without going into greater detail).
- Large variety of classes and class combos to play as, spells to cast, unique equipment to find, locations to explore and secrets to discover. I was expecting the game to be very shallow, since it's based on one of the early DnD editions. But depth kinda blew me away, even today.
- Various difficulty settings with a good balanced middle ground at Core - game slowly ramps up difficulty and never goes overboard, with some exceptionally difficult and often optional fights in between (except for the final battle, don't know what happened there - it's brutal).

Cons
- Graphics aged awfully and that's a massive roadblock for anyone willing to give this game a chance. Environment are often a pain to look at - a lot of obvious procedural duplication, and yet, everything seems hand placed at the same time. It's ugly and hurts to think about.
- Interactivity and quality of life features are, obviously, very dated. Don't expect fireball to have a circular ground targeting indicator, no, you're going to throw it blindly, and you're going to turn half of your party into lumps of charcoal (which could be considered a sadistic 'feature' of sorts, but will often just mean, that aoe spells can be thrown only at a large distance).
- SUPER NARROW cave environments and mazes mixed in with mediocre pathfinding for a party of six who are additionally colliders to each other. Need I say more? Ok, I will, sometimes characters will just clump into a single grid tile, and will get stuck in one place for a while - ALL SIX OF THEM.
- Personal opinion (spoilery) - I got bored of the story half way through. 'Kill this bad guy, but there's another bad guy pulling the strings, who also has strings, that are pulled by a third bad guy, and then there's some plot twist on top of that'. I don't know, it's a cluster. Honestly, I liked side quests a lot more, than the main storyline - bigger variety of enemies and things to do.

Overall, well worth the 5$ I paid for it, but comparing to some of the modern cRPGs, I would not give this game multiple playthroughs. Back in the day, I'd play it up and down many times over. Sadly, time was merciless to Baldur's Gate, and turned it into a gentle attraction you fondly remember liking as a kid, but would be too uncomfortable to ride as an adult (even though, I just finished it, as an adult... This doesn't make sense anymore, but i'll keep it in - it's a pretty sentence, and since comments are disabled, I'll :cringe: for you and with you, dear reader).

I originally played this game around 1999 or 2000. so coming back to this game, in the enhanced edition, some 20+ Years later is absolutely Nostalgic. Sure I remembered some vital things like characters, but the comparison to the two is so wild. Alot of neo-gamers, neo-cultured people complain about not maintaining true to source material. Screw all that edge-lord garbage. This is an excellent rendition of a book, of one of the best Series in Forgotten Realms. Sure the game isn't "remade" to modern standards. But Baldurs gate set the playing ground for many games to come. Hell, early WoW. But people want to cross swords of this or that. This game is iconic. Once I finish this one, I will certainly be moving on to two, and three. If you've been on the fence. Get off your fence. Buy this game, and revel in the joys of what is possibly the best Forgotten Realms story next to the Dark elf trilogy.

Excellent AD&D adventure with plenty of side quests. The enhanced edition is levels ahead of the original. I love the auto calculations and highlights for who can use equipment. Color text shows the advantage vs disadvantage of inventory items (so less THAC0 confusion for new AD&D players). The tutorial has been expanded. Ammo counts are 4x higher, increasing carrying amount. Extra carrying cases from other games are introduced early. I'm exploring the new spells, sub-classes, and fighting styles. The auto-reveal of interactive items and map journal is a time-saver. 
An overseen feature is the time clock. Characters in the party can grow impatient about unfinished missions, keeping the player focused on the main plot. Travel time, action speeds, and carrying capacity were real issues in this edition. You may have to triage some of that treasure. And actions have consequences. If you get caught stealing, leg it before the guards arrive.
It has a few flaws, but I'm very happy with the overall game. Otherwise I wouldn't have played it again. The biggest flaw I can find is only one campaign can be saved. If you want to play a new character, the old one is lost. A small sacrifice for a good game. Play it through and try another race/class/alignment after completion.

Baldur's Gate Enhanced Edition is the remake of an old classic at 2012,  which was originally released at 1998. So at core, you are looking a game that is 22+ years old. There were lots of license limitations to Beamdog as far as i heard. 

It's a party based isometric RPG that uses Dungeons&Dragons 2nd edition ruleset. You create main character, find NPC's suit to your ideals, goals. Overcome enemies, gain levels and items, solve plots, help people or help yourself, deal with the brewing trouble in the region.
Main quest is kind of a linear but nearly every little quest has multiple paths and they affect you one way or another. With every class comes a different play style so multiple play-throughs are quite common. 

This game changed cRPG in its release and set way for a new era, many awards and professional critics have already shown its excellence. Here is my thoughts anyway. 

+++Story / World : One of its strongest aspects, BGEE defines a very intriguing world. Political, personal events are curious, lots of quests and characters to discover. Empowered from D&D universe Forgotten Realms, your adventures take place on Sword Coast, which many books, games already established quite well. When you set foot and pay attention to details, you will find yourself immersed in an magnificient world.
Your character can continue to Dragonspear and then to BG:II EE which i strongly suggest. Then the positive comments i can gave is not enough. Upon completion, you will be like you have read 9 books of good fantasy role-playing.

+/- Game System: 2nd Edition D&D is imbalanced and complex. I am a DM-GM of 5thE and Pathfinder 2.0 on pen &paper and i don't want to go these old systems. However since it's a PC game, some of that imbalance turned into a feature for most people.
You can make characters can single handedly finish game , even on harder difficulties. Lots of cheesy combinations. Some like it some dont. There are mods to fix this, or bump this aspect more. Anyway 2nd edition created immense replayability for BGEE that's for sure.
So it's neither a plus nor a minus. 

+Graphics / technical: Well its'a game of 22+ years. It's working on modern systems, with 21:9 and 144hz 3440*1440 support, i had NO crashes or bugs /crashes due to technicality.

+++ Voice Acting/ Sound/ Music: It requires mention. Quite good regarding its age. Music is masterpiece. 

Overall EE fixed TONS of bugs, made it modern day compatible added new items, BGII classes and kits, new difficulty and its still updated and supported and its still modable with active and helpful community
Visit: https://forums.beamdog.com/categories/bg%3Aee-discussion for all kind of info and help. 
+2022 Edit: If you haven't yet played with mods, do it. 
BG Quests and Encounters, BG tweak anthology, Unfinished Business, Transitions, NPC Project .. many  awesome content awaits. 

This is the way to enjoy a true classic.

If you've never played isometric RPGs before, this is absolutely the definitive starting point. All games in this genre that came after (and even the few before) can trace roots to the masterfully crafted gameplay and design of Baldur's Gate. From a Forgotten Realms perspective, this game franchise put the Sword Coast on the map and immortalized many iconic characters, including Minsc & Boo, Jaheira, Irenicus, Sarevok, and even Bhaal and other deities.

Long story short, I'm still playing this game over two decades later. Get this one in your library!

I so wish that I could put stars instead of just thumbs up or thumbs down. 

It was great to go back through BG and all the extras, Tales of the Swordcoast, but I'm 45 minutes into SOD and I'm just hunting through how I can afford to get rid of Safana as soon as possible.

I got the EE without any knowledge of Beamdog, their expansion, any of their writing, anything, because I played the original BG, BG 2, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, all of it. I wasn't really paying attention to anything to do with these extras or this company. I still am not really. But 6 years after their huge release controversy, I understand and agree with that their writer Amber Scott is off her rocker and needs desperately to learn to do better more nuanced writing. Because this is kind of butchery.

Safana gets dumped into your lap as a forced character when you finish BG and the game flashes to SoD prologue in a dungeon and Imoen, no matter your choices, is a trailing character and not a companion talking about current events and helping along, but not directly. Ok. Sure. 

But Safana takes to some pretty creepy sultriness. Pushiness in fact, like she's just a hairs breadth from tackling you right there in the middle of the dungeon right in front of that skeleton rising out of its crypt attacking you. It's really creepy. Her click, select, and order lines are super cringey. The last thing I want is a nymphomaniac that has now been turned into a super sarcastic dissenter (I haven't gotten that far?) that keeps throwing suggestiveness at me like a dog in heat. Sultry "Yes dear?" Stretched out into almost 4 syllable lengths every single time. Poor voiceover acting drawing everything out painfully long is making me dread having her for even another minute.

Ok, so past the prologue. There are only 2 thieves in SoD.

In BG which I have just enjoyed fully revisiting I ended up getting rid of Khalid and Jaheira as soon as I could conscionably do so because I simply could not abide the reality of a WARRIOR that is a defender, a front line strong man that is meant to take on all kinds being a simpering coward and stuttering fool jumping at every shadow and every kobald we had to fight. How does a WARRIOR, a FIGHTER have literally less spine than a stable boy? And Jaheira's general disgust for all things civilization that makes her intolerable if you don't want to occasionally mocked lightly "omni present authority figure" in a mocking tone, funny enough, but eventually gets annoying. But what is obnoxious is her constantly going on about every trace of people and it's destruction on nature. I get it. She's a druid. But she's a bloody HARPER. They DEAL in civilization. 

But Khalid and Jaheira being annoying are not deal breakers in BG in ANY WAY! because there are a PLETHORA of companions in BG. And they can be endearing if you don't mind their issues. Me? I mind a coward of a fighter that is best as an archer with gauntlets of ogre might, renamed in EE edition to Tokkar or whatever for composite bow, or given dexterity gloves to survive better as a pseudo tank front liner. It just doesn't match any form of "role playing" to handle his personality for me unless you really get into a Jaheira that is a truely domineering woman forcing him into everything. Pretty grim assumptions, especially with Amber Scott (the writer from Beamdog) perspective that she CLEARLY trashbinned because "we cannot have a nagging housewife trope Jaheira, so I'm going to write a sweet romancy side quest for them 2" uhhh that does not fit any role-play my friend. It just... doesn't. It really does not.

Moving on. SoD is harmed deeply by Safana by anyone who cannot stand this extremely forced nympho not nympho rewrite re-voiced overacted responding to everything because by GOD Amber Scott wanted her to not be seen as JUST a sex object but now she is MORE THAN EVER, I guess until you get to her side quest... because there are only 2 thieves. Where as before in BG there are 4 fighters, and several fighter multi-classes. 3 druids, 2 clerics, several cleric multi-classes. 

You are FORCED into having Safana. Forced to deal with Amber Scott's rewrite, and forced to have the "Yesssssss ddeeeeeaarrrrrr.....??" every single time you activate her. "Sweetheart?" "Mmmmmmm" like a moan.
Direct her "Whatever you like."
LIke. WHAT? I'm NOT in a relationship with you! Don't call me that. What is so breaking for me is that she IMMEDIATELY, well, that, the second she throws Coran out for cheating on her after a... 2 month relationship? Double standards much? SO CRINGE.

And for whatever reason no matter who else is in my party, she is the only one that responds to external situations, and makes it as sexual as possible. I really don't want to deal with that overt of a narrative and pushing on of characters onto me. 

So this get's a thumbs down overall because the Enhanced Edition is Beamdog is Siege of Dragonspear. They did some pretty clumsy and terrible implementation, overdone and poor writing, and then pushed it on agenda rather than being nuanced. In terms of their ideas for representation, sure, great, whatever, just make it actually representative and nuanced. Not completely out of the norm and bizarre or blunt force trauma. I just met a character, they just dumped a guy, now they are sexually harassing me with every click for the rest of the game because I am forced to have them in my team when I had no interest in them in my team ever before just because the Beamdog writer didn't like how she was one dimensional? I mean, no one I ever knew that ever played BG ever bothered with Safana. Ever. So... now she's forced on people because this one writer didn't like her? And that character is forcing herself on the player in what feels quite a rebound, over the top harrassment style? This does not feel ok.

Thanks but no thanks Beamdog. If I hadn't already purchased all of these enhanced editions because they were all on extreme sales because of these major writing faux pas' of yours, I wouldn't be buying them at all because I don't know how I will be getting past the hours between Safana and recruiting the next and her having definitely skipped the sexual harassment seminars at work and school. Do some better coding so it isn't ALWAYS that one character responding in a group selection, so there is variable response, so it doesn't feel like it is Safana's party when it is in fact my character's party. Ugh. So much Ugh trying to get past the prologue and handle having Safana totally forced on me. I may just have to ditch my character and make a thief dual or multi-class so I can actually see the rest of the expansion.

edit: Apparently whomever you put as last in the order of your companions responds more frequently, or is the 1 whom responds to everything. Not sure if that will be companion responses to NPC dialogue yet, but at least I've got her moaning in my ear less by moving Minsc to the 4th slot, though that sucks for formations. Oddly, Minsc never chimes in where she constantly moans at me.

Edit 2: Fortunately, you can immediately kick Safana when you start "chapter 8" after the prologue and replace her with the other thief. You cannot backstab with him, which leaves much to be desired, especially as a thief/cleric his range is slings, but I guess he'll do.

Overall it was a pretty good game. Completed the entire thing Co-Op with my dad. The Co-Op worked surprisingly well for a game of this age besides a couple disconnects. This was our first type of game like this where you control a full party of adventurers as opposed to one character each.

Pros:
- A whole lot of bang for buck if you shoot for the 100% playthrough (306.7 hours for our one playthrough of main game, Siege of Dragonspear and Black Pits)
- Tons of variety between the default companions in the game and the ability to make custom ones

Cons:
- Graphics are quite dated
- Tons of reading since there's minimal voice acting
A landmark game that has been lovingly cared for by Beamdog Software to bring it back from the brink.

Even though this game has aged, the story is still a good one. Things happen more abruptly with less drawn-out storytelling but the gameplay is still pretty nice even being based on 2E. You have a variety of companions, plenty of places to explore, etc. If you have the patience for it, a pretty solid game. 

That said, my nostalgia from playing the originals as a kid on our ancient home computer probably still has me seeing it all through rose colored glasses.

I really wanted to give this a positive review, because it was one of my favorite games when I was younger. However it has not aged well.

The story and writing is still there and it is good, but the gameplay is torturous. D&D is an amazing system for roleplaying, but it doesn't transfer well to a computer game, it transfers even worse to a real time game with sloppy AI. There's no dungeon master to narrate and change the flow of a fight, it's just enemies that can decimate your party if you're not going in completely min-maxed.

The narrative in the game is good, and there's an interesting adventure to delve into but the entire game revolves heavily around fights and the fights are, excuse my french, dog shit.

A game that's best left to childhood memories.

Baldur's Gate is an absolute classic of the genre and the Enhanced Edition brings in features from the later games in the series as well as a number of modern quality of life improvements. This is a fantastic way to experience this title for the first time, and has enough new quests and characters to give veterans something new to do.

After more than 22 years of it's original release I was able to play through this game.
I would say, nowadays the story is nothing special, yet interesting and keeps you moving forward to see how it develops to the end.
The game mechanics are good, however you need to dig into deep into the rules to understand what you need to use for different enemies, especially for the harder ones, otherwise it's manageable.
The Enchanced version makes the game better, however some of the added NPCs breaks the immersion which is frustrating sometimes, but you are able to ignore them fortunately. And last but not least, you have to walk a lot.

The expansion Dragonspear is quite different, but worth to play, even if it's linear.

In overall, I think every new fan should give a try to this game.

A classic old school CRPG updated for modern machines. A great story done by Bioware a great remaster done by Beamdog. Just an all round great game. The second edition AD&D rules are a little dated now and there is no speed up like in newer games such as Pillars of Eternity but the background art is still amazing and so is the story. If you are a fan of these types of games then this is a must have for your library.

A-grade: Very good old game, not easy or rather too hard at least now, cos, you have so many difficult choices that anyone can make it & enjoy the story. Recommend to look some tips/guide videos, even the game has nice tutorial in it. First time player i recommend normal or easy difficult, with these levels you can changes difficult level at middle of the game, you'll find that in options. Story mode is also there if you just want to enjoy the story and get know familiar with the game, so no matter if you not gonna learn the game well and feel its very difficult for you, you still can enjoy it with these easy and story mode levels. Game uses AD&D 2nd edition rules, but can be played fully even you not got them right every percent, you don't have to hurry either, just go easy and remember Quick save is very important to use it often. I get a very nostalgia feeling with this game from my youth and it was so nice to play it with all those flashbacks. Finally with this BG.EE i got a chance to play this hole story and game through, cos, i never was able to play it back then, i never had the physical game to myself, i played with my friend's place and woo it was good back then, this game is one masterpiece! Well all what has said: Hope this helps & good luck to your adventuring!

I literally cannot complete this game. Which is sad because I am playing on story mode my first time through so I literally cannot die. No the problem comes when I get told to clear Nashkel mine fairly early in the game. Now I went through and thought I cleared the mine, exited out the other side, returned to the foreman, and he acts like the quest is still active. So ok maybe I missed some kobolds somewhere. I go back in and methodically check each level of the mine I find a few stray kobolds and make sure every corner is explored. Nope still can't turn it in. I think "Ok well I should still be able to turn in the main quest to the mayor right?" Nope I return to him and he just reiterates the need to clear out the mine. I don't know if there's some hidden door (because they sometimes blend in a little too well) or if there's just one stray kobold I can't seem to find. But either way I cannot progress in the main story and I frankly was not entertained by the game enough up to that point to waste more time on it.

Ultimately Baldur's Gate is a dated game that uses a frankly dated D&D system. I have no clue what a THACO is in my stats. I have no clue why they made interactable doors and chests glow but other transitional zones don't especially when they look like every other generic set dressing. I'm hoping future entries are a little more streamlined and polished than this one was if and when I decide to try the franchise again.

Classic dungeon crawler. This was the first RPG I ever played as a young child. As much as I enjoyed it back then, I never got very far because I didn't quite understand how to play the game. This isn't your typical hack and slash dungeon crawler. This game requires a lot more strategy and involvement. I enjoy it even more now that I am grown up and understand how to play. 

Would recommend Baldur's Gate to anyone in to old school RPGS that aren't afraid of a game that requires strategy and commitment.

Honestly I'm really surprised how sub par this game is, the combat is boring and repetitive, there are multiple systems in the game that serve no purpose (rumors, church donations), resting is an extremely annoying mechanic, wizards are entirely underpowered and unfun to play (only able to cast a couple spells a day) and overall the game just feels extremely boring. The good of it is the art and the graphics which are still quite beautiful but the characters are all one note and uninteresting and the story isn't much better.

the predecessor to all Western RPGs and a true DnD experience. the graphics are bad, the gameplay is primitive, its based on archaic 2nd edition DnD rules, and it can be brutally difficult but its a challenge that all RPG and DnD fans should know. it was my first DnD game and it set the tone for all other "true" RPGs that i would ever play. 

except on the highest difficulty. do not play the highest difficulty without console command mods. it is not fun and it is not worth your time or the Steam cred. i just finished the game on the highest difficulty immediately prior to writing this and i will never do so again. just as you should do never. i am writing this review *specifically* because of how unfun and tedious the LoB difficulty is, despite the game being otherwise challenging. 

the highest difficulty goes beyond a challenge and makes the game unplayable. entry level enemies that have 80 hp and can one shot your most powerful fighter at lower levels. a single lightening bolt trap can wipe out an entire party at lvl 12. do not play this game on the highest difficulty without mods that allow you to instantly heal or kill at your will. i would usually feel bad for cheating the "challenge" but this was no challenge, it was a stupidly balanced setting and it should have never existed. 

just to be clear, i am a freakn master of this game, i've been playing it for almost 20 years.  i had a meme team of demi-gods with maxed out stats, all at lvl 10-12, which is 2-3 levels higher than the level cap.  i spent months building this team. the 4 melee's all had over 150 hp, which is a freakn lot, and they had grandmastery in all their preferred weapons. it *still* took me 15-20 seconds to clear a group of kobolds or gnolls. oh? did you take a bunch of damage spells with your spellcasters? lol jokes on you bruh cuz ur finna sling about 5-6 Fireballs at a group of Kobolds to kill em. 

they could have easily just jacked up the damage and AI without turning *everything* into a damage sponge. 

aside from that, if you love DnD then you owe it to yourself to complete this game on the base setting, AD&D core rules, and perhaps even the 2nd highest difficulty if the final battle doesn't scare you away from the game forever.

After playing through what must be my 4th character, and my second completion of Siege of Dragonspear, I am thoroughly sick of this game, but my inability (or unwillingness) to play it again does not come from the game's lack of charm, diverse characters, or mechanics, in fact, it's quite the contrary. I have made it a goal to do all there is to be done, and after my most recent playthrough, I think that I can confidently say that I can address a quarter of what this game has to offer. 

The story itself (not including its sequel ), is pretty decent throughout, but I think where this game shines is its ending. But I must admit, that the Enhanced Edition cutscenes do not portray the story nearly as well as the original (which I have never played), so I would ask you to look up the original cutscenes to truly get the best story experience, as I think it makes major plot points more clear. 

The classes are fun, diverse, and interesting, although I would have liked to see more balancing with some of the subclasses. In theory they are awesome concepts, but in use, they are underwhelming and underpowered (ex: the Shapeshifter is great example of this). 

The combat and mechanics hold up relatively well today, in fact, there is a reason why many other similar games use this very same system, it works. The game itself can be a little overwhelming at first, but where the game truly shines is its subsequent playthroughs where you can explore and experiment once you have gotten use to the tricks and niches this game plays to. 

I haven't experienced any game breaking bugs or what not, in fact, the only problem I had was a reforming party screen carry over through saves, but was quickly fixed by restarting the game. 

8/10 - Probably should gather your party before venturing forth and stop buying that dollar store iron.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

If you like D&D, then you will like Baldur's Gate.

An absolute classic, with some nice quality-of-life enhancements.

Though the NPC companions add plenty of character to your game, sometimes you just want to roll with your own crew. In older versions of BG, that was theoretically possible, but very difficult to actually make work. Here, it's as easy as creating a character. I've made the Companions of the Hall, Edificant/Spirit Soaring crew (post Castle Trinity, pre Rufo) (albeit not accurate, since Cadderly can't use crossbows, and Pikel can't be a druid), as well as groups of some of my Neverwinter Nights characters.

The addition of half-orcs is also a great improvement. And the addition of Neera (powerful but unpredictable magic) nicely fills the gap between Edwin (best mage, but evil and rather nasty) and Dynaheir (good, but kinda sucks).

This is probably the best RPG of all time- in my opinion. I prefer SOA and TOB but this original game has given men a lot of enjoyment

Classic DnD experience and one of the best RPGs I've ever played. I have finished 2 campaigns - Baldur's Gate and Siege of Dragonspear. The story is very interesting, i just couldn't stop playing, I wanted to know what's gonna happen. There are many companions so you can easily choose who suits your party better. They have their own stories and quests so you can know them better. There is a lot to explore, the world is big and filled with side quests (they are not repetitive), secrets and traps of course. You have a lot of freedom and in many situations you have to make a choice (you have to choose 1 of 2 options and it's good/bad most of the time). So you can play a good character and help the others or be a villain and steal stuff, kill people etc. The game is hard, i played on core rules and died a lot, like A LOT. It's kinda easy to get stucked on a hard boss fight and you can try several times or comeback later. I actually learned to make a quicksave every few steps. The combat is meh, i don't like it that much and playing mage is a nightmare escpecially on low lvls but it's getting better tho and in Dragonspear it felt really good. The game is old so of course it doesn't look amazing but graphics aren't that bad and it didn't bother me.
I like old games and i just love good stories so i really enjoyed this game but i think it's not for everyone. So if u also like old games and great storylines you will have good time with this one.

Baldur's Gate was the game that put BioWare on the map, and although most of the studio's trademarks aren't quite here yet, this is a really cool game for its own reasons. This is a game premised on recreating the experience of low-level Dungeons & Dragons, and it really commits to that part; The stakes are low for most of the game, more dangerous monsters like dragons and beholders are nowhere to be seen, and the player probably won't even reach level 10. It also emphasizes freedom to explore with a large number of maps to roam around freely, even in the early game, and you have plenty of sidequests to find. Although your companions aren't particularly complex, they all fit well into broad D&D archetypes and there's no shortage of options. The one thing that will probably be a sticking point for a lot of new players is the fact that the mechanics are based on second edition Advanced Dungeons & Dragons, and as such, they can be confusing or even unfair. There are plenty of difficulty options to remedy this, though, including a trivially easy "story mode" setting.

Baldur's Gate was a landmark in its genre, and I think it still holds up with its focus on recreating the early parts of a tabletop campaign.

I have done a single playthrough. I'd never played this game before a month ago, so this was a fresh game for me. After 26 years, it holds up. I understand this is a remaster of sorts, with some mechanical changes imported from Baldur's gate 2. Like I said, I never knew the original. Lots of replayability options with this game. The classes are pretty expansive, the magic system has depth, the stories are fun. Many, if not all, quests have varied endings. Choices matter to a surprising degree. You'll trip over the number of companions you find, and that's on top of being able to custom make a party of 6 yourself. It's filled with charm and character, much like Witcher 3 now that I think about it. There's adventure on every tile, and behind most doors. Literally, just start opening doors. After checking for traps of course. Quests abound, and if you get dialogue options it's best to assume your affecting one. It's old school DnD, so less forgiving. Combat might take some getting used to, I played on Core Rules. That said, I look forward to higher difficulties. 

Tips: The highest roll for character creation is 108. If you get 85 you're good. An even spread of stats is not rewarded. Pick 1 to 2 stats to put at rock bottom, pump other stats.

An absolutely legendary RPG. Baldur's Gate is the beginning of one of the most underrated series in all of gaming history.

THE GOOD:

- Loads of options for character creation that vastly changes your playstyle on repeat playthroughs.
- Plays just like classic D&D, except it's much more fluid and combats don't (always) take 2 to 3 hours.
- A wealth of charming characters and party members all around. Yes, INCLUDING the Enhanced Edition characters: they aren't nearly as bad as all the boomers make them out to be. They blend into the game extremely well.
- Getting lost and running around the map on a looting frenzy is pure bliss.
- The music and sound effects, while obviously a product of their time, still hold up well to this day.
- The game's real-time combat is very well handled. Being able to stop time and micromanage your moves whenever and however much you want is very handy and satisfying.
- Finally, the story. Wow. This is without a doubt my favorite story in any RPG game. The main plot is simple but takes some really creative directions, party members have awesome stories that start here and carry over into the sequel, lots of fun sidequests to follow, and the interlude, Siege of Dragonspear, was actually one of the highlights of my playthrough. Baldur's Gate has all the energy and joy of a tabletop romp with your friends, except the story is all just for you. This is undoubtedly the star aspect of the game.

THE BAD:

- Some of the old voice acting is kinda cringy.
- Damn, 2nd Edition rules are confusing as hell and make my eyes bleed.
- In true D&D tradition, Wizards and Sorcerers are the best classes in the game, but are complete garbage for the first 5 to 8 levels. The maximum level in Baldur's Gate 1 is level 9. If you want to play a mage, you will have to survive the entire first game being carried by your party before you can unleash pure carnage upon the Sword Coast in the sequel.
- Stealth can be really finnicky and hard to understand at first.
- There are some pretty extreme spikes in difficulty in this game. Make sure you save often, and if you get stuck don't be afraid to go do something else for a bit.

ADVICE FOR NEW PLAYERS:

- Don't be afraid to play a mage; you can definitely still contribute to your team, just be aware of the risks.
- Don't listen to all the yammering minmaxers online; unless you're doing a solo + hardest difficulty run, basically every class is viable in some way or another.
- Playing an Evil character with an Evil party is really fun, but be aware that it makes the game harder.

I'm going to give two partial reviews I read from another gaming site because they said it well. Crewman06 stated: "I purchased the original game before the company of the "enhanced" edition took part in taking down the original to sell this. The game adds new content which takes away from the hard work that the original company put into their game, the essence of the original is twisted and ultimately lost. The hard work put into the original is what made the game great. the new content feels like someone's poor attempt at writing themselves into a great story, with little effort and understanding of what made the original story great, while forcing their views and values upon future readers and, taking credit for the whole thing... No, just no. "
While DKapple's post had a nifty title I think should be re-stated; Avoid Beamdog products at all costs. "I rushed out and bought the "enhanced" versions of these same games without doing my due diligence, and so I refuse to believe that that 4 star rating is an actual representation of player satisfaction with the "enhanced" version of the games. "Enhanced" -- it turns out -- doesn't mean "patched to fix bugs" or "updated to run on modern machines" -- it also apparently means "bland graphics and shoe-horning in characters and writing that never existed in the original games and were never meant tod". Couple that with the fact that you must now buy the bundle just to get the original, and the whole thing is a deal breaker for me. 
I agree. I screwed up too. Say no to the enhanced versions of any game before investigating properly into what "enhanced" really means.

299 days later (ingame days, although it sure felt like real ones), Baldur's Gate finally lays beaten!  I tried a great many times to get through it over the decades, but I alius get bored of its big empty world and dull gameplay eventually.  Well, this time thanks to the Enhanced Edition and its much needed QoL updates (mostly highlighting interactable objects so you don't have to painstakingly hover over everything as if this was a darn point & click game), I finally managed to slog through it.. although it was still not a great experience

Seems to me you just spend most of yer time waiting for yer characters to slowly move from point A to point B, once in a while getting distracted by a pack of weak mobs that get demolished within a second or two, even on the (second) highest difficulty.  There's absolutely no challenge, no thinking or strategy needed (except for two battles.. the superboss and the final boss, and said strategy only consists of casting buffs, drinking a few potions, and moving back to a strategic position).  There's no puzzles, the maps are bland and boring to explore, every indoor area is recycled to shit and mostly pointless, there's not really any story to speak of, and what little there is of it is told poorly and inconsistently

Overall, the "game that revived and saved DnD, and created its own genre of classic RPGs" is, imo, the dullest and most overrated DnD game there is.  Before I move on to a non-BioWare CRPG to see if it's the genre or the company that's the problem, I guess I'll play through the new fanmade-but-totally-official Siege of Dragonspear xpac, just incase I stick around long enough to play BG2 someday.  Will edit my review accordingly, once I'm done

Baldur's Gate is the classic CRPG that started it all (Probably) and it's stellar sound track, story and characters will never be forgotten. The Enhanced Edition simply brings it to modern pc's with minor graphical tweaks, enhanced resolutions and combines the original baldur's gate with the must have Baldur's gate Tutu mode of old. It basically makes the game run on the Baldur's Gate 2 engine with all the updated classes, kits, weapon skills, updated spells and what not. Just now you don't have to mess around with disk swapping, modding and multiple levels of installs! 

Along with those tweaks they also added 4 new characters who can join your party to fill out the new kits added in Baldur's Gate 2: A Blackguard (Not an actual kit sadly) , a Wild Mage, a Sorcerer and a Monk. All of but one of which have a quest for you to go on, new weapons and armor to find and brand new fully voiced dialogue, most of which fits in pretty well with the original audio quality from 1998 lol. And if your a purist, don't worry, you can completely ignore them or kill some of them on sight and just be done with them lol.

As an added bonus included with the game is a new mode called "The Black Pitts" , an arena mode where you make a party of up to 6 custom characters and fight 15 battles for a psychotic and charismatic Drow arena master by the name of Baeloth! His voice acting is fantastic and stands out among the new content. It's fun, short and lets you easily build up a custom party of adventurers you can take back into the main game, or just goof around with. Very fun, absolutely recommend you check it out as a fun bonus!

All in all Baldur's Gate Enhanced Edition is an amazing package of a game with tons of content, memorable characters, great voice acting, outstanding music and I cannot recommend it enough! And after your done here there's also a new expansion for the game called Siege of Dragonspear and the much superior sequel Baldur's Gate 2! Which has also got the enhanced edition treatment! And don't forget Icewind Dale Enhanced Edition for ever more of the same! Get out there and play them all!

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] Interesting story & characters, 
[*] Deep mechanics [i](even with the dated D&D 2nd Ed ruleset)[/i]
[*] Fun combat [i](tactical, real time with pause),[/i] 
[*] "Painting" environments [i](character models/sprites are dated)[/i]
[*] Amazing & Nostalgic Music and Voice / Sound Effects
[*] From 0 to Hero progression
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] Some random "oldschool" [i](dated/anoying)[/i] mechanics
[*] Inventory Management can be a chore sometimes [i](moving/stacking items around) [/i]
[*] Slow Character Movement [i](locked at 30 fps - you can increase it up to 60fps on the .lua file under Documents/BG, value after "Maximum Frame Rate" - this may somewhat clip the in-engine "cutscenes", since everything hapens faster, but dialogue remains the same speed - i recommend 45fps)[/i]
[/list]

Enhanced Edition includes lots of mods (resolution, ui, etc), bug fixes and some pretty good new content (party members, items, locations).

I've played this game and its sequels off and on for over 20 years. I still love it to this day. The story is compelling in a way that all the CRPG's I've played since haven't been. The mechanics are a bit dated, but I enjoy them. The graphics are also still a bit dated, but I still enjoy them. The music and dialogue and voice-acting are top notch.

I only with the game would get a full and true visual remaster and completely updated cinematics one day.

A completionist's hell: there's too much to do, too many options. I know I haven't put that many hours into this- but I'm already getting FOMO from meeting so many potential companions. This game could probably be played a hundred or more times without having the same experience. That's a little stressful. 

This is obviously a classic- it inspired many of the other games I play. It's a good early attempt to translate TTRPGs into video game form. I think there have been some serious improvements over the years though. The game kind of relies on the player already understanding the math of TTRPG dice. I don't actually play TTRPGs, so telling me a sword hits with a certain dice roll doesn't help me figure out if the sword is good. D&D alignment systems have never made much sense to me either (neutral vs. chaotic, good vs. neutral seem very subjective). I got the fallen ranger achievement accidentally, I don't even know what I did that was wrong. I know being a murder-hobo would make me chaotic evil, but lawful alignments depend on me personally finding a law un/just. Sorry for getting philosophical in a game review.

I've just finished my first playthrough of this gem and I'm already planning for my next run to use even more disgusting, exploitative cheese.
