This is a great RPG and well worth the time to play it at least once. My time of 70 hours reflects a VERY thorough initial playthrough, and I still feel like there is enough left undone to make subsequent playthroughs just as exciting. 

The game has aged well and it is quite easy for modern players to quickly become comfortable with the systems it uses. There is a wide variety of abilities at the player's disposal, and gathering information, scouting, and changing my skills to suit upcoming challenges was an absolute joy.

I highly recommend this game and encourage players to avoid any and all spoilers until they have played it at least once. The story is fantastic, and anticipating "what comes next" was a good part of my experience playing.

I played this game when it first came out on discs and I loved it then, and still play it to this day! I have closer to 600 hours on this game. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes D&D, Magic the Gathering, or any games with spells, monsters and heroes. Rolling characters was one of my favorite things about this game! You can roll a 90+ character and have such great stats at the beginning. You loot magical items and recruit more party members to slay monsters. You can create a stacked 6 person party, or just start with one character and fill up your party as you go or just solo the game. It has many difficulties as well so you can learn to play on normal or core and work your way up from there. It even has a story mode if you just want to auto-pilot while you play. Overall give this game a 10/10.
This is a game that requires a grind of time to defeat, but definitely worth the time.  Save Early and Save Often.  Fall in love with the characters and play thru as different classes :-)

100% recommended. Great value for your money.

If you want to know more details, here is my Baldur’s Gate: Enhanced Edition video review:

[h1] Classic Dungeons and Dragons Adventures in the Forgotten Realms [/h1]

After 150 hours of adventuring the Sword Coast, I feel like my adventure has come to an end. I thoroughly enjoyed my time exploring the hand-painted maps, discovering hidden artifacts of power, facing orcs, goblins, gnolls, dragons and so many other creatures. The dialogue, the books, and the music kept me engaged as I gained experience and together with my friends, defeated the evil threatening Faerun. It was really fun to cast spells, disarm traps, unlock chests, and crush my enemies. Party management and combat strategy opportunities made this game really fun to play. It brought me back to my teenage years as I played D&D with my hometown friends.

The Dragonspear expansion is also really fun and adds valuable content to the game.

*****THERE IS A NEW EDIT AT THE BOTTOM*****

I am posting this on both the review for this game, and the first in the series, Baldur's Gate: Enhanced edition.

I absolutely LOVE this game, and everything about it, and the other game in the series. I loved the combat, the UI was tight, everything was well-polished when Beamdog re-released the game. I was actually in the middle of a run through the entire game on the hardest difficulty with only the main character...

Before IT happened.

The update to Siege of Dragonspear affected both games, and it's been nothing but negative for me so far. I can no longer access the Command Console (used for fixing the many glitches that can happen here and there), the UI is buggy and, when it does work, is clunky and, frankly, ugly as sin itself. My saves have all disappeared into the wind, and my character's data has become ridiculously bugged (Level 34 at the tail end of Throne of Bhaal suddenly turning into a level 17 with all of the items from her run through BG1 and 2? What?) and more. 

Before now, I would have recommended this series in a heartbeat. This game, nearly two decades ago, defined and revived a dying RPG era. But now? Now it's nearly impossible to play. And, unfortunately, it was the fault of the people who brought it back in the first place.

--HOW BEAMDOG CAN FIX THIS--

-Implementation of the old character and save game formatting
-Option to use the old UI
-Option to turn the Console Command on and off IN GAME. The steps to do this in the first place were a nightmare in and of itself.

--Things that COULD help--
- Scale the difficulty levels back down a little. Insane difficulty jumped from enemies doing 50% more damage to 100%, and Legacy of Bhaal makes the game nearly unplayable.


As it stands right now? DO. NOT. BUY. THIS. GAME. It pains me to say that (as you can no doubt see from my time in this game), but as it is right now, it's not worth any money.

*****EDIT 7/2/2022*****

It's been a long time since my initial review after the Siege of Dragonspear update. While I can say that the DLC is still very much not worth your money for what it is, I can say for certain that, as I have said in a comment below, it has gotten much better. Settings were introduced and added that allow you to play the game with as close to its classic UI as possible with a few added bells and whistles. I'm going to leave this review up for the most part. Enjoy!

Oldest RPG I have ever played. There is bunch of content here, but at same time you can feel old age in this game. Would say that it has aged as gracefully as it can, but there things sticking out as a sore thumb.
Used program to roll stats (human paladin), Core Rules difficulty, played with full party (mostly didnt cheese), did Tales Of The Sword Coast expansion (didnt do Black Pits or newest DLC), use of wiki was limited (mostly for checking which companions should pick).
Will continue with Baldurs Gate 2.

PROS:
+ Bunch of spells to learn and use
+ Can play solo or in party
+ Bunch of items to find and exploit/sell
+ Interesting quests/encounters (many interesting moments)
+ The land and Baldurs Gate feels big
+ Dungeon design is very good
+ Combat generally is challenging (as long as you dont cheese or arent going to a lot lower level zones - there isnt any kind of enemy scaling in the game)
+ Feels rewarding to master the system (still feel as beginner, even though managed to beat the game)

CONS:
- No bank, mostly store spare equipment in barrels/boxes
- Graphics (the quality is the problem not aesthetics/style, but this is an old game)
- Easy to miss content (need to check all nooks and crannies)
- You will die a lot
- Incompatible companions will kill each other or leave party
- Too high or low reputation will make specific companions leave
- Disbanding companion most of the time will make them stay in the same place (RIP Faldron, your fault for not running out of flooded mine)
- No indicator for size of AOE spells/effects
- Movement for full party can be clunky (blocking each others movement)

+/- Bunch of companions (some come in pairs), basically impossible to see everything in one playthrough
+/- If you know then many ways how to cheese system

Summary:
If you dont have any more modern RPG you want to play OR if you want to know from where many modern RPG game decision took place (or at least got inspired from) OR if you just a big DnD fan (who is interested in older systems) then I suggest this game. Game is solid, but you can feel age on it.

Will Rate:
You must gather your party before venturing forth out of 10

Baldur's Gate 1 is a hard game for me to reccomend but at the same time this game is a masterpiece of its time and it should be played by pretty much any western rpg fanatic.
The story is... flawed, the first 5 chapters pretty much just boil down to "now you must fight the bigger bad" repeated like 6 times in a row until you get to the city of baldur's gate and most of the characters outside of Sarevok (the main villain) are incredibly shallow and uninteresting, even your companions barely have any dialogue most of it being their introductory dialogue, banter while you explore and their combat lines, there are exceptions such as Minsc who is a lovable goofball but they are that, exceptions.
The story, at least for me, fails to intrigue due to a lack of interesting characters and a very weak first 5 chapters as so much of it can be boiled down to "you kill the bad guy who tells you hes working for another bad guy who you kill but you learn he was working for a bigger bad guy who is actually also working for a bigger bad guy" it gets quite repetitive and the story feels like its at a standstill until you get to Baldur's Gate at which point the story improves drastically.
This game is frustrating, clunky and you have to learn an edition of Dungeons & Dragons that hasnt been in use for like 20 years just to know what THAC0 is, all of this while youre trying to learn the basics of combat, spell use and a solid party composition or why the fuck 3 of your longswords broke in the same fight against 5 hobgoblins. Its going to be overwhelming for a new player without a guide.
Once you finally understand how to play the game well this game becomes genuinely very fun to play and steamrolling through the game on a second playthrough thanks to all the knowledge you gained from that first playthrough is very cathartic.

TL;DR: Baldur's Gate 1 is a clunky, outdated game that is very hard to get into as someone that just didnt play it when it came out or hasnt played many games from that era of gaming and also has a story that i dont consider to be very good for the first 5 chapters but it was a revolutionary game that changed the landscape for western rpgs to come and its a very important game for that alone.
Is the game worth playing? Kinda, as a casual gamer that just wants to find something nice they can jump into and just play for the story, no, its gonna be painful and unfun. 
As an rpg fan that wants to experience a relic of its time that while clunky helped pave the way for many games to come, many of them being incredibly popular franchises and games such as Dragon Age, Mass Effect, Kotor and many others, yeah, i'd say its more than worth giving a shot, you might find something you really like.

Classic RPG from the 2nd Edition days of Dungeons and Dragons (AD&D). Takes a minute to learn all the mechanics and the older-style UI. The game puts some roadblocks on you and expects you to "earn" the right to progress, and bets on you having nothing better to do in your life to push on through, maybe it worked in 1998 but go get a better game.

You'll see that most strategies rely on cheesing more than taking foes head on, which is testament of how the game is appreciated by those who "appreciate the genre" 
All in all i rate it a sunk cost fallacy out of 10

[h1][b]Review of:[/b] [i]Baldur’s Gate: Enhanced Edition[/i][/h1]

[h2][i]Camaraderie, adventure, and steel on steel. The stuff of legend! Right, Boo?[/i] ~Minsc[/h2]

[i]Baldur’s Gate[/i] returns as [i]Enhanced Edition[/i] and brings some sweet new features to the table as well as definitely makes it more convenient to play, especially for newcomers. The original game was developed by BioWare and released by Interplay Entertainment in 1998, whereas the remastered version was done and released by Beamdog in 2012. 

[i]Baldur’s Gate[/i] is a good old classic isometric CRPG based on the 2nd edition of [i]Advanced Dungeons & Dragons[/i], which is heavily related to rules of the ‘90s tabletop roleplaying games. Well, the main difference is that you don’t throw dice here, simply because the game does it automatically, besides it’s conducted in real-time with an option to pause whenever you like. Anyway, despite being old, [i]Baldur’s Gate[/i] looks genuinely decent even after all these years, mostly due to its unique 2D graphics generated by Infinity Engine. Not to mention the atmospheric soundtrack composed by Michael Hoenig and amazing storyline.

When it comes to the storyline, to put it briefly without going into details, [i]Baldur’s Gate[/i] takes place in Forgotten Realms, which is a high fantasy setting. The prologue starts in an ancient library fortress Candlekeep and serves as a tutorial. Well, as it quickly turns out, the protagonist has to immediately leave this place along with his foster father Gorion. However,  as soon as they walk past the safe walls of their home, things get complicated. The story unfolds step by step, as the hero progressively is being thrust into the world at the brink of war and chaos, with countless monsters, bandits and assassins hired to take his head. Eventually, it all leads to discovering an intricate plot developed by an evil mastermind, as well as learning the origins of the protagonist’s sinister heritage.

Alright, but what’s new about [i]Enhanced Edition[/i] and what’s been changed to make good ol' [i]Baldur’s Gate[/i] worthwhile for both veterans and new players? Well, first of all, the original expansion [i]Tales of the Sword Coast[/i] is now an integral part of the game. Furthermore, there are a lot of bug fixes and overall improvements, including a new interface with high resolution widescreen support as well as cross-platform multiplayer option. However, most importantly, what makes [i]Enhanced Edition[/i] worthy of your time, are the new features related strictly to the gameplay - this is where the remastered version shines, especially after comparing it to the original. Well, at the very first glance you can see that old cinematics have been replaced by new cutscenes in hand-painted style, all directed by Nat Jones. Besides, during the character creation process, you’ll notice new portraits and voices, not to mention the variety of colours to customise appearance of the protagonist. Speaking of which, now you can choose from a few additional classes for your hero, whereas the original ones already have their respective kits. Another significant novelty is the Story Mode difficulty level, which is just perfect for new players, simply because it works as a sort of "god mode". Apart from that, Beamdog changed sprites of many items, reorganised journal and character record tabs as well as added really useful mechanics such as highlighting objects and containers, quick looting and screen zooming. Also, now the game pauses whenever you open the inventory tab, which is a huge relief. Surprised? Well, in the original [i]Baldur's Gate[/i] if you opened up your inventory during a fight, everything was still in motion. Finally, it’s worth mentioning that now, when you travel between locations, loading screens appear no longer.

Ok, now about the controversial part - [i]Enhanced Edition[/i] introduces four new playable characters and three of them have their own unique questlines with a few new tracks composed by Sam Hulick. The only problem is they stand out from the rest of the recruitable companions way too much with their dialogues and classes, however, they’re rather solid in general. Well, at least those unique quests yield some useful items. Oh, I almost forgot about [i]The Black Pits[/i], which is a sort of separate adventure with arena battles. Yeah, I almost forgot to write about it simply because it’s mediocre at the utmost.

All in all, [i]Baldur’s Gate: Enhanced Edition[/i] is a well-made, solid remaster of a legendary, classic cRPG that was a worldwide bestseller at its time. [i]Enhanced Edition[/i] gives a second life to one of my personal favourite games and I simply can’t say no to Imoen, Jaheira, Khalid, Dynaheir and, of course, Minsc and Boo. So, in the end, 9/10 would gather my party again. And, lastly, thanks for reading my review.

A fun game if never played before and some nice enhancements for those that have.  The maps have more information, looting is way easier, you can copy notes and discard them (once quests are done), and the AI is very good if you choose to use it.  The bad thing is it goes through spells, potions and fast key scrolls and wands at a really fast clip which diminishes your supplies early, the good thing is it goes through spells, potions and fast key scrolls and wands at a really fast clip which gives you optimum chance for success.  A few places I struggled a bit I decided to let AI try and it got me through.
Anyway, it's a fun turn-based party build which is fairly easy to progress as long as you save often and use the space bar to pause and think and plan properly.

So, i remember playing this when I was about 9 and it blew my mind, now, revisiting it, i realise i didn't even appreciate the depths of attention paid to every single event, area, items or NPC. Nor did I appreciate the subtle yet overwhelming information provided by each item, contributing to the overall lore, that tells multiple stories about nobles, monsters, towns and history if you just pay the slightest amount of attention. 
This game truly spoiled me as it was quite far ahead of its time. It set a rather unfair precedent for other adventure/fantasy/DnD games to follow, as the devs were obsessed with DnD prior to creating this and the main dev had read every single printed book, magazine or general information about Faerûn and put all of that knowledge into making the perfect game.

Each area has side quests, both self contained and far reaching, seemingly random events, absolutely brilliant background art that even to this day has never really been reached in both quality and detail and most areas are used in the main quest too. 

Each magical item has a backstory, some unrelated to anything to do with your adventure and some only seemingly unrelated, yet brilliantly injected with information one might find useful and fascinating. 

You'll start on an adventure after witnessing your foster fathers death, seeking aid from his friends that will lead you to a country wide iron shortage, orchestrated by a corrupt merchant guild, yet somehow seemingly intertwining with your own personal journey 

This game was always intended to have a sequel and you'll find yourself level capping at 9 (higher with patches) but that was always intended to be half of the journey.

All in all this game still holds up in every way, even the graphics are beautiful to this day.

Before I get absolutely flamed, let me just say that I really do respect this game. It's one of the classics, and it was revolutionary for its time. The key phrase being: "For its time." As someone who didn't grow up with this game, I found it to be a frustrating, clunky experience that I would not recommend. 

The game runs on very old school D&D rules, which are very restrictive. When I won a tough fight, I never felt like I won due to any strategic planning on my part, it was all just a roll of the dice. Characters die at the drop of a hat, and there's nothing you can do to get an edge in combat, other than re-loading your save every two seconds and praying the gods rule in your favour. 

Maybe back in the 90's, this game was a masterpiece. But when compared to contemporaries like Pillars of Eternity and Divinity, it just doesn't hold up. If you're REALLY curious about experiencing a piece of history, then pick it up. If not, then give it a pass.

Loved BG when it came out. Picked it up for the chance to play multi-player with a friend. The hideously unreliable multiplayer in this title prevents this. Constant disconnections with the multi-player make it an exercise in frustration. Single player works well. The enhanced edition does make the title playable on a modern system. 

Sadly, a single-player experience was not why I purchased the title. Issues ongoing and reported to the developer since 2013 remain in the game. Those issues reported again in 2016 remain in the game. Yet again, reported in 2021... and they remain in the game.

I've tried using the built in connection tool. Kicks players out shortly after logging in.
I've tried a VPN and direct connect (LogMeIn). Kicks players out shortly after logging in.

So, no. I do not recommend the title for anyone wanting a multiplayer experience with other players.
As a single player experience, sure. Great game.

One of my favourite games from when I was a kid. The story, the open world nature of it, trying to explore and understand what was going on... I played through it many times when I was younger, and I had a hankering to do it again. I'm not sure if I've seen all the 'enhancements' so far in this version. There are certainly a few extra NPCs to add to the party, and they've reworked the Inventory interface to make it much clearer what your stats are, and what different equipment does to your stats (young me would have appreciated that as the first time I played it, I had no clue!). They've improved the journal a bit as well, it doesn't look as pretty but it keeps track of your quests in a bit of an easier way. That's a good and a bad thing, as it makes it feel 'gamier' and slightly less immersive, but it is convenient. So I'm on the fence about that change.  

Overall, I always thought that Baldur's Gate 2 really improved on this one in terms of visuals and gameplay. I was kind of hoping that the enhanced edition would make this game feel more like that one. It doesn't quite do that, but there are some improvements, and at the end of the day the original game is just so good that you should play it!

Before there was Skyrim, there was Baldur's Gate...

SHORT REVIEW
Every now and then a game comes along that completely defines (or redefines) a genre of game and Baldur's Gate is one such masterpiece that is one of the most important games of all time as it defined the cRPG genre.

PLOT:  Good but not exceptional.

COMBAT:  Game uses AD&D 2nd Edition rules set.

GRAPHICS & SOUND:  Adequate but dated.  There is no getting away from the fact that this is based on a 20+ year old game.

REPLAY VALUE:  Excellent ,may different companions and side quests.

ISSUES AND BUGS:  None.  Works “straight out of the box” with no messing around and appears to be completely bug free!  In over 130 hours of game play I have yet to have a single issue.

ACHIEVEMENTS AND TRADING CARDS:  Steam achievements and trading cards for those interested.  There is an awful lot of achievements in this game (129 in total).  Many require the Siege of Dragonspear DLC to complete.

VALUE FOR MONEY:  The base game isn't too bad but by the time Siege of Dragonspear is added it gets a bit pricey.  Look out for bundles and offers in sales.

LONG REVIEW
Every now and then a game comes along that completely defines (or redefines) a genre of game and Baldur's Gate is one such masterpiece that is one of the most important games of all time.  Yes, it is is 20+ years old and does show it's age but this is the game which defined the cRPG genre.  I also accept that it since been surpassed by Baldur's Gate 2, Planescape Torment (still the best cRPG of all time in my opinion) and more recently the Dragon Age, Pillars of Eternity and Divinity series of games but it is definitely still worth playing whether it is your first time or you are returning to the game having played the original.

There is a good amount of content here.

BALDUR'S GATE.
The original Baldur's Gate gate game but updated the the Baldur's Gate 2 engine and numerous bug fixes (mainly to the background mechanics of the game).

TALES OF THE SWORD COAST.
The original expansion to  Baldur's Gate. Again  updated the the Baldur's Gate 2 engine and debugged.

SIEGE OF DRAGONSPEAR.
This is a separate DLC and not part of the base game.  It does offer genuinely new content (a bolt on adventure) that can be played as a follow on after the main game is completed or as a stand alone game.

THE BLACK PITS.
An arena style combat game.  No further comments as its not really my cup of tea.

With Pillars of Eternity and Torment: Tides of Numenera this style of gaming, having fallen out of favour, has made a comeback.  I think this is due to the fact that, whilst graphics moved on and games became more visually appealing the actual gameplay often suffered and there was a whole era of games that looked visually stunning but were real dogs to actually play.  (Whoever thought quick time events were a good idea should have been strangled at birth!).  Although playability is one of the strengths of the game people new to the games (as opposed to old hands returning) might struggle a bit at first picking up the vagaries of the 2nd edition AD&D rules set.

In terms of what the enhanced edition offers over the original other than the ability to run seamlessly on modern hardware and support for modern screen resolutions I'm not sure most of the other added features really add a lot for the game to be honest.  The “auto loot” function is nice and the capacity of containers (gem pouches etc.) has been significantly increased so inventory management is less of a chore.  Personally I couldn't care less about the multiplayer options.

The difficulty curve in spot on with no nasty difficulty “spikes” that some games suffer from.  It may be advisable to go to the end game and face Sarevok before doing the expansion areas accessible from Ulgoth's Beard.  I played the full game including the expansion before facing Sarevok and with the extra equipment and XP found him to be a bit of an anticlimatic walkover.

The game works “straight out of the box” with no messing around with settings and is exceptionally stable.  In over 130 hours of game play I have yet to encounter a single issue.

Extremely buggy, crashes frequently enough that it's unplayable and I played through the original Baldur's Gate back in the day with the bugs back then.  When I say it crashes frequently I mean every 1-2 load screens it locks up and I've never had this much trouble with another game.

One day I started the game and it stopped crashing for a couple days and when I was able to get it run stable I didn't shut it down for fear of it going back to crashing. For two days without shutting the game off and just pausing and alt-tabbing out it ran fine. It seems to be related to auto-save or steam access. I have tried turning off auto-save, cloud saves used offline mode but nothing seems to work. This seems like a very solvable issue but still makes the game very unplayable 90% of the time.

Runs smooth and plays well when it works but it just crashes so frequently it's hard to justify the purchase even at the low price. It's very unfortunate since I loved the original Baldur's gate. Unfortunately the support provided by the company is minimal. You're likely better off with Divinity Original Sin or another RPG that offers some modicum of game stability.glen

Taken at face value, Baldur's Gate is perfectly fine. It's an isometric CRPG adapting the rules of AD&D which allows for an automated dungeon crawl experience. I remember playing it as a kid and it was great then, but that's because it was one of the genre progenitors. Looking at it through the lens of over 20 years of genre evolution has shown how much subsequent titles have raised the bar, despite owing a lot to this one for laying a lot of the groundwork.

For the higher-level RPG aspects such as party members, story, quests, etc., the game is incredibly shallow and unsatisfying. Nearly all quests are returning an item an NPC lost. Party members have very basic introductions, simple quests, and little beyond their introduction and quest dialog, almost never talking beyond their confirmation or selection voice barks. Almost every NPC around the world has little or nothing to say with barely any dialog trees to explore, and an overwhelming majority of those that talk to you have 2 or 3 options that all lead to a fight. The world is devoid of interesting locations or things and even the dungeons are fairly bland.

For the vast majority of the game, however, the combat is what you'll be engaging with, and that's at least the highest point of the game. Throughout the entirety of the genre, I feel that real-time-with-pause is incredibly poor and turn-based combat is irrefutably better. Unfortunately very few of these games offer a choice between them and so here you're stuck with the RTWP option. There's not a lot to it, you click on the enemies and then your characters go to attack them, do so, kill them, and you repeat it for 40 hours. Again, as an early release in the isometric CRPG genre, there's a lot missing that has become standard. Melee characters have little in the way of skills and abilities, instead relying on potions/scrolls to do things for them and then proceeding to swing repeatedly at whatever's in front of them. Even thieves and rangers and anything else you use as ranged is very similarly restricted. Playing as a magic user as the main character, at low levels there are so few spells to use that there are few options for even a caster. It's not bad, but it's not good.

Finally, for the base content, there's the Tales of the Sword Coast expansion content. It's geared towards absolutely high-level parties towards the end game and even then it's almost overtuned. Playing with a high-level thief with dozens of points in trap detection and disarming about half the traps in this content were insurmountable. The enemies and encounters were similarly difficult and occasionally reliant on special damage that was incredibly uncommon to find. Quite honestly if it were possible to remove this content from the game I would have done so. As it is, it's thankfully easy to avoid completely.

Beyond that, the Enhanced Edition has plenty of technical improvements or game updates, some are fantastic, some are horrible. Obviously, the fact that it simply runs on a modern system is a massive positive. It also supports 21:9 resolutions out of the box and everything overall looks sharper. Fixing 20-year-old bugs is also an obvious unquestionable win. The less positive options are the additions. There are new NPC's and their related locations that don't mesh with the game well (at all really), aren't enjoyable in their writing or personality, but thankfully can be avoided almost entirely. The EE also has included some "advanced AI" scripts for party members which I cannot recommend turning off fast enough. All of these scripts cause the AI to attack on sight, often meaning encounters cannot be taken at your pace or by your planning. They also use offensive spells and abilities even on enemies they're not needed for and use defensive spells even outside of combat and far away from an encounter, wasting them for no benefit. There's also the new Black Pits combat-centric content but with my aversion to this genre's (and in particular this game's) real-time-with-pause combat, I cannot recommend it in any capacity.


Overall the original Baldur's Gate is an okay game, but it is nearly impossible to recommend after so many years of advancement in the genre. If you do feel the need to play this title make sure to grab it at a deep discount. Even under the idea of "completionist" or a prelude to the sequel, a one-paragraph summation of this game is all you need before you start Baldur's Gate II: Shadows Of Amn. Having played about three hours of the sequel, even that short introduction makes that title infinitely easier to recommend due to how much further along all aspects of the game have evolved in that short time span.

Baldur's Gate is one of the best CRPG's period, it inspired so many of the new titles we are getting right now and even though it is old and it might have not aged well with all the new systems of recent games being very clear on how they work, Baldur's Gate still shines in its exploration, its story while not being the best is still clear and well thought of, and the quest design and how the things you fight are both from a mechanical aspect and a story aspect mostly fit the level you are in, which some games nowadays can make you fight hydras at level 4 like its not a big deal and you will be mostly fine. the enhanced edition is a fantastic remaster by beamdog adding all the new companions and their story lines with new enemies and even locations. and the DLC that was released with the game back in the day stands the test of time as an actual worth while piece of content. If you really like CRPG's then you gotta give this game a shot, it will probably be tough to swallow but it will be very satisfying once you get a grip on its mechanics.

Game play is.. blah

I should like this game, but its very... I dont know the words to use. 

I have been playing D&D for over 20 years, someone with a THACO of 6 does not miss 4 out of 5 times, and someone with an AC of -7 doesnt get hit 4 out of 5 times. 

The quests are not geared for the correct level, for example I am playing a level 7 fighter and I am put up against 6 to 20 enemies at the same time.. then I wonder why I die a lot. 

The quests are very vague and offer very little guidance as to what you need to do, and a lot of it just seems like your running back and forth constantly instead of being able to just keep moving forward.. 

example QUEST "kill the mage in the temple" [you travel across the world to go kill the mage] QUEST UPDATE "I have killed the mage, now I must go back to Bob and let him know" [travel across the world to tell Bob] QUEST UPDATE "I have told Bob who now wants me to go back to the mage to make sure hes dead [Travel back across the world] QUEST UPDATE "I have verified the mage is dead, now I have to go back to Bob" 

Such a huge waste of time.. On top of that you get all these little quests.. in which you have to battle odds where you are VERY outnumbered and VERY out leveled!! like wizards who just repeatedly cast "confuse" or "fear" that always hit you even though you drink potions that are suppose to prevent it.. I also have party members who, for what ever screwed up reason that I cannot figure out, cannot use their weapons all of a sudden? (Corbin in my game cannot use her bow, no idea why, its equip but I cannot get her to select it.. she has 1 buff on her.. she has arrows and shes not over encumbered..  magic resistance which apparently does NOTHING cause she still gets "confused" or "feared") 

Now, I am sure your gonna get the people on here who say "oh this was so boring, I beat the whole game in 6 minutes and was able to level up with ease and yadda yadda yadda.. I dont understand why I am struggling with this game, but MY game is just plain BS with the impossible odds, the fact that enemy wizards can just cast "Fear" and "confuse" again and again and again and it seems like it take 2 minutes in real time before its gone.. and NOTHING can prevent it.. then they put 30 to 50 enemies on you all at once but dont give you real opportunity to gain the levels necessary to actually be able to fight that many.. I probably wont put much more time into this.. I want something I can actually have a shot at enjoying and I just find myself more confused and pissed off than actually having fun.. Gonna start from scratch one more time, then its getting uninstalled and never looked at again.. games should be fun.. not made to intentionally piss you off due to glitches and impossible odds..

I've been playing NWN online since it came out 20+ years ago.  I suddenly had the urge to play some of the old school single player games from the 80's.  Yes, very different than what you youngsters might be playing but there is just something very attractive and fun about being able to control a party of 6 with summons that don't take up any of those 6 slots.  

You can pick a pre generated party, or roll all new 6 characters for your own party or mix it up.  Also, once you get going in game you can pick up npc characters but you need to drop your own to keep it at 6. Dropped characters from the party remain where you leave them and can be grabbed again later.  I myself rolled 6 of my own characters but then swapped my rogue for lmeon, and npc,  which wasn't bad but wished i had stayed with mine.

I love the fact i can pause at any point i wish other than when aving dialog with NPC's but then it's pretty much paused anyways then.  But to be able to switch up how i am going about a combat situation at any moment is great.

Yes there is alot of side quest but dont kick yourself in the ass trying to complete everyone of them, but i had fun completing most.  It's slow at first, but things pick up once you learn areas and how to handle ceertain creatures.  Save game ALOT so you can come back to a moment earlier than your last death.  Every time i was about to leave an area i save, after a big fight i saved, after moving along a map so far i saved.

Graphics is limited to making character look at you want, but its an old game and for me i was 100% satified with how the over all graphics was for such an old game.  Spells casts look great, can see arrows fly and hit, blood and gore.

Once done with all 3 of these i'll probably do it again with a different character set up and stick to my own all the way thru as much as possible.  If you are in a hurry to lvl and just win, i suggest moving on.  Enjoy the content of the game to get the full feel.

[TL;DR at the bottom]

It has taken me a decade to finally manage a single finished playthrough of roundabout 35-ish hours of this game. With the CRPG genre having experienced a revival as of recent years, beginning with Pillars of Eternity through Disco Elysium and now Pathfinder; Baldur’s Gate still stands out as this juggernaut of a game and while I have never played the original version, I can kind of see where a lot of the nostalgia seems to be coming from, but likewise it’s a pretty rough game compared to what players of modern games of the genre may be used to.

On a technical side, the game ran largely fine. I did not experience any major bugs, glitches or similar. Abilities and whatnot seemed to be working fine as well. Although I did experience two crashes within only a few hours of trying the Multiplayer. There are a plethora of frustrating gameplay quirks too, which may very well be attributed to how old the game is but nevertheless are worth mentioning: Most notably, the horrendous pathing causing parties of any size to regularly get stuck on map geometry. This is particularly an issue on harder difficulties – and also during the later stages of the game, when more precise actions and managing your party is required to overcome harder fights, although given the relatively low level cap of BG 1, this will present a larger critique for Baldur’s Gate 2. 

Aside from that, this Enhanced Edition of the game has been in the center of a fair bit of controversy, ranging from UI changes to the inclusion of new party members that are often mentioned as feeling somewhat out-of-place. While I haven’t bought Siege of Dragonspear, which seems to be generally accepted as the worst offender, I did not feel like this was the case and reasonably enjoyed playing around with E.E. content.

Gameplay-wise, BG doesn’t feel like the hardest game to get into. Despite concepts like THAC0 being often mentioned as roadblocks for new players, BG also makes a solid effort of simplifying your character management – from very simple UI design of color-coding positive/negative changes in your attributes like AC, to managing your different spellbooks; Essentially, BG does not feel any harder to grasp than any of its modern contemporaries. Spells do have a tendency to become fairly complicated in their descriptions but as with the pathing, this does not really become an issue until the very late stages of the game. 

Where BG does feel different, however, is in the way the game’s story is structured; And is likely the biggest factor in the decision of whether it is worth trying today. This is a twofold problem as well: Firstly, BG 1 is not in itself a thoroughly finished story and instead has an open end that directly leads into BG 2. Secondly, the game is incredibly tonally inconsistent. This latter point can be either incredibly charming or immersion breaking depending on your experience with DnD as a tabletop. Without spoiling any specific quests, what BG often does is flip-flop between humorously written sidequests while also trying to lead the player through a campaign that may have them commit mass-murder within the first third of the story. 

This often ends up feeling a little odd, even amateurish from a storytelling perspective, but does capture this very human impression of regular DnD campaigns. Seeing the staff having modeled for the original character portraits, or sneaking in some snarky jokes into the PC’s possible responses and also the voice acting being overly dramatic heavily leans against modern trends of featuring stricter and consistent storytelling. 

This tone, together with comparatively extremely large maps and combat encounters almost on a minute-to-minute basis has the first half of the game, or about twenty-hours of content at times feeling more than an ARPG akin to Diablo rather than what people may have grown to expect from the genre. BG 2 is fairly similar in this, doubling down on earlier and more grandiose dungeon crawls, while also becoming more sophisticated and consistently serious in its writing. 

Another notable difference to both BG 2 and other genre contemporaries is how companions are handled. BG 1 features a fairly large cast of almost thirty characters. Naturally, one result of having such a sizable selection is that this game only features very lukewarm interactions with said characters, like extremely short quests that are often tied to their permanent recruitment / availability, or party banter. However, what is interesting and I have not seen any other game try to thoroughly attempt, is to create cross-companion conflict. Usually these kinds of games tend to tie the contentedness of the PC’s companions only to the player’s own actions – rather than their choice of whom to travel with. Here, however, if you take companions that have personal conflict with one another, either due to their alignment, or actual personality, companions may actively turn on each other. I do like this kind of interaction and coupled with the more in-depth writing of companions in Baldur’s Gate 2, think that it made roleplaying my characters a lot more interesting, albeit also more dependent on my own creativity / head-canon. 

[u]TL;DR[/u]
+ Generally stable; No outstanding bugs, or glitches. 
+ Competent and beginner friendly UI; Although somewhat lacking in in-game help during character creation.
+ Active community; Easy-to-access modding tools.

+/- 30-40 hour long campaign
+/- Pacing may alienate players; Little connection to the larger plot until the last chapters of the game.
+/- Large map design and over-reliance on enemy encounters may make certain stretches of the game a slog and contrast the heavier text-focus during the later chapters.
+/- Cliffhanger ending that requires continued play through Baldur’s Gate 2 and onward to properly appreciate the story.
+/- Companion interactions (Aside from E.E. additions) may feel lackluster under modern RPG expectations.
+/- Tonal inconsistencies that may turn certain players off of the already thinly stretched story.

- Horrendous pathing issues that are exasperated by prominent dungeon-design decisions; i.e. extremely claustrophobic corridors prohibiting proper party control.
- Difficulties in Multiplayer connectivity / crashes.
- Gameplay suffers heavily during the latter stages of the game due to the inability to control the flow of combat over pausing; No distinct overview over turn/round-order;
- Inability to experience the rule of Tiax’s duke of manure as an Ending.

I am not sure whether I enjoyed Baldur’s Gate. It’s certainly a unique experience and it’s worth a playthrough just to see how the CRPG genre has developed, but it’s also an absolute slog to actually play through and I am not willing to believe that this is entirely down to personal preference rather than actual design flaws. Large maps and frequent combat encounters lend the game a Diablo-esque feeling and leans well into the adventuring fantasy of the DnD tabletop. The writing is equally ambitious as it is charmingly stupid; depending on the player to know when to take it seriously and when to just roll with the snappy remarks of a what often feels like a middling DM. Beware that you’re not buying the kind of immersive experience that you may have come to expect from modern titles, and that Baldur’s Gate 1 is not a complete experience without it’s sequel and, with a bit of patience, it can be a pretty good experience even today.

The game itself stems from D&D 2e, so many of the innovations added later, like feats, aren't in the game; so you'll be choosing a main class or maybe one of their subclasses, which are largely divided along racial lines, & mostly be leveling those or multi-classing (with which humans have a special advantage). It also uses THAC0, meaning the LOWER you armor class, the better.
And using this old ruleset also means things will be very difficult, sometimes your characters will get crit-ed & explode into hamburger meat, or get turned to stone, or get hypnotized & attack your other party members; some encounters will be borderline unfair, that'll just be the nature of it.

The story is troupe-y high fantasy, the kind of old fashioned story that I find refreshing compared to modern fair that work hard to "be taken seriously", as if such things are inherently juvenile.
The villain is a towering armored giant covered in ridiculous spikes. There's an ancient prophesy, evil gods, the bad guy shows up to murder your dad. And there's other stuff, like crimes in the region's metal trade and schemes within merchant guilds. Lots of things happen that I won't write out here, but it's solid.

Once you get to the first major area after the start of the game, you're attacked by a wizard assassin. You can't lie about who you are, despite the game pretending you can. Way to go with the "rpg elements", btw. Just like with games today, it's all pretend.
You also can't run away, because he follows you into other areas. There is no warning about him, either. But surely you can defeat him. No, he stops you from being able to control your character and then bursts you down with magic missiles. 

So I looked up how to beat him, because this doesn't seem right.
Well, earlier in the story I met two extremely shifty people who were trying to rope me into some kind of scheme involving a mine. The game threw an NPC at me whose only purpose was to warn me of them, and sure enough, they talked just like snake oil salesmen. 
"Great," I thought. "I mastered that encounter by not falling for it!" Later I learned that the mine was producing bad iron, so I felt confirmed in my suspicions. 
Well, the joke's on me, because you need those two to beat that fight with the assassin!

So, that's Baldur's Gate. A game that throws more and better curve balls than the best pitchers.
Some people might like this kind of absolutely bad design, but I for one am glad we left it in the last century.

The Baldur's Gate games were some of BioWare's earliest triumphs in RPGs. With the upgrades worked into the game by Beamdog, the original Baldur's Gate is well worth a try.

Baldur's Gate is an old game. Beamdog modernized it in several ways, as I understand it, but it's best to go into it with the mindset that it's a game from 1998. The game systems are converted from 2e AD&D, and have plenty of clunk as a result. Dialogue and character choices abound, but what was a staggering ability to change the Realms and companions around you nearly 25 years ago may feel somewhat limiting today. I'd suggest treating the game partially as a sandbox, and to treat the clunky or limiting aspects as prompts- let your imagination fill in the rest.

The story of Baldur's Gate revolves around the ward of a fellow named Gorion. Growing up in Candlekeep, the largest repository of lore on the Sword Coast, their peaceful life is shattered when Gorion tells them to prepare for a journey and leave. Along the Ward's adventure, they'll meet colorful and fleshed-out characters. They'll use their unique abilities to slay monsters, decide the fate of the innocent and guilty alike, and unearth a mystery baked into their very essence. The story is intriguing, and the characters are interactive and well-written. The companion quests are some of the best parts of the game.

The combat is a conversion of 2e AD&D. It's real-time with pause, and the harder fights are going to require some micro-managing of your party (or at least, they did for me). I never found the difficulty in Baldur's Gate 1 to be a roadblock, but I also never engaged with it very heavily. It didn't serve to further the experience for me, but it was inoffensive. If you want to engage with it on a highly strategic level, you'll need an understanding of THAC0 (To-Hit-Armor-Class-Zero), saving throws, and spellcasting. I personally wasn't interested in engaging with the system this way, but the game didn't generally force me to. I played a Half-Orc fighter, which was a highly effective and simple build.

It should be mentioned that your character in Baldur's Gate can be carried onto Baldur's Gate II, and your save information from Baldur's Gate II goes straight into Baldur's Gate: Throne of Bhaal. I actually gave up on my playthrough a short way into Throne of Bhaal, after spending several years with my character going through Baldur's Gate I and II (at a leisurely pace, the games aren't that long). Throne of Bhaal becomes way more combat focused (and way harder), and the story drops in quality bit. In fact, It might be more accurate, actually, to say there was way less story. There was occasional dialogue and cutscenes that seemed designed to ferry me to the next combat encounter  This is due to time constraints when it was developed, if I'm understanding correctly. Regardless, it sucked to suddenly have the difficulty jump so high after 200 hours of playing. Do with that experience as you will.

Beamdog's additions are fantastic, by the way. Neera is a personal favorite, and the added romances really make Baldur's Gate feel lilke a more modern BioWare game.

Personally, my greatest joy in playing Baldur's Gate is taking note of the origins of some of BioWare's games. BioWare games have been favorites of mine since I was a young boy, with KotOR, and I've enjoyed almost everything they've made since. It's an absolute joy to see the origins of KotOR's D&D-inspired mechanics, and Dragon Age and Mass Effect's multi-game world states.

If you're curious about Baldur's Gate, it's worth a try. I'd make sure you buy it on sale, though. It's got a lot of charm, and a lot of intrigue, but even with Beamdog's enhancements, it's a 25 year old series. There's clunk there's issues, and $20 is maybe a little steep. It goes on sale very frequently, though! I'd recommend giving it a try, and seeing how you like it!
As a note, if you like Baldur's Gate, or even if you enjoyed parts of it but had issues with the greater whole, you should try it's modern contemporaries! Pathfinder, Divinity, and the like are all worth looking at. And if Baldur's Gate turns out to be exactly your jam, check out all the rest of the Infinity Engine games!

While not as good as the sequel, this is still one of the best RPGs of all time. Now, some might think that many people feel about BG in this way due to nostalgia or elitism. But here are some arguments why BG is really better than most modern RPGs:

1. BG is based on D&D. Even though more complicated than your usual open world RPG, having a rule system like this is quite rewarding. First, every stat can be calculated easily and nothing is hidden from the player (unlike modern RPGs). So when you fail, you always know WHY you failed. Secondly, the D&D system ads a level of complexity that makes BG worth playing several times. Thirdly, combat allows many tactical possibilities and is quite challenging (unless you use exploits of course)

2. BG does not take you by the hand and still, you always know what you have to do. This is a balance that not many games achieve.

3. The game world is huge. Even though it consist of different maps, the world is interconnected in such a way that it feels like an open world. It gives you a sense of wonder because behind every corner, there could be a new adventure. While modern RPGs get boring very fast by following fixed rules of what you might find at a point of interest (a collectible, a quest, some other repetitive chore), BG manages to surprise you.

3. The story is one of the most epic stories in video game history. The Forgotten Realms setting, while full of cliches, gives a rich lore that fits it perfectly

4. You play with companions. This makes the game more tactical and motivates several playthroughs. Furthermore, the characters are quite likable. 

Unlike the sequel, BG 1 has some flaws: the dialogues are poor. Some of the areas feel quite empty and could have been smaller. Finally, if you are a new player, the game might be too hard. Better watch some tutorials or read a guide before you leave Candlekeep...

Nothing is perfect, so it is said, but this software makes a pretty darn good vanilla game. There's so much love out there for the entire compendium--the number and type of mods is incredible! Beamdog did a great job of breathing the life back into these titles. It was harder to run the old floppy copies in emulators than seemed worth it. if you don't know the Baldur's Gate lineage and you do like isometric-perspective computer RPGs, then I think you'll do yourself a favor by dipping into this library. I played D&D in the 70s but for some reason never played Baldur's Gate.  I am having a lot of fun with it. Very much like the dice based game without the work.  There are UI mods available to make it look more like modern game's cleaner interfaces.  Bought it for $2 during the Winter Sale and have already played more than 30 hours.  Fun game that doesn't require a lot of manual dexterity.  After learning to zoom and pause it is also easy to see for people llike me who have vision impairments or low vision.

The difficulty settings are a bit misleading.  The "normal" mode does not follow some D&D rules.  I like the fact that if my main character dies it cam be resurrected, but if you are going old school all the way you want to set the difficulty one notch higher than normal.  Be aware that this is a great way to kill all caster when you first start out.

Let's face it, it was a groundbreaking game when it came out but it hasn't aged well. I wouldn't recommend it unless you are a CRPG geek and/or a die-hard fan of D&D (which I am).

The overarching story is well-written, the characters, dialogs and interactions are great fun, but after a well-paced start in terms of plot progression, you get stuck in a rut (chapters 3-5) exploring large area maps at a dreadfully slow pace with no way to speed things up (all walk, no run), and you are pretty much forced into it in order to get the money, items, and to level up if you want to survive until you can unlock the interesting bits of the main story.

The side-quests in each area are very basic, and a lot of the combat is against small mobs of low- to medium-level creatures. Rather than 'Dungeons & Dragons', it felt like 'Wilderness & Pest Control' at times... This was all fixed in Baldur's Gate 2, so if you're looking for less exploration and more story + engaging side quests, you can skip this one.

This game uses AD&D (aka Second Edition D&D) rules. I was an avid player of pen & paper AD&D as a kid, but this reminded me how imperfect and weirdly balanced those rules were when they first came out... At least in P&P, we could improve on the rules, adopt the numerous modifications published later in fanzines, start our characters at level 5... The video game follows the core rule set, which means that all of its shortcomings can be felt here. Plus it's a truncated version of the original rules (e.g. unlike in the P&P, Wisdom and Intelligence are not used for saving throws here, so unless you're a class that depends on those, they are useless abilities; Charisma is used a bit in interactions, but unless you have 16 or more, the points are wasted...), which is all the more frustrating.

So prepare yourself to be patient—and die a lot on the harder difficulty settings—in the beginning, with no way to skip ahead. You will not have much fun until level 5 (especially with the spell casting and rogue classes; Warrior classes get all the fun) and progression in the beginning is rather slow—turning into a crawl if you multi- or dual-class, as you will be splitting your xp between the various classes.

Bottomline: If you're gonna get it for the nostalgia factor or for story continuity, go for it. Otherwise, ask yourself how much time do you want to spend watching your party trudge through pixelated landscapes, and whether you will find it soothing or aggravating... Depends on the day for me.

How do you describe one of the greatest D&D RPG's ever made? This game was first released in 1998 and it still satisfies today with the Enhanced Edition.  If the original wasn't brilliant then Beamdog wouldn't have touched it.  I am one of the long standing fan base who played the original game multiple times and loved it.  So does this version hold up?  Whilst the content added by Beamdog to the new version is decent, It didn't blow me away.  The most valuable additions to the game have been in making it user friendly, better looking, more balanced, more fun and enjoyable.  I also have been a Dungeon Master for D&D tabletop games and this game is in my opinion the single greatest at recreating the joy of playing D&D.   When beamdog improved the multiplayer experience they achieved the aim that Bioware had always intended but was elusive when the game was released, recreating the fun of playing a multiplayer D&D adventure.  If you try this game be prepared for tough learning curves, but unlike other RPGS from the 90's the game rewards every step of your investment and the learning curve is based on legitimately learning skills.  The best RPG's in the modern era such as Skyrim owe a lot to the template of sandbox gaming with strong narratives set in place by this game.

Baldur's gate is my all time favourite game series.  It uses a Real Time with Pause system which no longer popular nowadays.  The rules in the game are based on D&D 2nd edition. 

While this game series is well known as classic games, the entry level of this game to the new players are actually very high.  D&D 2nd edition carries a lot of concepts that is very different compared to the latest generation of video games and some of the concepts are difficult to digest even for players familiar with latest edition of D&D rules.  Examples are concepts like THAC0, Dual Class.  These concepts are abolished since D&D 3rd edition.

Spellcasting related concepts add another layer of difficulty to understand the game mechanics.  Any one who read the spell descriptions would feel lost easily.  Casting time is a numerical number;  Spell effect lasting in rounds, turns, and seconds, which the length of a round or a turn is never explained in game;  Saving throw mechanism is not explained as well.  So basically the developer expected the players to be very familiar with the whole D&D 2nd edition rule books.  This in my opinion is the biggest hurdle new players need to cross.

Next challenge is the RTwP system.  This is a system more difficult to understand than turn-based systems, but it carries its own advantages.  While turn-based combats requires the players to control every character for every action, in the RTwP system the players can just buff the whole team with one or two spells then sit down and watch the team to eliminate all the enemies.  So RTwP is a system that is friendly to experienced players, but unfriendly to new players, especially compared to turn-based system. 

The game’s main story line is excellent.  Side quests are plenty and interesting.  Teammates are fun and charismatic.  Interactions between teammates (includes you) are amazing.  Romance options are not bad.  Plenty of challenging fights to enjoy.  The whole game experience is very satisfying.

Although this game's main story line does not change, it still has a lot of replay value.  The player can test out difference character builds, try different team components, make different choices, use different spells, etc.  

If you are wondering how I played for so many hours, I have been replaying the game with additional restrictions.  I set two additional criteria for my runs:  1) solo  2) no-reload.  No-reload carries a Role Play factor and a much higher level of stress.  It presents a challenge that if you are really in Faerun, what will you do?  While in a normal run you can handle all kinds of situations easily, in a solo no-reload run, you have to think very carefully about how to handle situations that normally is not handled by your class.  

For example, when playing a non-thief class, how to handle a trap with a domination spell?  A failed saving throw for the spell in a solo run means death instantly, and for a solo no-reload run means the end of the run.  Try the luck, or buff up saving throw, or summon minions to be the sacrificial lamb, or use a protection scroll, or drink a mind protection potion, or use a charge of a necklace, or simply don’t take the risk and walk away.  There are plenty choices and only in a solo no-reload run, you will seriously weight all the available options and decide carefully.

I have successfully complete the solo no-load runs on insane with berserkers, bards, sorcerors, fighters, archers, paladins, and several multiclass characters.  These runs give the most satisfying gaming experience so far, and I will recommend the experienced players to try.  In these runs, you will re-learn your spells, portions, scrolls, weapons, items.  You will have a new understanding about different classes and play styles.  

The DLC siege of dragonspear is newly created by Beamdog team.  The quality of the DLC is decent and worth to play through at least once.  

Achievements in this game are very challenging.  The biggest challenge is the Legacy of Bhaal difficulty.  This is only recommend for very experienced players.  Especially in the earlier stages, the game difficult is at least 5 times higher than insane difficulty.  New players please do not start on this difficulty, it will ruin your game experiences no matter how good you are with other PC games. 

DLC related achievements tests more on patience than skills.  The choices made in earlier chapters of the DLC will have impact on the final chapters which will affect your achievements.  Some of the DLC achievements are very easy to miss without a walk through.

It's a classic, the remaster is executed very well. If you like rpgs you owe it to yourself to play one of the best ever made. The Siege of Dragonspear expansion is noticeably different in tone than the original content but still good. Start a character, then make sure you import them into Shadows of Amn and Throne of Bhaal. I know that it says 4 hours spent on the game, but that's only for the Steam version. Elsewhere (the app store, on my old Mac), I had put in at least ~40 hours- and that was rushing the game. The story is very engaging, with interesting plot twists. The combat is clunky, but sort of lends to the games' charm. I love the NPCs, especially Minsc. He's my favourite. 

It's not all pros, though. As this is reliant on the old AD&D system, the game is lethal by design. I save scummed my way through my first playthrough, and had to as combat was very difficult. Not necessarily a con, but be warned going in. That being said, there is a game difficulty where it is literally impossible for you to die, so there's that.

A pet peeve of mine was that, despite all the great writing, I personally found the ending very anticlimactic. It was a disappointing change in quality, and a shame that it effected my overall enjoyment of the game.

Enhanced, but not as much as I would like it too be.
(this isn't about BG, just about EE)

Many features make it much more user-friendly and enjoyable than the original:
* sum calculation on character creation (adding the stats was tedious in the original)
* item/gem/spell containers 
* auto-pick dropped items (very useful)
* max-xp-per-level and auto-learn-spell options (I hated saving/loading 100 times)
* 80 arrows per slot, 
* more gems/scrolls per slot,
* can now hold a bow as an alternate weapon config, without removing the shield for the 1-handed config. (still can't switch between dual-wielding and sword-shield, but that's OK.)
* F/M/T now has two weapon slots (hooray!)
* better journal/map marking
* nwn-style tab-item-highlighting 
* hard-core unpause on inventory has been removed.
* a few new characters, some of them interesting, namely Dorn and Baeloth, (while the monk s*cks, both personally and as a class < lvl 14, which is unreachable in BG1).
* better graphics resolutions (the base that every EE offers and, some of them, nothing more)
If they'd gone so far as to port back v3 rules (even as an option), it would be perfect. (now that we've seen them, v1 are intolerable in comparison)

And a few have surprisingly become worse: 
* character development, 
* then new character sheet page is somehow less functional.
* travel durations are now visible only arbitrarily
* intrusive auto-enabled auto-profiles (I wonder who wants spellcasters to empty their slots on the first wolf they see)
* BG2-weapon-proficiencies (guys, those are only meaningful for the ~lvl 20 characters of BG2).
* the cap stays to tales-161k 
* more limitations in dual-classing (no specialist classes, no BG2 rules this time)
* all the cinematics have become worse, 
* spellbook is less functional (scrolling is annoying if you knew the spells)
* somehow old characters are not importable (twasn't that difficult).
* weapon/spell slots could have been even more now that it isn't 800x600.
* still 6-chars per party (I'd like to see this as an option, in case in my 1000th run I'd like to see some interactions of characters otherwise unsuitable for any purpose)

In summary, I'd expect much, much more for a version that is supposedly maintained 20+ years later. Nothing too bad, though, and It's still BG, one of the best games ever, so for me downvoting it is not an option.

Baldur's Gate has undoubtedly aged. The ancient AD&D ruleset is its biggest barrier of entry with unintuitive mechanics and a harsh difficulty curve that's brutal for the wrong reasons. While the story is an early effort from BioWare with dated presentation and minimal party interactions, Baldur's Gate still has a lot of old-school charm with plenty of exploration, hardcore gameplay, humorous characters and a simple but well-written plot. The quality-of-life features of the Enhanced Edition are much appreciated, but the additional content is underwhelming and certain gameplay changes were needless, while the party pathfinding is just as troublesome as the original.

So I've tried this game in 2018, and again in 2021.  I like modern day cRPGs, and so I keep going back to Baldurs Gate: Enhanced Edition to see if I can play it.  I can't, and for many reasons.

- The system is too complex to understand. THACO sucks.
- The game is so unbalanced at the beginning.  I've read that it GETS good, but you have to slog through the beginning to get there.
- So many things that are not explained (like Charisma in conversations and so on.)
- There are many small things I take for granted now that are missing here (such as item comparisons.)
- Fights are decided by a single attack.  When that's combined with level 1 and 2 characters being wimps, your party gets wiped... you load... get wiped... you load... get wiped... you load... you defeat the enemy.  Save scumming in a game sucks, but it's the only way to progress in this game.

There's the more obvious graphics and clunky engine because this game is so old, but I could look past those things if the other issues weren't so glaring.  I will never beat Baldur's Gate 1.


I'm glad this game came out, as it paved the way for future cRPGs that I really liked.  That being said, the genre has moved so far forward in terms of user-convenience, voice acting, story telling, and graphics that it is hard to get in through the campaign in 2021.

I picked this up for about two-and-a-half bucks during the Black Week sale. After having played for about 8 hours, I still feel like I spent too much.

This game is everything that a roleplaying game should NOT be. It's tedious: a walking simulator full of fetch quests where most of your time is spent on inventory management. It's boring - unless you like all that walking, I guess -, with two-dimensional NPCs, crap dialogue and a storyline that failed to really draw me in. On top of that it's quite railroady, and there's no "open world" to explore. If you're looking to get to know the character you created, fill them with life and tell their own unique story... look elsewhere.

The game is also just not fun to play. In true D&D style, it's all about fighting - and quests, but those are invariably about fighting, or fetching items (for which you'll have to fight). 

And the fights aren't even particularly fun, and you'll find yourself quick-saving all the time because any random encounter might kill you. In fact, your safest bet is to scout out the terrain one step at a time - foes 
you cannot see also do not see you and remain utterly oblivious to the carnage happening right next to them. If you feel that this is unrealistic and distracts from the immersion, tough luck.

FWIW you're also well-advised to save ALL. THE. TIME. Another meta-strategy you'll quickly pick up is, after stumbling into a fight you cannot handle, to reload the save you made five seconds before and try again, armed with the knowledge of the looming encounter - which your character doesn't have, but hey, who cares about realism. You'll probably have to do this a couple of times until you get lucky with the die rolls. But hey, reloading is free.

I would usually set a very low bar for a game I only paid about 2.50 for, and wouldn't complain if I'd gotten even one hour of fun out of it. As it is, though, I not only lost an (admittedly modest) amount of money, I also lost about eight hours of my life that I'll not get back. I would've much preferred to keep both, and I can only advise anyone who has NOT played this game yet to stay away from it - unless you've already played other D&D-based games and know that you're OK with all this.

This is my first time playing, and I gather that there is much left to do, but I have to write this review and share my initial thoughts. Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is a blast. Against the advice of the game, I played without first going through the tutorial, but many aspects of the game that I was initially confused on (mainly HUD elements) were easily figured out after a few minutes of exploring. 

Graphically, this game is quite impressive. I gather that it is a remake of a game that came out in '98. If this is how it looked back then, hats off to the graphical artists. The HUD, as I alluded to above, is rather confusing if you haven't encountered anything like it before. I've played Tyranny, Pillars of Eternity, and the Divinity series, so I wasn't 100% unfamiliar with a HUD of this type. The story so far is very intriguing. I am absolutely invested in the mysteries that this game has put before me.

So, i'll end this with my best praise for this game and my biggest criticism of it. First, I am very impressed with the degree of choice and freedom that BG offers. Nonlinear stories are the bread and butter of RPG's in my opinion and BG excels in this. It even feels kind of like i'm playing D&D sometimes, which is a hard feeling to accomplish in a video game. 

My biggest criticism, however, is mainly with the graphical options. I play on a 55" 4k TV, so the HUD of the game (which looks like it is meant to be displayed in a lower resolution) is quite small. It would be great if I had the option to mess with the HUD in-game. At least to increase the resolution. Maybe they tried this, but it made the game unstable? I'll never know, I suppose. This problem is fixed by changing the resolution in your PC settings, but it is a slight pain to have to do it every time before I play. 

Now, for my breakdown;

Graphics: 3/5: Would be 4 if I had an easier way to change my resolution. For the time, these graphics were great. By today's standards, the character models are super pixelated and don't look very good, but the environments are fantastic.

Sound Design: 3/5: The ambient noise is very relaxing and immersive, but hearing the same sounds from monsters over and over gets slightly old.

Voice Acting: 2/5: By today's standards, this leaves something to be desired. I've cringed at a few instances, but there is some good voice acting here.

Music: 5/5: Each piece fits its environment exceedingly well and is an absolute joy to listen to. I regret not buying the bundle that includes the soundtrack! I may have to pick it up separately at a later date.

Character Creation: 3/5: I wish there were more options to customize the appearance of your character. I've never really liked the "pick a portrait and make a character similar enough to it" style of appearance customization that is popular in these sorts of RPG's. However, 2nd Edition AD&D holds a special place in my heart and I very much enjoy creating a character with these old rules.

Story: 5/5: As mentioned in my summary, this is probably my favorite part of the game. There is a whole world of people-- both good and evil-- who are looking to take advantage of your assistance. Lots of quests, interesting characters, and a very memorable and intriguing story. I don't feel like i'm following a questline like in one of my favorite RPG's, Skyrim. I feel like i'm hearing about things and investigating them on my own. As a side note that is somewhat related, I love the journal. Mainly because I can add my own entries. I've had a blast writing about things i've done and need to do as my character. It is also an incredible boon that keeps you from getting lost in a mountain of quests and story threads, as was the case with many RPG's of the time.

Replay Value: 5/5: I read that you can get upwards of 80 hours of play time in this game. I'm only 11 hours in, but i'm already thinking of what i'm gonna do differently next time. The endless amount of ways a quest can turn out and the many ways you can play the game lead to Baldur's Gate: Enhanced edition having a ton of replay value. And i've yet to play through the other adventures! I can see myself playing this game again and again for many years to come.

Overall Score: 5/5: While I have outlined a few problems I have with the game, I feel like I would be cheating the developers, the fans, and even the game itself if I gave Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition anything less than a perfect score. The positives far outweigh the few negatives and i'm looking forward to completing the game and then running back through it again!

Baldur’s Gate is an isometric turn based old school RPG based on the table top game Dungeons & Dragons. It tells the story of a medieval adventurer who is chased by a hulking armored figure that killed his step father and is somehow trying to provoke a war that will drag all the Sword Cost. 

[h1] A Few Words [/h1]
First I have to say that I played Dungeons & Dragons with my school friends when I was a kid, so playing Baldur’s Gate now felt like an emotional rollercoaster to me. Playing this game gave me moments of nostalgia, where I remembered the D&D campaigns I played with my friends, but also provoked me legit anger, because of some weird game play decisions like enemy placement (basilisks) and the final boss fight. 

[h1] About the Story [/h1]
The game legit made me feel like a medieval hero (villain in my case) but I wish the story of the legacy of Bhaal was told along the many chapters and not just compressed into the final chapter. For the whole game you keep wandering around the Sword Coast being chased by hired killers, you get to meet famous characters like Elminster, Drizzt and you keep thinking: “what’s going on?”. And then, in the final chapter, boom! You have an immense amount of text and explanation telling you all about the game’s story. Feels rushed. That info and clues about your char and his half brother should have been explained earlier. That’s my main concern about this game. 

[h1] Weird Difficulty Curve [/h1]
The other would be some over the top boss fights, like the basilisks in chap 6 or the final boss fight, which are so over the top difficult that I had to use some clever exploits to win, like abusing the skull trap spell. I wonder if it was the devs intention to make those encounters THAT difficult??

[h1] I Rate it 4.8/5.0 [/h1]
