This review won't actually be as negative as you would think, I wish steam had a "maybe" option.

So, Baldur's Gate, [b] the [/b] CRPG - the game that is synonymous with the genre itself for 90% of people, and honestly I can see why, I really can.
It has got charm, it has got soul - it is just a labor of love, and you only need to look at the manual for the game (a 150 page pdf, full color with pictures and all) for that much to be apparent.

[b] I respect this game for everything it did to the RPG genre [/b] - its influence is not to be underestimated.
I'm giving it a not recommended simply because it isn't for me, and I think I gave it a fair shot.

Now [b] on to the game itself [/b] and why I don't recommend it.

It's pretty, it has that D&D adventure atmosphere and it feels nice to immerse yourself in it...

...But holy hell man [b] this game did not age well at all [/b] - now look, I actually love old school games - some of my favorite games (either now or when i was younger) were and will be games such as Doom, Quake 1, Diablo 2, older Total War games etc.

Take Diablo 2 as an example here - it has weak endgame content, it has weak build variety (compared to modern ARPGs such as PoE), it has poor UI and inventory management, it has weak widescreen support etc (all of this is in the context of the remaster not existing) - in other words, the game is [b] archaic, it is old, it doesn't have modern technology and comfort behind it and it is full of design philosophies that make 0 sense in today's world of game design [/b] - but it's still so fun to play. It just feels good to play, to listen to that story one more time, to slay monsters and get that random loot, [b] its age aged with it, if you will [/b] - it became a part of its soul.

Baldur's Gate on the other hand to me [b] feels like a chore to play [/b] :

-the game is just straight up [b] too RNG based [/b] - I feel this is much more true in the early game than it is in the late game, but holy shit man the amount of times a random spell just one-shot any of my characters except for the beefiest fighter tank is just stupid, no skill required and no reaction from the player possible.

-the game is [b] pure trial and error [/b] sometimes - like the early game Temple zone in the first town (why the fuck are there like 8 vampire wolves and worgs when they're literally immune to the damage low lvl characters can deal, since they don't have magic damage at that stage of the game?) or any encounter where you [b] need to know in advance [/b] which spells to prepare or which damage type weapons to have (since some monsters are just immune to some types of damage, but neither the game, its in-game books, tutorials, manual, or the non-existent bestiary will tell you that.
[b] Edit [/b] - Pathfinder Kingmaker has an example of how to deal with situations that possibly  could be trial and error by giving you a warning using in-game NPCs in a lore-friendly and immersive way - shortly, one of your companions writes a journal, and that journal is your quest log - everything in there is written by her, with her emotions - the quest that could have been trial and error literally has your companion writing a comment on that quest, stating "this seems shady, our hero (you) should probably take some invisibility potions or think of some escape, just in case that this might be a trap" - this is absolutely brilliant and it winks to the player that he will have to fight or flight his way out of that situation - it's 100% the players fault if he doesn't get properly prepared for this after this type of warning.

-the UI is clunky,

-tutorials are sparse,

-the manual is too complicated and yet still doesn't explain all the things a player should know,

-inventory and character management is tiresome and a waste of too much time,

-quest and side-quest directions are not really clear,

On top of all this you have [b] missing basic quality of life features [/b] that we've all come to expect in games today (in general, not just CRPGs):
- when i loot something, why doesn't that particular material/gem/arrow/item automatically stack in the inventory of the character that has those items?
-why are there no spell range/AOE indicators (what the fuck does 50 ft. of range mean)?
-why can't i ctrl+click or alt+click items to equip/unequip them faster?
-why can't I speed up the boring walking parts while exploring zones?
-why must I first select a character at a temple and then select the effect i want to apply to them (instead of just selecting an effect from the list and clicking on a character)?
-why must my whole party stop what they were ordered every time I order my party leader to speak with someone/investigate something... 
-why doesn't my party walk in unison - instead they all bump into each other and pause every half a second, making my ranged guys walk head-first into an enemy spellcaster or archer?...
...and the list goes on.

Heck, [b] I don't even need quality of life and modern day UI and UX philosophies that much [/b] - bro I've played Path of Exile for 1.500 hours and I've played a decent amount of Warframe as well, do you really think I'm not used to an absolute pisspoor user experience - and yet still [b] Baldur's Gate feels even worse when trying to get into it than those games. [/b]

One last thing to mention - the [b] story [/b], at least for now, feels somewhat generic, but I actually like that tbh, it's a nice break from Pillars' animancy, watcher and philosophical ancient civilization story lol. It just feels like an adventure that's waiting to happen, with okay writing.
The only problem for me is that it is perhaps [b] too predefined [/b] - I actually went through the pains of writing a personal biography for my character (there's an in-game option for that and it is clunky as all hell to write something coherent in that game box)... and then the game shoehorned me into being with Gorion, the guy that adopted me, my whole life... bruh.
Yeah, sue me, I like generic fantasy stories where the main party goes on an epic quest to get treasure/to save the world in a colorful high-fantasy setting.

This game is for people that either played it when it first came out or played other games at that time and are somewhat used to this level of clunkyness and weirdness - I may be playing old school games my whole life, but I was still born in the year 2000 - I've experienced too much quality of life to be comfortable playing this.

Maybe it's just not for me - that is always a possibility, we're all humans, we can't be good at everything and love everything.

Even so, I'll continue playing CRPGs, and will probably play Baldur's Gate 3 some day - it's not the end of the world if I don't like the game that basically spearheaded the genre, but I am kind of sad that that's the case...

I should note that i played games in this genre - I've put 100+ hours in Pillars of Eternity, I'm still planning to pick up the Pathfinder games (and i'll probably do a mini-update here when i do), so it isn't that this genre isn't for me, I don't think so. It's more that [b] this genre got so much better with the advancement of technology [/b], that going back in time with it feels downright painful, even for someone who tolerates weird game design.

BBaldur's Gate é um jogo antigo, portanto as mecanicas do jogo são datadas, os gráficos não vão agradar pessoas que preferem buscar por jogos "bonitos" e apesar de todas as atualizações recebidas ainda vão acontecer os crashes de vez em quando.

Dito isso, o jogo é uma obra de arte, a história, apesar de linear e não muito complexa, te puxa pra ela e a imersão que o jogo provem é espetacular. Os sons ambientes são gostosos de ouvir, os mapas são muito bonitos apesar de alguns repetir. As músicas ajudam com a imersão...muitos atributos que contribuem para uma bela experiencia se você está disposto a ver através dos problemas acima mencionados.

A criação de personagem é divertida, apesar de não ter muitas opções de customização (lembrem que o jogo é de mais de vinte anos atrás) ele ainda consegue te dar opções do que você prefere que o personagem use em combate (desde que seja algo permitido por sua classe, claro).

No geral, para quem gosta de D&D mas não tem grupo para jogar, ou mesmo para quem nunca jogou D&D mas tem interesse em ver como o sistema era antigamente...Baldur's Gate é o jogo que você estava procurando.

Baldur's Gate, as many of you may know, is the Grandfather of effective, PC,  Dungeons and Dragons, Role playing games. The mechanics of this game is strictly run by the books of old DnD RP rules. Considering the technology available at the time of the creation of the game, Baldur's Gate immediately achieved mastery of the DnD mechanics in PC games and has vastly influenced the culture and progress of all role playing video games across all platforms ever since its release.

The enhanced edition supports higher and modern resolutions with great resolution scaling differences based on camera zoom level, and it even adds new gameplay features such as additional companion options that are an essential for those who, like myself, were introduced to  the original game at an early age. The replay-ability of the game is also very vast, as there are an enormous amount of character class/race builds that offer a great amount of possibilities; especially for those who want to port their saves into Baldur's Gate 2 EE and then move toward getting ready for the full release of 3. While I do not have the information on whether Baldur's Gate 2 EE  will be able to port builds to Baldur's Gate 3, I am assuming that this wiil be an available perk for those who took the time to build their characters for the subsequent games. 

The story and engaging narratives of Baldur's Gate 1 EE are very intriguing and well thought out. I find myself reading the books found within the world and the character dialogues and narratives, and I really can tell that an enormous amount of thought and care was dedicated to creating a believable world that transcends the rather primitive graphics style.

This is definitely where all DnD gamers should start if they want to immerse themselves in the stories of the masters. Alternatively and if one decides they would like to try the game play mechanics of this type of game before diving right into to the "Big Daddy" of them all, I would recommend Icewind Dale. Icewind Dale is a lot more based on game play than story line. If you are like me, however, you want the ultimate of both features. If That is you, then I feel that Baldur's Gate is definitely for you.
One of the best RBGs of all times. Highly recommend it to every RPG lover out there.

I've enjoyed this game since it came out in the late '90s and Beamdog did an excellent update of the software so that I can continue to play this game.  It does use the older AD&D ruleset which can be confusing to those who are use to the current 5e.

I love multiplayer co-op games and D&D, so this is the perfect game for me and people like me. I also like the tutorial. It is very helpful and I strongly advise anyone who isn't familiar with the mechanics of this game to play the tutorial first as the game play is fairly complex.

I am new to D&D style gaming, but not new to RPG style gaming. It took me a few hours to get a grasp on the game play. Thus far this is my review. If you are willing to be patient, read (carefully). Not afraid to quick save and re-load (possibly a lot). Be willing to make decisions you might regret later and are able to let your imagination do a little work and immersion, you will definitely find yourself sucked into this game. I love how first off you are able to make your own custom character, which right off the bat makes you do a lot of thinking (if your like me and want to put a little bit of yourself and thought into your main character). I love the sort of hand drawn/painted landscapes and cut scenes, especially for when this game came out. The voice acting is not bad either and does provide a feeling of storytelling and immersion. I am only 10% complete with the achievements, and only 41 hours into actual game play and that only makes me even more excited to continue my adventures and see what other quests, tails of revenge, intense tactical battles, and certain death comes my way.

A bit of background first: I LOVE Fallout 1&2 and irl D&D and I'd heard amazing things about Baldur's Gate, so I decided to pick it up on the summer sale along with BG2, and it was well worth the purchase. I can't put it down.

In my opinion the best part of the game is the discovery. Everytime you find an area, you only start with a small scrap of visible land. Uncovering everything in each location is a lot of fun. However, you always have to be careful. I was wandering around a desert at level 1-2 and got my tank petrified, and then my leader. I came back a few levels later with magic that was able to prevent petrification, and still had a tough but fair battle. That demonstrates another great thing about this game, you really feel progression. I've only been playing for 20 or so hours but already I've changed from a twig to a tree, and I can't wait to grow even more.

Overall, this is one of the best games I've ever played, and would reccomend it to anyone(although be warned, this game does not hold your hand and is difficult, a tip: the lower your AC is, the better)who likes roleplaying, strategy, great storytelling and has some time to kill.

A great game, even after all these years.  Enhanced Edition has the same charm as the original, almost identical gameplay, but with the bugs fixed, Tales of the Sword Coast expansion implemented into the game, and some added content. Unlike the original, entering the inventory doesn't unpause the game (something that wasn't implemented until BGII), which is very useful when you don't have the right item or a potion equipped. And I, for one, don't miss having to change the CDs all time during the game (although, from memory, original was released on a single DVD at some point).

So, if you liked the original and want to revisit it (including the option to purchase two DLCs with more content), I'd definitely recommend this game.  If you are new to the game, but familiar with D&D, it is definitely worth a shot.  I bought it during the sale getting a great deal that also included the sequel, Icewind Dale games and Planescape: Torment (all remakes of the original games), and all DLC's associated with those games.  There's probably 1000+ playing hours between those.

Finally, just a couple of warnings, if you are looking for great graphics, this is not a game for you (just check the screenshots). The other is that the game is not overly balanced, since you can end up in the areas above the skills of your party, so it can get frustrating sometimes - save often.

I went through a bit of a roller coaster of emotions with this game; frustration at repeatedly being one shot killed, elation when things finally started to click and then impatience as the game turned into a grind at the end.

Summary:
Lots of people love the game and for most of the time you will too, but you also run the risk of being like me and ending up playing the game to get through to the end, rather than out of enjoyment. For that reason I can't recommend it.

I'll be reviewing the Enhanced Edition of Baldur's Gate 1 here, as well as a copy-pasta of my review of the Siege of Dragonspear expansion.

Baldur's Gate 1:

I love this game. 

Its a low level campaign based on a very good interpretation of Advanced Dungeons and Dragons 2nd Edition. Turns out a really well developed pen and paper role playing game also lays the ground work for a really excellent game engine.

The combat is "real time with pause". There are turns happening as in D&D, but they are all happening at the same time and taking place in real time. That's where the pause comes in. You can just let the combat play out in real time, but at any time you may pause the game to give out more specific commands to your party members. This allows for easy encounters to not become a chore and hard encounters can be micro-managed as much as needed.

The game is set on the Sword Coast of Faerun in the Forgotten Realms, a setting that will be familiar to D&D veterans. The story is straightforward but fun.

Baldur's Gate has a great balance between exploration, combat and story/dialogue. You'll want to explore each area you come across because you never know if you'll encounter a mad priest, a band of rouge adventurers looking for a fight, a mother looking for some one to save her son, or just some random crazy NPC that will make you laugh.

The combat can seem hard to grasp if you've not played before or even boring at level 1 if you can't hit anything, but there is a lot of depth to it, especially in the magic system from wizards and priests. There are a lot of awesome combat encounters in this game. There is also a nice progression of loot you get for your characters which is one reason that compels you to keep exploring - you never know what awesome loot you may get!

Although there is a lot of great dialogue in the game and a lot of opportunity for role-playing, the npc companions do not offer a lot of dialogue. Many have "quests" but they are short and underwhelming. There is some banter between NPCs but not a great deal so don't expect much out of it. BG2's companions are much better in this regard.

As for the enhanced edition, its supports higher resolutions which is great. If anyone ever played BG1 with the Tutu mod installed, the Enhanced Edition will feel very similar - basically its BG1 in the BG2 engine, including all the class kits and the ability to dual wield.

The enhanced edition also adds four new NPC companions - a monk, wild mage, a blackguard (an evil paladin) and a sorcerer. These companions all have a legitimate quest for you and in general are more fleshed out than the original npcs. The community is divided as to whether these companions are a welcome addition to the game. I like all but the monk.

Overall, more than 20 years later, I still think Baldur's Gate is worth a playthrough (or severl) to this day.

Recommended.

Siege of Dragonspear:

I really enjoyed this expansion.

Although it is much more linear than BG1 or 2, it's not the straightforward dungeon crawl some people make it out to me.

In the story you are following an army as they advance across the Sword Coast on their campaign. Thus, once you proceed with the army to a new area, you cannoy backtrack. But in each area there are a ton of side quests to do. Some of them are really great.

The game features many higher level enemies than BG1, and in many ways feels like a warmup for BG2, in regards to to the enemies you face and environments you'll encounter. In one chapter there is even a huge underground sections that reminds of the Underdark from BG2.

The game is beautiful. There are many incredible and colorful settings. The game also has some really fun large scale battles, which were a lot of fun.

I liked the story. Is it necessary for BG2? Obviously not, we'd been playing BG2 for more than 15 years before this released. But it's fun, and it does take you right into BG2.

The companions are very good. They have side quests and a lot more lines than the original Baldur's Gate. Also, they did an excellent job with the cannon party members, in terms of voice acting and scripting.

Also worthy of note, the experience cap in SoD is 500k xp, perfect for dual classing. You can now start BG2 with your fully dualed fighter mage!

Overall I think it's worth experiencing, at least once if not on each playthrough of the trilogy. People will say that it's not necessary, and again, of course it's not BG2 has been just fine without it since it's release. But Tales of the Sword coast was equally unnecessary in terms of BG2 - this game at least feels like a continuation of Charname's story rather than a total side quest.

Recommended.

I would to preface this review by saying two things: 1. I am reviewing this as a young person. This game is older than I am, so the perspective I present in the following review will not be blinded by nostalgia. In fact, I first played it earlier this year. 2. The fact that, unlike other steam games I've reviewed, I am not doing a joke review, speaks volume to how good this game is, and how much I care about it.

This game is AWESOME. Immersive, fun characters and dialogue, charming world, fun combat system. This is the kind of game you can sink hours into playing and discovering the world. By far one of the best games I've ever played. 

The best part of the game for me are the characters, both the party members and NPCs. Each character has their own motivations and backstory, with their own morals and ideals. You can have a party full of good characters and go around the Sword Coast being heroes, or have a party full of evil characters and cause chaos around you. Better yet, you can have some good and some evil party members, and watch them clash with each other and argue (until the lawful good paladin attacks the lawful evil half orc and dies (YES, your party members can kill each other if they disagree enough. modern games just wont do this kind of stuff and its awesome)). For a game so old, the developers put a ton of effort into the different interaction party members can have, and I think they pulled it off quite well. 

This game is also extremely fun to explore. Every area - even the "unnamed forest area number 57" kind - has something for you to discover, whether it be a wacky NPC that will ask for 1000 gold pieces, an OP magical item, a fortress full of Gnolls, or a pair of golden pantaloons, there is not a corner of this game's world that the developers did not put some secret into. The exploration in this game just feels SATISFYING, the gameplay loop of slowly uncovering an area and talking to NPCs with fantasy name generator names is extremely addicting to me, and if you're the kind of player who enjoys to be immersed in a world, this is the game for you.

HOWEVER, this game is not for everyone. There are aspects of Baldur's Gate that I can imagine ruining the game for some players. For instance, the combat at early levels (1-4) is simply unfair. The game will throw inescapable encounters at you that your party will be unable to deal with. For me, this is not a deal breaker, as I find the story and exploration make up for the unfair combat, but if you're the kind of player that doesn't have the patience to bang their head against a hoard of Amnian Soldiers for an hour straight, this game simply isn't for you. 

The combat does become relatively fair from level 5 onward, but even then there will be some encounters that are simply unfair. This isn't helped by the fact that the developers basically expect you to complete every sidequest in the game, otherwise you will quickly find yourself underleveled for the games already absurdly difficult encounters. 

It's not that the combat SYSTEM is bad; it's essentially a 1 to 1 replica of 2nd edition D&D, and there is a ton of fun to be had with the variety of spells, items and abilities each class has. The combat system is very fun and dynamic, it's just that the developers made the encounters too hard.

The game DOES have a "Story Mode" difficulty where you are given the ability to breeze through every combat encounter, so this problem is technically fixed, however I find the mode immersion breaking and only turn it on in extreme circumstances (which, admittedly, is every third encounter at level 1). 

All in all, this game has one of the deepest and detailed worlds of any game I've played, fun NPCs, endless replay value with its variety of classes and races, and a simple (and kind of generic) but fun story that oozes with D&D charm. The only drawback is the horrible encounter balance, which is an aspect that can easily ruin the game for some players, but can be overcome with patience or the Story Mode.

Baldur's Gate is one of my all time favorites. The story, characters and the world are just wonderful. For me the story flows well and I like the free exploration too, unlike some other players. The original one has very few cons for me, if at all, but the EE version has those new characters you can recruit that just don't feel right to me. Luckily you can mod them out. And don't flame me, but the so called "canon" party has started to bore me a little...Otherwise I have very little to complain about this gem of an rpg. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good party based rpg.

How can a game from 1998 instill within me such a sense of wonder and awe. How can i still lose myself in this world i've been through so many times before. How can every minute detail still impress me so, be it an NPC way off the beaten path who foreshadows my grandiose destiny or some uncovered treasure that i've never even thought of looking for. How can these companions, with no more than a few catchy lines of dialogue, seem to me as good old friends who i'd never want to part with. And by god, Durlag's Tower still stands there as my favorite dungeon in video game history after all these years.
Maybe i'm just blinded by nostalgia or maybe this game really still has that something, that sense of adventure like no other that makes you giddy with excitement at every turn. If you're a fan of the new CRPGs, you owe it to yourself to play this and find out more about the genre's history. A word to the wise though, keep away from Siege of Dragonspear, you'll thank me later. 
After all that i still ask myself, how can it be that the sequel is better in every single way when this one is this good.

I've played many RPGs, many different kinds of games. I knew that these earlier DND based RPGs were difficult and had a lot to them. 4 hours of playing, no level up, no new equipment to improve stats, and hitting road blocks in every part of the first city. Not enough gold to buy potions (which are outrageously priced for early game) no where to earn large amounts of gold (winning battles and searching might net you 10-20 gold). Selling equipment is also unnecessarily difficult. Trying to find shops that will buy, and then finding out the 10 swords you carried to make gold are worth 1 gold each. I have always heard great things about Baldur's gate, however, I find it cumbersome, tedious and inaccessible. Maybe it's nostalgia that bring people back to the game. Maybe it's experience with DND type RPGs, I am not sure. But even on "normal mode" I can't seem to make any reasonable progress. And grinding for xp yielded no results.

This is the game I love the most and it's my favourite RPG of all times. Maybe this is the magic of the first game ever, maybe the magic of sitting on dad's lap while he was fighting with kobolds in the mines - but maybe this is just a well-written gameplay which ages like fine wine. I understand that the graphic needed some adjustment to current times and still needs (however this was done by BGT and then by EE really well). I know that our NPCs do not say much and there is a lot of maps where you can find basically just a lot of trees and that is all - but this is absolutely not how I remember this game and not how I perceive this game when I play it. 

The plot of the game is so interesting and so addictive that for me the story happening on the screen was the one thing, but the one I had in my head - it was the other. So there's this guy (or lady, usually I played the guy) who lives in a nice place called Candlekeep with his father, the great magician. He's old, silver-bearded and has a long coat, just like all great wizards have. And one day he says - we need to go. Prepare yourself. This is the tutorial and it is done so nicely that only after playing this THOUSAND times you can feel bored by tasks in Candlekeep. And then, by night, you get out from Candlekeep and you get attacked by a group of strangers led by huge person in a heavy armor with a big sword in the hand. He seems unbeatable. He kills the father without any problems. And you need to run. And the only thing you know is - go to the Friendly Arm Inn. There are some friends. They will help you out.

And then you meet them, and you start your journey, and you need to find your way around this messed up world, the iron crisis, the murderers chasing you for no particular reason, the bad guys you never saw when you were spending your days in dusty Candlekeep libraries. But there's a power inside you and you are good in fighting these bad guys. And you get new friends who are coming with you and are fighting by your side - some of them are a little odd, some of them are very very small (though I am sure that among cosmic hamsters Boo is the biggest and the bravest one), but all of them are with you till the very end.

The world has one plus that BG2 does not have in my opinion - it is very down-to-earth. You won't find githyankis, kuo-toas or other weird creatures - instead there is a lot of monsters that seem very real and I think that if somebody did not used to the DnD world (e.g. 7yo myself) it looks like a story that totally could've happened. Maybe this is the magic? I still don't know.

But I recommend trying this game. Use mods for additional discussions between NPCs, romances, new missions - but try this world. And I am sure you won't regret.

Completed the first game (even tho after completion i don't think i'll play it again), now playing Siege of Dragonspear.

BG1:
The pacing was horrible, often during traveling and questing it was either dispersive or an area a bit too large where i couldn't wait to just get over with.

The story was okay but imo the way it was narrated (and the pacing) could have been better. Way too many "pointless" houses and areas to explore, mixed in there with quest npc or interesting items/rewards as findings.

There are several recruitable NPCs, more than in BG2, there are also some bad game design IMO, like some NPCs will leave permanently if dismissed or come in pairs. There is also a level cap and your characters can get "only" up to level 8 or the likes. The game in particular, like BG2, is pretty intensive on the save/load mechanic you basically fail something and reload in hope of getting a better result, reposition, dice roll etc. You can avoid doing that if you wish, but stepping on a trap, losing a party member or getting hit by certain attacks/spells is generally a big deal in this game.

BG1 SOD:
One of the good is that Siege of Dragonspear starts right away as continuation after you finish BG1 (you can also skip BG1 and start directly from SOD, characters will be at around level 6-7 with pre-set gear in such case). You'll have your character and party with the level and items you were carrying in the first game. 
First thing i noticed is you can tell it has a more "modern" feel, there are fog effects and subtle graphic details, a lot more npcs on screen with passive dialogs. Also the way it's narrated, and the dialogs both from npc and companions has a bit more "realistic" approach compared to BG1 and BG2, where it felt more like you were playing characters in a tale.

Personally i prefer BG2 so far, where quests and story and NPC dialogs are more meaningful and better designed (not exceptional, but way better than BG1).

I personally would recommend BG2 over BG1, the areas, quests and point of interests are more condensed, less empty/open areas to travel without much of interest.. it boils down to personal taste as usual, some players prefer 1 others 2, or both.

Maybe a post update to follow if i complete the Siege of Dragonspear expansion.

Note: This game can be played solo or with other players, if the latter I would recommend it played with a small group of "patient" type of players, as per willing to stay put, read, wait, discuss, eventually going through several attempts/reloads if failing etc and it can be a real nice experience with the right players, this is not a game where to rush stuff same goes for BG2.

Upvote cause, well it's a renowned classic apart from my personal taste and game runs pretty good, some minor bugs (some quests in journal not marked as completd if you don't run things in a certain order and conditions)

I'm not much of a hardcore gamer (see my profile) and really only got into RPGs for the first time playing Divinity 2 with my husband. But I fell in love with CRPGs because of that and decided to give one of the classics a shot.... Well, I tried and failed to get into it probably 5 or 6 times. I would start up the tutorial and flounder for an hour and get frustrated and quit. Because frankly even this enhanced edition feels very foreign to someone who first played CRPGs in the context of a modern 3d game.

But I kept hearing about how great Baldur's Gate is and so I kept trying and finally after my sixth attempt and after reading some guides online I jumped into the game and I've now been playing for nearly 50 hours. I love it. The writing is so good. I feel like I'm playing through a high fantasy novel. Combat is very complicated from my perspective but I read guides about how important magic protections and buffs are and once I started using those liberally it became very tractable on a normal difficulty. I plan on playing through all of the expansions and the second game using my character. I LOVE how it all transfers and I get to go from a weak level 1 nobody to a level 20 demigod over the course of however many hundreds of hours the game will last. 10/10 Glad I was persistent.

Baldur's Gate is the godfather of isometric cRPGs. When I originally purchased it off a store shelf in 1998, I had no idea what an incredible ride I was in for. It was like I was playing pen and paper Dungeons and Dragons, but I controlled the entire party and didn't need to coordinate schedules with others in order to play. And the story, world, atmosphere, open exploration, excellent music... just blew my mind. I was quickly hooked.

I've since come back to replay Baldur's Gate and Baldur's Gate 2 many, many... many times over the years. The game world almost feels like a second home. The Enhanced Edition makes the game easier to install on modern PCs, and adds a number of helpful quality of life improvements, some bug fixes, and support for modern resolutions-- so this is the way to play Baldur's Gate in the present day. The added characters are decent as well. I'm a particular fan of Dorn Il-Khan for an evil party. I'm somewhat less of a fan of Neera and Rasaad, just personal taste.

This is a great game, and I continue to enjoy it in 2021. If you can get over the dated visuals (which look much better in high resolution, zoomed out a bit), I think you'll enjoy Baldur's Gate. And it's sequel, Baldur's Gate II, only gets better.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#11 out of 500+)... it's time for Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition.

Baldur's Gate is one hell of a game. Sarevok's reign of terror along the Sword Coast, the Iron Crisis, the progeny of a dead god wreaking havoc on the realm. It's a classic, make no doubt.

Though more of a fresh coat-of-paint than the remake we all wanted, Beamdog's Enhanced Edition is overall an improvement over the original game--especially now that the many bugs that plagued the game at launch have been ironed out. Of particular note are the additional party members and quest content, which are closer in quality to the quintessential sequel, Shadows of Amn, than the original.

Baldur's Gate is a masterpiece. I recommend--in the strongest possible language--that every gamer play both main titles at lease once. I must, in a heartbeat, recommend any gamer out there who hasn't already picked up Baldur's Gate to grab the Enhanced Edition immediately.

In a heartbeat.

But to players of the old school, my fellows and friends, I cannot say the same. Beamdog's Enhanced Edition of Baldur's Gate is nice, and in many respects superior to the original game, but the new content is far from game-changing, and there's simply too little there to justify a full play-through if you've already journeyed through the original game a half-dozen times. Unless you're a huge fan of the game, I guess. Like me. In which case: have at it!

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

I played this game religiously, back in the day, and this 'enhanced' version has hit me right in the nostalgia.  Hearing Winthrop once again proudly proclaim, "My hotel is as clean as an Elven arse!", actually made me tear up a little.

Yes, it is old (just like me) and yes, the visuals are appallingly dated (just like me), but it still puts modern rpg's to shame.  The depth of the story and the excellent writing are second to none.  The pacing is slow, by modern standards, but that just gives the player more time to appreciate the effort and love that has gone into the making of this genre-defining game.
Play it.  Just..play it.

I have been aware of Baldur's gate for years being an active player of D&D since 3.5e, but didn't get to sit down and play till the last couple years. I did however grow up with Icewind Dale and will use that as my starting point on the game.

Where Icewind Dale either encouraged you to make a full party or play online with others; BG gives you the third aspect of recruiting heros mid game as you adventure. I made the mistake (not really one but ya miss out on some dialogue/story)of making a full party my first run through. I high suggest just making your primary character and then choosing which companions to keep as you come across them or loose them. 

If you haven't played BG, it uses the old 2e D&D rules which can be hard and unforgiving at times. With that in mind this is a game you should save a lot and frequently. 

While the graphics are old, even the enhanced edition came out several years ago, it still plays well on a modern gaming laptop. I currently use an Omen and I have no issues in compatability or just clashing of old graphics with new tech; like you sometimes see in playing a 1st gen console on a modern hd tv. The music is also really good and frequently aids in absorbing yourself into the game. My only complaint there is while the game was full screen I couldn't adjust laptop volume with normal hotkeys...typcially had to alt-tab back and forth till right.

Depending on how focused on the main story you are, the difficulty (from 1st run on I always chose the normal....basically settings set to match 2e rules), and whether playing solo this game I would say takes rough 15-20 hours average. I've had much longer runs but that's typically due to wanting to do every quest or turning my character into a merchant and finding/selling every item.

If you're into RPGs, if you want something to play solo or with friends, and most importantly if you want something that doesn't necessarily require the internet I highly suggest this game!

There is little I will be able to tell you about the Badur's Gate series that you probably did not already know, or that someone has already described elsewhere in this section.

However, if asked if you should play this series, then I can tell you with a resounding 'YES' that you should.   Now, it's been awhile since the original game has come out, and since then Beam Dog has released the enhanced versions of the games.  This has drawn a lot of controversy with how they have handled the original licence, especially when it comes down to the expansion pack (which was all done by Beam Dog).  By expansion pack I am refering to Siege of Dragonspear.

I won't go into the reasons behind the controversy, but personally, although I think this content is weaker than anything else in the series, it is still extra content.  If you miss this, then you will probably always be wondering what it was that missed.  You may even feel as though you have not experienced the entire story, although there is a counter arguement that the entire pack is unneccessary.

Personally, I would take a new party out into BG1 and just play through everything.  Baldur's Gate 1 is a great game, and was the best representation of Advanced Dungeon & Dragons on the computer.  The series, which was already ranking high on most people's favourite's list, then went into the stratosphere with the launch of BG2.  That game is a lot of people's all-time favourite game, and it is easy to see why.   

After the initial escape from a dungeon, you emerge into the city of Athkatla, and it is here that everyone just gets really exciting and interesting.  There is a crazy amount of things to do, and events happening.  Trust me, for those who read this and know, they will have a 'knowing smile' about what I mean.  If you enjoyed part one, then you will absoloutely love BG2.

So should you buy this game?   Yes, most definitely!

Hundreds of hours of fun lay ahead!
Its a classic. A wonderful storyline

Good remastering of a classic DnD RPG, which was a watershed moment for PC gaming, and breakout moment for a once very reputable and small RPG developer called Bioware from Edmonton, Canada(for Canadians, you will notice some excellent easter eggs of Canadiana ingame btw) until that small developer got involved with EA, got into drugs and alcohol; resulting in them eventually ditching RPGs altogether and making a baby called Anthem, phew! 

But this isn't about the life choices of developers and the publishers they love. This is about Beamdog's remastering of a Bioware classic and the one that got them both started. 

Now not much really to "review" either know these games, or you don't. They are tough. They can be confusing and super overwhelming. They will make you question why people think something like Dark Souls is challenging as they can be so unforgiving on even normal difficulty. 

They are also awesome, engaging, and deep games that allow you to play out a story in your own style, with a classic DnD feel set in arguably the best locale DnD sports, the Forgotten Realms. Add in some very challenging and fun tactical combat, and an amazing story picked right up again with the second game, and you're looking at one hells of a game play experience for the asking price. 

Now the bad. Okay so as of writing they are still putting work into polishing these games up(major patch just last May surprised me, figured like most remasters out there these were pump and dumps, but nope, Beamdog is very passionate about their Enhanced Edition series of games and is a very active developer overall), however there are still "issues" with the games, mostly due to limitations of the game engine, and here they are:
[list]
[*]Some quests, NPC interactions are not bugged but clearly were never well thought out by Bioware from the get-go. Some have been fixed or shortened by Beamdog, but overall confusion and "where the f do I go" is high with this game still, so here's hoping for some future fixes to quest descriptions so we can lower the amount of alt-tabbing to Baldurs Gate wiki lol 
[*]Pathfinding is flat-out, hot garbage as well as the AI overall. There is no way around this, it is an old engine, and you can dress it up in all of Saturday night's best clothes, but it is still an old grey mare. Party members will block each other constantly, prevent you from simply entering a house etc, so be ready as this is an updated OLD game. 
[/list]
Beyond those two issues, I can't really hack it. I just wanted to give some fair warning about more dated or janky aspects. 

If you did not grow up playing these games, you have a "crap factor" adjustment ahead of you, but trust me, it is worth it, and Beamdog is nowhere near done supporting these games. 

Overall score:
B+
Some flaws, little dated even with updates, but for the price, especially if you never played Baldur's Gate before, you will be in for a treat once you become familiar with the game. 

Oh, the DLC Beamdog made for this is good too, really feels like something could have come out between the two games back in the day, in a very good way.

To put some context: I have only played through this game once, in multiplayer with two friends.
It was truly a terrible experience. We all thought the game to be awful, but couldn't bring ourselves to insist to the other two players that we should stop playing, as we didn't want to be the kill-joy and because we also thought that it might get better down the line. It took a while for us to realize that nobody liked it and that we were all just trudging along out of consideration for the others.
Now, what is so terrible about this game you might ask?
The answer is everything except for the soundtrack.
The dialogues and voice-acting are of poor quality. A lot of the main characters are downright annoying or insulting in their quirkiness.
The main scenario is so forgettable that we, in fact, kept forgetting it. Even racking our three brains together, we could barely remember what the story was supposed to be about at any given time.
The side quests are as boring as they come, on the level of MMORPG quests, which probably take inspiration from this game anyway.
Exploration was terrible, with the map being mostly large swathes of emptiness, and rewards always disappointing.
And most importantly, the core part of the gameplay, battle, which is burdened by some of the worst UI ever designed by man.

If you want to play something similar with your friends, I strongly suggest playing something better, like Divinity Original Sin.

Maybe this game is just a little too 'DnD-esque' for me.

First, the good stuff: the characters are fun, and it's impressive that they managed to convey so much character with little more than a picture card and a few voice lines. I think the number of potential party members starts to get a bit ridiculous, and if you're not familiar with (or interested in) the intricacies of DnD and just want to kill things adequately then most of the character stats are going to blur together.

I'm sure the world is fun too, if you get into it, but it seemed very painfully generic to me. Is this because it's a standard DnD world, or because so many games have been based on Baldur's Gate since? Can't tell. But it seems like the kind of world your computer would create on its own if you Googled the word "fantasy" and called it a day.

I'm not going to complain about the gameplay (slow, confusing and buggy) or the graphics (pixely) or even the interface (cluttered) because all these are the stumbles that BG pioneered when trying to switch from turn-based to realtime and pioneers always make mistakes. The worst part about this game is the plot.

It's really, really boring.

At time of writing my quest log has been insisting I "investigate the cause of an iron shortage in the area" for about 6 hours and I literally cannot think of a less appealing call to adventure. The inciting incident of this game was my mentor being murdered, and now I'm supposed to bumble around and play bureaucrat? Where's the amazing story that people online have been praising BG for for 20 years? But joke's on me, because when I finally gave up and looked up a plot synopsis, the iron shortage IS the story. I'm supposed to investigate the iron shortage, play out the Master of the Universe "Haha, I was working for a different guy the whole time!" gambit a few times, and then fight the big bad who orchestrated the whole thing. The whole iron crisis. Which I am supposed to care about. Zzzzzzzzzzz.......

If you get really jazzed about mineral shortages and are willing to push through one of the oldest RPGs ever to scratch that itch, this game is for you.

Baldur's Gate is one of, if not THE greatest Dungeons and Dragons game of ALL time. You can loose yourself completely in the game for hours, between making yer character, to traveling through the wilds of the Western Heartlands of Faerun. It's amazing! 
That said, I wish they hadn't changed the Art Style for the characters on screen. The Original art for yer character, how it shows weapons, armor, attacks, etc. was AMAZING! Icewind Dale I had the same style. NOT the Equipment screen, the model for yer character, the original artwork was great. The new style is more Balder's Gate II / Icewind Dale II, which is ok, but not as great. The Weapon animations are changed as well. It's okay, but the Original's is better. The artwork for changing Areas / Chapters is mediocre at best. The original had great hand drawn pictures, and little movies, the new artwork is pretty bad. Showing a weird Friendly Arms Inn, and odd Nashkel scenery... The new characters are pretty Bleh as well... Other than that, it still plays like the Original, and is great! Will I play it more than the original Disc Version that I have? Probably not... But I will play, and love My time in the wilderness of Faerun.

BG1 is unfortunately a CRPG best left forgotten.

D&D 2.0 can be quite fun at mid-high levels: that is the level range conveniently featured in its loved and clearly superior sequel Baldur's Gate 2.

Unfortunately, BG1 is low-level D&D, and it happens that playing D&D 2.0 at 1st level is a torture: any character can be instagibbed with one well rolled hit and the only viable strategy (outside of save scumming) is to equip a ranged weapon on every character and kite melee enemies. For ranged enemies, the only thing you can do is pray to the RNGesus and hope to not get instakilled.

This gameplay loop will remain as such for many, many hours, for 2 reasons:

1. Because level 1 and level 2 characters have access to no fun abilities. Mages have only access to 1 spell slot (always Sleep because it's your best shot of winning early fights outside of RNG) and other classes unlock their special abilities at later levels.

2. When you manage to finally kill a group of 5 ranged kobolds or whatever without anyone dying, you get rewarded with 35 EXP.  You need 2000 EXP to reach 2nd level. It's. Too. Fucking. Slow. This game simply doesn't reward properly the player for his efforts.
EXP is also further divided by the number of characters in your party.

You spent time on character creation screen, carefully picking your class kit and weapon proficiencies? Don't bother, none of that will matter in BG1. The game will end around level 8 or 9 and while you do unlock some interesting abilities at this point, you'll still be far away from the really fun stuff you can get in BG2.

Personally, I couldn't stand that boring as fuck gameplay. I turned on the convenient "story mode" that made my characters invulnerable and went on with the story (which isn't that great to begin with).

Zones are still pretty with great ambient sounds and musics, but these (huge) zones feel empty outside of seemingly randomly placed enemies and NPCs rushing to you to talk about mundane stuff you don't care about then promptly disappearing never-to-be-seen again.

Character sprites, spell animations and combat visuals have aged poorly. They do the job but they obviously can't compare to the amazing visuals we get in modern games.

This game is one of the best Classic RPGs out there, if not the best. 

It follows 2nd Edition Advanced DnD rules, meaning the manual is a whopping 154 pages long, and the character creator can seem daunting to most people who're either new to this type of game, new to the series, new to DnD or just new to Classic RPGs in general.

Though the story is a lot more enjoyable from the perspective of a Good/Chaotic Good character/party, as back in 1998 the Dungeons and Dragons franchise wanted to distance themselves from the media speculation -- Evil characters are by far the least satisfying to play as, and don't have a great deal of influence on the overall story. (Though it was fun to meticulously explode pretty much every NPC in sight at that point, despite little consequences beyond more guards being spawned.)

The gameplay itself is Real-Time with Pause, and there are so many different combinations and layers of experimentation to try out within the game's boundaries, it's hard to say any particular build/set of builds are good, you'll have to find what works for you and your current play style. That being said, it is insanely difficult just jumping in without doing any form of "grinding", which for me was doing sidequests, arguably the main focus of the game.

The Black Pit is also a great addition, though not exactly story-based it was certainly a fun gauntlet for post-game characters, even being able to import/export that progress between the normal game. I even managed to get someone to play Multiplayer for this particular game mode, starting characters from scratch, and I've never in my life had to do so much planning to beat a boss before. It was insane, but gratifying.

I've almost played 100 hours of the game, beating it once for a Good party and again for an Evil party, and I can't imagine I've even come close to finding all of the content within the game. But I definitely want to, and it gets my gamer brain going just thinking about the different quest possibilities and outcomes -- something that seems far more important than the actual main story.

Pick it up, it's totally worth it if you haven't played it already. I have no nostalgia whatsoever, my bias is actually more towards just preference of the genre than anything else. So if something complicated, long-winded and difficult is your cup of coffee, then I'd definitely recommend it. There's a reason this game was incredibly influential, though there are a lot of dated aspects it deserves to have the current Heroic (20) reputation it has.

All these years later and Baldur's Gate is still one of the best PC RPGs. Beamdog has done an outstanding job porting a PC game from 1998 to modern hardware and operating systems. Along with their many fixes the new content they've added to the game doesn't feel out of place.

All that said, Baldur's Gate will not wow many with it's visuals and the difficulty (especially in the early game) can be punishing. But the game still gets a thumbs up from me for it's great characters, wonderful open world, fantastic score, and incredible attention to detail. Highly recommended.

Pros:
It's Baldur's Gate, the game was solid back then, still is today.
If you liked it more than twenty years ago, you'll probably like it now.
I really appreciate the ability we have now to zoom/dezoom, allowing us to see a very large portion of the map

Cons:
I think this "enhanced" version should have come with: 
Better multiplayer management -> like, interrupting all players when any of them starts a dialogue with a NPC is really annoying
Better dubbing/translation -> in French version, some voices are still in English at random moments in the game

There are probably some rooms for improvements in terms of inventory management, or combat timeline as the game is turn-based, etc. but overall, it's fine, the game runs smoothly.

EDIT:
Oh one major thing should be fixed in this game: pathfinding/collision, but mostly pathfinding, i.e. the way characters move on the map -> it's buggy AF, they'll stay stuck for entire rounds before figuring out the way to go. 
Sometimes, the struggle for finding a path makes sense but most of the time it does not which leads to extremely annoying moments where your characters get stuck and sometimes killed because they seemed to dumb to even walk straight...
Brings back memories of when I first played many years ago, was fun then, and still is.

Many years later and this game holds up. The story and the gameplay. The characters and the Voice acting. It's all still great. Moving on to part 2...

I want to REALLY like this game as it is so similar to my beloved game, Never Winter Nights. With it, the ability to control squads of characters? Sounds awesome! But is executed... horridly. 

First off, the controls are weird. It takes a while to learn and it isn't easy. The UI inventory feels clunky and all over the place. Dropping items for example on the ground could be implemented much more smoothly. No shift-clicking or control clicking is implemented. Drag item, drop here, with weight AND limited inventory space per character. Get used to setting up your keybinds for a good while.

The main UI is also strange. You can't customize it to your liking, even though it is overall O-K.

Left and right mouse click will let your units move. With that said, accidental move orders are bound to happen; misclick. There is no option in the game to select your entire party except yourself. Finally, my biggest gripe, slow XP gain. I haven't even gotten to level 2. Each and every party member who kills a unit will not share XP to your party. Just themself. Or it is as it feels? Enemies are therefor too tough and I constantly die. Getting gold is also difficult until eventually you cannot afford to resurrect your party and all you have left is a mage with 4 hp. 

Great idea. Horrid gameplay. I'm still going to TRY to play through it though and I spent a lot of money on the game. BUT.... I do not recommend anyone getting the game. Stay away. It's not fun.

Some things in life are like comfort food. Some comfort foods are just as good as you remember them, some are only comforting because of a distant childhood memory but aren't particularly "good" meals, some comfort foods are those that have been a staple forever and they are constantly being updated and added to.

Infinity Engine games, of which this is the first, are all of these things. While the classic game has some definite issues when played on modern machines, the core game is solid and has managed to remain playable even two decades later. However, the enhanced edition came along and made it playable by incorporating updates to the UI, mechanics, and made it match up with its even more expansive sequel. 

Bioware cut its teeth on this game, and it shows as all the things they have evolved over the years have their foundations in this game and its ability to humanize the NPCs, provide options for play, and make the same quests still interesting even years later. I find myself resisting the urge to create new characters again and again, and I am pretty sure that character roll screen has consumed a significant portion of the gaming hours in my life.

I do sometimes wonder if I hadn't experienced this originally in 1999 if it would be as tasty today. A part of me thinks it definitely would be, but if I had grown up on more modern UI instead of playing the Ultima, Bard's Tale, and SSI Gold Box games in the 80s, I wonder. Yet many games today are still trying to capture lightning in a bottle like this classic as can be seen in Pillars of Eternity, Wasteland 2 & 3, Torment, and others. Hell, I would play a game today in the Infinity Engine if it were brand new - and you now can thanks to Siege of Dragonspear (although I haven't played it yet - I plan on going into it after I finish the game with this new character, unless I get distracted).

I got this game a while back and kept playing it off and on over a couple of years. I finally sat down, made a new character to get the full experience instead of taking breaks, and finished it. After finally finishng it while also completing a decent chunk of side content I can say without a doubt that this game just isn't worth playing to me.

The game is 7 chapters in total (not including the dlc which adds another chapter after the main story ends), but each chapter is only about 30 minutes to an hour long if you decide to just go from story beat to story beat. The only reason the game is as long as it is is because there are so many different areas to explore you spend the majority of your time not even doing the main quest, it's running around these side areas. This would be fine if not for the fact that these side areas have almost nothing in them, are pretty big, and your character moves at a walking speed. You can run into enemies, npc's to help with world building, and side quest stuff. Now I don't mind having these 3 being the main focus in side areas to bump into when exploring, the issue is that there are so many side areas and almost none of this stuff to do in them. It just becomes a slog to go through all these areas looking for something cool, and you realize the majority of it isn't. One area had me defend a cow from a bunch of enemies and that was supposed to be the fun encounter, and another had me pick up a cats body for a girl so she can bring it back from the dead. None of it is interesting and I feel like I got nothing out of exploring other than some better items. 

Now it's DnD and getting better items is cool. However at a certain point you just have so many you don't care anymore. Hell I got to the point where if I had to identify an object I would just ignore it because I had so many items I needed to identify already, and sitting around waiting for the ability to cast identify just to find out it's the 4th wand of paralyzing or another cursed ring got incredibly tedious.

As for companions, there were very few I enjoyed. The majority of them had a quick side quest you do with them once you meet them, you do it, and then they ask if they can stick around for a while. The only one I noticed who had a quest that actually took some time to complete was Neera the wild mage and even that ended on such a poor note I genuinely got angry at the devs for thinking that this was the way you end a companion quest line. Another major issue to me is the fact that the companions will just leave out of the blue. Now, I have to say I don't mind the idea that companions can leave or even turn on you if they don't like what you are doing, it's something that could happen in Planescape Torment and I loved it there. The issue here is that there is no warning other than a complaint made halfheartedly , and they can leave almost immediately after getting them. I ran into a drow elf and helped her out, and she started to travel with us. I ran between 2 different side areas, helped someone out, and next thing I knew she was gone. No warning, she just left the party and all the stuff I gave her was gone.

The combat is fine, it's the AD&D rules set and while I never played it in the tabletop format it works fine here. My only major issue with it is that the rogue I had in my group, Imoen, would refuse to detect traps until she was right on top of them and at that point they had already gone off. 

As for the story, something that this game gets very high praise for and what I wanted to care more about other than the combat, it just isn't well done. The prologue holds my attention but once I hit chapter 2 i'm bored out of my mind. You don't feel like what you're doing is connected to what happened to you in the prologue, and while the whole thing is actually connected it really isn't revealed until the end of chapter 3 or 4 where you learn what's going on, but by that point I just didn't really care. I get that this is supposed to be the first half of a campaign with Baldur's Gate 2 being the second awesome half where all the cool stuff happens and the story comes to a close but if I was playing in a tabletop campaign that had a slow first half and the DM said "I know it's boring now but just put up with all of this till the second half of the campaign, it gets much better I promise" I would walk away, because i'm not gonna put in the time to wait half a campaign to get to what the DM considers to be the good moments when the DM could have just made the first half of the campaign have awesome moments. 

Now, you can't compare this game to the newer CRPG's on the market, as time has gone on where newer games will perfect what Baldur's Gate did. However, I find that even comparing this game to other CRPG's released around the same time it still doesn't compare. The 2 major ones coming to mind that I can compare this game to is Planescape Torment and Icewind Dale 1. Planescape Torment is a smaller game than Baldur's Gate but the story held my attention all the way through and had much more interesting companions with companion quests that didn't suck. I enjoyed every moment of that game and the philosophy it poses is really intriguing and made me want to go back and do another play-through sometime soon. Now one could argue that Planescape Torment is a different kind of CRPG in that it's less combat focused and much more story focused than Baldur's Gate  and that's why the story was better, and beccause of this I have to talk about Icewind Dale 1. Icewind Dale has much less of a story and is much more combat focused than Baldur's Gate, and I would still argue that Icewind Dale has a better story. The game is much smaller than Baldur's Gate and because of that it leads to a more streamlined well told story because everywhere you go to is tied to the main story, it isn't like Baldur's Gate where you can end up in a bunch of the unmarked side areas that aren't important. In Icewind Dale everywhere you go is important and I remember that story so much more because of that.

In conclusion, while I get that Baldur's Gate 1 is the game that heavily influenced the CRPG genre into becoming what it is today, I would rather play the games that came out only a year or 2 afterwards as they  do what Baldur's Gate 1 tried to do so much better in my eyes. I do plan on playing Baldur's Gate 2 still as people say it is the better of the 2 games, but at this moment in time I'm gonna hold off as the amount of wariness this game instilled in me makes me afraid the sequel will be the same or worse.

Thanks for reading.

This game was a next-level RPG dream when I first played the demo after I left high school. I still own the cardboard sleeve with the multiple CD-ROM disks. If you also played this and loved it, why are you reading reviews?

I completely and totally recommend this if you ever played it when it or Icewind Dale were first released. You will surely not be disappointed in how this enhanced edition holds up. But, if you're a younger gamer who cut their RPG teeth on Elder Scrolls or any other games released in the last ten years, you might be in for a disappointment and I think it's only fair to be honest here: this game came out in December of 1998. It's a great game, but a mechanical step down if you're spoiled by games with modern graphics.

If you can step over that hurdle, this is one of the classics that every gamer should play through at least once. The storytelling is solid, the humor is consistent, the character building is what D&D was all about. Walk around like an overhead RPG, then spacebar to pause/unpause for refined control of the action in battle. Want to be a ridiculously powerful evil mage? Done. A noble paladin? Got it. A thief who just steals everything not nailed down with the help of the save and load feature? I mean, sure. The best experience is with all the DLC and the sequel, as you can transfer your characters from one game to the next and the DLCs unlock some extra levels which helps in curbstomping enemies.

So, if you're a pen and paper RPG fan or a nostalgia buff or one of the every-gamer-who-should-experience-this that I mentioned earlier, this is a classic RPG experience. Just don't buy this thinking you're getting Skyrim or Final Fantasy XV. This is a game that's worth the full price, although since you really want to get the two Baldur's Gate and two Icewind Dale games and all the DLC to properly go through the entire story, maybe you get it on sale because that's a lot of game to buy at once.

Baldur's Gate is an rpg based on Dungeons and Dragons 2nd edition. If you're completely new to Dnd, it might take a bit of learning to understand a few core concepts like Armor Class and damage dice, but the game gives you a decent explanation at the start. I'll be honest, I've played this game dozens of times since I was very young, and I still have not committed to memory what THAC0 means. 

Baldur's Gate has a lot more story and reading that a lot of games you might be used to. That's a feature, not a bug. The story and dialogue include some of the best parts of the game. Another great thing about these old dnd games, is that side-quests are both lengthy and rewarding. You hear people complain about modern single player games when they only feature an 8-hour linear story. While Baldur's Gate side quests might not be 8 hours long, you can sometimes take 4 hours or so on a well-written and engaging side-quest that will reward you with loot and a more fleshed out interpretation of the world.  

A few things are different between this version of Baldur's Gate and the original. I still have the CD's sitting at my folk's place, but they don't work on my newer computer. Some menu stuff is different. A lot of it I think is a matter of preference, but I have to say I like the old Journal better. The new map is nifty how it zooms in and out. For all the things they did fix, I can't fathom why they didn't fix the clunky movement. In the game, you'll probably have a party of 6 adventurers, and they quite regularly get tangled up when they try to go through narrow spaces and whatnot. That would have been my #1 thing to fix, but you get the authentic Baldur's Gate experience. 

One final note, I and many other people have always liked Baldur's Gate II even better. A big reason for this is because in Baldur's Gate 1, you start at level 1. Thematically it makes sense, but combat flows quickly in real time as the game processes the turns taken by all the characters and enemies, and when you're level 1, you can get 1 shot from a stray critical hit from just about anything. If you choose to play a mage, you could be getting one shot from level 1 all the way until you reach level 4, and you'll probably end the game around level 8. So this game is one where you'll want to be saving every couple minutes. On my most recent playthrough I purposely made a tanky fighter because it's just annoying to play a level 1 mage and get one shot from a bandit's arrow. 

I realized I kind of focused on the bad things, but Baldur's Gate is a true classic. The storytelling is great. The customization regarding what type of character you want to play is great. The world is very well fleshed-out. It'll drag you in for hours on end and you won't know where the time went. And then you get to play Baldur's Gate II afterwards which is even better.

You don't have enough inventory space to carry their junk after they get killed, so that all gets left behind unless you root around to maximize the value of your inventory- not that it matters since there's virtually nothing worth spending your money on anyways. Every which way you turn, another ridiculously overpowered enemy is waiting to get dog-piled and somehow still kill all 5 characters in your party without taking a single hit after a solid minute of combat, even with party members equipped with magic gear and casting spells on them! I managed to, by pure luck, kill everything on both road areas and completed all the quests in Candlekeep and at the Inn, but not a single level increase, since the xp required is well into the thousands and I only earn a dozen or so xp at a time! How do you even play this game?!

Baldur’s Gate is clunky in this era of smooth gameplay and fast action, but it is filled with excellent content with an engaging storyline that carries you through hours of content.  There is an impressive amount of flexibility in how you complete this game.  Play in a meandering fashion with storylines that weave a colorful tapestry of lore with every location and hidden corner or follow the main path with plenty of content to enjoy.  Your companions, should you choose to have any, have auto-combat options that give you options on the way you play as well as rich narratives and quests.  Although the graphics can be considered “outdated,” the art style is one I enjoy and is more than capable of creating beautiful landscapes, sprawling cities, and dark caverns.  There are complexities to the Dungeons and Dragons leveling mechanics that I was unfamiliar with when I played but it did not affect my ability to complete the game with satisfying builds.  With a bit of patience this game is a true winner.

I loved playing this game, it is just so fun and interesting. This was my first time through it as I was much too young to have played it when it originally came out, and it really did hold up. Some things are pretty dated, like the inventory, but at the root of it all is the great RPG gameplay you would want. I know some people recommend starting with the second game instead and it feels like you would be doing yourself a disservice doing that. The beginning is for sure that old Gygax play style of just being brutal and aiming for a party wipe, but you get pretty powerful pretty quick with some exploration. The difficulty options introduced are really nice, as you can scale back and forth if you find yourself getting stuck and can't figure out a way around it. The story itself is just interesting too and I found that it did a very nice regional crisis story while still feeling very personal for the main character. I'm sure I could replay this game with a different class and party and have a thousand variations to each encounter, it is a vast system of skills and gear. Final thing, make sure you explore around the world, you don't want to miss the expansion content that it does not steer you towards. Some of that content is the best of the whole game and left an impression. 

Hey also, Mages and Murderdads is an excellent podcast to listen to while you give this a play, tons of fun little details and feedback from people playing totally different styles.

Edit... Thank you Julius for the response. I had tried that already and it did not fix it. But, I started up Neverwinter NIghts last night and noticed it was also made by Beamdog but I had sound. So the light bulb came on in my brain and I went into the /Neverwinter Nights /bin /win32 folder and copied these files into my BGEE folder, openal32.dll and soft_oal.dll, and that seems to have resolved my sound issue for now. I have changed my recommendation for the game and hopefully anyone else who has this problem and has both games can use the same fix if nothing else worked for them.

Beamdog's Treatment Of Baldur's Gate

To be blunt it's been awful, riddled with bugs, and full of useless upgrades that are sometimes worse than useless.  Today's version is completely useless, so bad that I can't even play it any more.  There is no mouse, hasn't been for months.  You can't play the game without a mouse you see.  Beamdog resolutely refuses to admit there are bugs in their product, even though there are more than in the average roach motel.

There was an awful problem with action music coming on and staying on that was introduced with a "patch" that came out soon after the EE game came out.  Developers refused to admit they could duplicate it, until in a hurried rush, they fixed it with the advent of the disastrous BG 1.5.  Their computer was probably one of the few playing the game that couldn't duplicate the problem.  They finally "fixed" the problem by causing the forum threads about it to disappear.  They also introduced a revised method of reporting bugs, that makes it virtually impossible to report a bug.  I tried to report a problem on the new, improved bug reporting system, and couldn't even get logged in on it.

This game was better before it was modified in any way, except to upgrade the code to make it play on a modern computer.  My suggestion to Beamdog is to jettison all the new crap you've loaded on it (including BG 1.5) and publish as it was to start with.  Believe me you have added nothing worthwhile to the original.

Today I finally removed both Baldur's Gate and Baldur's Gate 2 from my computer.  I can only hope that some kindly company in the future ugrades the coding of the original game without trying to fleece it for all the money it's worth.  I was not compensated for this review.  I bought the game for myself.

I made a SINGLE COMMENT on the Baldur's Gate 2 forum, criticizing my permanent ban from the BG1 forum and was IMMEDIATELY AND PERMANENTLY BANNED from that forum.  I have tried to report this police state behavior to STEAM, but have not been able to find a way.  I believe the company should be permanently removed from its possession of this game on STEAM.

As  of April 25, 2021 the game is still completely unplayable.  Beamdog has taken what was once a great game and completely ruined it.  I continue to hope that someday they will lose the franchise to the game, and that it will be taken over by a company with some moderate degree of skill and respect for the original game.  But I'm certainly not holding my breath.
