Baldur's Gate. A game which revolutionized RPG genre 22 years ago. A game which stole my heart and a lot of hours of my life. It was amazing then and you know what, it still is! Beamdog's Enhanced Edition has everything original Baldur's Gate had + a lot of improvements. I could talk about support for higher resolutions or widescreen but those are given, and of course a great improvement to the old classic. I could talk about 2D, painted backgrounds but those are great and did not aged at all. I cannot tell the same about characters' sprites but those only look bad when you zoom in (a new addition in EE version). The music is great and the voice acting too.

The most important part for me though is the world, story of my character and his/her companions and RPG elements. If you are familiar with D&D and Faerûn, you will instantly fall in love with the computer version of it. You will spend hours on character creation screen to make sure you get those dreamed dice rolls and you know what? You will love every second of it! You will start your adventure and if RPGs (not some modern action RPGs like Witcher 3) are your thing, you will sink into the game wanting to know more and more of the story. The world of Sword Coast will be open to you and your companions (and with Beamdog's 4 new characters you will be able to choose 5 out of 29!). You will not get any question marks or exclamation marks on the map. But do not be scared, you will never get lost. You are free to roam and discover the world and by exploring you will find a lot of great, interesting places. You may or may not find quests by talking to NPCs. You will know where to go by reading your journal or quests description. 

I mentioned earlier that you can compose your party of 6 by acquiring 5 additional companions out of 29. It does not mean that any party will do. Some companions do not go well along with others. They will express their feelings, attitude and will comment on your achievements (or lack of those). They may fight with each other when their alignment is in opposition. They may ask you for a favor before permanently joining your company. I finished the games a few times and I did not check all of them, and I am not sure if I ever will, there is so many possibilities. I tested 3 out of 4 newly added characters (Baeloth, Dorn and Neera) and they meet high Baldur's Gate's standards. Baeloth is my favourite and will suite the evil party nicely (not recommended for a first play-through in my honest opinion).  

It is also worth mentioning that the EE includes the expansion pack Tales of the Sword Coast. It adds the best dungeon in the game, the Durlag's Tower. It is not only huge but also greatly designed and it scratches the itch to dungeon crawl. It presents a challenge but also adds great rewards. Worth visiting by any adventurer and 'must see' place for every Dwarf!

I could write more about combat, spells, enemies but there was so much already written about this game that I will just say that: Metacritic User Score: 89, Metascore 91. I know that EE has lower scores and I will never understand why as it is good old Baldur's Gate with some quality of life changes plus some great additions.

Must play RPG! If only to see how it influenced the genre and allowed it to flourish for years to come!

A great RPG classic that has been enhanced from the early original.  If you like challenging battles, a good storyline, interesting personalities, lots of map exploration, being able to swap party members, lots of skills to develop, main and side quests, dungeon crawls, and many character types along with hunting for gold and items, then this RPG will probably supply you with hours and hours of enjoyment.  Despite today's more graphically intense RPG gaming options, this is a really good place to start IMHO.  The UI is a bit clunky, but I still found it very engrossing, allowing enjoyment of the game rather than always sitting back and critiquing it.  Will move on to BG II, Icewind Dale series, Neverwinter Nights series, etc when finished here.  You can always move forward to newer RPGs, but there is a lot of bang for your buck here in BG, even an expansion pack to enjoy.  Hope everyone likes it as much as I am currently, and also hoping that my quick review here is helpful and not misleading in some way.

This initially took me a while to get into due to the outdated graphics, ui, and old D&D ruleset.

However now that I have beaten the game I can easily say this is one of THE BEST games I have ever played. This is the original Divinity Original Sin or Pillars of Eternity. I encourage you to stick with it if you are thinking of trying it out.

Here are a couple tips for things that were not immediately obvious to me when I started.

- Armor class and chance to hit do not work the same way they do in D&D 5E. AC is called THAC0 "To hit armor class 0". In this case lower numbers are good, high numbers are not.
- Quicksave ALL THE TIME. This is a hard game, you will need to quicksave and reload quite often and rethink your strategies for fights.
- When your characters are out of spells or injured you will need to rest to heal them. If you have any healers in your party they will automatically cast their healing spells on rest. You can rest in the wild or at an inn, and do it as many times as you need.
- If one of your characters dies you can revive them at a temple in one of the cities. Its not quite obvious HOW to do this though. When talking to the priest you have to click on the grey portrait of your dead character and then the revive option will become available. The dead character will then respawn next to you, and you will have to go back to where they died to pick up their items.
- Some of the potential party members have timed quests. Some party members (like Montaron and Xzar) will leave the party if you do not complete their initial quest soon enough. This is not initially obvious until all the sudden they walk out on you when you are in the middle of something. If a party member starts complaining you need to address their concerns so they do not leave. If you really need to I think you can edit a game file to adjust the timing so they won't leave right away.

I just had my first experience with this game in the year 2021.

For the context I am a Dungeon Master whom really didn't like the books setting because I didn't have any childhood nostalgia so I almost always wrote my own DnD Settings.

Let me get into this review though.

You start by rolling a character. Yes rolling as you can kinda just roll the dice over and over and over until you get the stats you want. I would prefer a point buy that player can set so you can be as Under powered or overpowered as you would like. Maybe have an achievement for beating the game "Peasant" 10's on each stat. and let players be as strong as they want to be without re-rolling stats 1300 times (This is not an exaggeration sometimes.)

I started with my 6 man Meme team of Alex Jones, Feedle Dee Keys, DORF (The elf hunter), Gorions person, Bark Souls the Berserker, and Pharrel Williams the Bard. I realised I was missing a lot of plot elements having a party like this though so I started from scratch and entered a more serious Play through as Gorions Ward "Faith" a Fighter Cleric.

I resolved the Iron Crisis, Fought Bandits, but all this culminated in Durlags Tower... DAMN what a very satisfying dungeon! Filled to the brim with traps and monsters and puzzles and lore. I loved this thing.

The main story is Alright but it's 2e so the games systems are all "Magic Items" and potions. The armor class also works... Backwards? Using this weird Thac0 system.. Gonna be real Thac0 sucks but it basically replaces "attack" and Armor class. Smaller numbers is better more or less for AC. 

Really great game though, possibly better then Pathfinder Kingmaker which is a MUCH newer game.

The difficulty even on normal is still a challenge and if you look for an easy "battle fest" this game is not for you. Some changes have been made compared to the original that I personally find confusing. These are mainly the added characters and now the overwhelming flood of new adventuring possibilities. I've played Baldurs gate since it's release in 1998. Since then, I have played it for around a thousand hours. (I'm aware my steam account says just under 70 hours, relax.) 
It's a DnD style (DnD Advanced rule set) with a top down display that has a customized pause setting for people who want more control over game play during battle.
I've beaten it using all classes and on all difficulties. This game is for players who enjoy the main story and play right through, but the real value comes from all of the side story stuff. When you know what to do in this game, the mechanics, and have experimented with everything, you can beat this game in about 40 minutes. You heard me right. (I should note that in order to get to that point, I was already a player for years.) 
When played well, this game offers around 50-60 hours of amazing stories, tough (and I mean friggen ridiculously though) fights, music, playable companions and their story lines, forgotten ruins, bar fights, drunk d-bags, beautiful women, and lore. You want lore? This game has more lore than any game I've ever played.
 This game is a classic in it's own right. What you see isn't just what you get, because this game has so much more to offer. It has DLC, an amazing sequel and I can honestly say that once you've finished everything (DLC, sequel and sequel DLC) You'll look back on your character and everything they went through over those 150-250 hours of gameplay and feel like you've grown as well. 

My advice as a seasoned player, Take your time. Read the conversations, ALWAYS check for traps and learn how to build a good team with the characters the game provides. The enhanced edition has an option to build the whole party from scratch but I can honestly say, don't do that, you miss out on the ability to build relationships and have wonderfully written story line moments with your characters. If you want to build the whole party and don't care for the party growth, play Icewind dale instead.

   This game is a masterpiece and will keep you coming back for more. I know I did.

I know that this review will draw the ire of most old school gamers (like me) but i tend to be fair in life and as such this review is to be as fair as possible regardless of the nostalgia it brings to some players of old.

For this review to be fair, i wont compare the game to the nowadays top down rpgs like Tyranny or Kingmaker or Pillars of Eternity. I will however compare this game to Icewind Dale, a game which shares more or less the same graphics, it follows the same gameplay principles, is set in the same setting and was published in the same period or so as Baldur's Gate. I will make no comments on graphics or character creation as it was based in an old and pretty strict pen and paper D&D version.

I have read many players commenting about how Baldurs Gate I is a game that stands out for it's story... I guess the story is... well it's boring... 

The prologue wins your interest, then you meet your first companion and begin to play the game... The thing about BG is that it offers lots of maps to explore, most of them though are not related to the story... This means that you are dumping the storyline and walk around for days upon days exploring maps and dungeons as if the main enemy is waiting for you to catch up... In the case of Icewind Dale most sidequests were either linked or were in the way of the main story... The heroes would literally solve quests which found on their way to the ultimate goal and not valse around to another area Ignoring the real threat for a "fetch me" quest as far as BG goes...

The games sidequests are also boring... "Fetch me bandit scalps oh good adventurer" (how the hell am i to play a good sided party when i am asked to gather the scalps of the outlaws you had me killed and not somehow bring to justice???), "My cow is sick and needs medicine, fetch it", "I lost my boots to the enemy, fetch it", "I lost my cloak to the enemy, fetch it", "I was attacked by "x" enemies, kill them", "My hunband is missing, find him", ""x" son is gone missing, find him" and the list goes on with quest missing context and  feeling... On the other side of the table in Icewind Dale i remember trying to find a Rose Made of Ice for a bard who was banished from his home for loving the kings daughter, and his quest in order to win her hand was to travel around the world searching for the flower in order to be able to return home and marry her. You meet him in a bar, drinking his days in sorrow after years of searching and not finding it... Eventually you had it forged in secret by a kick @ss blind dwarven crystal master smith who was literally guarding the way to a key npc of the story!! Side quest completed while running for main story... Or another, when i met a whole tower of undead Elves, some were mad and attacked others had their unique background and seeked my help in order to move on to afterlife...

Two games of the same period, two very different approach of how a story should be told... In BG from a certain point and on you literally "farm" around the maps of creeps, completing mindlessly the sidequests just for the crappy xp reward and low level gear. No sense of epicness. No sense of your party being heroes... There was no drive to play the main story at all, it was made clear of what was happenning since chapter 3 or 4? out of the total 7 and the only thing hanging was your heritage probably the only cool part in this whole game... In Icewind Dale on the other hand, every time you though you had found who was responsible for the events which were taking place, another clue or npc would pop up offering light to what you already knew and shifting the sand until the very end where you met the enemy and i was "holy hell, no one prepared me for such and epic battle..."

Timed quests... Jesus, really... who thought of those... You would have an npc giving you a quest but failing to mention that it should be done pronto, as if in 5 days or 1 month or something to hint that you need to hurry... This lead me to failed quests and reloading older saves backtracking and moving on... And ofc the npc had to join your party which meant you had to leave behind your favorite and dressed up set up to get the underleveled and undergeared npc in a cavern carrying him as a deadload, excluding him from combat or having him using range attacks just to be able to keep him at distance until the quest was completed and dumped at the nearest point to pick up your favorite companion again, who by the way had lost the xp of the quest since he was off party....

I have read in the Internet that there lots of hidden stuff to be found etc, but seriously who gives a crap about a tome which increases your stat, when the core of a game (the story) is boring and most of the sidequests are just a dissapointment...

Crappy gear... It took me several hours of gameplay to get my hands on some magical items, and there are very few choises at that... There is probably only 1???? 2h sword of worth? No Bastard sword loot? and in general all magic/special items resolve around very certain weapons in the game... the rest of the categories for some reason are left out forcing the player either playing with simple non magical items which later on are a terrible drug for combat, or entirely throw away their proficiencies and start to play with whatever comes their way hoping for the better... 

I haven't played the DLCs yet, and I haven't tried the BG 2 game either, I will though out of sheer stuborness... (blame the dwarf in me). Following the formentioned points of dissappointment it's no wonder why i have always started the game in the past and dumped it somewhere along the way....

To conclude this extensive review mostly on the games storytelling, I wouldn't recommend the game unless you find it on a good discount. Even then buy it knowing that this is a pass timer game, keep your expectations on story telling low and make sure you read on the internet which weapons are the most common to be found in magic or special edition and build you heroes around those choises. 

Thanks for reading this through :)

This game is very old and is bad compared to modern games. Most modern games, have better UI for casting spells and displays for AoE spells like fireball. It uses 2nd edition which is a bad edition of DnD. Some parts of the game feel slightly tedious and there is little input after character creation outside of spell selection and weapon proficiency. This is because it's based on second edition and 2nd edition is bad. The Enhanced Edition has a higher XP cap than the original. The XP cap is stupid and punishes what should be a valid play style. It should be a valid strategy to have a smaller party and get higher XP from being a small party. Kingmaker has that feature implemented and it's kind of balanced.

Overall, this game is not for everyone. I highly recommend this game to people who are fans of DnD/cRPGs and are also into historical video games. Buldurs gate is a classic and I recommend it to people who can appreciate it but that group of people is kind of niche.
This is the classic. If you want a full role play game experience, it is this one. Must have.

Baldur's Gate is a healthy starting point for people who are interested in the mechanics of a Dungeons and Dragons manual. By creating a character, and playing through a campaign developed by BioWare, players will have a head-start when sitting down at their first D&D session. The game is engaging, replayable, and is well balanced between story-development and dungeon-crawling. Pack your bags and buckle your seat-belt, this one is a ride to remember.

It's one of the cornerstones CRPGs, an absolute class and deserving of all the hype it gets.

The AD&D system it's built on shows its age and definitely is a detractor, but the story and characters and beautiful hand drawn environments more than make up for it.

Baldur's Gate is one of the best RPGs ever made.

The visuals, the music, the writing, the gameplay, the story - it's all fantastic.

I don't know what I can say about this game that hasn't been said before. I've been playing this game for the last fifteen years and I haven't gotten bored of it. I don't think I ever will.

I'm not blind to its flaws though. Once you reach the titular city the pacing kind of goes out the window and you have no reason in the story to explore the massive world this game throws at you. The companions are a little flat and there are loads of them, since I think the devs assumed that people would play this game with the mindset that they were disposable - hence why there are so many thieves you can obtain at different points in the game.

That massive world is also just a little too massive. There's not too much to do in it, but I honestly find it really relaxing to just walk around while listening to the music and diegetic sound.

There's up to 100 hours of content in this game alone. You have the main questline, the countless side quests, the areas to explore, numerous dungeons to crawl, the companions to meet, and so much more. I am of the opinion that this game contains the best dungeon in an RPG, ever, in the form of Durlag's Tower. The mystery, the puzzles, the battles, and the story are interwoven brilliantly.

Durlag's Tower is part of the Tales of the Sword Coast expansion released shortly after the original. Sometimes I want to replay Baldur's Gate, and then I remember this content, and I'm instantly convinced to make a fresh character.

Beamdog also contributed some new content in the Enhanced Edition, beyond just the quality of life improvements (and system overhaul). Four new NPCs join the fray, and they're a bit more in line with what you've come to expect from cRPGs in the modern day. That is to say, very chatty.

Their writing is pretty good though, and I'd say they fit into the game quite well. There's Rasaad, Dorn, Baeloth, and Neera - my favourite. They're hit or miss characters, and they're easily dismissible in their first encounter. All of them, with the exclusion of Baeloth, have their own unique quest that scores you some pretty neat loot and character interactions.

Baeloth is more of an easter egg character. He appears in Larswood after you hit level 5. He debuts in the arena mode that the Enhanced Edition ships with - the Black Pits.

It's what it sounds like. A pit fighting mode where you make a party of up to six characters and fight enemies of increasing power at the behest of *Baeloth the Entertainer!* It's fun for a good four hours, but it's not for everyone.

Yeah so play this game, please. It's good.
It's Baldur's Gate. If you haven't played it, or haven't heard of it, you're missing out. Period.

I have to turn off the sound effects, because there is a weird noise which occurs EVERY TIME your cursor pauses over or selects an item. ("sppplllliffff"--you are smoking sth). This is the only DnD game with lots of ability tomes, and the follow-up BG2EE has the Machine of Lum the Mad, which allows you to raise each ability one point per group. It is a bit tedious, in all, considering the way the 'monsters' follow your mage around, disregarding even the most stalwart fighters (with whom they are already engaged in melee combat--we are supposed to get opportunity attacks as well as the option to thwart their attempts to pass us by). Plus, you can't see more than about twenty feet ahead of you even in broad daylight (seriously)--making the game just as tedious as it can be. Other complaints, the only viable characters are berserkers and barbarians, due to the way the enemy magic users tend to cast group-affecting spells, such as chaos, horror, or confusion, as though it were something more than a mere annoyance (forcing you to resurrect characters and pick up/re-equip all of their stuff).

Been revisiting this game for almost two and a half decades. It still hasn't gotten old. Infinity engine games are the closest you'll get to the pen & paper sense of wonder. Somehow even more satisfying than newer versions of the formula such as Pillars of Eternity or the Divinity series (which are also great rpg's in their own right).
Currently replaying both BG's before I dive into the third installment! I urge you to do the same as they are timeless gems! And I know we tend to use the term often, but due to the depth of gameplay mechanics and the 2d "hand drawn" art style, these games truly don't age!

General description: strategic Diablo style game set in one of the D&D worlds. At first I didn't really like the game, mainly the first hour or so but with a proper guide to start you out you can get into it. It's based off the original D&D rules, it's got a good story and a good cast of characters and companions. The side quests aren’t tedious to do and it's really nice to see a good collection of classic D&D monsters. The game's been around a long time and the enhanced version is great for newcomers.

Lord, how many playthroughs is that now? 8, 9, 10? Every time I finish it, I say "That's probably the last time..." 

But it never is, I always come back. Even if there's nothing new to discover, there's always a different character build to try out, a different party composition... or maybe nostalgia just gets the better of me and before I know it I'm back at Candlekeep again. 

The first 10-15 hours are up there with my top experiences in gaming. Simple yet unforgettable, incredibly nostalgic stuff. I'll still be coming back to this when I'm taking assisted showers and eating liquidised meals. 

Speaking objectively, and going by today's standards, it's not a perfect game by any means. But perfection is vastly overrated anyway. The core of this game is so wholesome that even its flaws start to look more charming than annoying.

I sat down recently and blasted through the game on Story Mode. I really just wanted to refresh my BG memories before diving into BG3. So understand that I definitely didn't see everything Beamdog did with this venture, to include completely overlooking Siege of Dragonspear. 15 hours to clear the game is decidedly short. That being said, it was a much improved experience. Let's be honest, the combat was never all that fun. I'm sure there are some people who enjoy it and even have their PhD in THAC0 - I am not one of those people. Story Mode addresses that effectively - combat is a non-issue, you will win all of your fights with the most literal of plot armors. It doesn't feel great, but at the same time you can play through BG1 in time it takes to play the campaign of a modern FPS and enjoy revisiting the world. Certainly worth the price of admission.

I first played Baldur's Gate back in the 90s when the Abridged Edition was part of one of those demo CDs you used to get with computer magazines. Well, I played the hell out of it, so much so that I bought the full version, split across six CDs. Well, wouldn't you know it, I worked my way through to the Cloakwood Mines, had to insert CD #4, it was scratched, drive wouldn't read it and I had to abandon my playthrough.

Back to the store I went, and this time bought the game split across four CDs! Well, this was fine for a time, but eventually one of the CDs got lost or scratched or a friend never returned it... you know how it goes. So I bought it again, this time on DVD! This time I played right through to the end, but 
[spoiler] I had a lot of trouble with the doppleganger fight in the Ducal Palace (little did I know, Dispel Magic works to get rid of their Haste and Blur buffs). [/spoiler] Well, I finally win the fight and quicksave, autosave, save over my normal save, so happy I am to have finally won. But I can't progress. Why? At least in old versions of the game (don't know if it's the case now), [spoiler] Belt can die in this fight, and if he does, you can't go on to fight Sarevok[/spoiler]. So I never finished this game as a child, due to this oversight. But, in 2019, I actually (finally) did it, this time with the Enhanced Edition from Steam!

TLDR: I bought this game 5 times between 1998 and today and it took me 20 years to complete it. Would I recommend it? Absolutely.

Well, this is a take from someone who doesn't shy away from old games, even though I was still a little brat when this game came out. After investing 100 hours into the game, I can finally say that I'm ready to highlight some pros and cons. Pros:[list][*]Wide range of available companions and party combinations;[*]Narratively strong game by the late 90s standards (today - not so much);[*]Siege of Dragonspear DLC is genuinely good and feels hand-crafted and more focused than the main campaign.[/list]Cons:[list][*]Silly, uninspired writing;[*]By today's standards the storyline is very clichéd and weak;[*]Many boring fetch quests (go kill 'insert_enemy', bring back my 'item_name');[*]No companion banter (fixable by mods);[*]Slow running speed (fixable by mods);[*]Horrendous inventory management (you can improve item stacking by mods, but that's it);[*]2nd edition D&D rules suck for low-level adventures (mages are prone to be one-shotted in every encounter);[*]Empty maps with lots of wasted space;[*]Durlag's Tower is an exercise in patience and constant reloading;[*]Severely dated engine with annoying pathfinding and collision problems;[*]Multiplayer is often broken.[/list]Overall, this game is a relic of the past even in its Enhanced rendition. I've played a fair share of the late 80s and early 90s games (Wizardry, M&M, Gold Box SSI games) so putting up with a bad UI and other problems doesn't bother me too much, I can still enjoy the old-school experience, and that's why I won't leave a negative review. Would I ever consider recommending this game to my peers or friends? Definitely not. Honestly speaking, you can skip this one and go straight to Baldur's Gate II. That one is better in pretty much every aspect, albeit is more restrictive when it comes to world exploration. But that's for the best.

An exhaustive D&D video game experience that still holds up 23 years on. The full monty of characters, classes, combat, and LORE on display. Wield classic magic spells and items, under a satisfying isometric gaze astride a party of goofy toons all carrying unique catch phrases into your constant war against goblins, gibberlings, gnolls, ghasts, ghouls and… xvarts. There are almost too many characters (your party caps at 6 in total vs. 25! recruitable party members), feel like I need to play through the game thrice to *meet* everyone worth meeting. Storyline is fairly conventional but manages to be a satisfying yarn that hits all over the Forgotten Realms planescape. You get to meet both Elminster and Drizzt! Take your time, do the sidequests, and once more, I recommend a guide or walkthrough to fully soak the paths available. More than anything else, this game just makes one want to play D&D with your friends, as player or manager - so many characters and plots, so much loot, so many ideas! ~ 8/10

This game really hasn't aged very well, you can spend literally 10 minutes trying to roll optimal stats for your character instead of just being able to put stats where you'd like as in most RPGs with character creation. This rerolling also isn't optional, you're REQUIRED to have good stats even on regular difficulties because in this game there's tons of ambushes, assasins and fights in small, tightly packed areas which makes kiting really hard and if you have low stats, you'll literally be one shot by enemies. Even with maxed out CON, you will most likely be one shot by strong enemies at the start of the game, so you absolutely need maxed out DEX and that's before going into anything actually relevant to your character class that you want to play! The fact that there are 4 higher difficulty levels than that, which buff enemies far more in their damage, more attacks per round, better hit rate, better evasion and significant HP boost makes me question the sanity of the people who came up with this. On the comple opposite end of spectrum, Story mode difficulty literally makes your entire party unable to die!!!

The battles in this game sometimes relegate to me just standing and waiting while both parties keep missing for literally 3-4 minutes straight, with my shooters missing like 30 arrows in a row against a target less than 5 feet away from them even with good stats and being proficent in bows. I probably wouldn't mind so much but you can't retrieve any of these arrows that they miss and they cost gold!

You're also unable to run in this game, everyone just casually hobbles on a slow and steady pace. This makes navigation of the large open world areas take way longer than they should.

Issues that existed already when the game came out are even more obvious now, such as sometimes objects and treasures being literally completely lost in the backgrounds and sometimes doors and entrances to places being totally hidden, so you have to hover around playing "where's the entrance" on top of the buildings with the entrance area being very small and sometimes, you may not even realize that it was a place you could enter because of that. This is very annoying, since it's required to do as even these "where's the entrance" buildings sometimes contain important things, such as quests and followers that you may miss if you don't do it. There's option to turn these ugly floating text boxes and highlighting all containers and such, but it actually doesn't highlight any of the "where's the entrance" buildings entrances, only the super obvious and in clear view doors!!

The enhanced edition has removed all the video cinematics, especially cutting away the iconic intro was a real shame.


There's still some charm and fun in the game but it's just too cumbersome and frustrating to recommend for anything higher than -60% off the price during a sale.
It's a classic. If you get nostalgic for old school turn-based rpgs, this will always be the gold standard.

The game that started it all.  Bioware's love letter to DnD and western RPGs created a PC-oriented WRPG renaissance that spurred the creation of dozens of classics including the incomparable Baldur's Gate 2, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment and non-Infinity titles like Morrowind and Fallout 3.  All in all, Baldur's Gate sets the stage for all the tropes and key elements that led to countless classics.  Yes, the game is a bit slow.  Yes, very little happens in it, compared to other more grandiose titles but, ultimately, such faults can be forgiven for giving birth and spawning such a parade of excellence.

Description: Classic isometric RPG with real-time pause
Pros: ... it's a capital C Classic, I guess... ?
Cons: Repetitive combat based on sheer luck; identical locations; bare-bones story; interchangable characters; outdated graphics
Length: Probably at least 50 hrs, based once again on your luck more than anything else
Verdict: This is a disappointment all around. If you are a fan of good Bioware games like Dragon Age 1 or Mass Effect trilogy - then skip this game, because it has nothing on them. Characters are completely interchangable - you can't talk to them, you can't argue with them, and if you leave them they will be standing there for eternity, waiting for you to come back. This game has suprisingly low amount of text/writing compared to a modern 'revival' cRPGs like Pillars of Eternity, and whatever it has, it is boring. Combat system based on some DnD rules is atrocious (you can spend minutes trying to hit somebody and be missing them) and the only way I found to play Baldur's Gate and to get some enjoyment is in Story Mode. Don't bother with this; there is a dozen better modern cRPGs instead, like Divinity games or Tyranny etc. 3/10.

I wish I could give everyone the experience of how mind blowing this game was for me. I went from games, like Mario, Alley Cat and Crystal Caves, which were pure 2D games in four colours, to this colour rich, gorgeous scenery in isometric detail. 
It was like someone vision impaired being able to get full vision and not only in a regular way but in a fantastical world, with more abilities, such as seeing infrared and ultraviolet. I started playing Dungeons and Dragons shortly before playing Baldur's Gate, seeing the rule books come to life in such a fluid way on PC was a mountain of icing and cherries on an ocean sized cake.

I am currently going through my eighth play through, this time with a friend that has stuck with it for more than half the game and been drawn into it now, to the point where they are asking when we can continue playing it. 
Admittedly, I am a little too experienced, we flew through content, my characters are min-maxed, we started clearing map areas just to hunt for some experience to tackle the next bit of the story more. This lead us to Durlag's Tower at only level four, having completed Naskel, the Stronghold, the bridge and every map area south of the Friendly Arm Inn. For some reason, I had never completed the tower, I have gone up it a few times but this was the first time I realised that we could go down.
Durlag's Tower was gruelling, we had our first party wipes, multiple times, had to come up with more tactics, use scrolls, wands and potions for the first time. This totally optional bit of game play was a delightful, "Easter Egg" for me to stumble over, all these many, many years later.

Thank you Beamdog for keeping this game alive, updated and ever improving. It is greatly appreciated being able to come back to a game and not have it soured by problems running it or the graphics being stretched to 8x8 monitor pixels per game pixel.

This game has been tweaked to distraction. Hp-wise, you need (on normal mode) 2500 xp to reach first level. Classically, it is 1000 xp. I tried a thief and a mage. This makes playing an evil character difficult, because if you do not turn in the quests for xp, but rather decide to keep the items yourself for your own use, you have a very hard time leveling.

Also, the Open AL files download as old or corrupt. You, then, have to figure-out that this is the problem, and then find where to fix this. So sad. Wonderful classic game.

This game was classically hard in a couple of spots, but now it has been tweaked to make it nearly impossible on any mode that is normal or above. Modern game developers don't seem to know what "fun" is. "Fun" is when I don't have to re-do battles over and over again on normal level pulling out all stops and hoping for a better die roll. THAT is hard-cord. That should be the hardest possible level. I should not have to play through on story-mode (which here is stupidly easy) or the next easiest mode, then import my character to start them at a higher level to be able to play normal or above. 

"Fun" is choosing whether or not to stress your heart with the frustration of very challenging battles, but "fun" is not engaging in one impossible battle after the other, having to edit a character or game file to get what you need to succeed. I want a vanilla experience, in that I do not need to edit things to tweak my character to be able to succeed in the game. I accept reloading once or twice at the Friendly Arm in, at the end of the mines, and a few other spots, but not nearly constantly. 

Devs should remove the 25 strength off of the story mode. That's what I'm meaning with stupidly easy. Normal should mean monsters do normal damage and characters do normal damage. They are the same hd as the characters (bzw if there are 6 lvl 2 characters, the hit dice of the monsters matches that). Go down one level, the monsters do 75% damage and are 75% hd of characters total. Story mode should be monsters do 50% damage and are 50% hd to characters total + characters cannot die. Up from normal should be monsters EITHER are x2 hd of characters OR they do 150% damage, OR they are 125% of both hd and damage. The hardest level should be EITHER x3 hd to characters OR 200% damage.

Battles should be being hd scaled based on party content. This wasn't as easy back when this was developed and may not be possible now. If not, then battles should be based off of anticipated party content. It is expected that there will be 1-4 hd of characters, scale for 2, if it is not dynamically scalable. 

Beam Dog digs its hands too far into these old classics, messing them up. They are not made better. They are made stupider to match the modern trend of catering to power-gamers, rather than leaving us RPGers something to enjoy.

I've been playing this game (or a version of it) off and on since 1998.  It and its sequal BG2 are such good games mechanically, with such a responsive engine, that it's still my favorite implementation of the D&D rules (2nd edition/Advanced in this case) in any PC game.  On top of that, the story across these two games are incredible.  Yes, the character interactions are a bit weak in this, the first of the Bioware games, but a lot of the ground work that appears later is started here.  And better, of all the Infinity Engine games I've played, this one most encapsulates that feeling of wonder and terror that is low-level, old school D&D.  

Highly recommend this game.

I played these games originally when they first came out many years ago, eventually finishing Throne of Bhaal with my Blade character (with a Blackadder voice set mod!). Since I'd bought the Enhanced Editions on sale a couple of years back, I decided to try them out just to see if they were as good as I remembered....

It's been about 22 years since the original Baldur's Gate was released, and the age of this game does show, despite Beamdog's tweaks. A more modern game to compare it against would be Pillars of Eternity, which feels very similar, despite the 15 year gap between the two games. For starters, the in-game character models look blurry, and I cannot fathom why Beamdog added an option to let you zoom in on your characters when all it does it make them look even more blurred. Combat animations are stiff and jerky - don't get me started on the monk's unarmed attack, which looks like he's trying to kick a can while standing on an ice rink, or characters fighting with two weapons, who look like they're attempting to play the drums. The AI is also utterly brain dead; your characters will continually walk into each other in combat when you're trying to get your seriously injured fighter to swop places with the cleric behind him while an angry ogre is bearing down on you, and they routinely get stuck on obstacles when you click on them to move to an area far away from where they are. Enemies will moronically attack the characters in your party that are closest to them, so for example, a group of bandits with bows will all shoot at the fighter walking towards them instead of the mage just standing a little further back who happens to be busy casting a fireball spell. The early part of the game can be quite unforgiving while your characters are still 1st or 2nd level, and an unlucky random encounter while travelling on the overland map can easily result in your adventure coming to a premature end. Also, the game uses the Dungeons and Dragons 2nd Edition rule set and the learning curve can be quite steep for those people who've never played the tabletop version of the game. There is also very little actual voice acting in the game so you will have to read lots of text, but this won't be a problem if you're accustomed to games like Pillars of Eternity.    

On the plus side, the gameplay is quite addictive with lots of areas to explore, things to do and freedom to play the way you want. The game doesn't hold your hand, as levelling up is extremely slow by today's standards, and you are encouraged to think a bit both in and out of combat. The hand drawn backgrounds like the forests and towns are still lovely to look at, even by today's standards, and the game runs smoothly, with no in-game monetization or loading screens to contend with!

If you haven't played this before and you enjoy party based RPGs with real time combat like Pillars of Eternity, what are you waiting for? Even if you're a Baldur's Gate veteran like myself, it's nice to return to the game again just to be able to play it in Windows 10 with the enhancements Beamdog has added to it.

It's Baldurs Gate. What is there not to like.

This is a tough one to decide.  On the one hand, when these games first came out, they were amazing.  Even now, they still stand out for strong narrative, interesting characters, and great ideas.  The problem is that they aged poorly.  The enhanced edition improves the graphics and adds some great usability features, but the game is still so old that it's sometimes hard to keep going.  I have started this game so many times without finishing it.

If you're willing to look past its flaws, though, this is still an experience you really can't have anymore, and it's worth struggling through the awkward bits to get to the meat inside.

It's really a very cozy game so far! I barely feel I've scratched the surface at fourteen hours in; it didn't feel like that much time at all! I can see how some might find the game annoyingly unique in its pacing and presentation. But I really like it.

Enthusiast of the original versions of the Baldur's Gate series and even replaying the first game a decade and a half later it still holds up very well. Baldur's Gate 2 might be the better RPG of the two but god is the first game so much more fun in my opinion. Baldur's Gate 2 is better known for its high-level play as well as its superior RPG elements to the first but I gotta say the comfy low-level exploration of the first game, a good story handled as a well written mystery, as well as more entertaining characters (albeit static compared to the second game's characters) makes it more fun in my opinion.  The new characters for the Enhanced Edition feel out of place but they're easy to ignore. Besides that, most changes in the Enhanced Edition are for better ease of life including the scroll tube, gem pouch, and potion case which saves so much time for inventory management. Overall the Enhanced Edition for the first game is pretty good but if you care to get the classics, "Good Old Games" bundles the EE with the original version.

I haven't sunk as many hours into this game as others, though it is a game that I have thoroughly enjoyed. With a callback to the Advanced Dungeon & Dragons 2nd edition rules, it's already gotten me all nostalgic, and to be short and sweet, I recommend the game as it is a classic and a fun game, unlike the modern 5e D&D system. 

The interaction between NPCs, PCs and the choices really make this game fun, with the many options for interactions, Charisma being a helping factor and absolutely broken spell combinations, I can get immersed in the game for hours (one of the few games that does that for me).
The game feels like an AD&D game, it got me immersed and with the many, MANY NPCs who wants to join you, the replay-ability of the game is fantastic. I've often come back, again, and again just to see the different party makeups, or make my own. With the different settings for the game as well bringing you closer to the true AD&D rules, it brings both punishment and reward for the older players. 

The Siege of Dragonspear was more fun because I played it in Coop with a friend, and we were busy making fun of the writing than actually getting immersed in the game. I can't really recommend Siege of Dragonspear because the writing and story alone read like a snarky person, everything was either sarcastic, poor attempts for being witty or downright evil comments. The story too made me laugh more than anything, with the main antagonist being said to have almost a thousand swords by their side and the Good People having barely 500 swords.
For a single player, Siege of Dragonspear had the best mass combat I had seen displayed for a 2e DnD game. With castles, monsters, and magic going haywire, it was an absolute treat to participate in.

Posting this after completing the full story arc through Throne of Bhaal (include Siege of Dragonspear) with the same character.  This is not the first time I've played the game (I owned the originals when they were first released) but it has been over a decade since I last played. 

Regarding the basic game (ignoring the Enhanced parts):  This is THE rpg game for me.  I've played others, but in the end Baldur's gate  saga is the standard to judge by.  That said, if you had to get just one then go with BGII.  But, if you are willing to get both then include BG as well since then you can experience the full character arc, from lowly waif that needs to be careful of what you engage until you become an epic character from legends.  There are lots of choices you can make, companions to meet, and things to do.  So many so that you can replay and get a completely different experience just by changing what you want to focus on.

Regarding the enhancements:  bottom line is that they are worth it.  In particular, adjusting to modern screen sized, changes to inventory management, quick loot, etc. 

Regarding the Siege of Dragonspear: This was the weakest part of the saga, in part since it's pretty much linear.  That said, it's nice to close the gap between the end of BG and the start of BGII.  I certainly won't be skipping it on future playthroughs. 

Last: I've yet to play with The Black Pits content (since they aren't tied to the story arc) so I've nothing to say except: good to have even more content to play with.  I imagine this will be fun when I want to try out new character builds.

I played this game when it first came out over 20 years ago. Not only is this a walk down memory lane, but now I'm playing it at max video settings at 5k. I love it! Its like seeing an old friend who is doing way better now than they were doing way back when. 
This is a difficult game, even on Easy mode. If you like being challenged to the point on dying and reloading often, this is the game for you. However, having said that, there are mods out there for this game that can help make things easier (such as fully charging your wands) without cheating too much. The save editor alone makes this game worth playing, because it IS a good RPG with a good story that is very D&D.  Play it how you want, use the internet to help with quests, and spend hours playing this game. Honestly. Now that I have the resources at my disposal to help make this game more enjoyable, I can't stop playing it! I've spent a good 18 hours on Durlag's Tower alone, lol! 
Bottom line, age has made this old-school game even better! It may be VERY outdated graphics-wise, but its a game with good story and lore. Check it out!

BG 1 (Siege of Dragonspear review below this):

While there are some differences with the original version,  the enhanced version works well for more recent rigs and has some improvements with general game play.   Overall I think it to be worth it, especially for those wishing to take a trip down nostalgia lane or those who may be new to the Baldurs Gate series and like this style of game play and RPG should find it enjoyable.  HOWEVER......

BG1  (Siege of Dragonspear):   

For those interested in nostalgia, this may become an issue.  For those not having played from years past and this is their first run through with with having done BG1 once already, AND planning to play BG2, this also may become an issue.

SoD is an attempt by Beamdog to create a stream of continuity between BG 1 and BG 2 by explaining what happens between them(as there was originally a "left to the players imagination" gap in time before.

The story may not make some players feel clear(wont spoil it).  But also one of the biggest issues is that the equipment used in SoD is pretty strong, way more so than most of the BG1 gear and comparable to mid and just stepping into late game gear of BG2  as well.  This then makes the transition(again wont spoil) from Dragonspear to BG2 that much more frustrating(again with the story issues added). 

In my mind that's a serious imbalance. To put it bluntly,  Dragonspear is a monty haul that leaves the player feeling like it didn't need to be, especially with what happens in transition into BG2.  

Most of the story is a filler episode with only a very few things relating to the BG2 transition until the end of the story and in a way I didn't feel was plausible.  ***Sorry this time I will use a spoiler*** Having the the player's party go through building up(if played that way) through out BG 1 as heroes, then doing the same with massive fanfare even in the start of it) by the leaders of Waterdeep and the city's general population, have them again become huge heroes at the end based on what they do(again) and then because they are framed (and in a really badly written/'done way that is shark jump) for killing the daughter of 1 of the leaders of waterdeep(who was trusting of them throughout the events) and then all the rest of the leadership, people who earned rep with and worked with along the way during the siege story, is just completely and utterly a bad story "twist" (its not a twist, its just a bad plot hole).

Thus given the story's progression, the gear progression and more, SoD is just a sad mess.  It easily could've been done differently and more fitting into a good continuity gap, but instead it just has all the earmarks of some person wanting to put their rather mark on the franchise's story fumbling it like an amateur writer would and with a completely different writing voice making no attempt to have synergy with the writing previously.

Baldur’s Gate is a fantasy RPG where you control a party of characters in pauseable real time combat.

I played the original version when it first released in 1998, and finished it multiple times over the next few years. It was the first RPG I ever played, and the fact that I enjoyed it so much is what led me to other RPGs, from Baldur’s Gate 2 to NeverWinter Nights, Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age, Mass Effect, The Witcher, and many more.

The most important thing to say in this review is that, despite being such an old game (even this Enhanced Edition is now 7 years old), it still feels great to play. Its fair to say it doesn’t have the graphical quality of a modern game, but everything else – the story, characters and combat are high quality. I’d say the best comparison among modern games is the Pillars of Eternity franchise.

And in some ways BG EE felt like a new experience for me. The last time I played the original was probably 15 years ago, and while I still had some clear memories of the companions I’d recruit into my party, and some of the locations you travel to during the main quest, I also found alot of interesting side quests during my 30 hour playthrough that I either missed before, or were new additions to the Enhanced Edition.

If you enjoy RPGs but you’ve never played this classic game, pick it up (along with BG2 EE which I’ll be replaying soon) in a sale and play it while you wait for BG3 to fully release from early access.
There are some long sections of this game to build up xp and levels but the characters, interaction and dialogue, it was a great story adventure for anyone that ever liked or as curious about D&D.

One of the godfathers of computer role-playing games, Baldur's Gate has an engaging storyline; fun characters; lots of side quests; and a great look & feel that will keep you playing for hours. -REVIEW-
Happy 11th review to me! I think it's time I covered the game that has the longest playtime on my steam account(523 hours): Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition. Old one, eh? Still, I'm no stranger to the fact that this game was very revolutionary in how CRPGs were done back in the day, and even now, classic gamers like myself still enjoy this tale as immortal as time itself.

Gameplay is where I typically start, and...well, I'll be up front: this game is pretty darn outdated. Is it BAD? 

Answer: Heck no. If anything, the fact that Pathfinder: Kingmaker uses a similar system with updated graphics and rulesets shows how well known the Infinity Engine is, and that's a good thing. If anything, I love the overhead perspective, as it complemets the way battles are fought incredibly well: with tactical decisions that require plenty of forethought and pausing. Heroes and enemies alike are highlighted and easy to see, and I love how easy to figure out the HUD is. There is a bit of a learning curve to the whole thing, but there's a helpful tutorial that will assist you. The more D&D-related stuff you may have to look around for on your own, but if you have any idea of how it works, the game won't be too hard to pick up on. All in all, it's a very well put together system of selecting characters, selecting their actions, and implementing them in the world in some way. However, I do have a fair number of complaints that have stuck with me for many years:

1. Character attributes-they aren't really bad in and of themselves; I have to admit it's pretty fun to set them to super high levels if you want, but I wish they didn't have to be so blasted high in general just to get some handy benefits. Worse, some attributes do roughly nothing for characters who need them(Intelligence is the worst; even for wizards it only affects how many spells they can memorize, and wisdom can be used for lore bonuses just as easily).

2. Attack rolls, armor class, and saving throws-not these three things themselves, but rather the fact that they improve by going DOWN whereas everything else improves by going UP! I mean, talk about confusing the newcomers! Don't get me wrong, the math is easier to figure out than one would think, but I feel like 3rd edition's d20 system saved people plenty of headaches.

3. Class balance-dear freaking god, say what you want about spellcasters in 3rd and 3.5, but even then, it felt like more classes could pull their weight effectively! Not to say any class is useless, but there's a few standouts: clerics are better than druids, monks have some handy abilities that are gated until the second game, beserkers are WAY better than barbarians, kensais are only optimal if you dual-class with a mage, and wild mages are basically RNGesus bullies, among other issues.

4. Reputation-Boy oh boy, be careful how far you want to go if you're EVIL! The rep system honestly doesn't affect much outside of shop prices and special abilities for main characters. Don't get me wrong, I love how you can choose different alignments and even make choices that fit with said alignment, but aside from discouraging murder-hobos, I hate how letting your rep drop to keep evil companions happy means huge markups and bounty hunters riding your butts regardless of how your rep decreased, whereas all high reppers have to worry about are not hiring evil companions. I know I'm meant to be a hero at the end of the day, but the whole system feels so alienating, especially since this is a single-player game, and the DM is just the computer.

So yeah, I have issues, but the fact that I can control a party of six and take them on an adventure through a huge world, going on quests to slay monsters, aid the downtrodden, and make a crap ton of money in the process is a nice trade-in. The world is basically your oyster once the prologue is behind you, and there's quite a lot to do; it's pretty easy to get incredibly powerful if you work at it long enough. Being able to alter the difficulty as needed is a nice touch as well.

So yeah, the game's pretty fun, all things considered, but what about the story? Take it from me: this plot is freaking brilliant. It isn't super deep, mind you, but it's cleverly put together in a way that not only fits whatever alignment you choose, but also allows the one character you make to be the star of the show, due to the fact that the plot happens to him/her. It does a great job of progressing from humble beginnings(a "student" of sorts, raised as an orphan) to an adventure of solving an iron shortage, dealing with bandit groups and slave mines, and eventually investigating the machinations of a vicious madman who murdered your foster father and seeks to bring about a war that will allow him to claim the title of an evil god slain years before. Granted, the pacing is god awful, considering you have an infinite amount of time to solve everything, and chances are you'll have to jump on some sidequests to gain levels and grab some handy equipment, but the whole thing is still pretty fun, considering that this game was the closest you could get to The Elder Scrolls before that franchise was a thing.

As far as characters go, the companions you can travel with are pretty much the standouts, aside from the big bad evil guy. They all have incredibly campy and cliche personalities that do get an eyeroll from me now and then, but they're all still cool in their own way, mainly because they feel like the virtual representation of how an irl DM might describe such characters. Some even have quests of their own to complete, which adds a fun dynamic of earning their assistance. Each character also comes with their own alignments, so be wary of your reputation, lest they decide to take a hike. Moreover, some companions will actually come to blows with each other. It's a clever way of seeing personalities clash, and can be pretty entertaining as long as it doesn't happen at the wrong time! Gameplay-wise, the companions run the gamut of classes you can play as, so you shouldn't have too much trouble getting a solid party put together. Just be sure to weed them out; some companions are way better than others.

In terms of aesthetics, sound design is pretty much awesome. Voice acting is typically over-the-top, though in an entertaining way, and the music is just freaking glorious, from the calm ambient outdoor tunes, to the dark and suspenseful themes of dungeons, to the thrilling fanfare of exciting battle music. I can recount several of the tunes in my head, so...memorable points! Graphics are...well, not quite as amazing, but hey, it's an older game, and even then, I love how the Infinity Engine used these beautiful settings for their locations, especially outdoors. The less appealing bit of eye candy comes mainly from the sprites themselves. They aren't bad at all themselves, but man, you can tell there are sprites in the game; the 2-D models tend to clash with the overall look. The magic spell effects are nice to look at, though.

I'm honestly amazed I've played this game so long(a good chunk of it was screwing around with the character creator, I tend to let my mind wander on how I might play the game with each character class), but I guess that shows how much of a classic it is to me. The ruleset isn't my favorite, and even hundreds of bugfixes and other additions can only add so much(I do appreciate them, though!), but in the end, I still have a great time with it. My only regret is that I haven't played the sequel more, as I feel that's one of only a few CRPGs better than this timeless game. If you're into 2nd edition AD&D, CRPGs in general, or have a thing for the classics, pick this title up. It's a game that will stand the test of time. Thanks for reading.

And it is awesome! Good time to return to the game, folks!
 (The poison damage is now a percentage of HP, at least at poisoned arrows, don't yet know how to feel about this, poison now is more dangerous to the high and low-levels alike, but slightly less to low-levels if they can heal themselves)

In BG1 EE there are almost no enemies that can resist abusing his "hide in plain sight" ability, that makes him arguably the best class for solo gameplay in both BG1 and BG2. Yes, it made rogue class more viable,,, but to the point when it is overpowered and unfair.

This is a great must play classic game, made greater by EE. 

If you play it for the first time, there is alot of concepts to learn, not to mention spellcasting and restrictions on gear, class etc..

If you make it past the first 4 chapters the game starts to open up once you can get to Baldurs Gate itself. The game really makes you feel powerful and at the same time you can get rekt in no time once someone crucial to a fight fails their saving throw.. 

Having a well balanced party is important but you can do the whole game solo if you like, in fact going solo is very advantageous early game given the right build, as you can level up quickly on easy quests and then go about picking out a good party (which will level up to almost match your level in most cases, or even exceed it in a very few cases; since characters level differently based on their class choice).

That being said the real challenge is to avoid powergaming, savegame cheesing and metagaming or AI exploiting every major encounter.

Don't be afraid to mod it, a UI mod to get the game to Baldurs Gate 2 standard is easy to install.

A solid smooth playable version of the original game, which is my favorite game of all time.

The game adds in class kits from BG2, and some classes, like monk/sorcerer. Adds in a couple new npc teamates. This expands how much variety the game already has in it for multiple playthrus.

Playing the new stuff is fine, but if you know the original, it feels more rewarding to ignore the added stuff. Like if you look up speedruns for the game, you'll see only playthrus by a bard kit that wasn't available in original at all. Bard in original was a pretty tough class to choose.

As for difficulty, it adds story mode which will quickly let you get thru the game. I think that's great for players from BG3 who might want to see what the old story was all about!

Core difficulty is similar to what neutral was in original. But enemy spawns are reduced, so it is easier this time around. Above that, the game does well adding in more difficulties to challenge you! Even ones that weren't available in original, but are fun challenges. There's a lot of quality of life improvements, like having ammo stack to 80 instead of 20, that speed up the game too.

The combat might be un-intuitive at first. But if you set auto-pause options right, you'll quickly get a fast and effective rhythm going for controlling a party of six in any situation. 

Until the next remake of the original, this is the one to get!

I try to be as honest and unbiased with these reviews as I can because I realize the recommendation is not for me, but for you. With that said, I did not enjoy the game that much, but I'll still recommend it.

I'll start with the positives. The graphics in the Enhanced Edition are beautiful. I can't speak to the original because I've never played it. The hand drawn backdrop has a realistic feel to it, and really helps you engross yourself in each "map or "level." The Infinity Engine really stands the test of time, and for a game that was released in 1998, the EE looks wonderful. The story is decent. It's not the best story I've ever had the pleasure of playing through, but it does the job. In the first half I wasn't very interested, but by the end I did actually end up caring about my decisions and how things turned out.

The bad. The combat is horrifically dated. Some people like real-time with pause combat, some don't. I'm in the "it's bad" camp. It feels clunky and weird to pause in the midst of combat, select your spells or actions, and then carry on. I understand that this game is attempting to follow DnD rules (which I'll be honest, I know barely anything about), but I think the combat could have been much better had it been turn-based. It feels like an RTS, but a shallow RTS that I don't enjoy battling in. Again, maybe if I had played the game nearer its release date, I'd care more for it. However, as it stands in 2020, it's not my cup of tea.

All in all, I think the game is good, but not great. I can see why people consider it great, considering that it was released in 1998. It definitely helped pave the way for future RPGs, and for that, I can appreciate it. Even though I didn't feel like I enjoyed it that much, I keep thinking back on it and I've started considering playing the second one.

Just understand what you're getting yourself into before you drop money on this game. If you're unsure whether you'd like it or not, I'd recommend waiting for a sale, especially if you're not used to older CRPGs.

Baldur's Gate is a good game with entertaining and interesting writing buried behind an absolute slog of an early game. Much of the game is played at level 1-3 of D&D, which in this particular version is extremely brutal as every spellcasting class becomes useless for the first half of the game, and even then you get to save and reload constantly due to dice rolls not going your way. Given enough patience, there is some good gameplay to be found, and the original story of Baldur's Gate and its inhabitants is quite interesting, but the entire game is completely outclassed by its successor, Baldur's Gate 2, simply by starting at level 7 or so and allowing more leeway with spell casting, skills, and not having everybody explode the first time you stumble across an ogre.

There is very much a good game in here, and the writing is solid throughout, but the amount of reloading required for most options simply isn't worth it.

A great update on a classic title. If you like CRPGs, epic stories, and apparently sentient hamsters this is the game for you. The update adds a lot of polish to the game as well as some additional content. The only downsides of this version are:

1. The lack of the original cutscenes. I get why they remade them (low resolution would look terrible on modern machines), but the remade cutscenes lack the pacing and important beats of the original game's cutscenes. It's a minor gripe if you played the originals, but I'm sad that new players won't get to experience the amazing opening from the original game.

2. The Journal is terrible. I'm more annoyed by this one - the Journal in BGII was far superior to the Journal in this game - I really don't understand why they remade it with such a clunky interface compared to the original game.

Despite the flaws I still highly recommend this version - I'm having a lot of fun playing through it and I really like the new characters as well.

If you had never played D&D, the learning curve will be very steep. But once you overcame the initial obstacles, you will be rewarded with one of the greatest RPG ever made.

The Good:


After so many years, it still manages to be a fun pc adaptation of the D&D rules in a friendly manner. 
Good story.
Interesting side quests.
NPCs with personality.
Replay value: play good or evil; choose among different classes, subclasses and dual classes.
Minsc and his hamster.
Art style.
For those very demanding players: there are no quest markers.

The bad:

NPCs and player characters have not been improved upon in this enhanced edition. They still look bad, pixelated. 
Difficulty spikes. 
The Journal is way better than the original but, sometimes, it is hard to follow quests.

Conclusion: Fully recommended.

I recommend the later 2/3's of this game. The first 1/3 of the game is such a boring experience imo (the first half of the base game campaign, including side quests), I almost dropped it. It just took me over 30 hours to get past the suck part, so most likely not something worth enduring for most, and something to keep in mind for new initiates to this genre of game. It may have helped father this genre of games, but it's earlier sections have not aged gracefully. 

The only reason I pushed forward in this game being I had already beaten Planescape: Torment, and Fallout 1, and wanted to beat the last of the 3 main classic CRPG's that people point back to for popularizing the genre. And to see what had inspired Pillars Of Eternity, one of my favorite games.

 Once you reach a high enough level to tackle the Tales of the Sword Coast DLC content, which includes the famous Durlag's Tower, and the 2nd half of the main story (the actual city of Baldur's Gate), everything picks up and becomes much smoother sailing. Until then, you will be fighting the game's rng combat system so much you will be spending alsot as much time on save and loading screens as you do playing the game.

It doesn't help that in the base game, all of the companions I had chosen were such one note character's, I felt nothing for them at all. Except for Minsc and his miniature giant space hamster pet, Boo. and even then, in the base game, there isn't all that much to expect in terms of party interaction. at least in the party composition I had. I guess the party is supposed to interact with each other with little lines here and there, and they do. It's just there were no interesting interactions that stood out to me, imo. 

This changes in the Siege Of Dragonspear campaign, the npc's all come to life, and always have things to say and often contribute to various quests and conversations, with each other, and you. 

This game is hard at low levels, but not in the "this is a fun challenge" way, but the "i just keep reloading until i win the rng of the fight" way. then it becomes too easy as you can just let your party auto fight for you at the later levels. I never found a good balance in my style of play between too easy and too hard to the point on having to over rely on saves. 

In the end though, this is a game that's more about story. And if you play the game from start, to the very end of SoD, you will leave feeling more satisfied than you would otherwise expect, and feeling excited to play BG2.... if you can get past the first few dozen hours.

This Review is focused on Multiplayer Issues

Baldur's Gate was a staple for our preteen years. Growing up with the advent of computer games and such a golden age of innovation. There is no experience like it (well, now days there are many, but back then there weren't).

However, the Enhanced Edition on Steam has been a disappointment. Multiplayer has many issues ranging from connection issues to saving the game being super slow and laggy. Moreover, about once every other time we play together the game will randomly crash at anything from loading to just playing.

It's immensely frustrating to have to reassign characters to a player and check all of the boxes. Why are there boxes to check for the characters and not just a single one for the players? Divinity 2 got that part right for multiplayer...

Also, the chat window seems like an after thought and we ultimately find it useless. We call instead.

It's a bit frustrating to come back to a game we love, enjoy certain nostalgia from the mechanics and gameplay, but then hit hiccups like these.


A complete revision of the multiplayer system would make a huge difference and would turn my review from a No to a Yes.
