TLDR version: Newcomer to the series, no nostalgia. Initially had a negative knee-jerk reaction, now this is one of my absolute favorite games of all time. Baldur's Gate is fresh, deep, and most of all *FUN*. The engaging story, charming characters, and addictive combat are PURE PERFECTION; this combination remains unsurpassed by any other game without "Baldur's Gate" in the title IMHO. You owe it to yourself to experience this.
---

I'm a complete newcomer to Baldur's Gate. No nostalgia goggles. I have no familiarity whatsoever with AD&D, either in pen and paper form or any video games explicitly based on them. I've never played these games before, but I had heard good things about them all my life, and I was finally willing to see what the fuss was about. I played for a few hours, then had a negative knee-jerk reaction. There is an "upvoted" negative review here that summed up how I felt. I was wrong. VERY wrong. Here I am 100+ hours later to make it clear that I was as mistaken as it's possible to be.

You see, I was put off by the seemingly arcane pen and paper D&D rules (I haven't played an actual pen & paper rpg of any kind for over 20 years). I was intimidated by concepts like THAC0, and it all initially felt unintuitive to me. I was frustrated by the combat. My frustrations didn't seem to match expectations.

...But the game kept pulling me in. The setting, the characters, the quests, the storyline... After those initial hours expecting a Hallejuah moment (and not getting it, or so I thought), what I eventually found instead was...crack cocaine.

Once I began to learn the ropes, the game's combat completely and utterly opened up to me, and I soon realized it was the most thrilling, challenging, complex, rewarding, and PURE FUN combat experiences I've ever had with an RPG in my entire life.

Two examples at opposite ends of the spectrum (without spoiling much): One fight involving a wizard and a few basilisks was especially challenging. After experimenting with a number of ways to survive the encounter, I ultimately ended up using a combination of a friendly ghoul, a nearby group of hostile adventurers who had insulted me, my thief (with the effects of an invisibility potion) sneaking behind the wizard and ready to backstab, and a few well-timed spells. Body parts were flying (literally). 

The other example illustrates an initially less confrontational way I solved another seemingly insurmountable challenge. I was facing a large encampment of tough enemies (not cannon fodder). I tried to sneak a certain character in and use a special charm ability on one of them...and I was shocked when it worked! Not only did the enemy talk to me and answer my questions (and submit to being pickpocketed), I realized I could control them too. I suddenly realized I could walk them out of camp and into the woods away from their allies. So I walked the enemy towards my waiting group in the middle of the woods, and killed him. The other enemies weren't alerted. So far so good. After some trial and error, I realized there was no way to make this work with every enemy without alerting the camp (though that would've been hilarious), but I was able to charm, pickpocket, and then murder many of the toughest enemies in the group. Finally, I charmed the strongest enemy remaining, made him attack his friends, and then my party rushed in for a full-on assault to finish the job.

These are just two examples in my 100+ hour journey (and if anything, it almost felt like I rushed through the game).

Now there *is* some cheesey-ness...like greater werewolves constantly regenerating health, and not being able to kill them even with your strongest weapons and spells. But there are workarounds (eg special silver and anti-werewolf weapons). A minor quibble, but it's there.

Overall one of the most joyful combat experiences I've had in any RPG (what an idiot I was for almost giving up so early on)....and that's just the tip of the iceberg.

This is one of the richest, most immersive, most addictive worlds I've ever inhabited in any RPG. There is a pure *FEEL* that's just so right here...the way the game world *FEELS* to me, the sense you have as you explore and interact with the world. This is a living, breathing world that is in many ways far freer and more interactive than bleeding edge AAA titles of the current era. I feel like this game lives up to the promise of so-called "free roam"/"open world" RPGs in that you really can BE your character in a way that you can't in other games. There's so much creativity here, so many different ways you can play...there is simply nothing quite like it.

And there's also nothing quite like the story (that is, the main questline) and the characters here. The main story is extremely compelling, with conspiracies, twists and turns, excellent villains, and (if you're like me, coming into this 100% blind to story details) a satisfying revelation that the game steadily and intelligently builds toward. There are over TWO DOZEN unique companions here, each voiced, each with their own personalities and backgrounds. 

Bioware's other franchises (the Mass Effect games, the first Dragon Age, and the first KOTOR) came to mind; I had only played these more recent games, but I took it for granted that there was excellent story-telling and compelling, memorable characters. We're still looking for games like that today, aren't we? Well, look no further than the Baldur's Gate games. This is where Bioware did it first. The story and characters stand among their very best. Remember, I was initially frustrated enough that it was the story and characters that kept me coming back early on.

I'm happy to say that the quality of the story continues in Siege of Dragonspear which *beautifully* locks into place between BG1 and BG2 (I'm early in BG2 at the time of this review). SOD is a game that rewards you for overcoming BG1's big bad by giving you a heroic send off to embark on a large-scale siege. Thanks to the fact that SOD came out nearly 20 years after the first game, there are essentially no more hardware limitations, so the devs took the opportunity to MASSIVELY crank up the scope. What I mean is that in SOD, you'll see the streets of Baldur's Gate teeming with huge numbers of people like never before, and it's all part of a gripping plot; a refugee crisis in the face of an impending invasion. Without giving too much away, this culminates in large scale battles with massive enemy numbers. The flipside of this is a brilliantly dark plot twist that sets up the events of BG2.

I can't praise Baldur's Gate enough. Not only do I have BG1, SOD, and BG2 on Steam, I also recently purchased them for android as well. Unbelievable that I can play these games on a mobile device too. I will be revisiting these worlds again and again in the coming years.

As far as those "arcane" pen and paper rules, well I'm in BG2 now and it's 100% second nature to me, and I couldn't imagine it any other way. There's a reason Larian Studios went back to the pen and paper rules (complete with virtual on-screen dice rolls) for Baldur's Gate 3.

These games are now cherished favorites of mine. But not because of their status as "classics." It's because Baldur's Gate is among the most enjoyable and memorable gaming experiences I have EVER had in my life. I can't believe that almost wasn't the case. Again, I'm a complete newcomer. No nostalgia goggles. I *LOVE* Baldur's Gate.

Yeah, so when people say Baldur's Gate is an all-time great RPG that is still a benchmark for writing, atmosphere, memorable characters, and world design, they're actually talking about Baldur's Gate II. This one was a massive leap forward for RPGs but it's so full of rough edges that the second game and later CRPGs successfully smoothed over that it hardly compares to them. It's also severely padded with repetitive encounters and uninteresting side quests--totally lacking in respect for your time.

What would become a defining element of Bioware's great games to come--the unforgettable companions and the choice-driven conversations the player can have with them--are barely here. Random party banter which lets you flesh out your relationship with them is practically nonexistent (interestingly, except for the new Enhanced Edition characters, which range from bland to neat), which makes the writing feel a bit sparse, especially when so many quests, despite the regular dialogue trees, ultimately devolve into killing a pack of enemies here or a horde of them there. It makes you wonder what your choices really added when it ended up in a similar combat scenario either way--and there are so many similar combat scenarios strewn a bit too liberally throughout the game. This becomes less of an issue in the dense, dialogue-rich city of Baldur's Gate, but it takes so long to get there that the wait doesn't feel justified. Meaningless fights pad too much of the open world and the dungeons, but the experience isn't meted out generously enough to make some of the tough required fights fair or fun if you rush past optional content.

It's not an awful game, and there's a lot to love. It captures the feeling of wandering aimlessly around the Forgotten Realms at low level (complete with encountering Drizzt and Elminster in passing) where everything is dangerous fairly well, but that alone doesn't carry the game, and in fact starts to get tedious and frustrating well before you're done. Everything it does well is done better and sooner in Shadows of Amn. I shudder to think how many people in recent years have bought this game, tried it, and put it down when it got too boring, tough, or repetitive, then never tried the second game assuming it was more of the first.

This game is an absolute classic. BG2 was my favorite RPG campaign of all time, and BG1 is a close second. Even all these years later, I've yet to play a PC game whose single-player experience comes close to the experience of the Baldur's Gate series. It actually almost ruined gaming for me because I could never find a high this good after. Amazing depth, beautiful graphics and artwork that looks better than modern games, and the best companion of all time: Minsc.

BG2: 10/10. BG1: 9.5/10. Every other single-player RPG experience in existence must be distanced by at least 2 full points — it's just that much better.

This is probably the easiest way to enjoy Baldur's Gate nowadays if you don't want to bother setting up Baldur's Gate Trilogy, or if you want to run the game on modern systems.

Beamdog altered the original game greatly, with additions being split in four categories.

You got the usual qualify of life improvements that come with Enhanced Editions, like zoom in/out, having the ability to create a full party without multiplayer, increased reactivity and pathfinding, better party scripts, or even the ability to give a thief both a bow or crossbow, and a dagger plus buckler. There's also all the new kits from Baldur's Gate 2, and new classes from more recent editions of D&D, along with a bunch of bug fixes, and the Legacy of Bhaal mode, which transforms an already harsh game into a speedrun/speedhack frenzy.

And of course, there's the new content, including new companions, their quest lines, and even a new addon filling the gap between BG1 and 2. Here, you can tell Dorn was added later in the Friendly Arm Inn for instance. I'm not saying he's poorly written, but his dialogues and voice overs are probably too modern to fit in. Or too unconsequential to the main story. Same, or worse, goes for Neera, whose lines sounded very cringy and forced to me. But to be fair, I was not interested in playing with NPCs to begin with (which have weird and low stats and no personality for the greatest part).

And I mean, Baldur's Gate has always been about spending minutes on grinding, stealing precious items, cheesing the AI with hit and runs and fireballs, and hearing that distinctive leveling sound to finally reduce your THAC0, to kill more things and loot that rare +2 or +3 weapon, and save scumming because of the many death traps. There were already games at the time with better writing and better narrative.

There's also Siege on Dragonspear, which I've yet to try.

As for the game itself, I think it can still be enjoyed despite nostalgia, dated and unbalanced mechanics, teenager story ("You killed my dad, I want revenge and kill everyone on my way!"), and AD&D 2. Starting at level 1 and feeling the progression, doing solo playthroughs or hardcore playthroughs with new classes was very enjoyable.

If you are looking for a more linear but better told story with a more balanced gameplay, take a look at Icewind Dale.

The greatest game of all time

If you're here because you're wanting to experience a bit of gaming history, and maybe you've played a modern isometric CRPG like Pillars of Eternity before, or a modern strategy RPG like Divinity or a hack and slash like Diablo...

Then I don't believe you'll like Baldur's Gate 1. It has not aged as well as, say, Diablo II, or even Fallout 1 and 2. It is low level 2nd edition DnD. And it is MISERY. The combat is actively a detriment and consistently a negative, fun-killing experience.

There's real-time with pause, which some people seem to really like! But in practice here, you'll be doing a lot of waiting while your party swipes and whiffs at an ettercap or bandit. If the rolls aren't good, you'll just kind of die. Also, your party members still *take actions,* so even if you pause and give them a new order, you have to wait until their action pops up again. This gets VERY hard to keep track of between six party member, particularly when the flow of battle shifts quickly. It's a complex system but the complexity adds little but frustration.

You won't have many spells to begin with. Most of the "exploration" that takes place early in the game, before you hit the city of Baldur's Gate proper in Chapter 5, tends to be wandering around giant blocks of terrain that look more or less the same, slowly uncovering the map and if you're lucky coming across an extremely basic quest or two. The more interesting exploration and branching paths all come much, much later in the game, and it may take you a couple dozen hours or longer to even reach that point.

There are a great many niggling little issues, too. Save scumming is more or less required because if a companion dies, you have to resurrect them. To resurrect them, you have to go back to town, unless you're late in the game. Meanwhile, all of their equipment remains on the corpse, and to ensure nothing bad happens to it, you have to pick it up and patiently divide it amongst your party members. Every single time. And damage can be very spiky in this game, and until you get a stock of potions, and even after, healing is frustratingly limited.

The story is also quite boilerplate save for one reveal near the end, and even then the concept is not really explored until the new DLC, Siege of Dragonspear, and BG2. All of your companions are just kind of meme machines and you are afforded very, very few meaningful interactions with them until Siege of Dragonspear.

The Siege of Dragonspear DLC, however, is quite good, as it was made 17 years after the fact and took to heart many improvements the genre has made since those times. Also, you're at a higher level and there is significantly more impactful interactions with your party members. The villain of the DLC is slightly more interesting than BG1's, ultimately, but the story plays well with what BG1 set up. I do not believe it is worth the 40-60 hour slog it takes to get to that point, however, and I do not recommend it to anyone but the most die-hard fans, those who are curious about video game history, warts and all, or anyone who just HAS to be caught up before Baldur's Gate 3 even though BG3 takes place 100 years later.

I don't regret my time with the game for the tourism of a different time but the game's systems have not aged well and can cause more frustration than fun to those with no nostalgic connection to it.

Prior to playing Baldur's Gate, I had little cause to gather my party. When it was released, Baldur's Gate set the bar for what an isometric party-based RPG should be. While I think Baldur's Gate is a great game, it is very Dungeon & Dragons meaning it has a lot of the same quirks specific to D&D games that newcomers may find frustrating. I'm used to clerics not being able to use bladed weapons, or spellcasters needing to wear robes in order for their spells to function; but not everyone is. Baldur's Gate story is great, although I found the harder battles in the game required a lot of saving and reloading. I wish the battles could be fought turned based, like in the Divinity: Original Sin games, rather than real-time (or slowed) with manual pausing. Maybe this will be realised in Baldur's Gate 3.

I'm a fan of old cRPGs but I had to force myself to play through this one until the end and by the time I've reached the last boss, I've already hated the game. The main things I didn't like were the story that did little to break away from the generic Monomyth paradigm, extremely shallow side-quests, flat, single-trait characters and long exploration sequences that brought little in terms of gameplay or story. Combat isn't great either but as a tabletop player, experienced with D&D 2e, I did find some charm to it. Among the pros I should mention robust character building and a wide array of combat playstyles that you can pull off with it. In the end the whole ordeal felt like a forgettable D&D session with an inexperienced and maybe just slightly malicious DM running the show. Can't recommend.

This is the game, the one I played when I was a teenager, the one that I got absorbed in, the one wherein the story took me away from my world and into another, back when.... and it's aged a LOT better than most other things I played at the time. 

The story is complex and there are TONS of fantastic characters and the interactions between your various friends set the tone for most party-based role playing games since. 
Romanceable characters and romances between the characters in your party. 
Likeable characters, and Dislikeable characters. 
Pointless sidequests, and amazing lore filled sidequests. 

This was it for me. 
This set the standard for me. 

It's worth the play.

Baldur's gate is one of the best rpgs produced to date and still remains extremely playable even after 20 years.

While playing it became very easy to see the direct lineage lines that eventually formed the more modern CRPGs like Divinity Original Sin 2.  The 2nd edition dungeons and dragons rules are on full display here which can be a pro or a con depending on how patient and old you are.  I found the game to be a nice trip back to my youth, but could see how first timers or 5th edition D&D fans may find it archaic, tedious, and sometimes too hard.  A lot of the folks i know find it difficult to sink their teeth into games which have bad graphics or an older visual style and I would caution those types to steer well clear as this game has aged terribly in the visual department.  The story is mediocre by today's standards and the voice acting, while passable due to a few standouts, dances around the good and bad sides of mediocre.  In the game's defense i would have easily given this a review score of 9 or 10 in the late 90s, but today I think the best i could muster is a 7 / 10.  I will freely admit my bias towards The Forgotten Realms of the 2nd edition era and this game in general as both were very dear to me in their infancy.  I'm a few hours into Baldur's Gate 2 as of the time of this writing and am happy to report it has aged with much more grace.  If nothing else it might be worth powering through just to get to the sequel.

Baldurs Gate I is an excellent Dungeons n Dragons type game that set the standard back in the day. DnD made video game, and done damn well.
The plot and characters are interesting and neat *Bender takes a picture*.
The writing is hilarious. Plus there's plenty of other cool things for you to discover, like secrets and hidden treasure across the world.

There's tons of different classes and kits, you can dual class or multiclass to make just about any kind of character you want.
BGII also brings massive improvements to the playable classes/kits, compared to BGI some kits were quite under-powered in more ways than one. BGII has done quite the good job in fixing and improving upon what was already a standard-setting game.

I rate this game 10/10 & highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a great RPG, roleplaying, brainstorming and testing character builds, exploring a vast world with secrets you can easily miss, or perhaps discover.

Classic CRPG, well worth the very cheap price for this still decent and engaging content. If you are looking to 'get into' D&D, or can't wait for BG3, give this is a shot. You'll really enjoy it.

Two quite tips: Go into the options, then 'Pause Options' and turn a few things on, including 'when enemy sited' and 'when taken damage'. I also turned on 'at end of turn' as well, but if you don't micro-manage your battles, then turn on "story Mode" and just have fun with it.
A breathtakin good example of depth in a video game and in my opinion one of the best role-playing games ever. If you are not afraid of old graphics, you will be more than satisfied here.

The "Enhanced Edition" rerelease of Baldur's Gate has many convenience features that make the game easier to play from a modern standpoint, but at arguably too high a cost. Beamdog has not only removed around half of all the cinematics in the game, but also replaced the other half with (usually) pleasant-looking but shorter and blander substitutes. The humor, character and dynamicity of the originals are gone, unless you restore them with mods.

This is a theme that carries over to the rest of the Beamdog's "enhancements" as well—most come with a cost in character, usability, and/or vision. Someone at Beamdog must have a real chip on their shoulder about BG1, because they oddly and for no good discernible reason went through the entire game and redesigned many small gameplay systems and content with little to no regard to BioWare's vision or understanding of the original design's purpose. These changes include removing the outer gates of Baldur's Gate and other similarly arbitrary measures.

They also changed the original engine to the BG2 one, and neglected to port over the original character sprites, so the rerelease uses the sprites from the wrong game. Another side effect of this engine port is that they forgot to restore many small engine features from the original game that lacked from the sequel, like ambient character sounds for NPCs and creatures. This version lacks many such features from the original.

In version 2.0, they remade the UI engine from scratch, and in the process they introduced a humongous number of bugs and usability issues to it. In over four years, they haven't even started working on fixing these problems, despite early on promising to the player community that they would fix them. Since then, they've started a large number of other development projects and extracted almost all resources from the Infinity Engine games, ensuring that the countless bugs and regressions they've introduced to them will never be fixed.

That said, the original game is old and has its own long set of (mostly technical) issues. Unfortunately, it's difficult to say which version of the game is the best, as they all have their own drawbacks and it ultimately comes down to preference which ones you can tolerate the best. Still, if you think the issues I've listed about BG:EE would bother you, then I recommend you play the original version instead. Hopefully, at some point in the future, BG gets the remaster it deserves.

[h1] Do not buy this for multiplayer [/h1]

This is not a review for the Baldur's Gate games, which rank among the best games ever made. By all means, everyone should play them if they get the chance. However, Beamdog's enhanced edition of the games has *huge* problems in multiplayer involving crashes and connectivity problems that make it virtually unplayable for many. 

Fixes include ludicrous measures such as turning of one's firewall(!!!), tinkering with router settings, creating a network with Hamachi and more. However, even these "fixes" don't work for everybody. In a time, when you can just click "invite" in your friends list to start a session or outright jump into a game of someone else this is just unacceptable. For several weeks we tried to get the multiplayer to work, and even contacted Beamdog for support; but it was a lottery and we managed to actually *play* the game for only one session. 

Therefore, I would warn everybody who wants to play these games with friends, to rather get the original versions and mod them a bit. Else you might be in for a lot of frustration.

This is the best game implementation of AD&D on a computer out there. You can control a party of up to six (I think that's the max) members each with different skills and with the ability to control each independently of each other. It's a little old so it can take some getting used to, but once there's an understanding of tactics and with plenty of quick saves it becomes less frustrating. Outside of combat gameplay is driven by exploration and finding clues to guide you on whatever quests you have active. There are no map makers saying where to go so it's important to pay attention to what NPCs say and to read letters or notes you find on important enemies. If you aren't familiar with AD&D you might have to do some reading online to form a decent party, but it's completely worth it for a great story and a game that will keep you busy for a good long while.

Fantastic isometric rpg thats only intimidating because of the 2nd edition ruleset and terminology. if you're willing to learn the jargon like THAC0 and whatnot its a stellar experience, and even if you're not there is a story mode option where combat and spells and whatnot can be learned without pressure or necessity. Only gripe is the class-race restrictions, but hey. Mods.

The enhanced edition finally allowed me to complete this venerable game, including the Siege of Dragonspear expansion (which was very good too). Kudos to Beamdog for sticking it out all those years being doubted and mauled by the fan base :) In terms of what this edition offers over the old / vanilla version from GOG.com (which I also have), it's mostly quality-of-life improvements such as native support for modern resolutions, zoom in / zoom out functions, font scaling, etc - though there is also some added content in terms of companions and side quests. The game itself is as amazing as ever, with an epic story, deep character customisation, a large world to explore, ans challenging combat all in top-down 2D isometric view. The combat rules follow Advanced Dungeons and Dragons (AD&D) rules, so some background reading is advised (though there are several guides on the web to help understand the obscure rules). All in all, glad that I finally got to play and finish one of the all-time classics properly.

Pretty fantastic port, with lots of Quality of Life improvements to make the game more playable than it's ever been. This system is so much better for this type of RPG than the heavily 3.5ish systems like Pillars of Eternity and Pathfinder where there's just too much going on at level one. Controlling a party of six is completely unreasonable. In BG:EE however, mostly you can just attack in combat, and as you level you get more abilities, easing you into the combat system in a perfect way.

There's so much content in here, and it's a huge project to try to do everything. Instead, I recommend you just play and enjoy. There's no "wrong" approach to the game unless you are playing solo on Insane difficulty.

Just finished this gem, and I have to say I'm quite impressed.  It is another of a series of infinity engine cRPG games I never got around to playing as a kid, though I started up a campaign in my early teens.  After playing through Pathfinder Kingmaker I have to say, this game is much easier.   Though you can chalk that up to it being shorter overall.
What can be said about Baldur's Gate that can't be said about every D&D campaign you've ever had with your buddies and a tough (but fun) DM?  Wicked Big Bad with a terrible plan for wanton slaughter?  Check.  Campaign hook that starts with the death of the main roleplayer's (you) father figure? Check.  Monty Python-esque humor and writing that is as epic as it is self aware and fun?  Check.
This game is a timeless D&D experience on infinity engine goodness, waith all the cRPG quirks you'd expect. From stuck characters to crazy difficulty ramps, it plays hard and asks for investment.  Don't be discouraged if you die, it happens to everyone.  It's a game that asks for patience and strategy but rewards it with excellent sensation of triumphing against the odds and earning some sweet loot to boot.
As for the story itself, it's a mythology by this point.  Bloodlines of dark gods intermingling within the shadows of conspiracy, and a dark prophecy tying it all together.  Not exactly a twist you wouldn't see coming today, but like listening to an old bedtime story or hearing a campfire tale about a legendary hero vanquishing the forces of evil (or embracing its seductive power) you can't really fault it for being what it has always been.
A classic.  9.5/10

Maybe at one point this was one of the greatest RPG's of all time, but it sure as heck didn't age well.
I think I let a summer sale and a nostalgic yearning for classics sway me. 

The story, if there is any, is completely generic, just like how I found Pillars of Eternity to be forgettable.
Gameplay is tedious and actually difficult unless you like setting up party tactics and relentlessly pause and micromanage your group; or you set it to easy.
You have to be "nice" the whole game, otherwise you won't get your party, which really throws off the immersion.  What's the point of choosing to be chaotic evil if you really can't be, as you need a team to survive.

Every map feels like a big slog.  It reminds me of Diablo but not in a good way.  Click, click, click - as you explore the black areas uncovering nothing but boring fields filled with ambushing npc's.

Treasure is not remarkable - oh hey look it's another halberd or useless gem.

Dialogue is mostly pointless and doesn't feel like there's any strong repercussions; or at least you won't care.

It's glitchy.  At one point you're told to go to an inn to meet up with two potential friends.  However, if you waylay and do other levels first they won't appear at the inn.  And you won't know that, unless you google it after the fact.

Just don't bother, and save yourself the cash.

[code]This review is an excerpt. To view the full review, go [url=https://arcadetheory.net/baldurs-gate-enhanced-edition-review/]here on our website.[/url]
Visit our Steam curator page [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ArcadeTheory]here. [/url][/code]

[h1] Baldur’s Gate: Enhanced Edition Review | Arcade Theory [/h1]

When Baldur’s Gate III was announced, I was stoked to hear that Larian Studios would be developing it. No offense to Beamdog, of course, but to be able to experience a classic RPG series in the style of Divinity: Original Sin II was enough to motivate me to go back and play the original Baldur’s Gate games again in anticipation of the upcoming title. If you have read my [url=https://arcadetheory.net/icewind-dale-enhanced-edition-review/]Icewind Dale review[/url], you will find that I have expressed my favoritism of Baldur’s Gate over its sister game series. It is in this review that you will find out why.

Summarizing the gameplay mechanics would be akin to summarizing the D&D rulebooks, so I will leave you, dear reader, to read the manual on your own initiative. The game itself plays like Icewind Dale due to sharing the same game engine. It is isometric, real-time, and relies on the use of unseen dice to determine whether you land a hit or miss. Usually miss. Such is the folly of dice-based combat: it is by no means an unbalanced or unfair system, but it is simply mystifying how your paladin can completely miss swinging his broadsword at an immobile blob of jelly congealing on the floor or how your ranger fails to land his mark against a wyvern the size of a barn’s broadside. Outside of that, the game’s mechanics works without fail, even if it is frustrating to deal with.

Your character is canonically known as Gorion’s Ward, raised by your aforementioned foster father in the fortress of Candlekeep. You were doted on heavily, yet raised with a stern hand in anticipation of the events of Baldur’s Gate, though you were never told why you would ever need to step foot beyond the walls of the keep. Why has your father never told you of your true heritage? Why is it that even at the eve of your departure, you have never been lectured once on the topic of your destiny? It is through your adventures in the Sword Coast that you shall piece together the untold story behind your past.

But you will not undertake this adventure alone. Five companions of your choosing shall accompany you through bandit-afflicted roads and spider-infested forests. Like Icewind Dale, you may opt to create your entire six-man party at the very start, but in Baldur’s Gate, it is actually advisable to create only a single main character. Unlike Icewind Dale, there are actually recruitable companions scattered across the Sword Coast. They come in many flavors of classes and alignments, ranging from paladins to sorcerers and from lawful good to chaotic evil. The reason it is encouraged to seek them out is because they have their own personalities and unique dialogue, a stark contrast from your robotic player-made companions who are required to pick from a pool of generic voice sets just like your main character. The recruitable companions don’t have this kind of issue.

Let’s take Minsc, for example. Minsc is quite possibly Baldur’s Gate most popular companion. This loveable oaf is not quite right in the head, but where he lacks in brains, he compensates by being a bona fide killing machine, excelling in the two-handed sword weapon style as well as being proficient in the accurate longbow. Recruiting him is like nabbing two candy bars for the price of one as he is joined by his pet, a furry little hamster named Boo. In Minsc’s 8 Intelligence mind, Boo is the brains of the duo as he is a sentient miniature giant space hamster capable of dispensing sage-like wisdom when it is most needed. At least, according to Minsc.

If you decide to hire Minsc, you must also assist him in rescuing Dynaheir, a complimentary companion that serves as his “witch” and protector. Once you have rescued her, the pair becomes inseparable. If you dismiss one of them, the other leaves your party as well. Should one of the two die in battle, the other will react to their death—in Minsc’s case, he will go berserk, potentially maiming your own party in his grief. Such complexities in personality will only exist in your party if you choose not to go with the premade route. Each companion will express their likes and dislikes of other members of your party. Some companions will come in pairs just like Minsc and Dynaheir and will react appropriately should something occur to their partner.

I don’t want to reveal any more details about the story to those who never played the game. I will say, however, that the main questline is an enjoyable experience. The writing is a key part in that it is always fun to explore the choices you have in the dialogue line you get to say to the NPC you are speaking to. Being able to go from speaking like a noble paladin to being a chaotic evil jerk in the same conversation is hilarious until the NPC decides to end the conversation and attempt to cut you down for your insolence. The game may have tried a bit too hard in being immersive with voice acting though. See, every time you engage in dialogue with an NPC, a sound bite will play of a voice recording. This sound bite may just be the first several words of the dialogue. Other times, it may be a sound bite of the generic nobleman character telling you that he does not enjoy talking to peasants such as yourself even though his dialogue is very polite towards you. You will have to hear the same voice clip every time you interact with that NPC, which, I must say, is rather annoying. There are no fully-voiced NPCs in this game either. The most voice acting you will hear is perhaps the first paragraph of an NPC’s dialogue, but outside of that, there is little to be heard. It’s not a big deal though. Some prefer it that way as they would rather picture what the NPC’s voice would be like in their head. [...]

For the first couple of hours I found myself turned off by the old UI and the dated graphics, but then I continued playing and found the game to be a great amount of fun to be had. The game has it all, limitless character customisation, a great cast of characters, both companions you meet along the way and also random npcs that will make you grin and chuckle to yourself again and again. It is funny, epic and also serious at times. The soundtrack is epic, and the level design is well thought out and works seamlessly with the gameplay mechanics. There are many ways to kill monsters and the game gives the player a great deal of freedom. I have never played dnd and I am a complete newb and still managed to figure out how to play the game. If you have played newer titles and are curious about older games I would reccomend trying the infinity collection as they are stimulating, fun and original games.

Important Note: The game can be deadly with the roll of bad luck. Play on story mode or maybe prepare to save and reload sometimes if you're playing on Core or higher difficulty. Sucks when that wolf rolls a critical hit and one shots you at the start of the game, funny when you critical one shot it.

The game was made very early in the genre of Western CRPGs, and it has several design decisions that make it difficult to get into.

These may be no problem for you! I have friends who love this game, and more power to them. But I wish I'd known these problems before I bought the game. They affected my enjoyment so much that I have given up and wish I had never spent money on it.

1. The game follows the DnD 2nd ed rules very closely, and you start at level 1. This means you will be very weak, and combats are going to be very dangerous, so save early and save often. Unfortunately, the game design is pretty railroady, which means you won't be able to avoid combats. Some of them will very likely kill you unless you have specific character builds or luck out with the dice rolls.

2. The game, programming wise, follows on from older CRPGs like Strahd's Possession and Eye of the Beholder. So bear that in mind when you consider its rave reviews. They're comparing it to very basic, railroady, "you can die at any time and we expect you to keep reloading till you solve our arbitrary quest plan" type of design.

3. There isn't much room for error or deviation from the designer's plan, so don't try to emphasize too much on character roleplaying. Early in the game, two clearly evil NPCs offer to join your party. If you're playing as Good characters, you might quite reasonably turn them down, thinking the game has some alternative plan for your survival if you do so. It doesn't. You're going to need every miserable last advantage you can get, so bring them along as cannon fodder.

4. There is an early unavoidable fight where you're up against a far more powerful NPC who starts the combat by casting Magic Missile (projectiles that never miss and do guaranteed damage). This will kill any "squishy" class PC it hits, say, your starting Mage. Bring along an expendable Evil character as your cannon fodder.

5. There is an early unavoidable mine complex where you need to travel and defeat enemies to progress. Without any explanation or workaround, you will not be able to rest in the mine ("you are plagued with nightmares"). This means that spellcasting classes (such as, say, your squishy starting Mage) will not regain spells. Be prepared for a sprint experience to get through alive, not an Indiana-Jones-style spelunking exploration experience.

The game lacks the flexibility of later games - not all classes are equally viable, and not all alignments or character outlook can be properly role played without painting yourself into a corner. This game is historically significant (cool graphics! voice acting! isometric realtime grid based combat!) but it's still an intermediary link between the ugly CRPGs of "insta-death" yesteryear, and the polished, flexible, multiple-option CRPGs of today.

Baldur's Gate 2 and Throne of Bhaal, by contrast, are much more flexible and survivable with different character types - partially because even though they also are based on DnD 2nd ed, they automatically start you at a higher level so you're less likely to die with unlucky rolls or a mildly disadvantageous choice in character build.

Baldur's Gate is a classic CRPG for a reason. It represents a pretty faithful interpretation of the AD&D 2e experience into a computer game format, with compelling characters, a fun story, and what in 1998 was a pretty ingenious use of RTS controls into an RPG. My big issue with the game is that played straight it can feel quite grindy. In the early going especially, the combat is deadly and capricious, and it requires patience that a lot of modern players might not want to give it. But the EE does have Story Mode, which may seem like a surrender, but is also a great way to experience the story and characters more directly.

It's Baldur's Gate. Seen as THE game-defining isometric RPG for good reason. If you haven't played it before and want a D&D RPG experience, play this game.
I played the original version when I was very young and never finished it because I was too young/stupid to understand how mechanics worked. For people trying to play this game, the initial confusions over AC THAC0 and other outdated rulesets goes away quickly. The Enhanced Edition fixes this with simple interfaces, colour-coded weapon and armour comparisons, etc. If you've ever played a modern RPG or MMO, it's fairly easy to get used to the different ruleset. 
All that being said, the story is decently compelling, but it's the characters and quirkiness of the world that draws you in. A fairly typical RPG quest (you have to investigate, oh no bandits, something bigger going on) doesn't take away from the world and characterization at all.
Gameplay is decent if a bit clunky at times, but that's to be expected of a 2012 remake of a 1998 top-down isometric RPG.

Gameplay: 7/10
Story: 9/10
Graphics: 8/10 (why so high? Because even the remake is 8 yrs old at this point and it still looks decent)
Dollar Per Hour ratio: $0.4  ($22/~55hrs)
     (Haven't finished yet and I'm around 40hours in. The included Tales from the Sword Coast and Black Pits expansions will put average gameplay time at around 50-60 hrs depending on the player)
Bottom Line: 7.5/10 in terms of game, well worth the $ at around 40 cents per hour of game time.

This is a remake of the role-playing video game Baldur's Gate and its expansion Baldur's Gate: Tales of the Sword Coast which were both originally released back in 1998 by Bioware. This review will contain minor spoilers.

Graphics definitely shows its age and can be distracting for a newcomer who have not experienced such graphics before. Personally for me, i find it dated, but with a certain nostalgic charm. Environment art are pretty detailed however and are lovingly rendered in pixel art. Character sprites however look very generic and small. 

The music consists of nice sweeping orchestral pieces. Sound effects sound good with the clashes of swords and the swoosh of a magic spell. I did encounter issues where the volume would suddenly crank up for no reason at all during certain events (Eg: when a trap got activated).

The main 25 hours story unfortunately felt rather generic although it has a unique way of presentation with a narrator reciting the script as if like a Dungeon Master in the pen and paper version. As such, I felt that the general feel of the game doesn't feel at all like a video game, but feels more like the pen and paper experience translated into digital form. This may or may not be a good thing depending on your tastes.

I liked how organic and natural sidequests were presented. You could have a random NPC walk up to you for a chit chat which may lead to something more sinister or just wander around and help out along the way. I recommend not to slavishly do each and every quest, but rather play thru the game normally and just let your party randomly encounter these side quests. Also, because this game is old-school, do not expect it to hold your hand and show you your exact quest objective. You are expected to read the ingame journal which will give vague hints and you actually have to do some exploring.

The game has quite a high combat difficulty curve at least at the beginning when your initial party is low leveled. It will not hesitate to throw a tough boss or impossible random encounters (a crew of lvl1 characters against 8 higher leveled bandits. Really?!?) relatively early and wipe your party. Remember to always save your game before and after every conversation, and before and after every battle. Proper position and tactics are essential and vital to early combat.

If you persevere however, this difficulty curve will drop very significantly when your party members are around Level 4. At this point, you will find almost all non-boss battles to be a breeze where all you had to do is to select everyone in your party and just zerg rush mobs. Enemies do not scale to your level. I find this sudden drop in difficulty to be very strange and felt very odd considering how hard it was to survive during the early levels.

As for boss battles, its very easy to exploit the game by getting your magic users cast area effect spells before they even see an enemy to soften them up. This is particularly true for the last boss where I just lured his allies out one by one, zerged them, went out to rest and heal and repeat until he is the only one left standing. Needless to say he died in about 25 seconds to my zerg rush.

Overall Rating: 7 / 10
Criticizing this game almost feels like a crime considering that alot of people enjoyed it alot. I enjoyed this game for sure, but I felt it might have been a little too hyped up. My view is that it is a good game, but it could definitely be alot more polished. My main concern was that the story narrative was too overt instead of being subtle. You are literally being told a story instead of experiencing one (if that makes any sense)

For anyone like me who have played the original pen and paper version and also experienced older RPGs before, do give it a try if you haven't already as you might enjoy it. 

For younger players who have never experienced older RPGs and never touched the pen and paper version before, i'd recommend watching some gameplay video previews before committing to it as this game does show its age now.

Widely renown as an CRPG classic, Baldur’s Gate was in fact instrumental in preserving the love and interest in PC RPG games with players in the mid 90’s, when western RPGs were on a brink of ending like the genre of Adventure Games: Sidelined and often forgotten by the masses. It was also the very first successful project for Bioware team, which would later on create a dozen of widely celebrated & classic RPG games of all time. Baldur’s Gate was one of the games that renewed the flame for this genre back then and even now offers an amazing story and tactical Dungeons and Dragons combat experience, if you can handle the old fashioned look and style of play that has been polished with this Enhanced Edition.

[h1]“Your iron or your life. No, your iron AND your life. Yeah that one’s better.”[/h1]

Set in the year 1368DR, when all the cities and ports of the Sword Coast were in turmoil due to Iron Crisis, a young daydreamer along with their sister Imoen were living in the peaceful and secluded village of Candlekeep, doing everyday chores oblivious to the storm brewing outside. Gorion was taking care of these two younglings, until fate decided to knock on the door, and change their lives forever.

Before Baldur’s Gate, Bioware only released one game, a mech simulation called Shattered Steel which, while liked in the MechWarrior community, was rough in many of its aspects. But Bioware was always interested in pushing the limits in games and delivering high level of overall polish. Hence, when developing a game based on beloved D&D license, much of the writing was also handled to the Black Isle Studios, developers that would later on form Obsidian Entertainment, which also spawned many cult favorite RPG. A mix of these two developer studios have created on of the best “old-school” role-playing game series to date. 

Baldur’s Gate is a high fantasy RPG game, with clearly defined good and bad guys, fantastical realms where magic is commonplace, and a sprawling and straightforward story about the Hero’s Journey with a couple of clever twists and turns to spotlight the main character’s unusual history that would influence the balance of powers on the continent of Faerûn. 

[h1]“Hide away that which should not see the sun’s light”[/h1] 

Powered by “Infinity Engine”, the game provides a beautifully detailed 2D isometric background and animated sprites that to this day look endearing to behold. Every area has unique hand-drawn and painted, high-quality graphical presentation, thus making every level look like a pastel painting. Equally captivating is the orchestral soundtrack by the talented composer Michael Hoenig who also created many memorable movie soundtracks, and here most of the tracks deliver emotionally fueled tones that can be enjoyed and listened separately from the game. From renaissance fair-like track of “The Friendly Arms Inn”, imposing and mysterious tones of “Night Falls on Baldur’s Gate” while exploring the vast city and the Jewel of the Sword Coast, to the exciting and desperate combat music of “Gorion’s Battle” where every wrong move can cost you everything.

Make no mistake; combat in the Baldur’s Gate series never was oriented toward casual and action connoisseurs of RPG’s. Like the rule system it’s based on – Advanced Dungeons & Dragons, it is highly tactical and complex, slow and deadly. The first game especially rewards carefully positioning of your party members, using their unique skills and spells to control the flow of combat and masking their flaws and shortcomings before the enemy AI quickly discovers it and punishes you by constantly striking these weak spots. It is a real time isometric combat system that you can pause whenever you wish to give your fighters commands and then see the results of your planning.  When you start with your character at level 1, every combat is a life or death situation, no matter how trivial some of the enemy encounters might be. By the time you reach level 5, you’ll have a character that can take a beating and can survive a couple of poor combat choices, but your mistakes will always cost a lot, usually ending in party wipe. Speaking of your party, companions that follow you have an AI of its own, but you’ll quickly realize it simply won’t fight well enough and for them to truly shine, you’ll have to take matters into your own hands.

[h1]“Our iron no good! Crumbles like elf bones and make our clan into laughing stock! Ha ha, big joke… We kill you quick, no pain”[/h1]

Every character you meet, every companion that joins your cause, and every enemy that promises your quick demise are well developed with consistently high quality writing on the display that is short, expressive, to the point and playful enough. The overall story and most of its quests are simple by today’s standards, but the confidence of the writing team always manages to pull you into this dynamic world scarred with intrigues, wars, love and betrayals. 

Enhanced version delivered by Beamdog is an optimization and greatly improved coding masterpiece that delivers widescreen resolutions, better 2D sprites, reduces the colossally long loading times the original had, and fixes nearly all limitations and bugs the old engine had. It also delivers a couple of new interesting companions that can join you, new levels and quests that will demand you know combat and tactics exceedingly well.  The only baffling decision in enhancing this game and the only thing that bugs me about this game is the replacement of 3D cutscenes that were lovingly created in now low-polly resolution with lifeless and cheap cartoon cutscenes that look like something out of the early Flash games. Beamdog also created recently a full-scale expansion “Siege of Dragonspear” that is okay, with the only major minus being subpar and stilted dialogue and writing when compared to the original game and unimaginative and repetitive combat encounters.

[h1]“Die, pipsqueaks!”[/h1]

Do I recommend it? Absolutely, but do keep in mind I’ve been playing this game a dozen of times so far. Should you play it? If you are looking for a tough and no-nonsense RPG similar to D&D tabletop experience with a bit of “Lord of the Rings” vibe, then look no further, but if you’re not ready to commit to nearly 100 hours long epic journey or the highly punishing tactical combat is not something you enjoy, as you mull over your character’s next move for 10-15 minutes, you might want to skip it since it’s not for everyone. Baldur’s Gate has aged well, but it demands a lot out of its players and in return delivers one of the best role-playing experiences out there. It has influenced generations of player and developers, and to this date you can find a bit of Baldur’s Gate magic in nearly every western RPG.

[Update 2020]
After a long hiatus from the PC where I spent a couple years playing only console, I'm back and craving some deep RPGs. I'm going to give BGEE another try with a new game from scratch and hope I don't run into the breaking bugs again (6 years later). I played through to chapter 7 with not a single problem (although I'm stuck lol). 

[old review]
This game was mostly unplayable at launch due to bugs. For instance, the quest log--after I got to Chapter 5, it went away, impossible to know what the quests are, what to do, where to go. Just one of the many bugs. The people who give this glowing reviews did not finish the game. And, as you can see, I invested many hours into it. There are areas where if you talk to an NPC before doing something else, the game just about blows up--from talking to an NPC! Your party is stuck, unable to leave the zone. I mean, it's just one thing like that after another with this broken mess. Sure, it is nostalgic, it's FUN, but only if you dabble for a few minutes and then quit, as I suspect 99% of the reviewers out there have done. Play it to win it, and you'll see what I'm talking about. I played through most of the game's content but am not able to finish it to see how it ends.

[addendum] Beamdog fixed a lot of bugs during 2014, and I quit playing at one point toward the end without actually finishing. As someone here and on forums has suggested, the game did have corrupted savegame file problems that made a HUGE mess out of the game if you happen to be unlucky enough to have run into it, where the only solution is to reload from an earlier save. My best guess is, I ran into one of those problems, continued playing, and the game was messed up forever after that. Very possible starting a new game with the final patch would clear it all up.

That doesn't change the fact that the game was unplayable for me. And just because *you* played it through 100% without any issues, doesn't mean it didn't have problems last year.
A  good Game

I've played Baldur's Gate since the early 2000's, as a kid on my family desktop, then on my own laptop(s), and eventually on Android as well. It runs perfectly across all devices, and I love that there's cross-platform support for multiplayer. It also makes creating your own automatically updating cloud save folder a breeze, keeping saves in sync across devices without needing to change any file extensions or other editing for compatibility. It just works.

As for the game itself, Black Isle and WotC created something totally unique with the Baldur's Gate series. I've spent thousands of hours of my life in Faerun, and there are still places, dialogues, items, quests, characters, NPCs, and class combinations I've not played through yet. Beamdog did an excellent job with the Enhanced Edition, keeping the content and graphical style true to the original game with their optimised UI, engine tweaks, bug fixes, new user options and additional content. Definitely feels like it was always meant to be this way, the "enhancements" are all subtle, refined and appropriate.

The only complaint I have is the removal of the original Movies. All of the animated cutscenes from the original game (including the Introduction/Prologue at the end of the loading sequence, prior to the game's Main Menu, and the Movies at the start/finish of each Chapter in the game's main storyline) have been replaced with artistic drawings rendering a still image of the same scene. The Intro/Prologue has been particularly barbarised, in my opinion, with a rapidly mashed-together recording of only a part of the original audio, making the dialogue less mysterious, yet more confusing. Truly a step down from the original, awesome, full Intro/Prologue. To be fair, the artwork is excellent, and well in-theme with the game's original style. But I prefer the original animated cutscenes. Also worth noting, while I haven't tried this myself, I believe it should be possible to download the original movie files and put them into the game's directory in place of the Enhanced Edition cutscenes, fixing my complaint with ease.

Overall I'd rate this game a 10/10, for the sheer level of care that went into every aspect of its design. These days, RPGs that have excellent gameplay, multiplayer suppport and also solo replayability are often utterly destroyed by their lack of creative storyline, consistency, and most of all the environment. Baldur's Gate was made to be open-world in an era when that meant something more than just having HUGE amounts of space to explore. This world feels so real, I keep coming back to it. I don't think there's ever been a year that went by in my life where I didn't pick up a new game to try something different. Though that could be influenced by my nostalgia, there are other solid, respectable games from my childhood which I loved and played around the time I started playing Baldur's Gate, and they don't have near the same place in my esteem as this series.

The game that got me into both RPG games and D&D. The EE has helped tweak it rather than revamp is with some better AI, some nice graphical updates and a few other thing. Features a strong cast, some occasionally janky but generally solid game mechanics and enough dialogue/story/alignment/character options to keep you coming back for more. After I go through Dragonspear for the second time I'm going to hit the EE of BG2 and I am absolutely looking forward to it.

Balder's Gate is the original CRPG for the computer made in the early 2000's. BeamDog, the latest developer, only added a few new characters, and some graphical tweeks  but other than that; that is it. It is  the same game as when it released in the early 2000's. The graphic panel has changed from the original but nothing that can not be worked around. Balder's Gate uses classic 2nd or 3rd addition Dungeon and Dragon rules and monsters. Most of all, the characters are memorable especially Minsc. Minsc brings wonderful humor and personality in game which makes it a the game unique. Very few games has been able to pull it off with charm.  Down below are my thoughts of the experience.
 Graphics: Good but not as defined as today's CRPG
 Story: Awesome Story (no spoilers here!)  just play it
 Learning curve: Can be steep, if unfamiliar with the dungeon and dragons rules
Game play: Strategy type game with a mouse and click
Replayablity: yes, with many characters classes that have different strength the possibilities are staggering

Well, I played and beat this thing precisely because I have been trying to take the plunge into western RPGs. 80 hours later, after pushing through the frustrating early game hell, getting acquainted with the quirks of 2nd  Edition AD&D, and somewhat beelining it towards the final encounter, I have developed quite a complicated relationship with this game. It is very easy to see why they updated the rules for D&D, because there is a lot of problems with these - using dispelling mcguffins and spamming generic buffs is not my idea of clever play. Getting blasted to oblivion due to sleeping on the Real time with Pause system is also not great. This is certainly a game that encourages you to save scum. These quirks make Baldur's Gate greatly inaccesible in contrast to modern games - there is an element of needing  to respect the era in which this game was released to enjoy it.

However, if you can get past the quirks of the rules, and power through the early game hell, and respect what it meant to be an of the beaten path RPG video game developer in the 90s (squaresoft this is not) than Baldur's Gate might be the most earnest attempt to create an entire computerized world that I have ever played. More than the Witcher 3, certainly more than later bioware games (which are some of my favorites) and certainly more than it's Black Isle and further Bioware infinity engine sucessors (which I am looking forward to playing). While the focused story isn't too much to write home about, there is  adventure around every corner. If you stick with it, you will see your characters grow into the warriors that they are destined to become. It is truly a thrilling experience, and although I am ready for a break right now, I do anticipate a return to the sword coast for a more in depth playthrough now that I feel I have gained my footing.

In short, Baldur's game is a hard and often cruel game. I'm not even sure that it is works on many of the ways that I have come to expect video games to be proficient at. However it may also be the greatest masterpiece of a role playing campaign that I have ever experienced, and it is amazing to think that it was accomplished in the 90s as well as decently remastered for the modern era.
At time of writing, I am at 69 hours of play.....nice....and am about to do it all over again, again. Love the world, great story, fantastic characters. Has aged well considering what has come since.

Great game. I remember playing the original long long long ago. This includes all the expansions in it. Was very interested in the new content that came with the Siege of Dragonspear DLC. It was a good campaign that extended the original story well.
It is a shame that so many characters don't make it into that DLC though, (Ajantis, Alora, Branwen, Coran, Eldoth, Faldorn, Garrick, Kagain, Kivan, Montaron, Quayle, Shar-Teel Dosan, Tiax, Xan, Xzar, Yeslick). So if you were doing a play-through from BG1EE to the DLC, you might find some or all of your party are missing in action. This can be especially annoying for people who were going down the "Evil" route, as out of the 10 previously evil characters available, only 4 made it though, and no additional evil characters were added. Where as out of the 10 good characters from the original, 4 return and 2 additional are added.
This can also be especially annoying if you used books for stat increases on them, or in the case of Mages & Bards such as Xan, Garrick, Quayle, Eldoth, Xhar you have have loaded their spellbooks with harder to get spells in your travels, and now not have them available anymore.
Though it is a bit unfortunate that the new characters from SoD don't make it to BB2:EE (some for good reason), but once again having continuation is nice for a party, especially due to some of the above reasons. And once again with the limited number of Evil characters in BG2EE, it can also be difficult, if you don't play neutral/good to find party members who will stay with you.

[h1]Introduction [/h1]

I want to start this review off by saying this is written from the perspective of someone with no experience in CRPG's. This review is aimed at new players and those unfamiliar with CRPG's

[h1] Character Creation [/h1]

It's important to say upfront that this game is not new player friendly, the mechanics feel quite dated and when you start off it is completely overwhelming. Before you even start the game you're given an in depth character creator where you have to choose a race, class and your stats, there's tons of options to choose from and if you're not familiar with D&D your probably going to struggle to make a good choice. I'd strongly suggest either reading the beefy instruction manual or looking up a guide online, however on the flip side with the amount of options available gives tons of replay value once you're familiar with it.

The only area where i found the character creator lacking was in the visual department, you only get the option to colour swap a couple of pieces of your equipment and also the hair, just know going in you'll get a fleshed out deep stat based character creator which is severely lacking in the visual department.

[h1] Story [/h1]

So I'm going to be very vague about the story here because i don't want to spoil anything but the plot follows your created character who is the adopted child of a man named Gorion, as soon as the game starts you are informed that Gorion, your father wants you to gather your supplies immediately as you must leave in a hurry, you are both in danger and need to act fast, there is no time to waste. I won't give away any more plot details than that but the story moved at a nice pace and the side quests were fleshed out and just as interesting as the main quest.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The gameplay consists of three main sections, [b] exploration, combat and dialogue.[/b] All of these elements were fantastic and came together to make an incredibly fun game with a dense and complex world, I'll break down each part individually starting with exploration.

[h1] Exploration[/h1]

The way you move about in Baldur's Gate is between several small areas that are part of a larger open world, these can consist of towns, the wilderness or dungeons. In towns there will usually be Inn's, shops and quests to be found. 
Generally in town's you'll to pick up multiple quests for the surrounding area and stock up on gear. Sometimes these quests will be too high level for you but it encourages you to go back later, all your quests are written in a journal written by the protagonist, so rather then telling you exactly where to go it would say something like "I need to go collect some wolf pelts, I've heard wolves can be found up north" and you'll be expected to go find them yourself,

If you're not in a town you'll generally be wandering the wilderness, these are large open areas filled with NPC's, monsters and other surprises to find. All of these areas felt quite dense with content and rewarded you for exploring, I never felt bored since there was plenty of things to find in each area, sometimes you'll stumble upon an enemy or area which is too difficult for you so you can make a note on your map to return later. 

[h1] Dialogue [/h1]

The dialogue is where this game really shines, every conversation has multiple options for you to pick and it lets you role play however you want, you can be a hero a villain, a bit of both or even a mercenary for hire the amount of choice given is something you don't see in modern games. One great aspect of this is that it's possible to talk your way out of combat encounters by choosing the correct dialogue options, for example if you stumble upon a bar fight you can either try and defuse the situation or rile the people up and end up with a huge brawl breaking out.

Almost every conversation you have with characters in game feels is long and interesting, there's plenty of occasions where you'll have to make tough decisions and the choice isn't as simple as being good or evil sometimes you have to make the decision you feel is right at the time and deal with the consequences later. The amount of options you are given for conversations really makes talking to people fun and helps you role play your character, it really lets you choose how you want situations to play out

[h1]Combat[/h1]

Now the combat of this game is really difficult at first, if you've never played D&D before there's a lot to wrap your head around, all characters in your party attack at the same time but there is a pause button which you are going to want to use constantly if you want to survive, when you attack you roll a dice which determines if your attack hits or misses, now this sounds relatively simple but this game really makes you think as it can get quite complex towards the latter half of the game.

Rather than just mashing buttons and trying to spam your way to victory you have to stop and think about how to deal with every encounter, which spells are you going to use, which character is going to try and draw the enemies attention, where are you going to position your party members, long range or close range combat? These are the questions you're going to be asking yourself every single encounter and it makes the combat fun and engaging.

There wasn't a single instance of combat in this game I thought was easy, every single battle i had made me stop and think about how to tackle it, different strategies work on different enemies so sometimes you'll want to rush and kill everything as fast as you can while at other times you'll find yourself trying to lure enemies out one at a time so you don't get overwhelmed. The early game combat starts off pretty basic since you don't have many skills but the longer you play the more skills you get and the more complex and rewarding the fights get. Before you know it you'll be planning multiple steps ahead every single encounter so you can survive with your party in one piece, the game always felt challenging but never unfair, especially the end game dungeons with incredibly tough enemies and bosses which will push you to your limits.

[h1]Issues with the game[/h1]

As far as issues go I had very little to complain about, the only issues i can think of is that at the very start of the game it can be completely overwhelming with the choices given and it's also possible to build your character into a bad build and make it so you'll be unable to finish the game, however if you read the instruction manual or do your research on building a character this shouldn't be an issue. 

Apart from that my only issue was AI path finding, in certain dungeons you'll find your AI partners getting stuck on walls and edges, this is a minor annoyance but wasn't game breaking and only happened now and again.

[H1]Conclusion[/h1]

Overall I can't recommend Baldur's Gate enough, i went in not knowing anything about it and it ended up becoming one of my favourite games of all time. In depth character customisation leads to great replay value and a great role playing experience. The combat was challenging throughout and made me come up with a new strategy for every new encounter, the story is engaging and the side quests are all engaging and fun to complete. Baldur's gate is a masterpiece every fan of RPG's should play, just be aware of the steep learning curve going in, but i promise if yous stick with it you'll have an unforgettable experience.

This game advertises a complete cooperative multiplayer experience and, after several hours trying to start a multiplayer campaign with some friends we can attest that it does not provide what was advertised.

While attempting to play the game we encountered several problems the two most egregious ones being:
- Constant player disconnections every 5-8 minutes.
- The game crashing randomly when trying to look up at the character screen, inventory or any other essential game menu.
This rendered the game basically unplayable, after several hours of enduring this we hadn't even arrived at the first real quest of the game.

My friends and I bought this game with the intention of playing through the campaign together, this being our first BG game ever. With that in mind, I cannot possibly recommend this game to anyone trying to do a similar thing as It does not provide a fulfilling multiplayer experience.

It's honestly a shame, as after finally giving up the multiplayer I decided to try the single player to experience the game for the first time and I really enjoyed. It's easy to see why this game has become the classic that it is today, the writing is charming, the soundtrack is very good and the combat loops are engaging and fun to experiment with.

However it's shortcomings bring my opinion of this game way down. I'm sure that had my experience with the multiplayer been a positive one, this review would be very different. In the current state of the game I stand by my earlier statement, If you intent to buy this as a multiplayer game, I cannot recommend it, for it does not provide any sort of fulfilling multiplayer experience.
I wish the developer would've taken the time to fix this issue, before releasing this and claiming it to be a multiplayer game.

An exceptional, well-crafted D&D campaign and all round RPG with a steep learning curve. Keep in mind, however, that since this is the first campaign of a multi-part story (the story and character progression continues in Baldur's Gate II) the scope and power creep here is fairly limited, with your characters maxing out at levels 9-11 (or the respective dual/multi class exp equivalence). However, the gameplay remains fun and strategic, with there being a wide array of ways to approach every battle despite this. For those who enjoy the combat more than the other D&D elements, The Black Pits offers a relatively short, canned, arena combat focused side "adventure" with a fun story.

Exploration is a huge part of this game and it doesn't disappoint. There are tons of maps to explore and random encounters and side quests to enjoy. Combined with the large number of recruitable characters, each with their own interactions, interpersonal relationships, goals, and personalities, the game can feel different every time we play. It's easy to just get lost in the world  and forget about the main quest. The new Enhanced Edition characters and their respective stories, dialog, interactions, and voice actors are great.

Visually, even the Enhanced Edition gameplay presentation is somewhat dated but it's still enjoyable once you get used to it. The audio, however, is pretty stellar. Solid soundtrack throughout. The voice acting is similarly well done with all dialog being well written.

The game is relatively bug free but there are a few minor ones here and there. Another minor detractor is the pacing: while this is predominately under your control, the main plot tends to lose all sense of urgency when approaching the game with a completionist mindset. This can eventually place side quest plot at odds with the main plot, especially in the case of the Durlag's Tower and Balduran's Voyage end-game quests.

Strongly encourage also picking up Siege of Dragonspear.

Good RPG, the beginning of one of the better stories of any game, no surprise since it is D&D based and D&D bleeds creativity.  The game can be as easy or difficult as you want it to be, but there is always that exciting element of chance central to D&D mechanics, the dice roll.  Harder encounters may be determined by a role of the dice regardless of well developed strategy and proper prior preparation, which keeps things interesting.  Even on standard difficulty, using cheats, and knowing everything in advance, you may still get crushed by a bad roll leading to a failed save throw and instant death.  If you like the world and story, or if you liked the Lord of the Rings books/movies, be sure to check out the many D&D based books that are out there.  With this series of games and hundreds of new books to look forward to, you'll hardly notice that you're trapped in your house hiding from a global pandemic that threatens the world.

I played this when it came out the first time a couple of decades ago; this and BG2 and Icewind Dale and Neverwinter Nights and Planescape: Torment were all Kind of a Big Deal back then, Playing it now after running through some of the Elder Scrolls series and a couple of fantasy MMORPGs, you understand where the inspiration for a lot of today's games came from. Many people building today's fantasy worlds after BG (and a few others, like the original Fallout and - going further back - Ultima) are standing on the shoulders of giants...and that's not a criticism, it's a compliment. About the enhanced edition: Downloaded and installed with no issues on Win10. No issues with the gameplay so far; haven't run into any bugs, stutters, or autoclosing...though that might be due to technology improvements made since Win98 or hardware in general. Whatever the reason, definitely smoother and cleaner than the original. There's more characters and classes than I remember - always wanted to play a Monk on the paper-and-dice version back in the day so now I am - and despite having played much more technologically and thematically advanced games, I'm hooked again. If you really want the details of the enhanced edition, look'em up. Support for higher resolution, non-Win OS, improved code, alignment with BG2, re-done cinematics. Given this revamp and re-release was done in 2012, there's mods available but I'd recommend a vanilla walk-through before changing things up. 7/10 because it is an old game and may bore someone only used to current offerings, and Noober. 13/10 due to personal nostalgia, historical significance, plot/lore, a good and respectful rework of the original, and Minsc and his pet hamster Boo. So, 10/10 overall.
