Simply put, this game isn't as great as nostalgia remembers it to be. Played almost 200 hours trying to recapture that feeling, but it just isn't there. This game just doesn't hold up.

The companions are pretty bad all around. Mismatched stats, questionable skills, some you get WAY too late, others you can't keep around because of how much reputation you are forced to gain just through basic questing for the required levels, they all just feel really flat.

Early game is a nightmare because of how limited you are to anything and everything. All combat is completely random because you don't have access to skills that meaningfully add anything, and HP is so low that a bad roll will kill. Some spells like Horror are completely overpowered because at those levels nothing has a high enough save to reliably prevent it, and this game LOVES to throw it at you, and it has a gigantic area of effect.

Enjoy seeing a never ending chain of misses as you require to roll 16+ to hit anything while the enemies only need a 10+ on your front line, because THAC0 is just a really bad system without having the higher level skills to adjust for it.

I want to love this game as much as I remember, but I can't. The magic just isn't there. The maps feel so empty, the characters are fairly boring, and even at the end of the story, it's just meh. Roll with a few mages, Horror/Hold Person, then destroy everything. It's a tactic so useful it's the only thing that you come across in the endgame.

The addition of class kits from BGII is nice, but again, these feel underwhelming until you unlock a lot of their more fun things. A paladin is exactly the same as a fighter with better saves for the most part, which is the same as a default ranger.

Durlag's Tower makes having a high level Thief essential, when having a high level Thief in the base game is completely pointless since you won't come across anything that requires it. Resulting in a character that is a worse archer/fighter that can backstab some things. 

It just really doesn't hold up to my memory of it.

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition is an enjoyable 2D RPG. There is an immersive story line,  a variety of character choices for your avatar and dozens of side stories to pursue. The random rolls used for combat (this game follows D&D guidelines) means you will want to save often to prevent unnecessary redundancy. This isn't going to rev you up with tons of excitement like more modern games, but it is entertaining nonetheless. Totally worth its price on the replayability alone.

Eu queria que houvesse um meio termo entre recomendar e não recomendar, como um dedão pro lado. Eu daria um sólido dedão pro lado pra esse jogo.

Baldur's Gate é um jogo fruto da sua época. Eu imagino que ele tenha sido revolucionário quando lançado, e, sem dúvida, os bons momentos dele são realmente bons. A história é simples, e no geral satisfatória. Os personagens ajudantes são muitos, e variados, e em nenhum momento comandam o ritmo da história: nesse jogo, seu personagem é o foco.

Eu sou jogador experiente de RPG, e conheço por alto algumas regras do AD&D. Mesmo assim, tive MUITA dificuldade para entender as magias, seus efeitos, e os milhares de pequenos detalhes desnecessários que o jogo te dá (texto redundante e prolixo), ao mesmo tempo tentando descobrir as informações que o jogo não te dá (o que diabos é um turno e uma rodada em um jogo de tempo real?). É como se o jogo falasse "você quer aprender a jogar? vai ler o livro do jogador... e o do mestre... e aproveita e lê o guia de monstros enquanto faz isso tudo... depois a gente conversa." É um jogo que não se esforça pra facilitar esse aprendizado, e muito do que usei no jogo veio de fontes externas.

Os momentos bons do jogo são realmente bons e satisfatórios. Acho que vi poucas coisas tão excelentes, em termos narrativos e mecânicos, quanto a Torre de Durlag. É um conteúdo opcional do jogo para personagens de nível alto, e o nível de qualidade desta área é destoante do resto do jogo, e é absurdamente bom. Ouso dizer que as horas tediosas que antecederam esta parte do jogo valeram a pena.

Os momentos ruins do jogo são um porre. Diálogos longos, caminhadas longas, encontros aleatórios que rendem pouca experiência, e aquele clássico "mas o jogo não começa de verdade até o quinto nível". Seu inventário é limitado tanto em espaço e em peso, e você gasta um bom tempo otimizando a coleta de tesouros pra, da metade pra frente do jogo, dinheiro não ser mais um problema.

Eu joguei Baldur's Gate porque queria ver como era o jogo, e ver quais são as expectativas pro 3 que vai sair, e estou feliz de ter jogado. É um jogo longo, complexo, e profundo, com uma narrativa passável, e que me divertiu. Se você não quer se dar ao trabalho de aprender um sistema obtuso de regras (o que diabos é THAC0? Por que a armadura baixa é melhor que a alta?), ou se uma história repleta de clichês te desagrada, faça a si mesmo um favor e passe LONGE de Baldur's Gate.

I'll preface this by saying that I am a massive, abiding fan of Baldur's Gate 2.  I've played through it more times than I can count, going all the way back to the original incarnation's launch in 2000.  It is the single most influential video game I have ever played.  After beating it the first time, I remember trying to play through BG1 to see if it was anywhere near as good.

It was not.

I quit pretty quickly.  I don't remember how far I got, and, for years, I just dismissed it as boring and one-note.  But, having decided recently to play through BG2 again, for the 3,916th time, I decided to make a proper go of it and start with BG1, thinking maybe it got better with age.  Maybe it got better as my appreciation for BG2 grew.

It did not.

This game suffers from its low level play.  It suffers so badly from it.  Warrior types ineptly flail about, missing almost constantly (not aided by the engine animating the 5 attacks per round maximum even though you'll only ever have 1 or 2).  Pretty much anyone else can be flippantly one-shot by a stray arrow or a slightly lucky single bolt magic missile.  Casters have 1-3 spells to cast before they have to rest, and any offensive disabling magic (horror, hold person, etc) cast against you is practically a guaranteed full wipe.  My strategy very quickly became outfitting everyone with bows and slings, then tagging one character with decent (read, actually double digit) HP to run around in circles, luring all the enemies to endlessly chase him as the rest of the party pelted them slowly to death.  This strategy was basically a necessity until I got to around level 5 (at which point the majority of the game is over).  Anytime I tried standing my ground in the early game, my front line was inevitably slaughtered in short order.

The quest design and storytelling are similarly frustrating.  Nearly every quest apart from the main line is reduced to the form: I was wandering around the woods when <insert monster type here> stole my lucky <insert household/clothing item here>, get it back!  What's worse, each quest is presented as a uniformly imposing wall of text, and after trudging through it, you are always presented with the same two dialog options:

1. An over-exaggerated Medieval Times style acceptance replete with forsooths and anons, or...

2. A refusal written either by a rage courting psychopath or Tom Green who, as he is contractually obligated, just wants to show you how wacky and zany and hilarious he is are you laughing yet come on laugh laugh lauhahahahaugh...

This kind of "storytelling" is done practically everywhere in the game.  There's no pacing, no room for anything to breathe or effect.  The actual guts of the main story are interesting enough, to a point.  Investigating the leads in the mines and the woods and building a case against the Iron Throne is pretty cool.  As well, what they're up to in the city, with their competing merchant guilds, was interesting.  But once the big "plot reveal" happens, the story just dies.  What should be this massive, earth-shattering moment is delivered in a book.  You read in Sarevok's journal that you're probably a child of Bhaal and the game's just like: "Cool, okay, I guess this is proof that he's been doing naughty things and shouldn't be a grand duke or whatever."  And there's no questioning, no impact, no reaction from party members or allies.  It's just dismissed.  The centerpiece for your place in the entire series is introduced with a yawn and then dismissed.  It's incomprehensibly bad storytelling.

Fortunately, the game only limps on a short while longer.  And what fights that do remain are trivial things when pitted against...waaaaaand mouuuuuntain (seriously, I had so many wands by the end).  But the enjoyment of beating the game was limited strictly to enjoyment at the prospect of not needing to play it anymore.  I would have had a better time just starting with BG2 again.  Still boring.  Still one-note.

The wilderness exploration component is the only aspect I wish had carried through into BG2.  It had legitimate potential, even if it was largely wasted on pointless fetch quests.  Avoid.

This was my first experience with Baldur's Gate, having never played the original. The game has an extremely high learning curve at first and some of the game's hardest moments will be experienced within the first few hours of playing when you're under powered and even a wolf or two could possibly kill your whole party. Once you get over this and into the story you find a great game with some flaws (terrible pathfinding being the worst of them). Definitely a great experience but it is a true timesink like a lot of RPG's. Completing the whole game and all of the expansion set missions (Tales of the Sword Coast which is included in EE) took me a little bit less than 80 hours. I would also recommend to understand/google the rules of how armor and damage works in this game before spending too much time in it.

For the newcomers to this game: expect one giant exploration based rpg. There is an entire coast of areas to discover, including the city of Baldur's Gate, with lots of random stuff and quests. In addition, while the gameplay system might seem daunting if you are not familiar with tabletop rpg's, expect to spend hours figuring out what works for a character and what doesn't, which spells are effective when, how to approach certain enemies etc. At least half of the fun of the game is in exploring the system as much as the story and areas.

For the experienced: Do yourself a favour, and replay this with the EE, together with the mods BG1 NPC project and Holic's 3.5 remaster of this game, with basic AI enhancements from SCS recommended. This will breathe new life into the game, and boosts a lot of classes and combinations that used to be weak in the original version.

Especially I welcome the 3.5 mod's balanced approach to classes, items and feats. It is a hell of a lot of fun to explore the new feat system, the new abilities and the new spells as well as the new NPC classes. In addition, I feel with its revamped attack-per-round system and the changed stacking of dex bonus with armour the game is much more enjoyable, and a lot of classes that used to be very weak (without a dual class splash of fighter) are now much more effective, notably clerics and thieves. I must warn that the first two levels before you get to lvl 3 are also much more deadly! Liberal application of Sleep is recommended, and luckily druids also get that spell now!

[b]Bottom Line:[/b] Baldur's Gate is one of the forefathers of the CRPG genre, and a good one at that. I'd recommend for anyone into newer offerings like Divinity Original Sin or the Pillars of Eternity games, or anyone interested in the upcoming BG3 release, with the caveat that the older D&D systems may take some getting used to.

[u]Long Take[/u]
Disclosure - I absolutely love this entire series. And yes, that includes the recent Siege of Dragonspear xpac. A must play for anyone into CRPGs and story-based games, although newcomers to the series will have an adjustment period to the older D&D rule set. But once you figure everything out, boy is this a fun game. Most reviews cover what this game is about, so instead, I'll offer some tips to get the most out of a first foray into the Sword Coast.

[list]
[*]The mechanics, like mentioned, are antiquated. Lower numbers are better when it comes to things like Armor Class (AC), saving throws (resist magic and the like), THACO (your chance to hit). Big numbers are desired for stuff like actual damage and HP pools.
[*]Fighter variants are a safe first choice to play as. Dual/Multi classes are very strong but take some understanding of the rules. Mages begin very weak but become ultra powerful (moreso in BG2) if you understand their spellbooks - control/debilitation spells are quite good. A thief is vital for newbies when it comes to pick locks and find traps, so I'd recommend sticking with Imoen to cover this.
[*]In BG1 especially, take your time and explore some. You have a few companions who rush you towards Nashkel, but they'll shut up the first time you enter that area then you can go do whatever you want. Even moreso than BG2, this game is pretty open to the order of balance between side-questing and main story.
[*]If you're into the RP aspects, the game generally leans into the good approach. This includes the supposed "canon" party that is pushed on to you in transitions between BG1/SoD/BG2. However, if you plan a full saga playthrough, I actually think it wraps up quite nicely with an evil/selfish bent. Murder-hobo doesn't work well, but I personally enjoyed a power craving sort the most.
[*]There's some controversy to Siege of Dragonspear, the xpac between BG1 and BG2. I think its worth playing, if nothing else for the tactically interesting fights that are added.
[*]Modding! I actually recommend one mod for a first playthrough: "BG1 NPC Project". One of the biggest weaknesses of this game is that your companions are much shallower than in BG2, and this mod does a fantastic job of bringing them to life. It provides them with quite a lot of well written dialog interjections.
[*]Modding pt. 2: for those who want more of a challenge with superior enemy AI, look into Sword Coast Strategems. I wouldn't necessarily recommend this for a first playthrough, but its fantastic if you have experience with other CRPGs, are a patient sort who likes tactical challenges, or have played this game before but never with SCS.
[/list]

Expect what you would expect from a tabletop D&D campaign with friends; albeit with much better writing, visuals, and sounds.  If you haven't played either before, expect a narrative focused, deliberately paced, turn-based, western RPG.  There is a large amount of text, talking to NPC's, and wandering about from destination to destination as opposed to the predominantly combat heavy, action-oriented RPGs popular today.  If anything it is the definition of the CRPG genre and for those that enjoy the turn based RPG's of the 90's and prior, I would suggest giving it a shot if this one passed you by.  It somewhat captures the feel of a tabletop experience but is also a very well made game in its own right.  The music, dialogue, and artwork in particular are well done.  The pre-rendered backgrounds still look great and still worth checking out if you're in the latter camp.  If not, do some digging to make sure this would be right for you.  If contemporary Final Fantasy, The Witcher, and modern Elder Scrolls are your bread and butter for RPG gaming, you may find this is to be too tedious or slow.

Truly amazing! You can make this as much of a technical or role-playing experience as you want. Even based more than 20 years ago, the characters feel much more personalized than systems with sliders and modern graphics. This is the epitome of a role-playing game, you play a role in the world around you. This game uses an older version of D&D which is much more restrictive yet more concrete than 5th edition (which is fantastic but this was the version that I grew up with). These rules make the game challenging and, sometimes, unforgiving. Yet the game is rewarding and easily replayable. 

This game is truly amazing, the characters who you can pick up along the way (yes, Minsc & Boo!) or that you fight have fascinating personas, powers, abilities, and features that make them all unique. The voice acting is truly amazing and the artwork for each character is beautiful. The story is excellent but is a bit simple; but there are many side-quests and monsters to fight that can be done over and over again. 

I love this game, I've been playing it for years and I truly encourage everyone to join in. Sorry for being rambling, but this game is worth it!
It's one of the greatest AD&D game modules every created. It set many standards in gaming and also the AD&D tabletop community. It's worth playing through if you're a DM and want to get some ideas.

I recall back in the day in college playing BG with a buddy of mine. We only had one set of discs and had to do a full install on both machines and run the disks back and forth to finish the load screens, good times. 

BGEE is a great reboot of a good old game. The classic game is largely left as is and extra content is generally in line with the theme and feel of its predecessor. Yes it can be buggy and yes it is dated but its not a remake of an old game its a porting of an old game to new systems using the updated mechanics of its sequel. I for one am happy with the end results and am on a great nostalgia kick. 

This game gets a bit of flack from some for being dated or not as modern as current fantasy adventure games but that is kind of the point, this game is over 20 years old. Yes there are more modern games using the classic ISO feel like POE or tyranny and they are great games also but if you want a taste of the epic classic that really kicked it all off in a big way this is the game for you. A must play for any fantasy RPG fan.

I for one enjoyed the BG2 mechanics and the opportunity to play that in the original BG with all the gritty graphics of the late 1990's intact is just great. Some interface options feel a little clunkier than the original but most are improvements over what was available in 1998. Perhaps the name enhanced edition is misleading as not a lot has been enhanced, but rather updated for running on modern machines with the classic bugs mostly fixed (although some new ones have been introduced). I appreciate the fact that for the most part the original has been left intact, some lines of dialogue are missing here and there but its really not a game breaker. The new additions by beamdog of a few extra characters to join your party and their associated quests slide well into the game and play as though they have always been part of it so again no complaints. 

This game won't hold your hand or spoon feed you the solution, this is raw good old gaming when you had to figure it out for yourself. God I miss the days when every game didn't start with a 15 min here's how to press the button hand hold tutorial, but I digress.

Multiplayer seems to have the same buggy unreliability of the original 1998 version which can be a pain but again for me it was just classic business as usual, you could expect some stability improvements overall but I have to admit I haven't really had any of the issues in multiplayer that most people complain about. Lucky us I guess. 

I think Beamdog did a great job with the EE series, and am happy to recommend them to others. Get BGEE and BG2EE and when you are done with them get Icewind Dale EE and Planescape Torment EE and get lost in some gritty old school classic fantasy RPG. 

Then go play ultima and diablo and see how great BG really is for its time. (I like them too just BG/IWD are better IMHO, more so now with the EE versions)

Baldur's Gate is among the best, and possibly the first, attempts at translating the elements that make the Tabletop RPG experience unique and interesting into video game form. The difficulty is refreshing; keeping everyone in your party alive is truly a struggle at times, requiring planning, creativity, and occasionally sheer dumb luck. The battles are hard-won and rewarding because of it. 

To speak on the diversity of character builds, I will start by saying Baldur's Gate offers a breadth of options that put modern games to shame. It does this both by offering a ton of class options AND by making those decisions matter. Your decisions in this regard affect your gaming experience substantially, and BG encourages players to really experiment with their play style in a way that reaches far beyond the knight/rogue/mage idea you may see here and there. 

The game is also superbly written, with deep lore to unravel both on the macro (world) and micro (character) level. The world is alive; factions are breathing down each other's necks, the morality of it all is far from simple black-and-white good and bad, and the characters you end up interacting with fall out with one another based on deeper values and critiques. It's important to consider how you build a party, for instance, because while a balance of skills is key, a similar diversity of perspectives may lead to two party members coming to blows. A lot is happening all the time, and the scale this gives to one's take-away is satisfying to say the least.

If you are a fan of challenging but rewarding strategic RPGs with deep lore and replayability, this is the grandaddy and the standard bearer even 22 years on.

The original D&D CRPG. A true work of love towards that franchise, BG:EE is the perfect version of this game. With the enhanced edition, you get voice acting, multiplayer and many QoL upgrades. The multiplayer is a blast. BG:EE includes essentially two games. The main story, a good 80h + in itself, and the Black Pits, a gladiatorial-style of game. I think it has a story too, but I have yet to play it.

I highly recommend it for people that want to play D&D on computer, whether it's with friend or by oneself!

I cannot understate how bad the "Enhanced" edition is. Beamdog botched this thing on all fronts. It's just a bad hack. To summarize:
- most of the new features range from literal downgrade from the original (UI revamp, especially how the fucking zooming effect when you open the map) to worthless (new colored selection circles! greyscale on pause!) to bad (awful new NPCs) to "mods will fix it" (new modding capabilities, which are the only reason you might play this version)
- features that actually are useful were all just taken from various mods
- features that could and should be added, like balancing how the game plays on the sequel's engine (subclasses especially) were completely omitted 
- various technical nightmares - somehow for years EE was more bugged than the original, and still it lacks such basic features like changing game resolution

I mean jesus fucking christ. How could you fuck it so badly is beyond me.

The game is really good, until you've played it twenty times without ever completing it.
Don't get me wrong, it has replay value. I still find events and ways of playing that I've never seen before. However, as it is a story heavy role-playing game, playing through the same events over and over can become tiring. The advice I would give is to complete this on your first time through, to ensure that these events don't become repetitive. Additionally, I wouldn't recommend trying to do everything in every zone. It can be useful in the beginning, with some powerful magical items being hidden away, but will become overwhelming once you reach the major cities. It is easy enough to become powerful without finding every secret, so it's best to just play without worrying about what you might've missed.

Skip straight to BGII. This one's trash. Most of it's just spamming monsters at you, and at lower levels all you can really do is spam what few useful spells you have and then watch everyone smack each other. Except that you don't actually smack each other because your party spends 90% of the time smacking the air directly in front of their opponents. Not only is this extremely tedious when fighting weaker creatures in waves, and that just as rare moment that your enemy actually manages to hit you you pretty much die outright if your constitution sucks enough (again, more of a lower level issue, but still a problem). Dialogue is sparse, and while "immersive" though the sort of language it uses, it's god-awful boring. The enemy scaling is so blatantly obvious that you feel like you're going backwards instead of forwards each time you level up.

Everything I just mentioned is fixed in the BGII. Again, skip this, play that.

It was a classic at the time but it has not aged well at all.   I played the original and loved it. I convinced a friend in HS to buy it and he didn't like it.  Playing it now with fresh eyes I get why he bounced right off of it.

It's slow. Movement speed is slow as heck.  There's no particular reason for it but walking around town or whatever is just so  s l  o   w.  Combat is also slow and tedious.  There's longass pauses between attacks. 

Characters are also super fragile. A wolf will kill you in one hit. There's no in-game solution to this. There's no "downed" state to rescue people from. They're just dead. You are expected to reload and roll the dice again.  There's often not even a lot of room for smart tactics.  You micromanage your party to move them around and hope they don't get hit.  It's not fun. It gets a little better when you level up but it's a terrible early game.

Leveling is slow. You killed a wolf (after a few reloads)!  You earned 65 / 2500 xp needed to level. Yay?

The spellcasting system is classic D&D which is trash. You camp a lot to refresh spells. Sometimes you get ambushed and reload. It's not good.

The story is... fine, I guess.  The writing has some gems. 

So overall it's just.... it was good for the time and very ambitious, but it's not fun.

A classic, touched up with better graphics and gameplay, plus additional classes, characters, Tales of Sword Coast and the Black Pits. Also it integrates seamlessly with the Siege of Dragonspear expansion (purchased separately). Seriously, these games combined gives you hundreds, maybe thousands of hours of replayability. While the cutscenes are kind of dated, the gameplay, characters, side quests, and storyline provide hundreds, maybe thousands of hours worth of gameplay that I keep returning to year after year. It's truly telling how great the series is when it's STILL getting updates and expansions decades later, and still has an active community. If you haven't played Baldurs Gate, or Siege of Dragonspear, or Shadows of Amn, or Throne of Bhaal, it's time to pick them all up and start from the beginning to see what all the fuss is about. Jump in and enjoy.

Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition (BG:EE) revitalizes Baldur's Gate and adds popular fixes and hours of additional game-play to an already story rich and immersive game. The game allows you to immerse yourself at your own comfort level, wither you want to read all of the additional story rich in game text, or just play through an incredibly fun role playing game, its up to you. I played through the original game about 7 times, single player and multi player when it first came out, and have had just as much fun playing through BG:EE for the several times I've revisited this game. Additionally you can just jump right into the new content in the black pits, or even Siege of Dragonspear, which are a lot of fun as well, and allowed me a happy bit of nostalgia. The new characters are interesting, and encourage more party combinations than the old crews that I usually fall into. Anyone looking for an immersive isometric RPG that never fails to please will be happy with BG:EE.

Late to DnD, and finding this game has been amazing! Love playing with my group when we can't all get together for a full session.

It's a pretty good coat of paint on an old chassis.

The Positive: I've been playing the infinity engine games since release and as the years wore on, the amount of modding it needed to be playable on a modern system was kind of a chore (widescreen mod, etc.). So from that perspective, the EE versions make it very accessible for people coming at this new, or for people who just don't want to be bothered with the setup.

The Negative: The Beamdog made content (new NPCs, Siege of Dragonspear, Black Pits, etc.) is really uneven or even downright terrible. It's not so much that they tried to put some new NPCs to show off new kits and classes (wild mage, blackguard, monk, etc.) it's that the way they are written and even put in your face doesn't really match the tone of the original companion NPCs. Whatever, it's easy enough to ignore them (or preferably recruit them and get them killed).

The "I'm not sure if this is a bad thing or a good thing?" thing: The increased level cap from Siege of Dragonspear and the inclusion of BG2 kits, and BG2 spells. In the first case the increase from 161K to 500K creates a situation where you're character will be about 2 levels higher than they normally would be when you import them to BG2. Certainly you can skip the expansion or disable it to keep the old EXP cap, but it makes for a very different experience if you're planning to follow on with the sequel. Second to that is the inclusion of BG2 spells and kits. The original Baldur's Gate wasn't made with either of these mechanics in mind, and some of them can really trivialize certain encounters and it doesn't appear that Beamdog did much (if anything) to re-balance the game with these changes. On the other hand exporting characters to the next installment is much more streamlined, without having to respec.

All-in-all? Quibbles aside with new content, the addition of all of the quality of life improvements makes this a pretty good remaster/update. I just wish Beamdog had included a toggle to turn off the new companions or had integrated something like an SCS (Sword Coast Strategems) difficulty option so I don't have to do any modding.

One of the all time rpg classics! Of course graphics are outdated, movement is clunky and the interface is a pain in the ass. However, the game still has a lot of charme. Great NPC and character interaction, tons of lore and good sideqeusts make the game still worth playing even after two decades. Your actions and decisions have some impact on the NPC around you since you may play as one of the goody good guys or as an evel freak and this is what makes rpgs interesting.
D&D fans will like how the ruleset was implemented in the game, making character progression and leveling very complex. Character progression is rather slow and especially at the beginning your characters will have only a limited amount of abilities. Nevertheless, you'll have plenty of options later on leveling up your characters. If you are not familiar with the D&D ruleset you'll have to do some research on what is possible and what might suit your playstyle.
Moreover, it is great to see that a game can tell an exiting story without aiming at saving the world, the galaxy or the universe. It is a simple story but it should still make you curious and you will want to know what is going on at the Sword Coast and you'll want to discover the dark secrets of your main character. 

If you want to have a modern, fast paced game you will hate Baldur's Gate. If you are looking for a rather slow game experience extremely rich in details, with a solid or even good story then this game might be interesting for you. Make sure that you do not forget to use your savegame and thus the characters when playing Baldur's Gate 2 which is a really awesome colossus of a game!

The game has aged mostly fine outside of its visuals which look dated, although still charming in their own right. And Beamdog's quality of life and UI changes make this very much worth playing if you have any interest in the genre. The story is poorly paced with the most exciting moments of it all jammed into the last third of the game. The combat is easily the highlight of the game and after taking a few minutes to learn what the hell THAC 0, it isn't hard to figure out, especially since the game does all the dice rolling and calculations for you. Lower THAC 0 and Armor class is the only stuff you need to know to get started. Save often, the early game can be brutal.

There is a pretty big difficulty spike late in the game once mages start buffing and going nuts with crowd control. Although a lot of this difficulty comes from a lack of knowledge and mages being pushovers for the first half of the game and suddenly being real threats. Magic is where the brilliance and depth of the combat really starts to shine through. Learning what does and doesn't work throughout my play through of the game was a lot of fun, if not sometimes frustrating. There are several difficulty options available to you if you get stuck though.

The only thing I would recommend you do before anything is reading up on stats and probably some first time builds. You don't need to do anything complicated like dual classing. Just make sure you know what stats your class wants and what it can do without, and keep rolling. It's very easy to handicap yourself before the game even starts due to AD&D funkiness. Don't go in blind if it's your first time playing.

First off, the Enhanced Edition is far better than the trash incomplete version on GOG, even when modded. This version has so many improvements and cut content from the original, just quality of life stuff and stuff that should have been there plus a few new surprises. You don't have to hunt for the best mods or worry if things will get messed up, Beamdog has taken care of everything for you.

Now, moving on to what you want to know...

Baldurs Gate is an isometric rpg that does a good job of hiding the "holding your hand" technique, usually the typical process is a mini-map, arrows and markers but here in this game we have a journal and a world map, you're pretty much told wheee to go by name and just search with the clues given to you so technically ot still holds your hand but in a much more mature way than what we're used to getting in an rpg. Arrows and markers wouldn't make much sense in an isometric rpg anyway.

The mechanics are complex.. you know, there are some Jrpg's which use super complex mechanics in crafting, combat and so forth. This game buries anything else in the industry in terms of depth of combat and learning curve for mechanics. You can play this game for 80 hours and still not know all of the systems. Whether you're an experiened D&D player or new, you're still going to be learning the same amount.

Story-wise, it's not very emotional like some games I've played today (Life Is Strange, Transistor, Nier: Automata, I'm looking at you!). It's not going to make you cry but it might make you laugh. Voice acting is partial, there is some, enough to give you some personality to both npc's and playable characters who join your party. You're going to be reading alot, there's alot of dialogue and alot of choice.

As far as interactivity and exploration go, there's alot to explore and alot of side-quests. Random emcounters are a thing, if you set up camp and rest, bandits may come for you and try to kill you, you may wake up to find some of your items stolen. Make a wrong choice that your party disagrees with and they may abandon your party. Bounty hunters will be sent after you if you are murderous, the town will love you or fear you based on how you treat townfolk. There literally isn't a game on the market that matches the depth of the Baldurs Gate series in this regard.

There is alot of freedom in Baldurs Gate. It's thought of by many to be the 2D spiritual predecessor to The Elder Scrolls series but gives you more choice than them. You can be anyone, any class, kill anything or anyone, have a party of six or solo and much more.

"Story-Mode" difficulty has been added and what a joy it is to play if you find the combat to be an overwhelming joy or if you have better things to do than worry about dying or losing companions and gear. As someone whose work is getting more demanding, I was thankful for this option, I don't want a 60 hour game to be stretched out to 200 just because of deaths when I have to work alot and have other games to play and finish as well (My backlog is large).

Graphically, the sprites are not the best but the 2D backdrops are gorgeous. This is far better looking than the original version of the game. You can actually tell what things are, you can zoom in and see small decales like an inn symbol and so on. Sound is crisp like the original, there really isn't a change there but surround sound and headphones support has been added.

Controls: My only legit and validated compaint is that controller support hasn't been added. The PS4 port of the game proved that controller works better with the game's UI than mouse and keyboard. Who would have thought? I wish that this was an option like it is for Divinity: Original Sin. Alot of pc gamers seem to agree that controller would fit the game better now as we pass through the years. Otherwise, if you are happy with the mouse and keyboard, you won't care too much about this anyway.

Overall, you have an rpg game from 1998, that still gives you more freedom than any rpg today. Now that it's remastered, there's no excuse not to try this amazing rpg. Even moreso because of story-mode difficulty, you can breeze through the game on this setting so there's no reason to be intimated if you're not familiar to the D&D systems.

So ages ago I played this game (having had to talk my parents into buying a game featuring a skull on the cover) and it's nearly endless replayability led me to constantly turn to it in the wee hours of the night.  This was frowned upon by my parents who felt I should be sleeping and doing homework.  Needless to say the game presents gobs of content and back in its day it was a gem among games, literally taking gaming into the world of D&D in a very narrative driven way, like pen and paper D&D itself.  Needless to say I readily partook of all the other games: Icewind Dale, Baldur's Gate 2, Pools of Radiance (the 2001 game), and even Neverwinter Nights 1 & 2.  These games formed the core of my love for both the novels from D&D and the D&D pen and paper universe.
This Enhanced Edition is wonderful.  Bringing back the game with much wanted comfort additions to make the gameplay more fluid and up to date with modern games and PCs as well as just flat out adding content (like the Monk Kits). I'm recommending it with the caution that I'd estimate that 80% of the population doesn't have the patience to slog through this series when other, more cutting-edge products are out there.
For most people, I'd advise just playing Skyrim if you like sword & sorcery stuff, especially if you want a shooter-like experience, but with swords and bows instead of machine guns and rocket launchers.
If you want the experience of playing a party-based Dungeons & Dragons game that looks like low-res minatures moving around on a grainy map, this game is for you.  Like Minecraft, it can still be good, in spite of it being a little pixelated.

About two decades after I should have played this game, I finally got around to it. The big question was would it still hold up despite the many advances in graphics and interface that have taken place? Well I was pleasantly surprised. The game is old skool and doesn't hold your hand. The learning curve for the uninitiated (that's me) is high, but the rewards are worth it once you get the hang of the mechanics.

For those looking for an open world RPG, this is not the game for you. But it is a game that has choices which at times make you wonder which way your moral compass really points. So it's worth playing today when there are more "sophisticated" RPG options available.

The main criticism I would have of the game is that it just ends abruptly. It was nice to beat the game, but after all that time invested into the story I was expecting something else.

In summary, my son told me to sum the game up as, "a big fat YES!".

Baldur's Gate is one of my absolute favorite games. It's a true classic in the genre and is probably the reason I play D&D today. Fun quests, interesting followers and a large, active world to explore. The storyline is also a gem and has held up very nicely without becoming cliche.

The enhanced edition adds a lot to the game and I enjoyed finding the new followers and participating in the new quest-lines. 

My only gripe is that the multiplayer has never worked properly for my friend group. We've attempted to play multiplayer several times over the course of the last year or two. It normally disconnects us or bugs out and forces us to reconnect over and over, which can really take you out of the story with how often it occurs. This is with proper port-forwarding plus different hosts and configurations. Nothing stays stable long enough to actually play.

All-in-all, Baldur's Gate is a fantastic game and I highly recommend it to anyone that enjoys RPGs and Dungeons & Dragons.

The enhanced version of this classic cRPG also features the Tales of the Sword Coast expansion, as well as a brief new adventure module called The Black Pits. There are a few new companions with respective quest lines, but the biggest change IMO is the expanded resolution and widescreen support, along with the long list of QoL improvements. The main story on its own will take you at least 30 hours, and there's a lot more to do after you're done with that. Not much more I can say really -  this is an absolute masterpiece of a game, and a must-have for any RPG fan.

Baldurs Gate is not the first isometric rpg I've played, but oddly enough its the first I've completed.

I originally purchased this game many years ago on sale but found the somewhat "RnG" based Level 1 DND combat to be off-putting. A few months ago I saw some merit in trying it again and started a inquisitor paladin with good alignment. I got rid of any character that whined about going to Nashkel early on and ended up running mainly a "good-natured" party with some neutral characters. After some initial exploring and questing, I found that I was much more confident wandering around the world on my own. By that I mean of course that I had dumped the walkthrough that I was using before to get my bearings. The result of this is that I ended up enjoying the open-ended aspect of the game, where one could go anywhere or do anything provided they are the appropriate level or have the appropriate spells/equipment. I'd say for 75% of the game I was just wandering around doing quests and discovering new locales. As the game is quite old, nothing I discovered along the way was truly "ground-breaking" and in fact most of the game world is fairly rudimentary. However it was exciting to trek across the map and get stronger along the way. 

I guess the criticisms I have to level are the fact that after a certain point I didn't really have to change up my combat strategy. Granted, I was playing on normal difficulty and not core rules and perhaps that could've played a part in it. For instance, for the early to mid game one can simply get by with a couple decent tanks/fighter, a mage who has the "sleep" spell and perhaps a cleric. During the latter half of the game enemies do get a lot tougher but if you've been doing side quests and gathering equipment then some of those fights can simply be pushed through with force or excessive buffing. I also didn't particularly enjoy anything from Chapter 5 onwards, although Chapter 6 was interesting. I felt that Baldurs Gate as a city was far too convoluted/overwhelming and at that point in the game I was already burnt out on doing side quests, so I just wanted to push on with the main quest. The story gets better but obviously its very straightforward and there are not many twists and turns. A product of its age.  

All in all, I had a surprisingly good experience with BG1. I am excited to push through the expansion on to Baldurs Gate 2 which I hear is much better. If it only gets better from here than I am excited to see what happens next.

The original Infinity Engine RPG that started it all... a pure classic.

The Short Review (For those who have never played)

The game may not age too well for new players due to a lack of voice acting. This is old school gaming, and its not forgiving at all. You'll be loading and saving and dying and loading constantly. It takes just a second to do so it isn't going to really slow you down. I don't think the story is very interesting, but the characters are pretty cool, and the middle of the game is great as you're really finding awesome loot that supes up your characters. 

Its interesting to try and form a party that can function and stay together, as many characters won't get along due to moral differences. This is something I'd like to see implemented in more games, but Baldur's Gate still does a great job of it. 

I do think the game overstays its welcome after a bit. It's just...man it's so long. But there are tons of characters to find and try to use and you'll likely have fun doing it. Worth it if you're looking for an old school RPG experience. 

Score 7/10

Baldur’s Gate: Enhanced Edition is a fantastic game and a steal for $20 base price. This game is easily worth $20 with what is likely 60+ hours of material, and likely 80-100 for first timers into the series. The game is old, over 20 years in fact, and it's not easy by the slightest. This game is hard and is completely unforgiving unless you have quick saved before your party's death. This game is also extremely rewarding in the form of level ups, loot and new spells. For this review I am going to look at the good and the bad of the game and what you should expect going into it for your first time. 

Good:
Story - The game has a fantastic storyline and side quests that will keep you satisfied. Without going into any spoilers, the main story line lasts 7 chapters and you will likely go through 8-9 levels for your characters. The story is long, and excellent at the same time. 
Open World - The game is completely open world and is for the most part balanced to reflect this openness. I found myself completely lost in the many wooded areas and locations on the world map killing enemies that were challenging. You can pretty much approach the main storyline and side quests in different ways which is a good sign of the non-linear gameplay in Baldur’s Gate. 
Combat - The combat is a pause-based combat based on AD&D 2nd edition rules. It's very different from other CRPGs in recent memory. I suppose the closest example is Pillars of Eternity and Tyranny (both made by Obsidian) with their pause-based mechanics but the rest of the combat is significantly different. The combat is based on THAC0 or To Hit Armor Class 0 for physical damage. For magical spells the damage is calculated by whatever the spell says, typically # of times a dice of #-sided is rolled, EX: 2d8 meaning 2 rolls of an 8-sided die, (16 max damage, 2 minimum). Magical resistances are also a part of this game like other CRPGs. This system is radically different to CRPGs today so it may take some time to getting used to. Rule of thumb however is you want the lowest AC and THAC0 possible. All of this equals a super addicting combat system. Although it may be frustrating at times it's awesome to watch your enemies run in fear around the map after casting your horror ability or watching them burn alive after casting fireball. 
Companions - The older companions from the original game are a little dull, but the enhanced edition companions are fantastic, and some add unique quests and dialogue to the game. Be careful though because depending on your alignment your companions may be tricky to keep in line.
Alignment - This game is one of the few games where your reputations matters. In the game if you murder someone or add someone to your party that is evil your reputation will be hurt. And that has real game consequences. If you walk into town the guards may immediately attack you, and party members may leave depending on their alignment and your reputation. Being evil Is certainly harder than being good and reputation will interfere with some quest lines as well. 
Loading Times/performance - There are none. This game is so old it was made to run on 32-bit computers with floppy disc drives. Modern machines today make the loading times 0 so if you want a game that will run smoothly and never crashes on a potato this game is perfect. 
Character Customization - Boy are there tons of options. There are several classes to choose from and several more sub-classes after that. Choose Cleric, there are 5 priest options. Choose Thief, there are 4 sub-classes to that. While you cannot customize the way, your character looks all too much, you can customize what you want them to be. You do have to play as that class the entire game so choose wisely as you cannot respec or go down a different path like Divinity Original Sins allows you to.

Bad:
Graphics - This game is very old, and the enhanced edition does not improve the graphics that much. According to the devs all the in-game models and backgrounds were lost in a flood saved on disc drives. That is unfortunate if true as this game would look amazing if recreated on another engine like the ones that made Divinity or Pillars of Eternity 2. Though as it stands, the game is not very pretty but personally I don't mind the old graphics. You get use to them after having so much fun in the game. 
Spell indicators - The game lacks any AoE indicator for spells and other abilities. The game says that a spell has a # ft diameter but there is no way to gauge how much that is on the screen as there is no indicator. So, you could on accident shoot your own party with a fireball because you don't know how big the blast is. I suppose in EE they couldn't add that for the same reason they couldn't improve the graphics. Just be weary when firing AoE spells. 
CC - The CC itself is fine. It's just how long they last are the problem. Even when you win a fight the CC effects can last for several seconds to minutes which is annoying because you can't progress without your entire party. The effects last this long because the game is hard and if you are CC'd in a fight that generally means death. I wish the effects canceled after combat was over because then it's just annoying that you can't move. 

Conclusion: The game is great for $20 and has certainly aged well. This game is super fun and probably played best with friends. If you are looking forward to Baldur’s Gate 3 I recommend you play this game in order to fully invest yourself into the Forgotten Realms and the city of Baldur’s Gate.

I never played Baldur's Gate when it came out. I was too young at the time to know about it, or appreciate it. However, it was a game which I knew of for most of my teen years and 20's. When the Enhanced Edition came out, I decided to give it a shot.

There are very few story based games which hold my interest. I'm more of a sandbox type gamer personally, but Baldur's Gate had me hooked. This is unlike any RPG made today. It's challenging, rewarding, sprawling, and replayable. 

Most games today are too easy. They hold your hand- treating you like you are mentally handicapped. These types of games quickly become boring because they aren't designed to be played. They are designed to sell copies to everyone and their dog. Baldur's Gate caters to gamers. You will not make it far into the game without trial and error, nor will you solve the puzzles with just a couple of braincells. Everything about Baldur's Gate feels satisfyingly challenging. You won't become a god which steamrolls everything. Often times you will barely survive by the skin of your teeth. Some of the systems are easy to abuse, thus allowing you to cheese certain aspects of the game (rest, I am looking at you!) Despite that, the game is well designed to account for those elements. 

If you want a game with challenging content, that will keep you engaged for hundreds of hours. This is for you.

Few games are quite as rewarding as Baldur's Gate. Some of that is due to the mechanical rewards, such as items, armor, spells etc. There is a very deep itemization system even though it's not obvious. Unlike most games where you'll find a sword with +4346354634535 damage or a chest piece with +43254342 strength, the numbers in Baldur's Gate are small. However, they are vastly more meaningful. You can find items which make you immune to certain effects, give you the strength of 10 men, cause enemies to instantly die every time they hit you, etc. There is a huge array of items.

Part of the reward is finding the items. The other part of the reward is seeing the effects of your actions. The writing sells the weight of your decisions very well. While this game doesn't have some complex world simulation going on, your choices matter not only for how they affect you, but how they affect the people around you. 

Baldur's Gate is a large game, with a lot of content. Don't expect Witcher 3 open world exploration, but be prepared to scour each and every map for the tinest things to get the most out of the game. There's a plethora of optional content and forking paths to keep you busy. This is a game which has a very satisfying density of things to do and places to see. Not too much. Not too little. 

BG is certainly replayable because all of the classes provide different challenges. You can tweak the difficulty, play multiplayer with friends, and pursue different story arcs. Yeah, it's still going to be a linear storyline, so if that's not your thing, then multiple play throughs may not sound enticing. Still, for what it is, this game has a lot of replay value. I hate playing the same storyline twice, or watching the same movie multiple times unless it's really good. That's BG for you. It's so good, that it is worth playing through again, either to see what you missed, pursue a different path, try a different class, or bring your friends along for the ride.

SPOILERS: if you don't want anything spoiled then don't read on


Overall, I can see why people think this is one of the best RPGs out there. Was a bit of a learning curve since I wasn't use to this format but I got use to it.

The main story from the first game is pretty basic but it gets you going. Starting out as this ward, you're forced to leave for safety only to see your former father figure cut down before you. Afterwards, you're on your own to discover what has happened and go exploring.

And that's the main strength of the game: exploring. The main story I thought to be a little too loose and not really rope me into it until maybe around chapter 5 or 6 but that's where you'll be nearing the end. Exploring around though with all the interesting quests and locations are what kept me going. And Durlag's Tower and everything related to that; it's beautiful. Really true to D&D.

Then we have Dragonspear. It's...ok. I know that this gets a lot of flak for being very different (along with the addition of a trans character but is so minor that I won't linger on it, along with not bringing my beliefs), but overall it's a decent expansion. It tries to play out modern Bioware with the old and I guess it works. Kind of felt short and railroad-y for the most part though but with the payoff of a story that actually was keeping me invested. New enemies to fight, alongside one actual dragon, new items to get, it really isn't that bad...until the end. 

After the crusade is finished and you win, you're framed for a characters murder (previous companion in base game) and are basically forced back to Baldur's Gate as a murderer where you escape and then get ambushed afterwards. You have zero control. If you were the most good, honorable person in the land, doesn't matter. You're the child of a god of murder and killed a high officials child. It does tie back in with Durlag's Tower which I will give them that, but it doesn't feel that great to be railroaded/forced into this scenario at all!

But like I said, overall it's a good game. Haven't done the black pits yet but to my understanding it's just combat which is fine but not something I would like to do just for this. Now I got to start up Baldur's Gate 2 so I'm caught up for when 3 comes out.

This is the grand daddy of isometric rpg's and doesn't really need an introduction. Without a doubt one of the greatest games to provide a single player dnd experience with an engaging story, fun characters and compelling quests. It's pretty rough on anyone that is unfamiliar with the rules set being employed and the tutorial does nothing to help with understanding what all of the mechanics mean. However for the most part its fairly intuitive to anyone that has played any kind of rpg before, and most of the more obtuse mechanics can honestly just be ignored. As an example you don't need to know the ins and outs of THACO and how it's calculated. All you need to know is that making the number lower is good. Overall a fantastic game that has honestly aged surprisingly well, especially with these enhanced editions and the siege of dragonspear expansion isn't perfect, but is a very satisfying connector between the two games, making the transition from the end of the first to the beginning of the sequel less jarring

Do you know old DnD rules and wish to play a hardcore super campaign? Great! Does that sound a bit of intimidating? No worry, there are several difficulty settings that will allow you to tailor the experience to your liking.
The story. Oh my God! the story. It is very very well written and it continues in BG II which imo even surpasses the first one (and in which you can continue to play your character from the first, which is great).

To sum it all up: this game is a classic and it is well worth your time. The mechanics are which can put younger people off, but I say do try it - the game is great.

Smooth gameplay, good story and exciting adventure. You can create a unique party of your own design and go about this adventure as you see fit. Also mostly non linear, you can go just about anywhere anytime you want.

Review comes from a modern rpg player (I have played fallout new vegas, outer worlds, mass effect games 1 2 and 3, pillars 1 and 2, divinity os 1 and 2)

- most of the game is spent doing fun activities but the game can waste your time a bit too much for my liking when you have to move across maps you've already discovered. the fun of this game HEAVILY outweighs its problems. but to a modern player, these problems are still quite annoying.

What I liked: 
-the many choices
-the many side quests and activities: they are fun to play, and companions are numerous and have interesting backgrounds as well.
-the combat is enjoyable once you get the hang of it: uses classic dnd rules (advanced dnd or 2nd edition)

What I disliked: 
-The Slow pacing can be a problem, especially when you have to backtrack across maps it becomes a chore: since it happens over and over again.
-The Alignment system, some may like that system, I don't: if you want to play a paladin in this game have fun only being lawful good.
-If you're a mage you can't see where your aoe spells are going so you have to guess over time and just get used to that. 
-(minor) pathfinding can cause issues sometimes: slowing the game down even more


for newcomers it is slow to play and learn at first, but opens up to be a great classic rpg experience with choices and fun pause and play gameplay. for a game made in 1998, it's really good.

for modern players, who have played games such as pillars 1 or 2, divinity original sin 1 or 2, this is a great addition to any crpg like collection. just be prepared to be patient when making your party travel across individual maps
one of best rpgs in dnd style

What do we say about Baldur's Gate that hasn't already been said?

The classics remain as classics, for good reason. The game on offer here is a tough one, especially for those younger folks used to the comforts of modern gaming, where dialog boxes and tutorials pop up every three seconds that tell you "press x to win". This is a fairly hardcore rpg, and you won't get much in the way of hand-holding here. From a modern perspective, there absolutely should be more transparency of game mechanics on offer here, but part of the fun is also figuring it out. There are a ton of good guides and forums posts at this point that will help out anyone looking to crack the surface of the rather archaic 2nd edition D&D ruleset that this wonderful game is based off, so you're never going to be totally screwed.

But, what exactly is the appeal of such an old game? Graphically, this one isn't going to please everyone, but for that small subset of people like me who really yearn for the simpler times of computer gaming, you'll find yourself at home here, the character and monster models aren't great but the environments themselves are quite nice. Many indoor and outdoor areas have an awesome amount of details, like little items scattered on tables, shelves of potions and artifacts lining the walls of a wizards lair. The setpieces are very well done and very pleasing to play inside of. The dark caverns feel spooky, the dungeons forboding, and the forests lush. 

Sound wise, the spell effects and some of the music still sounds really great and pack that good old school punch. The voice overs are sometimes a bit distorted here and there but at the time this game was made, it wasn't too common to have a lot of voice acting in RPG's just yet. The voice acting itself is half-decent. The perfect amount of 90's cheesiness and delivery without descending into "so bad it's good" territory. 

The actual combat and gameplay is where the game truly shines. Levelling up is a slow process, good gear is rare and hard-earned. Spells are numerous and complex. The entire system is a big puzzle where you're given a ton of different pieces, where each piece could go any number of places. The really tough encounters act as knowledge checks and often you'll need to figure out the right combination of spells and buffs and characters to bring to each fight. Be prepared to abuse your save button, as some encounters will require you to suffer multiple defeats until you come up with good strategies to beat them. Every victory you earn and every new item you get feels incredibly rewarding as a result of how tough of a slog some parts of the game can be, and with the Enhanced Edition; you now have the option of tackling one of the toughest and most fun dungeons of it's era... Durlags Tower. 

If you're frustrated in the early game, I highly advise you to stick with it and maybe look up a character guide or two, once you get the games mechanics down and you're off on your adventure; few games will match how rich of an experience this is.

The best part is: literally everything I've applauded this game for is 3 times as better in the sequel.

Игра в которую повезло сыграть в детстве. Тогда она завораживала сюжетом и интересными диалогами. Механика игры была не простой и меня хватило наверное на треть прохождения. Потом вышла вторая часть, которой было посвящено добрых пол года жизни. И вот спустя почти 20 лет я решил купить и пройти игру до конца. Обновленный движок приятно удивил. Всё работает стабильно и за четыре десятка часов игры я не столкнулся ни с одной проблемой. Спасибо Beamdog за проделанную работу. Надеюсь однажды и мои дети тоже смогут прониктуться миром Forgotten Realms.

I recommend this game wholeheartedly. It's one of the first true RPGs and basically the model for a lot of later RPGs. I must have played through my original game a gazillion times, and through wear and tear, after nearly 20 years, my discs finally gave out, making them unplayable. So when it was released on Steam, I got it almost right away.

The game is set in the Forgotten realms, if you've ever played DnD, you'll basically recognize 100% of the content. If you haven't, and you have patience, then you're in for one of the better stories told. And patience is what the game requires. You need to figure out what the spells do, how the system works. Because just like DnD, it's basically a tactics game relying heavily on probabilities. What may seem like a great weapon or a great spell, might actually be bad, and what seems like a weak weapon or spell, may actually be somewhat overpowered.

But it has changed. If you have played Baldurs gate before, then you might notice these changes. What Beamdog did right was to fix a lot of the bugs that was never fixed in the original. They deserve kudos for that. But they also deserve a bit of a thumbs down. Their changes basically ruined the final fight. In the original, the final fight was a truly difficult fight. But it was winnable. I won it the first time I fought it. I was a kid back then, and almost all of my party died. But I won. This time around, I had to fail, reload, and fail again a dozen times over before winning. Beamdog changed things. They changed how summons work. They changed how enemies worked. They changed detection. I don't know if they changed the stats and spells of the enemies, but here's the thing:

Unless you know beforehand what goons the final boss brought, and unless you know what spells they will use and what abilities they have, you can never win the fight the first time around. Or rather - the probability of you predicting what spells and tactics you should utilize in order to win is incredibly low. And that's the bad part - because it means that Beamdog made the end fight unnecessarily hard and basically a game of trial and error.

Trial and error, in my opinion, only belongs in games which has expressibly included it in the gameplay. Baldurs gate is not one of those games. So when I finished the game, finally, I didn't have a sense of accomplishment. I just felt I had performed labour in order to win. It sucked.

But that doesn't remove the enjoyment I had during the rest of the game.
Beamdogs one mistake doesn't cloud the rest of the achievement.

The undisputed King of all RPG's in my opinion. Got this when I was younger, and blast me, I couldn't wrap my head around anything. All of those numbers and Thac0's and -AC's and Attack Rolls... A couple videos later however, I was pretty much set to go. And what a journey it was! People consider Baldur's Gate II superior to I, and I can see some reasons why it may be so, but in my heart this is the best old school RPG one could play. And no, not because of the apparent difficulty or deep systems, so nicely adapted from the tabletop, but because of the story, both the game's and yours.
